TITLE: Federal reservation of geothermal resources
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; OWNERSHIP; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HEARINGS; LAWSUITS; LEGAL ASPECTS; MINERAL RESOURCES; MINERAL RIGHTS; USA; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Union Oil had developed or was seeking to develop wells on the land in Sonoma County, California in order to produce geothermal steam for generating electricity. The US Attorney General brought a quiet title action pursuant to 21(b) of the Geothermal Steam Act of 1970 to determine whether geothermal resources are included in the mineral reservation under the Homestead Act. The US District Court granted Union Oil's motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted. On appeal, the Ninth Circuit reversed and remanded. In summary, the court concluded on the basis of the legislative history of the Stock-Raising Homestead Act that sources of energy are intended to remain in the government's possession, and the purposes of the Act will be best served by including geothermal resources in the reservation of mineral interests. Noting the strictly agricultural purpose of the Act, the subsurface estate reservation was broadly interpreted, even though title passed to all rights that were not expressly reserved. The court left open on remand the question of estoppel of the government from interfering with private lessees by developing subsurface resources compensation.This is a unique and intriguing decision, as it opens wide the definition of ''mineral interest,'' construing it in the timely terms of a valuable natural resource that may be in great demand for future energy needs. The decision is being appealed to the United States Supreme Court, and it will be interesting to observe whether this liberal interpretation of mineral interests will be upheld.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nat. Resour. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:1

TITLE: Texas energy resources: an outlook
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 11 NUCLEAR FUEL CYCLE AND FUEL MATERIALS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NATURAL GAS; RESERVES; PETROLEUM; TEXAS; COAL RESERVES; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; URANIUM RESERVES; COAL; FORECASTING; LIGNITE; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; NATURAL GAS LIQUIDS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; PRODUCTION; URANIUM; ACTINIDES; BROWN COAL; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; ELEMENTS; FEDERAL REGION VI; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; LIQUIDS; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERAL RESOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; USA; 011000* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 020100 - Petroleum- Reserves- (-1989); 030100 - Natural Gas- Reserves- (-1989); 050100 - Nuclear Fuels- Reserves, Exploration, & Mining; 150100 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: This work examines the energy resource base of Texas, what it has yielded in the past, and what is likely to be developed from it in the future. Ultimate recoverable energy resources in Texas are estimated at approx. 365 billion bbl of oil equivalent. Of that, about 1/4 has already been produced. The remaining resource base is a significantly different mix. Of the remaining base, only 28% is measured, indicated, or inferred, 45% is identified but subeconomic, and 28% is classed as yet-to-be discovered. Petroleum (oil, gas, and liquids) has made up 99% of the historic production of Texas energy; however, it constitutes only 50% of the remaining measured reserves, and only 30% of the estimated remaining resource base. Lignite and coal have contributed only 0.4% to historic production, yet they represent 40% of both the measured reserve and the resource base. Uranium production to date has been only 0.8% of cumulative energy production, but constitutes 10% of the measured reserve base. Geothermal resources make up 20% of the resource base.
RELATION: Journal Name: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Utilization of geothermal energy in a biomass-ethanol plant
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; ETHANOL PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL PROCESS HEAT; BEETS; CROPS; DISTILLATION; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; FERMENTATION; HYDROLYSIS; WOOD; BIOCONVERSION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DECOMPOSITION; ECONOMICS; ENERGY; FOOD; HEAT; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; LYSIS; PROCESS HEAT; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SOLVOLYSIS; VEGETABLES; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization; 140504 - Solar Energy Conversion- Biomass Production & Conversion- (-1989); 090222 - Alcohol Fuels- Preparation from Wastes or Biomass- (1976-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A study has been done on the uses of geothermal fluid in the processing of ethanol from wood and fodder beet. From a technical viewpoint, geothermal heat has large scale uses in the preheating, hydrolysis, and distillation stages. It is possible that heat exchangers would not be necessary as direct use of geothermal fluid could be viable. The financial advantages however are not conclusive assuming a geothermal steam and water cost of $2.50/ton.

TITLE: Hydraulic fracturing aids geothermal field development
AUTHORS: Katagiri, K; Ott, W K; Nutley, B G
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; ECONOMICS; EXPLORATION; JAPAN; STEAM; WELL SERVICING; WELL STIMULATION; ASIA; COMMINUTION; FRACTURING; STIMULATION; WELLS; 150906* - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology
DESCRIPTION: Hydraulic fracturing to stimulate steam production or improve brine injectivity has helped Dohan Geothermal Energy Co., Ltd. more economically develop Nigorikawa Field in SW Hokkaido, Japan. To make these wells commercial, fracturing treatments were performed in lieu of redrilling. To date, several wells have been treated in 2 separate projects. Seven were treated during fall 1978. In Spring 1980, 4 were retreated and several additional wells were treated for the first time. Although these frac jobs are the first known in geothermal wells, the enhanced production or injectivity that resulted in some cases has encouraged similar applications in other geothermal areas.
RELATION: Journal Name: World Oil; (United States); Journal Volume: 191:7

TITLE: Numerical approach to predicting stresses and displacements around a three-dimensional pressurized fracture
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 02 PETROLEUM; 04 OIL SHALES AND TAR SANDS; 12 MANAGEMENT OF RADIOACTIVE AND NON-RADIOACTIVE WASTES FROM NUCLEAR FACILITIES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 03 NATURAL GAS; FRACTURES; STRESS ANALYSIS; GEOLOGIC FISSURES; ROCK MECHANICS; FORECASTING; FRACTURING; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGIC MODELS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; STRESS INTENSITY FACTORS; COMMINUTION; FAILURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MECHANICS; 580300* - Mineralogy, Petrology, & Rock Mechanics- (-1989); 020300 - Petroleum- Drilling & Production; 040401 - Oil Shales & Tar Sands- In Situ Methods, True & Modified; 052002 - Nuclear Fuels- Waste Disposal & Storage; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware; 030900 - Natural Gas- Artificial Stimulation, Plowshare- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A numerical technique has been developed for analysis of stresses and displacements around a pressurized planar fracture of arbitrary geometry in three dimensions. The analysis is limited by assumptions of homogeneity and linear elasticity, but it is capable of considering the effects of arbitrary internal pressure distribution, normal and tangential initial stresses, and the presence of a free surface. The method of approach is related to both the Boundary Integral and Displacement Discontinuity methods but a simpler formulation is developed utilizing existing elementary solutions for an elastic half-space. The present application of the technique has been oriented towards the determination of far-field conditions, rather than stress concentrations. Sample solutions are presented, including a demonstration of the influence of fracture orientation and initial stress state upon free surface uplift.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. J. Rock Mech. Min. Sci. Geomech. Abstr.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:6
JOURNAL_NAME: Int. J. Rock Mech. Min. Sci. Geomech. Abstr.; (United States)

TITLE: State geothermal mapping program
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; MAPPING; THERMAL SPRINGS; FLOW RATE; HEAT FLOW; KGRA; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; US DOE; USES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; RESOURCES; US ORGANIZATIONS; WATER SPRINGS; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal energy resource maps are discussed. Two maps will be produced by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration for each state: a public usage map and a geotechnical map. Geothermal data sets depicted on the public maps include thermal springs and wells, temperature, flow rates, total dissolved solids content, depth of wells, descriptive paragraphs denoting areas of present or projected use, areas considered to have a high probability of discovering additional geothermal resources, gradient ranges, heat flow values, and known Geothermal Resources Areas (KGRA's). Addresses for each state and a discussion of the program structure are included. (MJF)

TITLE: Financing a geothermal project
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FINANCING; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The financing of geothermal projects is discussed. Geothermal projects generally require three sources of funds: equity funds, loan funds and government funds or government assisted funds. In general, sufficient equity must be available at least to obtain the leases, define the geological and geophysical features, plan tentative projects to utilize the geothermal resources, and carry the project through the next phase of funding. The federal programs aimed at assisting in financing geothermal projects are Geothermal Loan Guaranty Program (GLGP) and the new user project. Basically, there are certain criteria that must be met before the banker can consider a geothermal project bankable on a project basis. A list of these criteria would include such things as sales contracts, lease terms and an operator's experience; however, the single most important criterion is reservoir performance. (MJF)
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull., Geotherm. Resour. Counc. (Davis, Calif.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:11
JOURNAL_NAME: Bull., Geotherm. Resour. Counc. (Davis, Calif.); (United States)

TITLE: Gravitational stability of water over steam in vapor-dominated geothermal systems
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; VAPOR-DOMINATED SYSTEMS; STABILITY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PERMEABILITY; POROSITY; STEAM; WATER; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: Vapor-dominated geothermal systems exist in a most extraordinary state: a condensate or water layer several hundred meters thick overlies a main steam zone of undetermined thickness. Why doesn't the water fall down. We show that a heavy fluid phase overlying a light phase of the same fluid in a porous medium can be stable provided the permeability in the vicinity of the interface is not too large. The special behavior of a phase change interface in response to disturbances of the boundary account for the stabilization. Heavy fluids overlying light fluids in a porous medium are unstable, irrespective of permeability, if the fluids are immiscible. Application of the stabiliy analysis to vapor-dominated geothermal systems shows that the condensate layer can be stabilized if the permeability near its base is no large than about 40 nm/sup 2/ (0.04 millidarcy).
RESEARCH_ORG: Space Sciences Laboratory, The Aerospace Corporation, Los Angeles, California 90009
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B11

TITLE: Eastern geothermal resources: should we pursue them
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CENTRAL REGION; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; GREAT LAKES REGION; MID-ATLANTIC REGION; MIDWEST REGION; NORTH ATLANTIC REGION; SOUTHEAST REGION; SOUTHWEST REGION; EAST COAST; ECONOMICS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGY; SEDIMENTARY BASINS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; USA; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A geothermal resource that consists of hot water at moderate temperatures (below 125/sup 0/C) underlies many areas in the central and eastern United States. Programs funded by the Department of Energy have revealed that this resource is definable and economically competitive with conventional fuels for use in direct heat applications. The resource, therefore, has the potential for reducing our dependence on the imported oil used for space heating. However, front-end costs and risks to explore, drill, test, and evaluate the magnitude of the resource have inhibited development. The question is, therefore, how much federal stimulation will be needed to convince private capital to exploit this widespread low-quality energy source.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 210:4470

TITLE: America studies new geothermal options
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; RESOURCES; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants; 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: Anti-pollution laws and expensive abatement equipment are slowing the development of California's geothermal power plant at the Geysers, where the power stations operate primarily as chemical plants to deal with hydrogen sulfide. Geothermal efforts in the Imperial Valley are developing a binary-cycle plant, direct-contact heat exchangers, and downhole pumps. Other research programs are experimenting with hot dry rocks in New Mexico, district heating in Oregon, farming and food-processing applications, underground heat storage, and geopressured fields. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:11

TITLE: Geothermal resources and utilization in China: direct utilization of geothermal energy in the People's Republic of China
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CHINA; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; AGRICULTURE; CORROSION; ELECTRIC POWER; EQUIPMENT; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL PROCESS HEAT; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; HEAT FLOW; INDUSTRY; PIPELINES; RESIDENTIAL SECTOR; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; USES; ASIA; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; HEAT; HEATING; POWER; POWER PLANTS; PROCESS HEAT; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; SPACE HEATING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization; 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: The present development of geothermal energy in China is discussed. In the next five to ten years, three regions will be developed and one subject area will be investigated: (1) the Tianjin-Beijing (Tientsin-Peking) resource will be developed for space heating, with a secondary interest in industrial development; (2) the geothermal resource will be developed along the coastal area of Fujian (Fukien) and Guangdong (Kwangtung) province for agriculture, industrial and residential use; (3) electrical power generation will be developed in the Southwest at Tengchong near Burma; (4) strengthening of theroretical research in geologic structure interpretation, corrosion problems and heat flow. Specific observation in the Tianjin and Beijing area revealed the following levels of technology: (1) space heating has only developed on a single industry or building complex level; (2) in all of the industrial sites the water was used directly in the process; most of the equipment and processes were primitive and highly labor intensive; (3) pipeline consists of low carbon steels that are buried, unprotected, in the ground; (4) corrosion appeared to be a major problem, especially in Beijing where hydrogen sulfide was present in significant quantities; (5) even though seven power plants are in operation, the equipment is somewhat primitive. (MJF)
RESEARCH_ORG: Oregon Inst. of Tech., Klamath Falls, OR
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull., Geotherm. Resour. Counc. (Davis, Calif.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:10
JOURNAL_NAME: Bull., Geotherm. Resour. Counc. (Davis, Calif.); (United States)

TITLE: Geothermal resources and utilization in China: exploration and development of geothermal resources in the People's Republic of China. An analysis
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CHINA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; AGRICULTURE; ELECTRIC POWER; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT FLOW; INDUSTRY; REVIEWS; USES; ASIA; DOCUMENT TYPES; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEATING; POWER; RESOURCES; SPACE HEATING; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The present and future development of geothermal resources in the People's Republic of China is analyzed. Four areas of emphasis are: (1) continued development of geothermal resources for space heating and industrial uses in both Tianjin and Beijing; (2) improvement in the uses of the 80 to 90/sup 0/C geothermal resources of the Fujian (Fukien) and Guangdong (Canton) provinces in the southeastern area of the PRC for industrial but primary agricultural use; (3) continued development of the greater than 150/sup 0/C geothermal resources in the southwest in Xizang (Tibet) province for power generation; (4) strengthen geothermal research efforts in several areas including but now restricted to theoretical heat flow studies, geopressure resources, hot dry rock resources, causes of heat flow fields, and numerical modeling to aid in understanding the geothermal systems. More than two thirds of the provinces, municipalities, and autonomous regions in the PRC have now started reconnaissance surveys and exploration work for the eventual utilization of their indigenous geothermal resources. (MJF)
RESEARCH_ORG: Geothermal Services Inc., San Diego, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull., Geotherm. Resour. Counc. (Davis, Calif.); (United States); Journal Volume: 9:10
JOURNAL_NAME: Bull., Geotherm. Resour. Counc. (Davis, Calif.); (United States)

TITLE: Mapping seismic attenuation within geothermal systems using teleseisms with application to the Geysers-Clear Lake region
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; SEISMIC WAVES; ATTENUATION; ERRORS; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; WAVE PROPAGATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Though the exact relationship between temperature and seismic attenuation has not been defined, the thermal regime of geothermal systems exhibit high seismic attenuation. The attenuation of a seismic wave is proportional to Q/sup -1/, the reciprocal of the quality factor. The reduced spectral ratio technique has been used to infer Q structure. This technique is adapated to study a geothermal system. A generalized discrete linear inversion technique is applied to the observed differential attenuation data deltat* of teleseismic P waves to obtain a discrete Q model. Errors have a large effect on the Q model in a local area. Five sources of errors are involved in the estimation of deltat*. Four levels of random errors are added to synthetic data for eight different assumed models, using 12 events and 11 stations. These data are inverted to assess the effect of the observation errors on the inferred Q structures. For signal to error ratio (S/E) above 5 the models are reproducible; between 5 and 1 a dramatic degradation of fidelity occurs; and at 1 or below, numerous low Q cells are identified as high Q and vice versa. Acquisition of more numerous, better distributed data with lower error improves the quality of the inversion. A two-dimensional Q model of the Geysers-Clear Lake geothermal area is obtained using previously reported attenuation data of six teleseismic events with S/E of 4. A high-attenuation (low Q) zone is found located in the middle crust centered southeast of Mount Hannah, roughly corroborating the gravity and P wave travel time residual models.
RESEARCH_ORG: Center for Energy Studies, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B10

TITLE: Geothermal moves off the back burner. Part II
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; INVESTMENT; LEGAL INCENTIVES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150000* - Geothermal Energy; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The new Energy Security Act, a loan guarantee program, and energy tax credits are among the incentives spurring geothermal resource development. Direct-utilization projects often depend on government support, but if continued, the industry should be independent and cost-competitive by 1990. Market analysis cites lack of awareness, experience, and data among the factors slowing direct-use applications to the food, tobacco, textile, lumber, chemical, and leather industries. Certain factors indicate that economic viability and technological improvements reduce risks. Savings and federal funding, technical assistance, feasibility studies, and analyses are noted for numerous companies across the country. Faster development seems likely in western states. Space- and water-heating uses are growing even faster than process applications, with district-heating systems offering the greatest potential. Hot-dry-rock and geopressured resources also hold promise despite problems. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Manage. (Cleveland, Ohio); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:5

TITLE: Terrain effect on terrestrial heat flow
AUTHORS: Blackwell, D D; Steele, J L; Brott, C A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CONTINENTAL CRUST; HEAT FLOW; ERRORS; FOURIER ANALYSIS; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; MORPHOLOGY; TOPOGRAPHY; EARTH CRUST; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: A new approach to topographic correction for terrestrial heat flow measurements is presented. The approach features calculation of a Fourier series fit to the surface temperature - surface evaluation data where the surface temperatures are based on a model that includes surface temperature variations due to microclimate variations. Mathematics of the terrain correction problem are similar to upward (away from source) continuation problem in gravity and magnetics so several solutions, in addition to the Fourier series approach, are available in the literature that allow an accurate calculation of the correction provided the surface boundary condition is properly specified. However, the usual boundary condition applied, a linear relation between ground surface temperature and elevation, is shown to be inadequate for drill holes in the depth range 30 to 200 m no matter how low the topographic relief. Thus a model of ground surface temperature is developed that includes the effects of elevation, slope orientation, and slope angle. Because of the effects of microclimate, the classical models that have isothermal surfaces that generally parallel the topographic surface are significantly in error in many cases, and the patterns of isotherms near the topographic surface are more complicated than was previously recognized.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B9

TITLE: Developments in West Coast area in 1979. [Tabular data and maps]
AUTHORS: Blaisdell, R C; Dignes, T W
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; PLANNING; OREGON; WASHINGTON; EXPLORATION; EXPLORATORY WELLS; NATURAL GAS FIELDS; OIL FIELDS; PETROLEUM INDUSTRY; WELL DRILLING; DRILLING; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; INDUSTRY; MINERAL RESOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 020200* - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 030200 - Natural Gas- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: New-field discoveries in California were down in 1979 from the previous year. The total exploratory footage drilled was slightly lower, but the total number of successful exploratory wells was up 19% from 1978. One new oil field and 5 new gas field discoveries were reported in California. None of these discoveries appear to be of major size. During 1979, hydrocarbons were discovered in commercial quantities for the first time in Oregon - the Mist Gas field, in the northwestern corner of the state, in Columbia County. A pipeline was constructed for initial production in late 1979. This discovery has spurred drilling and leasing activity. Mobil drilled a second deep exploratory well in Oregon, to 10,412 ft, which was subsequently abandoned. Only 1 shallow oil and gas exploratory well was drilled in Washington State this year. As yet it has not been completed. Development drilling in California, although down from 1978, continued at an active pace and is related largely to steam-flood projects. Production of oil outstripped additions to reserves by 285.8 million bbl in 1979. Geothermal activity increased in California's Imperial Valley and Geysers area. Southern California Edison Co. has begun construction of a 10-Mw generating plant near Brawley in the Imperial Valley. Two other geothermal projects in the Imperial Valley sponsored by Southern California Edison include the development of a 50-Mw unit near Heber and a prospective 10-Mw plant south of the Salton Sea. Westmoreland Geothermal Associates also have plans to develop a plant in the valley. In the Geysers area, Sacramento Municipal Utility District plans to construct a 55-Mw plant. The Geysers capacity is expected to increase to 1238 Mw by the end of 1982.
RESEARCH_ORG: Chevron USA Inc., San Francisco, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 64:9
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Geothermal Energy Committee
AUTHORS: Root, T E; Goldstein, D B; Trower, E D
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LEGAL ASPECTS; CASE LAW; COMMERCIALIZATION; DRILLING; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; EXPLORATION; INVESTMENT; LAND USE; LAWSUITS; LEASES; LOCAL GOVERNMENT; OWNERSHIP; STATE GOVERNMENT; TAXES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; LAWS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: Significant government activities in the field of geothermal energy during 1977 were concentrated in the courts. Three cases dealing with the title controversy were resolved by finding that (1) geothermal resources are included in state mineral deposits; (2) geothermal resources are included in mineral grants; and (3) reversal of a lower-court finding removes geothermal resources from the same treatment as water in surface rights. Environmental cases were concerned with the impacts of commercial development, while taxation cases dealt with the use of investment partnership as a basis for claiming exploratory expenses.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nat. Resour. Lawyer; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:1

TITLE: Geothermal power picks up steam
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; FINANCING; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Electric utilities are showing interest in geothermal power production, although many of the new projects have been in the planning stages for several years. DOE participation, through cost-sharing and financing demonstrations and Federal loan guarantees for exploration and resource development, indicate that a trend toward alternative-fuel development is beginning. The Pacific Gas and Electric's Geyser station, for years the nation's only geothermal electric project, is expanding and now provides seven percent of the utility's generating capacity. A DOE-supported $140 million demonstration project nearing completion is the 50-MW plant in Valles Caldera, New Mexico (partners are Union Oil, 34%; Public Service of New Mexico, 21%; and DOE, 45%). (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Light Power (Boston); (United States); Journal Volume: 58:8

TITLE: Geothermal energy: a proven resource with costly potential
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; COMMERCIALIZATION; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: The commercial use of geothermal energy to generate electricity has been spreading across the country since the California Geyser site was developed in 1960. Petroleum companies see geothermal power generation as a way to broaden their own base. The binary-cycle technology to use hydrothermal resources will be ready by 1985. Power generation from geothermal heat will be costly even though the resource itself is free and renewable; but the economics will improve as fossil-fuel prices increase. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Chilton's Oil Gas Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:11

TITLE: Geothermal moves off the back burner
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; INSTITUTIONAL FACTORS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150000 - Geothermal Energy
DESCRIPTION: Despite economic, technological, and regulatory restriction, experts see great potential for direct-use non-electric applications of geothermal energy. Several successes are cited. A lack of awareness hinders investment and development opportunities. Prices of competing fuels, coal use prospects, confirmation of reservoirs, energy tax incentives, and government policy will increasingly affect geothermal programs and projects. The Geysers, the world's largest operating geothermal power plant, and other ventures are described. Developers are showing great interest in Southern California's Imperial Valley binary-cycle pilot operation and the possibilities of energy independence for Hawaii. Geothermal power generation is already cost-competitive with fossil fuel plants in some locations. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Manage. (Cleveland, Ohio); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:4

TITLE: Review of oceanic and global heat flow estimates
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EARTH CRUST; HEAT FLOW; EARTH MANTLE; SEAS; COOLING; REVIEWS; DOCUMENT TYPES; SURFACE WATERS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Direct comparisons of recent estimates of oceanic and global heat flow from the earth's interior are not simple because of the diversity of asssumptions and methods which have been used. Some of these estimates have been based on conceptually inappropriate or quantitatively unreasonable models of the cooling oceanic lithosphere. The cooling uniform half-space model is the most appropriate first approximation and is presently adequate to describe the preferred selection of oceanic heat flow data. Hydrothermal transport in young oceanic curst may account of 25% of the total global heat flow. After appropriate allowances are made for this, there is general consistency between recent estimates of total heat flow. Total global heat flow is probably 4.1 +- 0.4 x 10/sup 13/ W, which corresponds to an average flux of 80 +- 8 mW/m/sup 2/. The average oceanic heat flux is roughly 70% greater than the average continental flux: they are about 95 +- 10 mW/m/sup 2/ and 55 +- 5 mW/m/sup 2/, respectively. There may be significant fluctuations in total heat flow on time scales of 10/sup 7/--10/sup 8/ years.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences and McDonell Center for Space Sciences, Washington University, St. Louis, Missouri 63130
RELATION: Journal Name: Rev. Geophys. Space Phys.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:3

The areas reviewed include biochemical processes; coal, petroleum, and other fuels; energy conversion and recovery; inorganic chemicals; metals; organic chemicals; plastics and fibers; pollution control; pulp and paper; and miscellaneous technology. For each entry, product(s), process(es), user(s), features, and status remarks are listed.

TITLE: Terrestrial heat flow in the Brazilain Highlands
AUTHORS: Vitorello, I; Hamza, V M; Pollack, H N
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRAZIL; EARTH CRUST; HEAT FLOW; BASALT; INTRUSION; PLATE TECTONICS; PRECAMBRIAN ERA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; GEOLOGIC AGES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; LATIN AMERICA; ROCKS; SOUTH AMERICA; TECTONICS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: We report heat flow measurements from 84 boreholes and one underground mine at 19 widely spaced sites in eastern and central parts of Brazil. Three sites in the stable Sao Francisco Craton comprising rocks with Transamazonic ages (2600--1800 Ma) or older present an average heat flow of 42 +- 5 (sem (standard error of the mean)) mW m*u-/sup 2/, eight sites located in the Late Precambrian Braziliane metamorphic belt have an average heat of 55 +- 4 (sem) mW m/sup -2/, and three sites in the Parana basin, locus of Late Jurassic--Early Cretaceous basaltic volcanicity, have a mean heat flow of 68 +- 6 (sem) mw m/sup -2/. Heat flow results from the Late Cretaceous--Early Tertiary alkalic intrusion of Pocos de Caldas have yielded a site mean of 55 mW m/sup -2/, comparable to results obtained from the Braziliane belt into which the alkalic plug has intruded. Four other sites yielded results of lesser quality and are not included in the above means.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geological Sciences, The University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48109
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B7

TITLE: Characterization of a penny-shaped reservoir in a hot dry rock
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RESERVOIR ROCK; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; STABILITY; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 580300* - Mineralogy, Petrology, & Rock Mechanics- (-1989); 150906 - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology
DESCRIPTION: The mechanical stability of a penny-shaped revervoir is characterized by fracture mechanics including thermoelastic effects in connection with research into the extraction of geothermal energy from hot dry rocks. The condition for stability of a reservoir, which is not changing radius by propagating or closing, requires 0<k<k/sub c/, where k and k/sub c/ are the stress intensity factor and the fracture routhness of rock. From this condition the upper and lower critical flow rates m* and m/sub asterisk/, necessary for reservoir stability, are obtained in terms of the outlet fluid pressure on the earth surface, the fluid temperatures at the inlet and outlet, the geometry of the reservoir, and the physical constants of the fluid and the rock. The behavior of a reservoir when the inlet flow is changed also is studied. According to the value of the outlet flow rate m/sub 0/, the following three cases are considered: case 1; m/sub 0/=m*; case 2; m*>m/sub 0/>m/sub asterisk/; and case 3; m/sub 0/=m/sub asterisk/.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Civil Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois 60201
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B7

TITLE: Heat flow in the Bering Sea
AUTHORS: Langseth, M G; Hobart, M A; Horai, K
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BERING SEA; HEAT FLOW; OCEANIC CRUST; POLAR REGIONS; EARTH CRUST; PACIFIC OCEAN; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The basic pattern of heat flow in the Bering Sea is revealed by 43 measurements obtained in the Aleutian, Kamchatka, and Bowers basins. Averages of the observed values are 55 mW m/sup -2/ in the Aleutian Basin, 120 mW m/sup -2/ in the Kamchatka Basin, and 80 mW m/sup -2/ for two measurements in the Bowers Basin near the Bowers Ridge. Correcting these averages for the effects of sedimentation gives values of 69 mW m/sup -2/, 138 mW m/sup -2/, and 95 mW m/sup -2/, respectively. A useful nomogram for computing the thermal effect of an extended period of sedimentation is presented. Several methods of averaging heat flow values in marginal basins are compared using the data from the Aleutian Basin. If the Aleutian Basin was formed by the sea floor spreading process, then the heat flow suggests an age of about 44 m.y., which is considerably younger than magnetic data suggest. An alternative explanation is that the high heat flow is a residuum of thermal processes associated with the now extinct Kula Spreading Center and the Kula Plate, which underthrust the Bering Sea in the early Tertiary and thermally rejuvenated the trapped mesozoic sea floor underlying the Aleutian Basin. The high average jeat flow in the Kamchatka Basin suggests a considerably younger age for this basin, and the very high values in the southwestern part indicate either thin lithosphere or recent magnitic activity.
RESEARCH_ORG: Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory of Columbia University, Palisades, New York 10964
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B7

TITLE: Removing geothermal odors
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; REMOVAL; ODOR; STEAM; PURIFICATION; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; FIELD TESTS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; CHALCOGENIDES; FEDERAL REGION IX; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANOLEPTIC PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; TESTING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; 150802* - Geothermal Power Plants- Power Plant Systems & Components
DESCRIPTION: A new process for removing hydrogen sulfide gas from steam released at geothermal powerplants, developed by Coury and Associates Inc. for Electric Power Research Institute, was tested in cooperation with Pacific Gas and Electric Co. at The Geysers geothermal site, north of San Francisco, Calif. The test unit processed 1000 lb/h of steam; a 50 MW commercial unit would process 1 million lb/h steam. In the new process, geothermal steam is condensed in a heat exchanger; about 95% of the hydrogen sulfide and other noncondensable gases are diverted in a separate stream. The clean condensate is then re-evaporated by the heat extracted from the incoming steam. The steam thus produced goes on to drive a turbine and generate electricity. The new process will continue to remove the hydrogen sulfide and its odors, even when the plant is temporarily shut down.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Air Pollut. Control Assoc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 30:7
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Air Pollut. Control Assoc.; (United States)

TITLE: Thermal conductivity of aqueous sodium chloride solutions from 20 to 330/sup 0/C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SODIUM CHLORIDES; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; USES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DATA; DISPERSIONS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MIXTURES; NUMERICAL DATA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 152001* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: Selected thermal conductivity data reported in the literature for aqueous sodium chloride solutions are tabulated for geothermal energy applications. Experimental values were converted where necessary to a set of consistent units of degree Celsius, molal concentration and watts per meter Celsius. A selected empirical equation is given to reproduce the data over the temperature range 20 to 330/sup 0/C, concentrations between 0 and 5 m, and at saturation pressures. A table of smoothed values is generated by using the correlation which reproduces the experimental data to +- 2% up to 80/sup 0/C. Between 100 and 150/sup 0/C, the percent deviation is +17% to +31% for the one set of available experimental values. Recommendations for additional data needs are given. 2 figures, 3 tables.

TITLE: Feeding ecology of Gila boraxobius (Osteichthyes: Cyprindae) endemic to a thermal lake in southeastern Oregon
AUTHORS: Williams, J E; Williams, C D
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FISHES; BASELINE ECOLOGY; DIET; ENDANGERED SPECIES; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HABITAT; OREGON; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; DATA; ECOLOGY; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL DATA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; PLANTS; USA; VARIATIONS; VERTEBRATES; 520100* - Environment, Aquatic- Basic Studies- (-1989); 150600 - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Gila boraxobius is a dwarf species of cyprinid endemic to a thermal lake in southeastern Oregon. Despite a relatively depauperate fauna and flora in the lake, 24 food items were found in intestines of G. boraxobius. Ten of the 24 foods, including six insects, were of terrestrial origin. The relative importance of food items fluctuated seasonally. Diatoms, chironomid larvae, microcrustaceans, and dipteran adults were the primary foods during spring. In summer, diatoms decreased and terrestrial insects increased in importance. During autumn important foods were terrestrial insects, chironomid larvae, and diatoms. Diatoms and microcrustaceans increased in importance during winter. Chironomid larvae were of importance in winter, when the importance of terrestrial food items decreased substantially. Similar food habits were observed between juveniles and adults, except that adults consumed more gastropods and diatoms and juveniles consumed more copepods and terrestrial insects. Gila boraxobius feeds opportunistically with individuals commonly containing mostly one food item. Fish typically feed by picking foods from soft bottom sediments or from rocks. However, fish will feed throughout the water column or on the surface if food is abundant there. Gila boraxobius feeds throughout the day, with a peak in feeding activity just after sunset. A daily ration of 11.1 percent body weight was calculated for the species during June. A comparison of food habits among G. boraxobius and populations of G. alvordensis during the summer shows that all are opportunistic in feeding, but that G. boraxobius relies more heavily on terrestrial foods.
RELATION: Journal Name: Great Basin Nat.; (United States); Journal Volume: 40:2

TITLE: Heat flow from the Liberian precambrian shield
AUTHORS: Sass, J H; Behrendt, J C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CONTINENTAL CRUST; HEAT FLOW; LIBERIA; COASTAL REGIONS; REFRACTION; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; TOPOGRAPHY; AFRICA; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; EARTH CRUST; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Uncorrected heat flow in iron formation rocks from three areas within the Liberian part of the West African Shield ranges from 50 to more than 80 mW m/sup -2/. When corrections are applied for topography and refraction, the range of heat flow is narrowed to between 38 and 42 mW m/sup -2/. In comparison with heat flows from other parts of the West African Craton, these values are consistent with preliminary results from Ghana (42 +- 8 mW m/sup -2/) and Nigeria (38 +- 2 mW /sup -2/) but are somewhat higher than values from Niger (20 mW m/sup -2/) and neighboring Sierra Leone (26 mW m/sup -2/). The Liberian values are significantly lower than the heat flow offshore in the equatorial Atlantic Ocean (58 +- 8 mW m/sup -2/), suggesting large lateral temperature gradients within the lithosphere near the coast. Values of heat production from outcrops of crystalline basement rocks near the holes are between 2 and 2.3 ..mu..W m/sup -3/. A heat-flow/heat-production relation cannot be established because of the small range of values; however, assuming a 'characteristic depth' of 8 km (similar to the North American Craton) the reduced heat flow of from 20 to 25 mW m/sup -2/ is consistent with that from other Precambrian shields.
RESEARCH_ORG: U. S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B6

TITLE: Mexico spurs geothermal development. [Plans 40 TWh/year by year 2000]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CERRO PRIETO GEOTHERMAL FIELD; POWER GENERATION; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; GEOTHERMAL INDUSTRY; MEXICO; BY-PRODUCTS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; GROUND WATER; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; MARKET; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; INDUSTRY; LATIN AMERICA; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; WATER; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: although there are many geothermal sources in Mexico, only one has so far been commercially exploited on a large scale. The Cerro Prieto field in the northwest is the principal power source for an isolated network of the Comision Federale de Electricidad. The Cerro Prieto field lies in the seismic belt that extends down the western edge of the North American continent. Development of the Mexican field began in earnest in 1962. At the present, an area of some 12 km/sup 2/ has been fully investigated and reserves are estimated sufficient to generate 7 TWh/year for 40 years. The present four-unit power station has generated some 4000 GWh of electricity over its seven-year life so far. The development plan aims to have 620 MW in service by 1984. Most of this capacity will come from the second and third power plants. Construction should start on the second plant soon. Timing of the third plant depends on arrangements made for energy sale to a group of U.S. utilities. Besides utilizing the geothermal energy, the site is a source of chemicals. In particular, the present flow needed to support power generation could yield 86,000 tons/year of potassium chloride (almost the total Mexican requirement for this currently-imported materail). Fertimex expects a separation plant to produce various materials to be in full operation by 1982. Excellent results have been obtained from test drillings at another potential geothermal site south of Mexico City at Los Azufres. It is located in a broad active zone that stretches across the country from the Pacific to the Atlantic. By the end of the century, Mexico aims to have geothermal energy availability at 40 TWh/year. (SAC)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:6

TITLE: Analysis of reservoir mechanics of geopressured geothermal aquifers - the Brazoria County prospect
AUTHORS: Ohkuma, H; Sepehrnoori, K; Lewis, J T; Macdonald, R C; Knapp, R M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 03 NATURAL GAS; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GAS YIELDS; NATURAL GAS; GULF COAST; RESERVOIR ROCK; FLUID MECHANICS; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; DISSOLVED GASES; FLOW MODELS; FLUID FLOW; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; PRODUCTIVITY; TEXAS; WELL COMPLETION; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FEDERAL REGION VI; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; MINERAL RESOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; SIMULATION; SOLUTES; USA; YIELDS; 150700* - Geothermal Energy- Products & By-Products; 030900 - Natural Gas- Artificial Stimulation, Plowshare- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Aquifers of abnormally high pressures, known as geopressured geothermal aquifers, are found extensively in the Gulf Coast region of the U.S. The hot water contained in the aquifers may have a significant amount of dissolved hydrocarbon gas. A 2-phase, 2-dimensional simulator using a finite difference technique was developed for simulating the production behavior of these geopressured aquifers. A series of cross-sectional model calculations were performed to analyze reservoir mechanics operative in a geopressured aquifer. The effects of reservoir heterogeneities and completion strategies on resource recovery are investigated. Finally, an assessment is made of the effects of gas evolution about the well bore on well productivity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Tex., Univ., Bur. Econ. Geol., Guideb.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2; Conference: 4. Texas University bureau economic geology US Gulf coast geopressured-geothermal energy research and development conference, Austin, TX, USA, 29-31 Oct 1979

DESCRIPTION: The California State Lands Commission's net profits bidding system for geothermal resources is discussed. The history of the legislation for the Net Profits Leasing program is briefly detailed and a number of land tracts leased under the program along with the companies that bid on them and the net profit percentage bids are presented. The Net Profits Leasing System bidding requires companies to include in their bid the percentage of their net profits (gross income minus California State royalty and allowable expenses) that they will turn back to the state government. (JMT)

TITLE: Geothermal energy and its potential. [Utah]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; UTAH; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; DRILLING; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; REVIEWS; ROCK MECHANICS; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; MECHANICS; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; USA; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A brief review of geothermal energy and its potential as a future energy source is presented. The type of geothermal systems and their geologic occurrence is discussed, and the Phillips Petroleum Company's exploration and drilling programs in the Roosevelt Hot Springs area in parts of Iron, Beaver, and Millard Counties, Utah are detailed. A section on the rock behavior and mechanical properties of rocks in the Roosevelt Hot Springs area is included. (JMT)

TITLE: Resource assessment, scheduling, and economics of developing the geopressured-geothermal resource in Texas
AUTHORS: Cornwell, J B; Lesso, W G; Zinn, C D
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; METHANE; RECOVERY; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; SIMULATION; TEXAS; ALKANES; ECONOMICS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FEDERAL REGION VI; HYDROCARBONS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 030900* - Natural Gas- Artificial Stimulation, Plowshare- (-1989); 150000 - Geothermal Energy
DESCRIPTION: For the geopressured-geothermal resource to be a viable source of energy, a number of uncertain physical and economic conditions must be met. A series of models was developed to assess the feasibility of the resource under known and/or best estimate conditions and to determine the minimum acceptable values. The first model assesses the individual fairways ability to provide a designated flow for one well for a set minimum lifetime. The second model takes the usable fairways and produces a development scenario based upon chosen hit probabilities. The third model performs an economic analysis of the fairway development scenarios based upon the time line history, total number of wells required, and total methane recovered. Few fairways show promise of being viable sources based on physical properties, and then only if the price of natural gas is substantially increased.
RELATION: Journal Name: Texas Univ. Bureau Economic Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:3; Conference: 4. Texas University Bureau Economic Geology Coast Geopressured-Geothermal Energy Research and Development conference, Austin, TX, USA, 29-31 Oct 1979
JOURNAL_NAME: Texas Univ. Bureau Economic Geology; (United States)

TITLE: Late Cenozoic volcanism, geochronology, and structure of the Coso Range, Inyo County, California
AUTHORS: Duffield, W A; Bacon, C R; Dalrymple, G B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; GEOLOGIC HISTORY; GEOLOGIC STRATA; ANDESITES; BASALT; CENOZOIC ERA; FUMAROLIC FLUIDS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RHYOLITES; VOLCANISM; CALIFORNIA; FLUIDS; GEOLOGIC AGES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Coso Range lies at the west edge of the Great Basin, adjacent to the southern part of the Sierra Nevada. A basement complex of pre-Cenozoic plutonic and metamorphic rocks is partly buried by approx.35 km/sup 3/ of late Cenozoic volcanic rocks that were erupted during two periods, as defined by K-Ar dating: (1) 4.0--2.5 m.y., approx.31 km/sup 3/ of basalt, rhyodacite, dacite, andesite, and rhyolite, in descending order of abundance, and (2) < or =1.1 m.y., nearly equal amounts of basalt and rhyolite, most of the rhyolite being < or =0.3 m.y. old. Vents for the volcanic rocks of the younger period are localized on and near a horst of basement rocks within a concavity defined by the distribution of vents of the older period. The alignment of many vents and the presence of a considerable number of roughly north-trending normal faults of late Cenozoic age reflect basin and range tectonics dominated by roughly east-west lithospheric extension. Fumaroles, intermittently active thermal springs, and associated altered rocks occur within and immediately east of the central part of the field of Quaternary rhyolite, in an area characterized by various geophysical anomalies that are evidently related to an active hot-water geothermal system. This system apparently is heated by a reservoir of silicic magma at > or =8-km depth, itself produced and sustained through partial melting of crustal rocks by thermal energy contained in mantle-derived basaltic magma that intrudes the crust in repsonse to lithospheric extension.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Observations of a direct current concentration on the eastern Sierran Front: Evidence for shallow crustal conductors on the eastern Sierran Front and beneath the Coso Range
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; CONTINENTAL CRUST; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; GEOMAGNETIC FIELD; GREAT BASIN; VARIATIONS; CALIFORNIA; EARTH CRUST; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MAGNETIC FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SURVEYS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Observations of the dc magnetic field resulting from a temporary single-pole operation of the Pacific Northwest-Southwest DC Power Intertie indicate an unexpectedly large concentration of current on the eastern Sierran Front and the possibility of a secondary concentration of current associated with the Coso Range. High electrical conductivity in central and eastern Oregon, in the Basin and Range province, and on the eastern Sierran Front would account for these observations.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Three-dimensional Q/sup -1/ model of the Coso Hot Springs known geothermal resource area
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; ATTENUATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; SEISMIC P WAVES; WAVE PROPAGATION; CALIFORNIA; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC WAVES; SURVEYS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Observations of teleseismic P waves above geothermal systems exhibit travel time delays and anomalously high seismic attenuation, which is extremely useful in estimating the thermal regime and the potential of the system. A regional telemetered network of sixteen stations was operated by the U.S. Geological Survey in the Coso Hot Springs Known Geothermal Resources Area (KGRA) for such studies from September 1975 to October 1976. Subsequently, they deployed a portable Centipede array of 26 three-component stations near the center of anomaly. The seismograms of 44 events recorded by the telemetered array and nine events by the Centipede array were analyzed using the reduced spectral ratio technique to determine the differential attenuation factordeltat* for the events recorded with the highest signal-to-noise ratio. The deltat* variation observed across the Coso Hot Springs KGRA were small (<0.2 s). A three-dimensional generalized linear inversion of the deltat* observations was performed using a three-layer model. A shallow zone of high attenuation exists within the upper 5 km in a region bounded by Coso Hot Springs, Devils Kitchen, and Sugarloaf Mountain probably corresponding to a shallow vapor liquid mixture or 'lossy' near surface lithology. No zones of significantly high attenuation occur between 5- and 12-km depth. Between the depth of 12--20 km a thick zone of high attenuation (Q<50) exists, offset toward the east from the surface anomaly.
RESEARCH_ORG: Center for Energy Studies, University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, Texas 75080
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Seismicity of the Coso Range, California
AUTHORS: Walter, A W; Weaver, C S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; COSO HOT SPRINGS; SEISMICITY; EARTHQUAKE FOCI; EARTHQUAKE MAGNITUDE; GREAT BASIN; SLIP; CALIFORNIA; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580201 - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A 16-station seismographic network, approximately 40 km north-south by 30 km east-west, was installed in the Coso Range, California, in September 1975 as part of a geological and geophysical assessment of the geothermal resource potential of range. During the first 2 years of network operations, 4216 local earthquakes (0.5< or =m< or =3.9) defined zones of seismicity that strike radially outward from a Pleistocene rhyolite field located near the center of the Coso Range. Most earthquakes were located in zones showing a general northwest trend across the range. Six earthquake swarms occurred within the area that includes the rhyolite field. Fault plane solutions show regional north-south compression: earthquakes located in northwest striking zones generally had right lateral strike slip focal mechanisms, those in northeast striking zones left lateral strike slip focal mechanisms, and those in north-south striking zones both normal and strike slip focal mechanisms. Earthquake depths showed little variation across the Coso Range; the depth distribution is similar to that of several carefully studied segments of the central San Andreas fault. The b value calculated for the entire range is 0.99 +- 0.08. The rhyolite field has a significantly higher b value of 1.26 +- 0.16; if only the shallow events (depth <5 km) are used in the calculation, the b value for this area becomes even higher, 1.34 +- 0.24. The higher b values were interpreted as reflecting the existence of short average fault lengths (<5 km) within the rhyolite field. The seismic data and other data suggest that the fault system lying between the rhyolite field and the adjacent Coso Basin is an important tectonic boundary. Present information is insufficient to determine the geothermal production capability of this fault system, but is does suggest that the system is a good target for further exploration.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, 345 Middlefield Road, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Hydrothermal alteration enthalpy and heat flow in the Roosevelt Hot Springs thermal area, Utah
AUTHORS: Parry, W T; Ballantyne, J M; Bryant, N L
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ROOSEVELT HOT SPRINGS; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; HEAT FLOW; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; REACTION HEAT; SULFATES; ENTHALPY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; KGRA; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; USA; UTAH; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Mass abundances of hydrothermal alteration product minerals at the Roosevelt Hot Springs thermal area have been calculated using whole rock chemistry and mineral analyses. These computations together with appropriate formulation of the alteration chemical reactions have been used to estimate total enthalpy produced per unit volume of altered rock. Enthalpy of alteration varies widely depending on the model assumed for sulfate production and the intensity of alteration. Maximum enthalpy production for the most altered rock ranges from 2450 to 7070 J/cm/sup 3/, depending on whether none or all of the sulfate required to produce alunite is derived from H/sub 2/S oxidation. The mean enthalpies in the lower 30 m of two drill holes 60 and 66 m deep are 345 and 105 J/cm/sup 3/. Approximate age and depth-of-alteration constraints suggest heat flow due to alteration may be as low as 4 mW/m/sup 2/ or as great as 852 mW/m/sup 2/ depending on alteration intensity and sulfur oxidation. Even though chemical reactions could account for a substantial fraction of measured heat flow, comparison of measured temperatures with temperature calculations indicates an insignificant contribution of alteration reactions to present-day heat flow. The present thermal gradient is explained in terms of convective circulation with a mass flux of water of 1.3 x 10/sup -6/ kg/m/sup 2/ s estimated from alteration mineral abundance.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geology and Geophysics, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah 84112
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Distribution of quaternary rhyolite dome of the Coso Range, California: Implications for extent of the geothermal anomaly
AUTHORS: Bacon, C R; Duffield, W A; Nakamura, K
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; GEOLOGIC HISTORY; VOLCANISM; BASALT; FUMAROLIC FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HEAT FLOW; QUATERNARY PERIOD; RHYOLITES; CALIFORNIA; CENOZOIC ERA; FLUIDS; GEOLOGIC AGES; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Thirty-eight separate domes and flows of phenocryst-poor, high-silica rhyolite of similar major element chemical composition were erupted over the past 1 m.y. from vents arranged in a crudely S-shaped array atop a granitic horst in the Coso Range, California. Most of the extrusions are probably less than about 0.3 m.y. old. The area is one of Quaternary basaltic volcanism and crustal extension. The central part of the rhyolite field is characterized by high heat flow, low apparent resistivity, and substantial fumarolic activity indicative of an active geothermal system. The immediate source of heat for the surficial geothermal phenomena is probably a silicic magma reservoir that may still contain molten or partially molten material at a depth of at least 8 km beneath the central part of the rhyolite field. Outlying rhyolite extrusions probably reflect the presence of feeder dikes emanating from the reservoir beneath the central region. Azimuths of dikes appear to be parallel to the regional tectonic axis of maximum horizontal compression, analogous to some dike-fed flank eruptions on basaltic shields and andesitic strato-volcanoes. The areal extent of a magma reservoir and the present total heat content of the silicic magma system at Coso may be less than was previously estimated. However, the area is still considered to be one of significant geothermal potential.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Interpretation of chemical analyses of waters collected from two geothermal wells at Coso, California
AUTHORS: Fournier, R O; Thompson, J M; Austin, C F
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHLORIDES; THERMAL WATERS; VERY HIGH TEMPERATURE; WELL TEMPERATURE; CALIFORNIA; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; RESERVOIR TEMPERATURE; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Wellhead and downhole water samples were collected and analyzed from a 114.3-m well at Coso Hot Springs (Coso No. 1) and a 1477-m well (CGEH No. 1) 3.2 km to the west. The same chloride concentration is present in hot waters entering both wells (about 2350 mg/kg), indicating that a hot-water-dominated geothermal system is present. The maximum measured temperatures are 142/sup 0/C in the Coso No. 1 well and 195/sup 0/C in the CGEH No. 1 well. Cation and sulfate isotope geothermometers indicate that the reservoir feeding water to the Coso Hot Spring well has a temperature of about 240/sup 0/--250/sup 0/C, and the reservoir feeding the CGEH well has a temperature of about 205/sup 0/C. The variation in the chemical composition of water from the two wells suggests a model in which water-rock chemical equilibrium is maintained as a convecting solution cools from about 245/sup 0/C to 205/sup 0/C by conductive heat loss.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Aeromagnetic and gravity surveys in the Coso Range, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; GRAVITY SURVEYS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOMAGNETIC FIELD; HEAT FLOW; MAGMA; CALIFORNIA; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MAGNETIC FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; SURVEYS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The effect of an underlying magma reservoir cannot be identified within the complex gravity pattern in the Coso Range, California. Rather, linear gravity contours, which suggest a regional tectonic origin, enclose the location of most of the volcanic activity of the Coso Range. Faults along the edges of northwest trending, magnetic blocks probably provided paths of minimum resistance to the ascending viscous magma that was extruded as rhyolite domes. Dense, magnetic rocks associated with a complex mafic pluton 9 km in diameter form a relatively impermeable north border of the Pleistocene volcanic field. A heat flow high nearly coincides with the west half of a 6-km-diameter magnetic low. A 2-km-diameter outcrop of a pre-Cenozoic silicic pluton, which has low magnetization compared to the surrounding metamorphic rocks, presumably typifies the rocks that underlie the magnetic low and heat flow high. Hydrothermal fluids may have destroyed some magnetite in the more magnetic wall rock, further reducing the magnetic intensity.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Structure, tectonics and stress field of the Coso Range, Inyo County, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; PLATE TECTONICS; EARTHQUAKE FOCI; FUMAROLES; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GREAT BASIN; SLIP; STRESS ANALYSIS; CALIFORNIA; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; TECTONICS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The tectonics of the Coso Range has been described as having arcuate and ring faults both suggesting the presence of a circumscribed subsidence bowl or calderalike feature. New information suggests the Coso Range is situated in an area of transition between the stress of the right slip San Andreas fault-plate interaction and the extensional tectonics of the Basin and Range. Arcuate faults in the Coso Range are interpreted to have been produced by the regional stress field rather than to have been of volcanogenic origin. Focal mechanisms of small-magnitude earthquakes support the stress directions indicated by local fault patterns. Fumeroles in the area are primarily associated with oblique slip faults rather than with arcuate or ring faults. The geothermal reservoir is therefore much different from that of a caldera or subsidence bowl, and the overall geothermal potential is probably less than earlier estimates.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geological Sciences, University of Nevada-Reno, Reno, Nevada 89557
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Hydrothermal alteration enthalpy and heat flow in the Roosevelt Hot Springs thermal area, Utah
AUTHORS: Parry, W T; Ballantyne, J M; Bryant, N L
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; DRILL CORES; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; ROCKS; ROOSEVELT HOT SPRINGS; HEAT FLOW; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; ABUNDANCE; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; ALUNITE; BARITE; BIOTITE; BOREHOLES; CALCITE; CALCIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHLORITE MINERALS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; ENTHALPY; FELDSPARS; GEOLOGY; HEMATITE; IRON OXIDES; KAOLINITE; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; MAPS; MINERALOGY; MONTMORILLONITE; MUSCOVITE; PETROGRAPHY; POTASSIUM OXIDES; PYRITES; SILICON OXIDES; SODIUM OXIDES; SULFUR; SULFUR TRIOXIDE; TITANIUM OXIDES; UTAH; VERMICULITE; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM SILICATES; ALUMINIUM SULFATES; BARIUM COMPOUNDS; BARIUM SULFATES; CALCIUM CARBONATES; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CAVITIES; CHALCOGENIDES; CLAYS; ELEMENTS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON ORES; IRON SILICATES; KGRA; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MAGNESIUM SILICATES; MICA; MINERALS; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; ORES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM SULFATES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SULFATES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SULFUR ORES; SULFUR OXIDES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)

Enthalpy of alteration varies widely depending on the model assumed for sulfate production per unit volume of altered rock.
