TITLE: Reconnaissance electrical surveys in the Coso Range, California
AUTHORS: Jackson, D B; O'Donnell, J E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; MAGNETOTELLURIC SURVEYS; TELLURIC SURVEYS; DIRECT CURRENT; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; HEAT FLOW; RESISTIVITY LOGGING; CALIFORNIA; CURRENTS; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; ELECTRIC LOGGING; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SURVEYS; USA; WELL LOGGING; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Telluric current, audiomagnetotelluric (AMT), and direct current (dc) methods were used to study the electrical structure of the Coso Range and Coso geothermal area. Telluric current mapping outlined major resistivity lows associated with conductive valley fill of the Rose Valley basin, the Coso Basin, and the northern extension of the Coso Basin east of Coso Hot Springs. A secondary resistivity low with a north-south trend runs through the Coso Hot Springs--Devil's Kitchen geothermal area. The secondary low in the geothermal area, best defined by the 7.5-Hz AMT map and dc soundings, is caused by a shallow conductive zone (5--30 ohm m) interpreted to be hydrothermally altered Sierra Nevada basement rocks containing saline water of a hot water geothermal system. This zone of lowest apparent resistivities over the basement rocks lies within a closed contour of a heat flow anomaly where all values are greater than 10 heat flow units.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Heat flow in the Coso geothermal area, Inyo County, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; HEAT FLOW; CONVECTION; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; MASS TRANSFER; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; THERMAL WATERS; CALIFORNIA; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Obvious surface manifestations of an anomalous concentration of geothermal resources at the Coso geothermal area, Inyo County, California, include fumarolic activity and associated hydrothermally altered rocks. Pleistocene volcanic rocks associated with the geothermal activity include 38 rhyolite domes occupying a north trending structural and topographic ridge and numerous basaltic cinder cones and lava flows partly surrounding its southern half. In an investigation of the thermal regime of this Basin and Range geothermal area, temperature measurements were made in 25 shallow and 1 intermediate depth borehole. Geothermal gradients ranged from 25.3 /sup 0/C/km to 906. /sup 0/C/km. The high gradients arise from convecting hot water and former convective transport of heat by dikes that fed the domes and flows. Thermal conductivity measurements were made on 312 samples from cores and drill cuttings.. The actual process by which heat is transferred is rather complex; however, the heat flow determinations can be divided into two groups. The first group, less than 4.0 HFU, are indicative of regions with primarily conductive regimes, although deep-seated mass transfer is implied. The second group, greater than 4.0 HFU, are characteristics of regions with considerable convective heat transfer in the shallow subsurface. Heat transferred by convection of water would be rapidly exhausted if it were not intermittently supplied with heat energy from depth; therefore the heat flow data substantiate the concept that the surface hydrothermal activity and associated volcanic rocks are products of a long-lived magmatic system that has periodically erupted lava during the past 0.3--1.0 m.y. This magmatic system is the crustal heat source of the present-day Coso geothermal system (1 HFU=41.87 mW/m/sup 2/).
RESEARCH_ORG: GeoThermal Services, Inc., San Diego, California 92131
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Teleseismic evidence for a low-velocity body under the Coso geothermal area
AUTHORS: Reasenberg, P; Ellisworth, W; Walter, A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COSO HOT SPRINGS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; ATTENUATION; FLOW RATE; HEAT FLOW; SEISMIC P WAVES; WAVE PROPAGATION; CALIFORNIA; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC WAVES; SURVEYS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Teleseismic P wave arrivals were recorded by a dense array of seismograph stations located in the Coso geothermal area, California. The resulting pattern of relative residuals an area showing approximately 0.2-s excess travel time that migrates with changing source azimuth, suggesting that the area is the 'delay shadow' produced by a deep, low-velocity body. Inversion of the relative residual data for three-dimensional velocity structure determines the lateral variations in velocity to a depth of 22.5 km beneath the array. An intense low-velocity body, which concides with the surface expressions of late Pleistocene rhyolitic volcanism, high heat flow, and hydrothermal activity, is resolved between 5- and 20-km depth. It has maximum velocity contrast of over 8% between 10 and 17.5 km. The shallowest part of this body is centered below the region of highest heat flow; at depth it is elongate in approximately the N-S direction. The hypothesis that this low-velocity body is caused by the presence of partial melt in the middle crust is consistent with the local seismic, geologic, and thermal data.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B5

TITLE: Tapping the main stream of geothermal energy
AUTHORS: Whitaker, R; Roberts, V; Hughes, E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; FLASHED STEAM SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; CLASSIFICATION; HEBER GEOTHERMAL FIELD; CALIFORNIA; COMMERCIALIZATION; DEMONSTRATION PLANTS; PILOT PLANTS; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLES; CONVERSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants; 150600 - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Electric power generation success using geothermal energy at The Geysers has motivated nationwide identification and assessment of hydrothermal resources, as well as research and pilot projects for energy conversion. US geothermal projects are underway to take advantage of both high and moderate water temperature and pressure. About half of the electricity-grade hydrothermal energy in the United States is in the high-temperature range and can be converted using direct-flash steam cycle technology. The other half is in the moderate-temperature range, for which the binary cycle is used. The binary cycle involves a second fluid that vaporizes at a much lower temperature than water. The Heber Project in California will be the first direct-flash commercial generation plant. Some of the technical and environmental problems of the direct-flash cycle are being studied by the Electric Power Research Institute. The binary cycle is still in the pilot-to-demonstration stage. As the authors point out, the bottom line is still a combination of reliability and busbar electricity cost. The cost must meet the competitive market set by other fuels and technologies. Along these lines, the future of geothermal energy looks promising. (SAC)
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4

TITLE: Controlling scale formation in geothermal brines
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL HEATING SYSTEMS; SCALE CONTROL; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; ADDITIVES; CORROSION INHIBITORS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; SALTON SEA; SALTON SEA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; CONTROL; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HEATING SYSTEMS; LAKES; POWER PLANTS; SURFACE WATERS; TESTING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: The use of hypersaline brines from the Salton Sea geothermal field for power generation, mineral recovery, and direct heating now is in the early stages of development. Successful commercialization of these ventures will depend in part on whether ways can be found to avoid or control the severe buildup of scale that takes place on surfaces in contact with the cooling brine. The use of various chemical additives to prevent or inhibit scale formation has been investigated and several organic compounds that show promise have been discovered.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Technol. Rev.; (United States)

TITLE: Eruptions at Chaos Crags, Lassen Volcanic National Park, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; VOLCANIC REGIONS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; PETROGRAPHY; BASALT; BIOTITE; ERUPTION; GLASS; HORNBLENDE; LAVA; MAGMA SYSTEMS; PUMICE; PYROXENES; QUARTZ; RHYOLITES; SILICA; AMPHIBOLE; CHALCOGENIDES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; MICA; MINERALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; ROCKS; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Chaos Crags are a group of silicic lava domes and associated tephra deposits composed of intermediate and silicic lavas on the edge of the central plateau of Lassen Volcanic National Park, California. The plateau coincides with a negative gravity anomaly interpreted as a large silicic magma reservoir. About 0.15 km/sup 3/ of rhyodacitic pyroclastic flows were erupted 1100 years ago from vents beneath the present Crags and flowed for 21 km down the valleys of Lost and Manzanita Creeks. Pumice pyroclasts in the flows are characterized by high phenocryst content and low vesicularity. These eruptions were followed by the extrusion of 1.25 km/sup 3/ of dacitic lava as a stubby flow and three-lobed dome. The tephra and lava appear to be products of intrusion of mostly liquid high-alumina basalt into a large, partially crystallized rhyolitic magma body with subsequent mixing. The earliest tephra contain only a minor basaltic component while the youngest portion of the Crags contain approximately 20%. This change with time reflects either a vertical zonation in the magma inherited from the mixing event or a continued admixing of basaltic magma within the chamber during the span of eruptive period.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Volcanol. Geotherm. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:3/4

TITLE: Fault zone controlled charging of a liquid-dominated geothermal reservoir
AUTHORS: Goyal, K P; Kassoy, D R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; FLOW RATE; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; BOUNDARY LAYERS; CONVECTION; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; POROSITY; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; RIFT ZONES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; LAYERS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: A mathematical model is developed for the fault zone controlled charging of a geothermal reservoir. The model is used to describe a reservoir of finite vertical extent with an impermeable upper boundary. A quasi-analytic theory is developed for high Rayleigh number convection of liquid in a rigid porous medium. In this approximation, liquid rises up the fault and spreads into the near regions of the reservoir isothermally. The cooling effect of the surface on the fault flow is confined to a thin layer near the surface. This layer grows with distance from the fault. In the far field of the aquifer the full depth of the reservoir is cooled by the surface. A study is made of the effect of various parameters such as mass flow rate, Rayleigh number, and fault width on the pressures, velocities, temperatures, and their gradients at different locations in the fault and in the aquifer. This analysis can be applied to geothermal systems where the thickness of the impermeable reservoir cap is quite small compared to the reservoir depth.
RESEARCH_ORG: Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Colorado, Boulder, Colorado 80309
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B4

TITLE: Measurement of thermal conductivity of porous media by a needle probe method
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 02 PETROLEUM; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GLASS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; ROCKS; SCHISTS; PROBES; UNDERWATER; LEVELS; METAMORPHIC ROCKS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 360603* - Materials- Properties; 020200 - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: A needle probe of 4 mm diameter and 15 cm length is developed to measure the thermal conductivity of porous media. Thermal conductivities of glass bead packs and rock fragment packs are measured under water-saturated conditions and under dry conditions. The measured values under dry conditions are lower than that under water-saturated conditions. Measurements of thermal conductivities are carried out on cuttings or fragments of rock-like material from three wells at various areas in Japan. The weighted geometric mean equation is used to determine the thermal conductivity. For one well, the thermal conductivities of rock fragments by the needle probe method are compared with those of cores by the divided bar method. Measured thermal conductivities of siltstone are nearly the same with two methods, but there are large differences between them for schist.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dev. Jpn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:4

TITLE: Nigorikawa geothermal pilot plant
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPERATION; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; CORROSION PROTECTION; HEAT EXCHANGERS; JAPAN; PILOT PLANTS; POWER RANGE 100-1000 KW; SCALING; ASIA; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150801* - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: The basic engineering technology for construction of a large-scale plant (10,000 kW to 20,000 kW) has been established through the design, manufacture, and operation of a 1000 kW geothermal binary cycle power plant. The technology of heat exchangers is the key factor in the pursuit of an economical binary cycle power system. The study of heat exchangers should be conducted taking into account the heat cycle and the working fluids. Although satisfactory countermeasures against scale formation in heat transfer tubes were achieved in the pilot geothermal plant, the research on the problems of scaling and corrosion in geothermal energy systems should be continued.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dev. Jpn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:4

TITLE: Geothermal: hot energy for the future
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NEW MEXICO; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL PROCESS HEAT; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; RIO GRANDE RIFT; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEAT; HEATING; HEATING SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; PROCESS HEAT; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; SPACE HEATING; USA; WELLS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Using hot groundwater for indoor space heating and water heating has now emerged as a possibility that may alter New Mexico's energy future dramatically. The commitment to geothermal development at the state level has attracted national attention and funding. The New Mexico Energy Institute at New Mexico State University (NMEI-NMSU) in Las Cruces, where geothmal resources have been located, is a lead agency for federally sponsored operations research in the ten-state Rocky Mountain Basin and Range Region. The first production well will draw 17 gallons of water per minute at 118/sup 0/F to supply energy for hot water and space heat in the NMSU University Center Complex now under construction. Mechanical equipment will include air conditioning and a standard heat pump adapted to use hydrothermal energy. A reinjection well to pump cooled water back into the ground will round out the system. The Rio Grande Rift, which parallels the Rio Grande river's course down the middle of the state, is a vast geologic fault system that allows heat from the earth's core to rise conveniently close to the surface. Many of the state's major population centers sit atop this fault. The convenient hot water has given rise to many public and private schemes ranging from space heating, a geothermal greenhouse, and even industrial process heat for drying and dyeing operations. (SAC)
RELATION: Journal Name: N.M. Bus. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:4

TITLE: Baca Project: high mountain geothermal
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; NEW MEXICO; DEMONSTRATION PLANTS; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; ECONOMIC POLICY; ENERGY POLICY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; PUBLIC UTILITIES; REGULATIONS; US DOE; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Located at the 8800-foot elevation in high mountains with cold, snowy winters, the Baca Geothermal Demonstration project will deliver only 50 MW of power initially, with expansion possible to 400 MW. The three partner - the Department of Energy (DOE), Union Geothermal Company of New Mexico, and the Public Service Company of New Mexico - will cover the estimated $125 million cost. The organizations are different, with differing, sometimes conflicting, approaches to their jobs and with different goals. Representatives of the three organizations were asked to talk about each organization's project objectives, why each got involved, and how well their original assumptions have worked to date. The Union Geothermal representative and the representative from the Public Service Company were more project- and profit-oriented, while the DOE representative expressed the desire to help stimulate geothermal development, get answers to technical problems, and to show economic viability. Other topics such as media coverage of the project's environmental impacts, government requirements, and government delays were discussed by the three representatives. (SAC)
RELATION: Journal Name: N.M. Bus. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:4

TITLE: Ground radan survey of a geothermal area in Hawaii
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RIFT ZONES; HAWAII; KILAUEA VOLCANO; RADON; BASALT; PLATE TECTONICS; ELEMENTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; RARE GASES; ROCKS; TECTONICS; USA; VOLCANOES; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 580202 - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Rates of ground radon emanation, in the Puna geothermal area on the lower east rift of Kilauea volcano, were measured by alpha particle sensitive cellulose nitrate films. The survey successfully defined an area of thermal significance associated with the rift structure, and suggests that a thermally driven ground gas convection system exists within, and peripheral to, the rift. This type of survey was found suitable for the basaltic island environmnet characteristic of Hawaii and is now used in Hawaii as a routine geothermal exploration technique.
RESEARCH_ORG: Hawaii Institute of Geophysics, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, Hawaii 96822
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Res. Lett.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:4

TITLE: Sulfide deposits from the east Pacific rise near 21/sup 0/N
AUTHORS: Hekinian, R; Fevrier, M; Bischoff, J L; Picot, P; Shanks, W C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SEA BED; MINERALS; SULFIDES; THERMAL SPRINGS; COPPER COMPOUNDS; DEPOSITS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; HYDROXIDES; IRON OXIDES; MARCASITE; MICA; OCEANIC CRUST; PACIFIC OCEAN; PLATE TECTONICS; PYRITE; RIFT ZONES; SILICA; ZEOLITES; CHALCOGENIDES; EARTH CRUST; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON SULFIDES; ORES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PYRITES; SEAS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SULFUR ORES; SURFACE WATERS; TECTONICS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; WATER SPRINGS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: Massive sulfide deposits were discovered from the diving saucer Cyana on the accreting plate boundary region of the East Pacific Rise near 21/sup 0/N. The deposits form conical and tubular structures lying on a basaltic basement. Mineralogical and geochemical analyses showed two main types of intimately associated products: a polymetallic sulfide-rich material composed of pyrite and marcasite in association, zinc-rich phases, and copper-rich compounds, and an iron-rich oxide and hydroxide material (also called gossan) composed largely of goethite and limonite. Silicate phases such as opaline, silica, iron-silicon clay, and trace amounts of mica and zeolite are encountered in both types of material. Possible mechanisms for the formation of the sulfide deposits on the East Pacific Rise are discussed.
RESEARCH_ORG: Centre Oceanologique de Bretagne, Brest Cedex, France
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 207

TITLE: Geopressured energy fighting uphill battle
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 03 NATURAL GAS; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; ECONOMICS; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GULF COAST; METHANE; SALINITY; SOLUBILITY; WELL DRILLING; ALKANES; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; DRILLING; EXPLORATION; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; USA; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability; 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 030600 - Natural Gas- Economic, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Recent developments in exploration for geopressured systems reveal problems which make the outlook for profitable use less likely. The primary problem is the salinity of the water - the higher the salinity, the less methane can be dissolved. (MHR)

TITLE: East Pacific rise: hot springs and geophysical experiments
AUTHORS: Spiess, F N; Macdonald, K C; Atwater, T
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; PACIFIC OCEAN; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; GRAVITY SURVEYS; HOT SPRINGS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; BARIUM; BASALT; CALCIUM OXIDES; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHROMIUM OXIDES; GEOLOGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IRON OXIDES; MANGANESE OXIDES; NICKEL; OCEANIC CRUST; PETROLOGY; PHOSPHORUS OXIDES; POTASSIUM OXIDES; RUBIDIUM; SEA BED; SILICON OXIDES; SODIUM OXIDES; SULFIDES; SULFUR OXIDES; TITANIUM OXIDES; ZIRCONIUM; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALI METALS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS; EARTH CRUST; ELEMENTS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IRON COMPOUNDS; MANGANESE COMPOUNDS; METALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHOSPHORUS COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SEAS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SURFACE WATERS; SURVEYS; THERMAL SPRINGS; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; WATER SPRINGS; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Hydrothermal vents jetting out water at 380/sup 0/ +- 30/sup 0/C have been discovered on the axis of the East Pacific Rise. The hottest waters issue from mineralized chimneys and are blackened by sulfide precipitates. These hydrothermal springs are the sites of actively forming massive sulfide mineral deposits. Cooler springs are clean to milky and support exotic benthic communities of giant tube worms, clams, and crabs similar to those found at the Galapagos spreading center. Four prototype geophysical experiments were successfully conducted in and near the vent area: seismic refraction measurements with both source (thumper) and receivers on the sea floor, on-bottom gravity measurements, in situ magnetic gradiometer measurements from the submersible Alvin over a sea-floor magnetic reversal boundary, and an active electrical sounding experiment. These high-resolution determinations of crustal properties along the spreading center were made to gain knowledge of the source of new oceanic crust and marine magnetic anomalies, the nature of the axial magma chamber, and the depth of hydrothermal circulation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 207:4438

TITLE: Geothermal system at 21/sup 0/N, East Pacific Rise: physical limits on geothermal fluid and role of adiabatic expansion
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; PACIFIC OCEAN; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; QUARTZ; DEPOSITION; SOLUBILITY; SULFIDES; ADIABATIC PROCESSES; CHALCOPYRITE; COOLING; DENSITY; ENVIRONMENTAL TRANSPORT; EXPANSION; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MAGMA; METALS; MINERALS; OCEANIC CRUST; PYRRHOTITE; SEA BED; SPHALERITE; CHALCOGENIDES; COPPER COMPOUNDS; COPPER SULFIDES; EARTH CRUST; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON SULFIDES; MASS TRANSFER; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKS; SEAS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Pressure-volume-temperature relations for water at the depth of the magma chamber at 21/sup 0/N on the East Pacific Rise suggest that the maximum subsurface temperature of the geothermal fluid is about 420/sup 0/C. Both the chemistry of the discharging fluid and thermal balance considerations indicate that the effective water/rock ratios in the geothermal system are between 7 and 16. Such low ratios preclude effective metal transport at temperatures below 350/sup 0/C, but metal solubilization at 400/sup 0/C and above is effective even at such low ratios. It is proposed that the 420/sup 0/C fluid ascends essentially adiabatically and in the process expands, cools, and precipitates metal sulfides within the upper few hundred meters of the sea floor and on the sea floor itself.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 207

TITLE: Deep-sea primary production at the Galapagos hydrothermal vents
AUTHORS: Karl, D M; Wirsen, C O; Jannasch, H W
SUBJECT: 59 BASIC BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MICROORGANISMS; PRODUCTION; PACIFIC OCEAN; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ATP; BACTERIA; BIOSYNTHESIS; CARBON DIOXIDE; FOOD CHAINS; NUCLEOSIDES; OXIDATION; PURINES; REDUCTION; RIFT ZONES; SAMPLING; SEA BED; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HETEROCYCLIC COMPOUNDS; NUCLEOTIDES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RIBOSIDES; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; SYNTHESIS; 550700* - Microbiology; 150202 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Dense animal populations surrounding recently discovered hydrothermal vents at the Galapagos Rift sea-floor spreading center, 2550 meters deep, are probably sustained by microbial primary production. Energy in the form of geothermically reduced sulfur compounds emitted from the vents is liberated during oxidation and used for the reduction of carbon dioxide to organic matter by chemosynthetic bacteria.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 207

TITLE: Oxygen ion-conducting ceramics: a new application in high-temperature-high pressure pH sensors
SUBJECT: 47 OTHER INSTRUMENTATION; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 22 GENERAL STUDIES OF NUCLEAR REACTORS; COOLANTS; PH VALUE; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; MONITORING; YTTRIUM OXIDES; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; BRINES; ELECTRODES; MEMBRANES; CHALCOGENIDES; FLUIDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; YTTRIUM COMPOUNDS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 440300* - Miscellaneous Instruments- (-1989); 150302 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys; 220200 - Nuclear Reactor Technology- Components & Accessories
DESCRIPTION: Membrane electrodes fabricated from yttria-stabilized zirconia, a representative oxygen ion-conducting ceramic, show a linear voltage response to pH over the range 3 to 8 at 285/sup 0/C and a pressure of 1200 pounds per square inch (82 atmospheres). Test units have been operated continuously at 285/sup 0/C without failure for periods as long as 9 days. Unlike sensors which are based on electron transfer couples, such membrane electrodes are insensitive to changes in the oxidation-reduction environment and, in turn, exert no influence upon the environment. Such ceramic membranes can therefore be used for the direct measurement of the pH of geothermal brines, of water in nuclear reactors, and in high-temperature thermodynamic studies on aqueous systems.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 207

TITLE: DOE moves ahead with geothermal
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; REVIEWS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; POWER GENERATION; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; CONVERSION; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY CONVERSION; HEATING; RESOURCES; 150000* - Geothermal Energy
DESCRIPTION: DOE is cooperating with industry to develop geothermal resouces for direct heating and power generation as part of the national goal to seek alternative fuels. A limited number of sites are available for dry steam power generation, but underground hot water is more prevalent, and the largest source is geopressured water and dry, hot rock. The personnel and objectives of the Interagency Coordinating Council (IGCC), which coordinates federal research efforts, are described. Technology development is aimed at reducing the costs of recovering and using geothermal energy, the major thrust going to binary-cycle systems to use in geothermal fields with low and moderate temperatures. Environmental impact assessment, demonstration programs, and feasibility studies of geopressure and hot rock resources make up the major portions of the DOE program. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:2

TITLE: US geothermal resources
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; FORECASTING; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; USES; ALASKA; CALIFORNIA; FEDERAL REGION IX; HAWAII; IDAHO; LOUISIANA; MAPS; NEVADA; OREGON; REVIEWS; TEXAS; US ORGANIZATIONS; DOCUMENT TYPES; FEDERAL REGION VI; FEDERAL REGION X; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; USA; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The United States Geological Survey publication Assessment of Geothermal Resources of the United States - 1978 is described. Details of geothermal resources within the US are discussed. Geothermal applications in California, Oregon, Idaho, Nevada, Hawaii, and Louisiana are described briefly. (MJF)
RELATION: Journal Name: EDIS; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:2

TITLE: Obstacles to geothermal development
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FINANCING; LEGAL ASPECTS; GEOTHERMAL INDUSTRY; REGULATIONS; GROUND WATER; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; USES; CHALCOGENIDES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INDUSTRY; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; WATER; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability; 150600 - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Obstacles to geothermal development, both high-temperature, electric-generating, revenue-producing applications and low-temperature, direct-use applications, include environmental problems such as hydrogen sulfide emissions, ground-water contamination, conflicts between adjacent geothermal resources, loss of ground-water resources, and land subsidence; legal and regulatory problems, such as the placement of geothermal energy under utility regulation, making financing small-scale and high-risk ventures difficult; and conflicts with local laws, such as state land-lease bidding, minimum-acreage requirements, and bonding requirements.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environ. Sci. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:3

TITLE: Stopping of a rising, liquid-filled crack in the earth's crust by a freely slipping horizontal joint
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; CRACKS; CONTINENTAL CRUST; FLUID WITHDRAWAL; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; STRESSES; THERMAL CRACKING; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRACKING; DECOMPOSITION; EARTH CRUST; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; PYROLYSIS; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; WELLS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: The stress intensity factor K at the upper tip of a vertical, liquid-filled crack in the earth's crust is large for relatively small crack (K>3MPa m/sup 1/2/ when the crack length is larger than about 40 m). Consequently, the large water-filled cracks considered for use in the extraction of geothermal heat might be expected to pop to the earth's surface. in this paper it is shown that a freely slipping horizontal joint (as well as a not so freely slipping joint) can stop the upward motion of a large liquid-filled crack. If the joint is tightly fitting, there is not limit to the length of a stopped crack. If slip on a joint results in the joint being propped open, the maximum crack length of a stopped crack is given by the crevasse expression: total crack length =..pi..T/2(rho-rho')g, where T is the tectonic stress, g is the gravitational acceleration, and rho-rho' is the difference between the rock and liquid density. The results can also be applied to the problem of magma transport in the earth's crust. In particular, laccolith emplacement is favored when the nonhydrostatic tectonic stress component is compressive in character.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Materials Science and Engineering and Department of Geological Sciences Northwestern University, Evanston, Illinois 60201
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 85:B2

TITLE: Geothermal resources: an energy source for the US pulp and paper industry
AUTHORS: Howard, J H; Davey, J V
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; PAPER INDUSTRY; GEOTHERMAL PROCESS HEAT; DEMONSTRATION PLANTS; ENERGY CONSERVATION; INVESTMENT; NEW ZEALAND; POWER GENERATION; RETROFITTING; WOOD PRODUCTS INDUSTRY; AUSTRALASIA; ECONOMICS; ENERGY; HEAT; INDUSTRY; POWER PLANTS; PROCESS HEAT; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150801* - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation; 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: The extensive use of energy by the pulp and paper industry is discussed as well as the influence of rising energy costs. It is pointed out that the pulp and paper industry is the 5th largest user of energy and consumes 10% of all purchased energy in the USA. Geothermal resources are cited as a major possibility for new energy sources for the industry and plans are discussed and illustrated for two situations: (1) a retrofitted pulp and paper mill utilizing a geopressure geothermal resource; and (2) a newly designed plant using the same resource. A geothermal-fired pulp and paper plant in New Zealand is described which operates effectively, both technically and economically. The economics of geothermal utilization are discussed and it is concluded that overall rate of return is about 25%. The matching of plant sites to the location of geothermal resources is discussed and criteria are established to determine the feasibility of using geothermal resources. 2 references. (MJJ)
RELATION: Journal Name: Pap. Trade J.; (United States)

TITLE: Thermal evolution of plutons: a parameterized approach
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGMA; TIME DEPENDENCE; CONVECTION; COOLING; CRYSTALLIZATION; GRAPHS; HIGH TEMPERATURE; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; THEORETICAL DATA; WATER; CONFIGURATION; DATA; DATA FORMS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; 580100* - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989); 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: A conservation-of-energy equation was derived for the spatially averaged magma temperature in a spherical pluton undergoing simultaneous crystallization and both internal (magma) and external (hydrothermal fluid) thermal convection. The model accounts for the dependence of magma viscosity on crystallinity, temperature, and bulk composition; it includes latent heat effects and the effects of different initial water concentrations in the melt, and quantitatively considers the role that large volumes of circulatory hydrothermal fluids play in dissipating heat. The nonlinear ordinary differential equation describing these processes was solved for a variety of magma compositions, initial temperatures, initial crystallinities, volume ratios of hydrothermal fluid to magma, and pluton sizes. These calculations are graphically summarized in plots of the average magma temperature versus time after emplacement. Solidification times, defined as the time necessary for magma to cool from the initial emplacement temperature to the solidus temperature vary as R/sup 1/ /sup 3/, where R is the pluton radius. The solidification time of a pluton with a radius of 1 kilometer is 5 x 10/sup 4/ years; for an otherwise identical pluton with a radius of 10 kilometers, the solidification time is approx. 10/sup 6/ years. The water content has a marked effect on the solidification time. A granodiorite pluton with a radius of 5 kilometers and either 0.5 or 4 percent (by weight) water cools in 3.3 x 10/sup 5/ or 5 x 10/sup 4/ years, respectively. Convection solidification times are usually but not always less than conduction cooling times. 2 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 207

TITLE: Tectonic tilt rates derived from lake-level measurements, Salton Sea, California
AUTHORS: Wilson, M E; Wood, S H
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SALTON SEA; TECTONICS; INCLINATION; LEVEL INDICATORS; LEVELS; SEDIMENTARY BASINS; CALIFORNIA; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; IMPERIAL VALLEY; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Tectonic tilt at the Salton Sea was calculated by differencing lake-level measurements from two points on the sea. During the past 26 years, tilting was down toward the southeast. By 1970 differential vertical movement amounted to 110 millimeters between two gages situated 38 kilometers apart on the southwest shore. A reversal in tilt direction in late 1972 has diminished the net differential vertical movement to 60 millimeters.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 207

TITLE: Design of an isobutane binary cycle geothermal generation system
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; DESIGN; 2-METHYLPROPANE; CONSTRUCTION; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; OPERATION; POWER RANGE 100-1000 KW; ALKANES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150801* - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: A 1000 kW binary cycle geothermal power plant was designed, constructed, and operated. The technological feasibility of a future large operating plant was established. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dev. Jpn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:3

TITLE: Percentage depletion for geothermal energy: an alternative method for calculation of gross income
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ENERGY TAX ACT; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; DEPLETION ALLOWANCES; TAXES; ACCOUNTING; ECONOMIC IMPACT; INCOME; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCE DEPLETION; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; LAWS; MANAGEMENT; NATIONAL ENERGY ACT; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: As the search for alternative energy sources intensifies in the United States, more attention is being focused upon geothermal energy. The issue of how to tax this natural resource has been an active, if not satisfactorily resolved one. The Energy Tax Act of 1978 explicitly authorizes percentage depletion allowances for geothermal deposits, but in a manner not well suited to developing geothermal technology. The problems which have arisen under the current Treasury regulations on the subject suggest more-appropriate method of calculation based on a return-on-investment model, and offering some relief for the taxpayer. 29 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Land Water Law Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 15:2

TITLE: Utilization of geothermal hot water for controlled horticulture
AUTHORS: Ueda, F; Suda, U; Shibata, T
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GREENHOUSES; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; SOILS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL HEATING SYSTEMS; BUILDINGS; HEATING; HEATING SYSTEMS; SPACE HEATING; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: Ground-surface radiator tubes and underground radiator pipes are used, so that the geothermal hot water is circulated twice in a horticulture facility to extend the available thermal range. Means of minimizing the unevenness of ground temperature is then investigated. The purpose is to seek optimal temperature conditions to use geothermal hot water for controlled horticulture in snowy and cold areas. For the experiment, insofar as practical, highly economical equipment and materials were employed. In addition, the facility was such that it could be easily set up by a horticulture producer.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dev. Jpn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:3

TITLE: Field stress corrosion tests in brine environments of the Salton Sea known geothermal resource area
AUTHORS: Carter, J P; Cramer, S D
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; STAINLESS STEELS; FIELD TESTS; STRESS CORROSION; BRINES; CARBON STEELS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HASTELLOYS; INCONEL 625; NATURAL STEAM; SALTON SEA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; ALLOYS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM ALLOYS; CORROSION; CORROSION RESISTANT ALLOYS; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HEAT RESISTANT MATERIALS; HEAT RESISTING ALLOYS; INCONEL ALLOYS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; MATERIALS; MOLYBDENUM ALLOYS; NICKEL ALLOYS; NICKEL BASE ALLOYS; NIOBIUM ALLOYS; STEAM; STEELS; TANTALUM ALLOYS; TESTING; WELLS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: Corrosion research is being conducted to determine suitable construction materials for geothermal resource recovery plants. As part of this research, a 30-day stress corrosion test was conducted at the Salton Sea Known Geothermal Resource Area on seven iron- and nickel-base alloys in four brine and steam process streams using wellhead brine from geothermal well Magmamax 1. The tests showed transgranular cracking of AISI 316L stainless steel and intergranular and transgranular cracking of AISI 430 stainless steel in all four process streams. E-Brite 26-1 exhibited intergranular and transgranular cracking in three of the four process streams. Carbon steel, Inconel 625 and Hastelloys G and C-276 show no evidence of stress corrosion cracking.
RELATION: Journal Name: Mater. Performance; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:9

TITLE: Geothermal energy - ready for use
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL DISTRICT HEATING; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; REVIEWS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; COST; ELECTRIC GENERATORS; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; CONVERSION; DISTRICT HEATING; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEATING; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150000* - Geothermal Energy
DESCRIPTION: The use of geothermal energy in the United States for heating applications is discussed. The three major forms of geothermal energy, hydrothermal, petrothermal and geopressured, are briefly reviewed, with attention given to the types of energy available from each. Federally supported projects demonstrating the use of geothermal hot water to heat homes in Boise, Idaho, and hot dry rocks in Fenton Hill, New Mexico to produce electricity are presented. Data available from existing geothermal energy applications are presented which show that geothermal is cost competitive with conventional energy sources using existing technology, and government economic incentives to the producers and users of geothermal energy are indicated. Finally, advanced equipment currently under development for the generation of electricity from geothermal resources at reduced costs is presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy (Washington, D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 5

TITLE: Geology and mineral resources of Box Elder County, Utah
AUTHORS: Doelling, H H; Campbell, J A; Gwynn, J W; Perry, J I
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 11 NUCLEAR FUEL CYCLE AND FUEL MATERIALS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; UTAH; COAL DEPOSITS; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; MINERAL RESOURCES; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; URANIUM DEPOSITS; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; LIGNITE; METAMORPHIC ROCKS; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; THORIUM ORES; BROWN COAL; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; COAL; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION VIII; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; MATERIALS; NORTH AMERICA; ORES; RESOURCES; ROCKS; USA; 011000* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 020200 - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 030200 - Natural Gas- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 050100 - Nuclear Fuels- Reserves, Exploration, & Mining; 150100 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability; 294000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Fossil Fuels; 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources
DESCRIPTION: Box Elder County displays a variety of lithologic types in each of the major rock divisions: sedimentary, igneous and metamorphic, in a typical basin and range setting. Each mountain range exhibits a variety of structural situations; most stratigraphic units are folded and faulted, and many are intruded by igneous rocks. Exposed stratigraphic units range in age from Precambrian to Triassic for the more consolidated units and from Tertiary to Quaternary for mostly nonconsolidated or partially consolidated units. Box Elder County has had little production of mineral fuels. A small amount of petroleum was produced at Rozel Point on the north shores of Great Salt Lake and a small amount of natural gas has been produced from a few wells in the eastern part of the county. One well was drilled for its geothermal possibilities but the results were inconclusive. A lignite field in the northwest part of the state has only a marginal potential. Very low grade vein-type deposits of uranium and thorium have been discovered in widely separated occurrences in the county. 161 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Utah Geol. Mineral. Surv., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 115
JOURNAL_NAME: Utah Geol. Mineral. Surv., Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Economics of optimal geothermal resource extraction for electric power
AUTHORS: Blair, P; Cassel, T A.V.; Edelstein, R H; Paik, I
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; OPTIMIZATION; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants; 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A theoretical framework is presented for estimating optimal rates of extraction of geothermal resources from a hydrothermal reservoir for the production of electricity. The formulation integrates the technological characteristics of hydrothermal-reservoir management and electric-power generation into an optimal economic investment-production model. Of particular interest is the incorporation of time-dependent resource-decline phenomena into the model. Assuming an objective of maximizing net present value, the solution provides optimal rates over time of electric-power production, of capital investment in well-field equipment, and of hydrothermal resource extraction. 7 references, 4 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Syst. Policy; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:3

TITLE: Wellbore flow characteristics for optimal energy recovery from Gulf Coast geopressured geothermal sources
AUTHORS: Lamb, J P; Hamburger, C L
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; ENERGY RECOVERY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; FLOW RATE; LOUISIANA; TEXAS; BRINES; FLUID FLOW; GULF COAST; HEAT EXTRACTION; HEAT RECOVERY; METHANE; OPTIMIZATION; RANKINE CYCLE; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; SALINITY; ALKANES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FEDERAL REGION VI; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; RECOVERY; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLES; USA; WELLS; 150906* - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology; 150303 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging
DESCRIPTION: Geopressured geothermal brines contain potential energy in three forms: dissolved methane, high pressure, and high temperature. For optimal resource utilization one must separate the natural gas while simultaneously maximizing the conversion processes required for the liquid phase. The present paper discusses some basic thermodynamic concepts which determine the conversion effectiveness of hydraulic and thermal energy components. Using realistic resource data for Texas and Louisiana, it is shown that there is a range of well flow rates which maximizes the brine energy recovery. The effects of salinity levels on various flow parameters are also illustrated; in general, salinity is found to have a minor effect on theoretical performance. Hence, the major influence of dissolved solids would be on equipment performance.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Soc. Mech. Eng., (Pap.); (United States); Journal Volume: 81-Pet-18

TITLE: Application of petroleum engineering to geothermal development
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; CALIFORNIA; CEMENTS; DESIGN; DRILLING; ENGINEERING GEOLOGY; FORECASTING; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; MATERIALS TESTING; THERMAL EXPANSION; WELL CASINGS; BUILDING MATERIALS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EXPANSION; EXPLORATION; FEDERAL REGION IX; GEOLOGY; MATERIALS; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TESTING; USA; WELLS; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability; 150101 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal operations appear to be a natural extension of oil and gas operations because of the similarity of expertise, technology, and equipment required. The sharing of these items between the petroleum industry and geothermal developers is described. Some differences in transferring oil and gas work to geothermal development are noted for well testing, well stimulation, reserve estimation, secondary recovery/reservoir management, drilling techniques, drilling materials and bits, pipeline system design, and scale control. The US and world potential for geothermal power is estimated for the next 2 decades, i.e., 700,000 bpd oil equivalent in the US. 11 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Pet. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 32:1

TITLE: In-situ heat transfer in man-made hydraulically fractured geothermal energy reservoirs
AUTHORS: Murphy, H D; Tester, J W; Grigsby, C; Potter, R M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FRACTURED RESERVOIRS; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT TRANSFER; CALDERAS; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; GRANITES; HEAT EXTRACTION; NEW MEXICO; VOLCANOES; WATER VAPOR; COMMINUTION; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY TRANSFER; FEDERAL REGION VI; FLUIDS; FRACTURING; GASES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; PLUTONIC ROCKS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ROCKS; SURVEYS; USA; VAPORS; WELLS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Heat extraction results and reservoir assessments are discussed for 2 geothermal reservoirs created by hydraulic fracturing of hot granitic formations on the west flank of the Valles Caldera, a dormant volcano, in the Jemez Mt. of New Mexico. The second reservoir was created in a deeper rock formation using the same pair of operation wells, and appears to be approximately 8 times larger in heat transfer area than the first reservoir. Despite the larger size, the flow impedance of the second reservoir is the same as that of the first, and the down-hole water losses to the surrounding rock were requirements as a building block for commercial sized, multiply fractured reservoirs - 6 or 7 reservoirs similar to the latest one would produce 20 to 50 MW (T) for 20 years.
RELATION: Journal Name: AIChE Symp. Ser.; (United States); Journal Volume: 76:199

TITLE: Mass discharge of a geofluid from a geothermal reservoir - well system with flashing flow in the bore
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; TWO-PHASE FLOW; FLASHING; FRICTION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; EVAPORATION; FLUID FLOW; FLUIDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; WELLS; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: In this analysis the reservoir and wellbore are treated as a single open system. By appealing to the conservation equations for mass, energy and momentum and identifying the components of pressure drop through the system the mass discharge is calculated in terms of the terminal conditions, parametric quantities and well constants. A numerical example is used to illustrate the respective effects upon the mass discharge of single and two-phase friction factor, wellhead pressure, phase slip and reservoir drawdown. 8 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3-4

TITLE: Construction of a probe for measuring temperature and pressure in deep wells
AUTHORS: Adorni, N; Ceppatelli, L; Grassi, A; Palama, A; Rosselli, P
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; PROBES; WELLS; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: This paper describes a temperature and pressure system for geothermal wells. The system permits (at real time and on the ground) the electrical recording of temperature and pressure profiles in deep boreholes to a depth of 3000 m with maximum running temperatures of 240/sup 0/C and pressures of 250 bar.
RESEARCH_ORG: Cent Inf Studi Esperienze, Milan, Italy
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3-4

TITLE: Thermal techniques for characterizing magma body geometries
AUTHORS: Hardee, H C; Larson, D W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGMA SYSTEMS; HEAT FLUX; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CALCULATION METHODS; DIKES; GEOMETRY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT TRANSFER; ENERGY TRANSFER; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MATHEMATICS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: The surface heat flux distribution resulting from emplaced magma bodies can be used to help characterize the magma source. Closed-form analytical solutions for the conduction heat transfer from various idealized magma geometries (dikes, sills, and spheres) are obtained using either the Schwarz-Christoffel transformation theorem (dikes and sills) or the 'method of images' with superposition (spheres). 14 refs.
RESEARCH_ORG: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, NM, USA
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3-4

TITLE: Hydrothermal metamorphism in the Larderello Geothermal Field
AUTHORS: Cavarretta, G; Gianelli, G; Puxeddu, M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LARDERELLO GEOTHERMAL FIELD; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; METAMORPHISM; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HIGH TEMPERATURE; ITALY; MINERALS; TECTONICS; EUROPE; WESTERN EUROPE; 150202* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The various tectonic units underlying the Larderello-Travale geothermal region have undergone hydrothermal metamorphism. The hydrothermal mineral assemblages are generally consistent with the temperatures now measured in the wells, leading to the hypothesis that solid phases deposited from a liquid medium during a hot-water stage that preceded the vapor-dominated one. 61 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3-4

TITLE: Radon measurements at three New Zealand geothermal areas
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NEW ZEALAND; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; RADON 222; MONITORING; BROADLANDS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; CARBON DIOXIDE; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; PERMEABILITY; WAIRAKEI GEOTHERMAL FIELD; ALPHA DECAY RADIOISOTOPES; AUSTRALASIA; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; DAYS LIVING RADIOISOTOPES; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HEAVY NUCLEI; ISOTOPES; NUCLEI; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RADIOISOTOPES; RADON ISOTOPES; SURVEYS; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Radon-222 measurements are reported for geothermal areas at Wairakei, Broadlands and Ngawha, New Zealand. They suggest that for Wairakei the origin of the Radon 222 is deep, follows the carbon dioxide, and there is little contribution from local ground water. The reverse is true at Hgawha, and Broadlands is intermediate. 16 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3-4

TITLE: System H/sub 2/O-CO/sub 2/-CH/sub 4/-H/sub 2/ at Travale, Italy: tentative interpretation
AUTHORS: Nuti, S; Noto, P; Ferrara, G C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; ITALY; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; CARBON 13; CARBON DIOXIDE; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HYDROGEN; METHANE; WATER; ALKANES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON ISOTOPES; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; ELEMENTS; EUROPE; EVEN-ODD NUCLEI; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; NONMETALS; NUCLEI; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; STABLE ISOTOPES; SURVEYS; WESTERN EUROPE; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys; 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: The Travale geothermal field lies south-east of the well-known geothermal field of Larderello in Tuscany, Italy. It was discovered and exploited at a later date than Larderello. The chemical composition of the major gas species is presented and interpreted, particularly the relationship between the gases, water, carbon dioxide, methane and hydrogen. Using these relationships and the isotopic results some hypotheses are made on the origin of the gas species and the possible chemical and isotopic equilibria between the different fluid components. 33 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3-4

TITLE: Control of gas absorption in a geothermal steam direct contact condenser
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; STEAM CONDENSERS; CARBON DIOXIDE; CONTROL SYSTEMS; COOLING SYSTEMS; CORROSION RESISTANCE; GASES; PILOT PLANTS; WASTE DISPOSAL; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CONDENSERS; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FLUIDS; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; MANAGEMENT; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; VAPOR CONDENSERS; WASTE MANAGEMENT; 150802* - Geothermal Power Plants- Power Plant Systems & Components
DESCRIPTION: The absorption of geothermal gases by the cooling water of a turbine exhaust steam condenser can be minimized by a combination of design and control technology. The condenser system should comprise the two stages of a condenser and gas cooler with parallel cooling water supply and hot water disposal systems. The control system discussed allows the condenser to retain its traditional flexibility of improved vacuum in cool weather and yet maintains a distribution of heat loads between the condenser and gas cooler without the use of accurate heat balances. 3 refs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 9:3-4

TITLE: Corrosion in geothermal brines of the Salton Sea Known Geothermal Resource Area
AUTHORS: Cramer, S D; Carter, J P
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; CORROSION; MOLYBDENUM ALLOYS; NICKEL BASE ALLOYS; STEELS; TITANIUM ALLOYS; TITANIUM BASE ALLOYS; ZIRCONIUM ALLOYS; CARBON DIOXIDE; CARBON STEELS; METHANE; PITTING CORROSION; SALTON SEA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; SCALING; STAINLESS STEELS; STRESS CORROSION; ALKANES; ALLOYS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM ALLOYS; CORROSION RESISTANT ALLOYS; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HYDROCARBONS; IRON ALLOYS; NICKEL ALLOYS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: Corrosion research is being conducted by the Bureau of Mines to determine suitable construction materialls for geothermal resource recovery plants. High chromium-molybdenum iron-base alloys, nickel- and titanium-base alloys, and titanium-zirconium-molybdenum alloy exhibited good resistance to general, crevice, pitting, and weld corrosion and stress corrosion cracking in laboratory tests in deaerated brines of the Salton Sea Known Geothermal Resource Area (KGRA) type at 232/sup 0/C and in brine containing dissolved carbon dioxide and methane. Only titanium-base alloys were resistant to corrosion in oxygenated Salton Sea KGRA-type brine. Copper adversely affected the resistance to general corrosion of low-alloy steels in deaerated brine, whereas chromium, nickel, silicon, and titanium improved it. Carbon steel, type 4130 steel, and types 410 and 430 stainless steels exhibited poor corrosion resistance in field tests in five brine and steam process streams produced from geothermal well Magmamax 1. These alloys were highly susceptible to pitting and crevice corrosion. General corrosion rates were high for carbon and type 4130 steels.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Soc. Test. Mater., Spec. Tech. Publ.; (United States); Journal Volume: 717
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Soc. Test. Mater., Spec. Tech. Publ.; (United States)

TITLE: Geothermal energy in California: policies to improve the economic impact of energy resource development
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ECONOMIC IMPACT; SOCIAL IMPACT; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; REGIONAL ANALYSIS; IMPERIAL VALLEY; COOPERATION; DECISION MAKING; ENERGY POLICY; PLANNING; CALIFORNIA; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 290200 - Energy Planning & Policy- Economics & Sociology; 530100 - Environmental-Social Aspects of Energy Technologies- Social & Economic Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Energy development in the United States faces problems of regional acceptance. This paper examines the regional energy development decisions generally by looking at the impact of geothermal energy development on Imperial Valley, California. While land use will vary for different energy source development projects the basic economic trends will be similar. Regional, interregional and regional-national policies intended to improve the impact of development are discussed. Basic to any national energy goal is the cooperation among decision and policy makers on the local, regional and national levels. (SAC)
RELATION: Journal Name: Growth and Change; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:1

TITLE: On some computation methods of unit response functions from varying-rate data. [Geothermal well, natural gas well]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 03 NATURAL GAS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; DATA PROCESSING; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; ITALY; NATURAL GAS WELLS; LEAST SQUARE FIT; RESPONSE FUNCTIONS; ENGINEERING; EUROPE; FUNCTIONS; MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD FIT; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; PROCESSING; WELLS; WESTERN EUROPE; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance; 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing
DESCRIPTION: This paper studies the conditions under which unit response functions can be computed from experimental data and presents some new computing methods to accomplish this. These new methods are compared with other existing methods. Some applications to Italian geothermal reservoirs are also shown. 7 refs.
