TITLE: Boise planning to expand thermal heating project
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS; GEOTHERMAL DISTRICT HEATING; PLANNING; IDAHO; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; RETROFITTING; SPACE HEATING; BUILDINGS; DISTRICT HEATING; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEATING; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; USA; WELLS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 320600 - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Municipalities & Community Systems- (1980-)
DESCRIPTION: The sponsors of a $15 million geothermal project predict that commercial firms in downtown Boise, Idaho will be able to cut their heating bills by 20 to 50%. The project is sponsored jointly by the local water district and the DOE. The Boise geothermal resource low mineral and contaminate content permits the use of off-the-shelf equipment, although there is disagreement over the efficiency of using conventional equipment rather than plate heat exchangers for the 170/sup 0/F water. The project developers will concentrate on buildings with existing ductwork and needing little retrofit work. The cost of installing geothermal systems in new buildings is comparable to that of oil and gas systems. No formal agreements have been signed, although 53 businesses and a shopping-mall developer expect to negotiate when the rates are announced. Geothermal wells have been used in Boise since the 1930s, but interest lagged until the recent increases in utility rates. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:52

TITLE: EEC focuses new energy budget on solar and conservation R and D
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; COMMON MARKET; ENERGY CONSERVATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; BUDGETS; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SOLAR ENERGY; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPEAN COMMUNITIES; INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; 299000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 291000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Conservation; 150102 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 140505 - Solar Energy Conversion- Photochemical, Photobiological, & Thermochemical Conversion- (1980-)
DESCRIPTION: Solar energy, followed by conservation and geothermal energy, will have top priority for the European Economic Community's (ECC) $142 million energy research budget through 1983. Proposals for the cost-shared projects, of which EEC will pay half, are being accepted by eligible companies and research organizations. Committees for each technology advise the European Commission on which proposals to accept and suggest an appropriate funding level. The EEC also funds demonstrations of promising research to determine economic feasibility. Major emphasis will be placed during the present four-year budget for solar research on photovoltaics. Other projects include a European solar-insolation atlas and solar-heating manual, advanced batteries, and energy storage systems. Geothermal projects will focus on resource mapping, exploratory drilling, hydrogen production, and energy forecasting. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Res. Rep.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:22

TITLE: Structure of two-phase hydrothermal flows in permeable media
AUTHORS: Sheu, J P; Torrance, K E; Turcotte, D L
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; TWO-PHASE FLOW; STEAMBOAT SPRINGS; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; BOILING; CONVECTION; GROUND WATER; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; PERMEABILITY; STEAM; WATER; FLUID FLOW; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NEVADA; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PUBLIC LANDS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 580100* - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Numerical solutions are obtained for the ascending convection of ground water with boiling. The results are applicable to geothermal reservoirs above cooling igneous intrusions. The steady vertical flow of water in a uniform permeable medium is assumed. Pressure release boiling results in a two-phase, steam-water zone. Within this zone, steam percolates upward relative to water. Near the surface is a water zone due to conductive cooling. The conductive cooling prevents boiling at low water flow rates. Calculated results are compared with temperature and pressure logs from drill holes in the thermal systems of Steamboat Springs, Nevada, and Yellowtone National Park, Wyoming.
RESEARCH_ORG: Sibley School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Cornell University, Ithaca, new York 14853
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B13

TITLE: Geology of a submarine hydrothermal field, Mid-Atlantic Ridge, 26 /sup 0/N latitude
AUTHORS: Temple, D G; Scott, R B; Rona, P A
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ATLANTIC OCEAN; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; SEA BED; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; LITHOLOGY; MANGANESE OXIDES; PACIFIC OCEAN; RIFT ZONES; SEA-FLOOR SPREADING; SEDIMENTS; CHALCOGENIDES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MANGANESE COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESOURCES; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 580500* - Oceanography- (1980-1989); 150202 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A comparison of structural and lithologic features observed from two stereophotographic transverses of the Trans-Atlantic Geotraverse (TAG) hydrothermal field, 26 /sup 0/N, Mid-Atlantic Ridge, with features of the French-American Mid-Ocean Undersea Study (Famous) hydrothermal site and the Mounds hydrothermal field of the Galapagos spreading center show that all three areas have hydrothermal deposits with restricted and patchy lateral extent and are associated with closely spaced normal faults commonly of small displacement. No one lithology characterizes either the rocks or the that underlie the hydrothermal deposits. Regions without hydrothermal manganese oxide deposits such as the rift valley at 37 /sup 0/N in the Famous area exhibit larger and fewer faults and lack the abundant permeable semiconsolidated breccia seen at 26 /sup 0/N. Thus structural factors which facilitate hydrothermal circulation by enhancing permeability appear critical to hydrothermal deposition. Structural features of the rift valley wall at 26 /sup 0/N include inward facing normal faulting, outward facing normal faulting and outward tilting by rotation of fault blocks. These observations support a viscous drag mechanism of uplift of the rift valley walls.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Oceanography, Texas AM University, College Station, Texas 77843
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B13

TITLE: Hydrothermal mounds of the Galapagos Rift: Observations with DSRV Alvin and detailed heat flow studies
AUTHORS: Williams, D L; Green, K; Andel, T H.V.; Herzen, R P.V.; Dymond, J R; Crane, K
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OCEANIC CRUST; HEAT FLOW; PACIFIC OCEAN; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IRON SILICATES; MANGANESE OXIDES; RIFT ZONES; SEDIMENTS; CHALCOGENIDES; EARTH CRUST; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IRON COMPOUNDS; MANGANESE COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESOURCES; SEAS; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 580500* - Oceanography- (1980-1989); 150202 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Ranging in height from gentle hills of less than a meter to steep-sided giants of more than 20 m, the mounds of the Galapagos Rift are spectacular hydrothermal features. Their internal temperatures have been measured at up to 13 /sup 0/C above the bottom water temperature, and total heat flow (conducted plus convected) can be several hundred to several thousand times the normal oceanic values. Fluids, when they discharge from the mound, do so at a very slow rate and at temperatures probably quite near the bottom water temperature. The mounds are principally composed of iron silicates intermixed and incrusted with lesser amounts of manganese oxides. They are generally found in rows, in a uniformly sedimented area above faults or fractures in the crustal rocks which permit fluids to escape from a deep hydrothermal aquifer. The sediment blanket in some way alters the chemistry of the ascending thermal fluids and leads to the development of mounds. The mounds field, covering an area of at least 200 km/sup 2/ and consisting of thousands of individual mounds, is probably less than 300,000 years old; and many of the mounds may be only a few tens of thousands of years old or less.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Box 25046, Federal Center, Denver, Colorado 80225
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B13

TITLE: Cleaning of geothermal steam simplified
AUTHORS: Dagani, R; Makrides, A C; Harvey, W W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; REMOVAL; NATURAL STEAM; DESULFURIZATION; SCRUBBING; COPPER SULFATES; PILOT PLANTS; PRECIPITATION; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; TECHNOLOGY UTILIZATION; TESTING; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COPPER COMPOUNDS; FLUIDS; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STEAM; SULFATES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 150600* - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: A. C. Makrides and W. W. Harvey of EIC Corp., working in cooperation with Pacific Gas and Electric Co., have developed a new process for removing hydrogen sulfide from geothermal steam. The EIC process, field-tested at a 5 Mw pilot plant at The Geysers, Calif., scrubs the 100,000 lb/hr of steam with a sulfuric acid solution of copper sulfate, which precipitates at least 95Vertical Bar3< of the hydrogen sulfide as an insoluble copper sulfide and which also removes ammonia, boron compounds, and rock dust. Since the scrubbing solution is at the same temperature and pressure as the steam, there is hardly any loss of thermal energy. The presently used hydrogen sulfide-removal procedure, developed by Pacific Gas, is effective but cumbersome and expensive.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. News; (United States); Journal Volume: 57:49

TITLE: Geothermal development in California's Imperial Valley
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; IMPERIAL VALLEY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; CORROSION; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PERMITS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; SCALING; ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; FEDERAL REGION IX; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; WELLS; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: The Imperial Valley is one of the most active geothermal areas in the United States. This large area contains about 500,000 acres of land under irrigated cultivation and large tracts of land have been leased for geothermal development to a dozen different geothermal companies. Over 90 deep geothermal wells have been drilled in the valley, and four geothermal fields have been found to be potentially productive including Niland, Brawley, Heber and East Mesa. One geothermal power plant which will commence operation this year has been constructed by Magma Power Company at the East Mesa Field. A second power plant will start up in early 1980 with steam supplied by Union and the power plant constructed by Southern California Edison at the Brawley Field. Intentions to develop geothermal resources to supply power plants have been announced by Republic Geothermal at the East Mesa Field, Chevron at the Heber Field and both Magma Power and Union Oil Company at the Niland Field. There are a half dozen companies that have permitted well locations that are either drilling now or will be in the near future. A brief description of the current activities in each of the geothermal areas is given.
RESEARCH_ORG: Union Oil Co. of California, Los Angeles
RELATION: Journal Name: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Historical perspective on geothermal theory
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; INFORMATION; REVIEWS; ENGINEERING; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; GEOTHERMAL INDUSTRY; HEAT; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; THERMODYNAMICS; CONVERSION; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; ENERGY CONVERSION; INDUSTRY; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RESOURCES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 150000* - Geothermal Energy; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The controversy between the evolutionary geologists, represented by Lyell, and the mathematical physicists, represented by Sir Willian Thomson, over the geothermal theory reached an intense level because one sounded the voice of popular science and the other defended the scientific tradition. Although there was no decisive termination of the debate, the mathematical and experimental approach eventually prevailed. Geothermal science, as was the case with all science, followed the path that produced useful results. Mathematics and experiment gave results that were quantifiable, verifiable, and cumulative. By the use of standards of measurement, geothermal science has accumulated a body of knowledge that is not subject to the change in popular opinion. Geothermal science, soundly based on scientific tradition, is applicable to all conceivable conditions that a geothermal engineer might encounter.
RELATION: Journal Name: Aware; (United States); Journal Volume: 111; Other Information: Reprinted from ASTM Standardization News, October 1979

TITLE: Alternate method of preparing polymer concrete from mixtures of liquid and solid monomers. [Compression strength after exposure to simulated geothermal brine]
AUTHORS: Carciello, N R; Zeldin, A N; Kukacka, L E
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; CONCRETE-PLASTIC COMPOSITES; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; SYNTHESIS; ACRYLAMIDE; CONCRETES; COPOLYMERIZATION; COPOLYMERS; METHACRYLATES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POLYMERIZATION; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; THERMAL ANALYSIS; USES; AMIDES; BUILDING MATERIALS; CARBOXYLIC ACID SALTS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMPOSITE MATERIALS; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC POLYMERS; POLYMERS; 360301* - Composite Materials- Preparation & Fabrication- (-1987); 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development; 360303 - Composite Materials- Mechanical Properties- (-1987)
DESCRIPTION: This study was performed to facilitate the handling of solid monomers for commercial usage and to confirm the belief that these monomers can be incorporated into aggregates to produce high-strength, chemically resident, and thermally stable PC (polymer concrete). In the monomer system mentioned, the curing temperature is 60/sup 0/C. Evidently at this temperature the Aa (acrylamide) or MAa (methacrylamide) dissolves in the surrounding liquid monomer before polymerization occurs. There appears to be no segregation of constituents. However, thorough mixing of the solid monomer is essential for a good particle distribution, otherwise the desired ratio of monomers to form complete copolymers will not be achieved. It can be seen in the thermal analysis, and physical properties, that both hot and room-temperature methods of preparation can be used to produce the same product.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Appl. Polym. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:10

TITLE: Interaction mechanisms between poly(methyl methacrylate) and tricalcium silicate (C/sub 3/S). [Before and after exposure to simulated geothermal brines]
AUTHORS: Sugama, T; Kukacka, L E; Horn, W
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; CALCIUM SILICATES; CONFIGURATION INTERACTION; POLYACRYLATES; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; CHEMICAL BONDS; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; ELECTRON SCANNING; HIGH TEMPERATURE; INFRARED SPECTRA; METHYL METHACRYLATE; MOLECULAR STRUCTURE; STABILITY; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; THERMAL ANALYSIS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBOXYLIC ACID ESTERS; ESTERS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; METHACRYLIC ACID ESTERS; MICROSCOPY; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC POLYMERS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLYMERS; POLYVINYLS; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SPECTRA; SPECTROSCOPY; 400301* - Organic Chemistry- Chemical & Physicochemical Properties- (-1987); 360402 - Polymers & Plastics- Structure & Phase Studies- (-1987); 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: Interaction mechanisms between poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) molecules and tricalcium silicate (C/sub 3/S) occurring in a C/sub 3/S-filled PMMA molecular structure before and after exposure to a simulated 25% geothermal brine solution at 240/sup 0/C have been investigated by use of thermal analysis, infrared spectroscopy analysis, scanning electron microscopy, and compressive strength tests. For C/sub 3/S-filled PMMA samples before exposure to hot brine, it was observed that an interaction between the C/sub 3/S filler and the CH/sub 2/ groups in the main chain of the PMMA occurred. After exposure to the hydrothermal environment, indications were that the brine solution induced ionic bonding between the carboxylate anion (-COO/sup -/) groups in the PMMA and the Ca/sup 2 +/ ions from the C/sub 3/S. The reaction contributed to improvements in the thermal stability of the PMMA.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Appl. Polym. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:10

TITLE: Heat flow in western Virginia and a model for the origin of thermal springs in the folded Appalachians
AUTHORS: Perry, L D; Costain, J K; Geiser, P A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; THERMAL SPRINGS; HEAT FLUX; VIRGINIA; CONVECTION; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; THERMAL WATERS; TOPOGRAPHY; CENTRAL REGION; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; USA; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Five new heat flow values in the Blue Ridge (37/sup 0/02'N, 80/sup 0/12'W), Valley and Ridge (38/sup 0/00'N, 79/sup 0/50'W; 37/sup 0/54'N, 79/sup 0/54'W; 38/sup 0/14'N, 79/sup 0/49'W), and Alleghany Plateau (37/sup 0/12'N, 82/sup 0/06'W) provinces of Virginia are 36.3 +- 1.3mW/m/sup 2/, 317 +- 20mW/m/sup 2/, 48.2 +- 0.3mW/m/sup 2/, 49.5 +- 1.5mW/m/sup 2/, and 55.8 +- 1.7mW/m/sup 2/, respectively. The value of 36.3mW/m/sup 2/ in the Blue Ridge agrees with values predicted by the contour map of Sass et al. (1976) for this part of the eastern United States; the values of 49.5 and 48.3mW/m/sup 2/ in the Valley and Ridge province do not. The high value of 317 +- 20mW/m/sup 2/ at Hot Springs, Virginia, is the result of convection along a fault zone and is not regionally representative. The value of 48.3mW/m/sup 2/ determined at a site about 8 km southwest of Hot Springs, Virginia, is regionally representative of the heat flux. New data support a model of moderately deep circulation of meteoric water entering near-vertical sedimentary beds at relatively high topographic elevations and circulating downward via bedding plane permeability and fractures within Silurian quartzites and/or adjacent carbonate units. The moderately deep circulation is then intersected by vertical transverse linear fracture zones along which the water rises. All of the warm springs are located adjacent to topographic gaps which have developed along zones of weakness associated with the transverse fracture zones.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geological Sciences, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Virginia 24061
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B11

TITLE: Solid electrolyte behavior of NaMgF/sub 3/: geophysical implications
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EARTH MANTLE; SOLID ELECTROLYTES; IONIC CONDUCTIVITY; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; FLUORIDES; GEOPHYSICS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MELTING POINTS; OXIDES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; ELECTROLYTES; FLUORINE COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TRANSITION TEMPERATURE; 400400* - Electrochemistry; 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: In the solid state, NaMgF/sub 3/ transforms smoothly with temperature into a solid electrolyte phase; the conductivity is 130 siemens per meter just below the melting point. The isostructural compound MgSiO/sub 3/ should behave similarly under conditions obtained in the earth's lower mantle, and so it is expected that the electrical conductivity in that region is ionic rather than electronic.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 206

TITLE: Geothermal energy in Arizona
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ARIZONA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEOLOGIC MODELS; GEOLOGY; METEORIC WATER; RESERVOIR TEMPERATURE; EXPLORATION; GROUND WATER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESOURCES; USA; WATER; WESTERN REGION; 150300* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology; 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Bureau of Geology and Mineral Technology, Geological Survey Branch, has been exploring for geothermal energy since May, 1977. The known major geothermal systems in Arizona are apparently caused by deep circulation of meteoric water through the complex fracture systems of the Basin and Range region and transition zone. This type of system is thought to be capable of generating geothermal reservoirs with temperatures on the order of 150/sup 0/C to 200/sup 0/C at 2 to 3 km depth in the intermontane basin.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:11

TITLE: Pseudopolarographic determination of metal complex stability constants in dilute solution by rapid scan anodic stripping voltammetry
AUTHORS: Brown, S D; Kowalski, B R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; ARSENIC COMPLEXES; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; VOLTAMETRY; CADMIUM CHLORIDES; CADMIUM COMPLEXES; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; QUANTITATIVE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; LEAD CHLORIDES; LEAD COMPLEXES; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; GLYCINE; GRAPHS; TABLES; AMINO ACIDS; CADMIUM COMPOUNDS; CADMIUM HALIDES; CARBOXYLIC ACIDS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; COMPLEXES; DATA; DISPERSIONS; FLUIDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; KINETICS; LEAD COMPOUNDS; LEAD HALIDES; MIXTURES; NUMERICAL DATA; ORGANIC ACIDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SOLUTIONS; 152001* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions; 400102 - Chemical & Spectral Procedures
DESCRIPTION: The theory of anodic stripping voltammetry (ASV) states that at any deposition potential, the deposition current will either be the limiting current or a fraction of the limiting current, depending on the deposition potential with respect to the metal deposition potential. By using a computer controlled anodic stripping voltammeter with automatic background correction, pseudopolarograms can be obtained by plotting the peak area vs the deposition potential for a series of stripping voltammetric runs. With ASV as a method of amplification, the ligand number and stability constants are determined for metal complexes at concentration ranges expected of natural water systems. Results for lead and cadmium with chloride and carbonate are in excellent agreement with those of less sensitive methods used at higher concentrations. No complexation of lead and cadmium was found with glycine at pH 4.68. The structure of arsenic(III) at 1.0 ng/mL in acidic solutions was determined to be As(OH)/sub 3/ using a gold film electrode. Finally, the speciation of lead in a geothermal water was examined by pseudopolarography and a shift consistent with a PbCl/sup +/ complex was observed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Anal. Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 51:13

TITLE: Convective instabilities in vertical fractures and faults
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; CONVECTIVE INSTABILITIES; CONVECTION; GEOLOGIC FISSURES; ROCK-FLUID INTERACTIONS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; INSTABILITY; PLASMA INSTABILITY; 580100* - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Natural convection of water contained in a vertical fracture or fault in which the temperature increases with depth is strongly influenced by the heat transport processes not only within the water itself but also by the heat transferred to and from the surrounding rock mass. The results of a linear stability analysis indicate that the critical Rayleigh number R* is time dependent. For spontaneous neutral stability, R* (t=0) approx. =10(h/a) /sup 2/, where h and a are the fault height and aperture, respectively. Since h>>a, R* (0) is several orders of magnitude greater than the value 4..pi../sup 2/ that would pertain to the same situation without the influence of the surrounding rock masses, e.g., a porous bed with large horizontal dimensions. The resultant cell motion consists of rolls about axes parallel to the aperture. These rolls are of height h and closely spaced in the strike direction. Cases of spontaneous instabilities in fractures or faults are expected to be infrequent, but initially subcritical convection could be fostered by other means such as tectonic displacements at the fault. Because R* diminishes as time /sup -1/2/, eventually, this subcritical convection becomes unstable, and exponential growth ensues. As the heat of the surrounding rock is depleted and an isothermal state is approached, the convection eventually dampens until a period of thermal recovery allows its resumption.
RESEARCH_ORG: Geosciences Division, Alamos Scientific Laboratory, Los Alamos, New Mexico 87545
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B10

TITLE: Non-electric utilization of geothermal water and steam from production wells of geothermal power stations in Japan
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL DISTRICT HEATING; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; WASTE HEAT UTILIZATION; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; BALNEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HATCHOBARU GEOTHERMAL FIELD; KAKKONDA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; MATSUKAWA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; ONIKOBE GEOTHERMAL FIELD; ONUMA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; OTAKE GEOTHERMAL FIELD; DISTRICT HEATING; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEATING; MEDICINE; POWER PLANTS; SPACE HEATING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WASTE PRODUCT UTILIZATION; WELLS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization; 150801 - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Non-electric utilization of a portion of the geothermal fluid from production wells is described at four of the six geothermal power stations in Japan: Ohnuma, Matsukawa, Ohtake and Hatchobaru. There is no non-electric utilization at the remaining two, Kakkonda and Onikobe areas. In general, the geothermal fluid flows through a heat exchanger in which it heats fresh water from a nearby river. The heated fresh water, in turn, is used for a variety of purposes in the environs of these stations. A major use is in bathing which is a reflection of the bathing-loving trait of the Japanese. District heating and greenhouse heating are, of course, also found in some of these areas.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dev. Jpn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:2

TITLE: International developments in geothermal power
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; REVIEWS; FLOWSHEETS; ITALY; JAPAN; NEW ZEALAND; POWER; TABLES; USA; ASIA; AUSTRALASIA; DIAGRAMS; DOCUMENT TYPES; EUROPE; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WESTERN EUROPE; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: The status of geothermal electric power generation throughout the world is reviewed. A tabular summary of installed geothermal power capacity is given for eleven countries. A closer look is taken at the activities in Italy, New Zealand, Japan, and the United States. Examples of the most recent projects are described and illustrated with flow diagrams and site photographs. Some of the unsolved technical problems facing the geothermal industry are pointed out.

TITLE: Special situations require careful planning in tubular design
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; WELL CASINGS; INJECTION WELLS; DESIGN; CARBON DIOXIDE; CORROSION; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; DIRECTIONAL DRILLING; FRACTURES; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; STEAM INJECTION; STRESSES; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; WATER; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COMMINUTION; DRILLING; ENHANCED RECOVERY; FAILURES; FLUID INJECTION; FRACTURING; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RECOVERY; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; THERMAL RECOVERY; WELLS; 150901* - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware; 420206 - Engineering- Mining & Drilling Equipment & Facilities- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Special situation like doglegs, directionally drilled holes, geothermal or steam injection wells, corrosion and fluid injection systems dictate the emphasis on more criteria applied to tubular design programs. Such situations require design consideration above normal collapse and frequently need design criteria on tension, internal resistance, and others. For doglegs and directionally drilled holes the tubing has to contain internal and external pressures as well as normal tension. In geothermal and vapor injection wells the tubing is subjected to large increases in temperature causing an expanding tendency of the tubing. Since the tubing is fixed at both ends this results in tubing rotation and axial compression. For injection wells and wells subjected to hydraulic fracturing, the tubing is subjected to additional tension and compression forces not normal to production situations. The presence of CO/sub 2/ and H/sub 2/S along with water can cause galvanic corrosion and tubing fractures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Pet. Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 37:10

TITLE: Mutual diffusion coefficients of Na/sub 2/SO/sub 4/-H/sub 2/O and MgSO/sub 4/-H/sub 2/O at 25/sup 0/C from Rayleigh interferometry
AUTHORS: Rard, J A; Miller, D G
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGNESIUM SULFATES; DIFFUSION; SODIUM SULFATES; INTERFEROMETRY; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; QUANTITY RATIO; RAYLEIGH SCATTERING; WATER; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; COHERENT SCATTERING; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SCATTERING; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SULFATES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: The volume-fixed mutual diffusion coefficients of Na/sub 2/SO/sub 4/-H/sub 2/O and MgSO/sub 4/-H/sub 2/O have been measured, from dilute solutions to near saturation, to an accuracy of 0.1 to 0.2% by free-diffusion Rayleigh interferometry. These results are compared to other available diffusion data for these salts. The diffusion coefficients of Na/sub 2/SO/sub 4/-H/sub 2/O and MgSO/sub 4/-H/sub 2/O decrease regularly with increasing concentration, while those of many other salts exhibit both a maximum and a minimum as a function of concentration. A few diffusion coefficients have also been measured for KCl-H/sub 2/O. 3 figures, 5 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Solution Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:10

TITLE: Mutual diffusion coefficients of NaCl-H/sub 2/O and CaCl/sub 2/-H/sub 2/O at 25/sup 0/C from Rayleigh interferometry
AUTHORS: Rard, J A; Miller, D G
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALCIUM CHLORIDES; DIFFUSION; SODIUM CHLORIDES; AMMONIUM CHLORIDES; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; DENSITY; INTERFEROMETRY; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; RAYLEIGH SCATTERING; WATER; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; AMMONIUM COMPOUNDS; AMMONIUM HALIDES; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM HALIDES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; COHERENT SCATTERING; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SCATTERING; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: The volume-fixed mutual diffusion coefficients of NaCl-H/sub 2/O and CaCl/sub 2/-H/sub 2/O have been measured to an accuracy of 0.1 to 0.2%, from dilute solutions to high concentrations, by free diffusion Rayleigh interferometry. These diffusion coefficients are compared to other diffusion data for these salts, obtained from Guoy interferometry and the conductometric method. Discrepancies between data in the literature are resolved using the present results. Some diffusion coefficients have also been measured for KCl-H/sub 2/O and NH/sub 4/Cl-H/sub 2/O. 4 figures, 5 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Solution Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:10

DESCRIPTION: Solubilities for the binary systems, salt-H/sub 2/O, of the chlorides of lithium, rubidium, cesium, magnesium, calcium, strontium, and barium from near 0/sup 0/C to the saturated boiling point are reported. The experimental data and coefficients of an equation for a smoothed curve describing each system are listed in the tables. The data are improvements on those previously reported in the literature, having a precision on the average of +- 0.09%. 2 tables.

TITLE: Potential-pH diagrams for iron and nickel in high salinity geothermal brine containing low concentrations of hydrogen sulfide
AUTHORS: Macdonald, D D; Syrett, B C
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; IRON; CORROSION; NICKEL; PH VALUE; SALINITY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; METALS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 360105* - Metals & Alloys- Corrosion & Erosion; 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: Potential-pH diagrams are reported for iron and nickel in sulfide containing high salinity geothermal brine at 25 and 250/sup 0/C. Metal sulfides, as well as dissolved chloride complexes, were considered in deriving the diagrams, and the potential-pH relationships for those equilibria involving dissolved H/sub 2/S or its anions are plotted for a constant total dissolved sulfide content of 10 ppM. The diagrams are used to analyze the general features of the thermodynamic behavior of iron and nickel in geothermal systems, and to identify processes that might be expected to occur in high temperature sulfide containing brines.
RELATION: Journal Name: Corrosion; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:10

TITLE: National geothermal exploration technology program
AUTHORS: Ball, L; Salisbury, J W; Kintzinger, P R; Veneruso, A F; Ward, S H
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; NATIONAL PROGRAM PLANS; COST; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MANAGEMENT; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; RESERVOIR ENGINEERING; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; ROCK MECHANICS; TECHNOLOGY UTILIZATION; US DOE; WELL LOGGING; ENGINEERING; EXPLORATION; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; SURVEYS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 150300* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: In response to the Geothermal Energy Research, Development, and Demonstration Act of 1974, a federal geothermal program has been established with the objective of stimulating the commercial development of geothermal resources. The program goal is to increase the annual rate of energy utilization from the present 0.04 quads (500 MWe) to 0.3 to 0.5 quads in the near-term (about 1985), 4.0 to 9.0 quads in the mid-term (1985 to 2000), and 16.0 to 28.0 quads in the long-term (by about 2020). The realization of these goals depends upon the discovery and exploitation of many new geothermal resource areas. The Department of Energy program for geothermal exploration and assessment has been structured to address technological barriers presently hindering the economical discovery and delineation of geothermal resources. The program elements - exploration technology, reservoir assessment, reservoir confirmation, and reservoir engineering - are described in light of the need to evaluate some 1500 new prospects in order to meet the federal midterm electric power goal of 20,000 MWe on line by the year 2000. The program elements are illustrated with suggested sequences from exploration, assessment, and confirmation of a 200-MWe resource in the eastern Basin and Range physiographic province. The estimated costs for these sequences are $385,000, $565,000, and $3,190,000, respectively. Deep drilling constitutes the major element in the confirmation costs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:10

TITLE: Intradune flats of the Algodones chain, Imperial Valley, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IMPERIAL VALLEY; TOPOGRAPHY; EAST MESA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; EROSION; MOTION; SAND; WIND; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A striking characteristic of the southeastern part of the remarkably linear northwest-southeast Algodones Dunes chain is a succession of regularly spaced, wholly enclosed flats exposing the alluvial substrate. Each flat is bounded on the northwest by a high active slip face of sand and on the southeast by a more gently inclined deflated sand slope, suggesting that the flats are moving southeasterly along the chain axis. Measurements over a 12-y interval confirm this movement and indicate an average southeasterly movement of 35 to 40 cm/y. Development of alluvium-floored intradune flats is presaged by formation of ridge and hollow couplets father to the northwest. Embryonic ridge-and-hollow forms extend almost to the northwestern tip of the chain. Development of long, linear transverse, sand-trapping ridges, which are instrumental in creating downwind hollows, appears to be an inherent characteristic of eolian transport under conditions of relatively smooth terrain, scanty vegetation, and a limited flux of sand supplied approximately orthogonally to a dominant resultant direction of drift. Principal resultant sand drift produced by a multidirectional wind regime over the dunes is southeast; northeast is the next most favored direction. Secondary influences of faulting may account for the unusual linearity of the chain, which is probably a belt of shoreline dunes about 37,000 y old. Intradune flats are large enough to be resolved on orbiter photos of Mars, and some of the patterns on the martian surface attributed to eolian processes may involve intradune flats.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 90:10

TITLE: Pyroclastic flow deposits
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 12 MANAGEMENT OF RADIOACTIVE AND NON-RADIOACTIVE WASTES FROM NUCLEAR FACILITIES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; VOLCANIC ROCKS; GEOLOGIC MODELS; USES; BUILDING MATERIALS; ERUPTION; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; LITHIUM; PUMICE; RADIOACTIVE WASTE STORAGE; THORIUM; TUFF; URANIUM; ZEOLITES; ACTINIDES; ALKALI METALS; ELEMENTS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; MANAGEMENT; MATERIALS; METALS; MINERALS; RESOURCES; ROCKS; STORAGE; WASTE MANAGEMENT; WASTE STORAGE; 580202* - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 052002 - Nuclear Fuels- Waste Disposal & Storage; 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: Pyroclastic flow deposits are found throughout the geologic record, from Precambrian times until only a few thousand years ago. These deposits have proved enigmatic to geologists; until recently, many were mistaken for lava flows or sedimentary rock units. Over the last twenty years, however, numerous field and laboratory studies have begun to explain the eruption phenomena that created them. Portions of these deposits have provided singularly useful building materials, and ancient dwellings were actually carved into pyroclastic deposits on several continents. Today, young deposits provide evidence for underlying geothermal reservoirs, which may prove to be valuable resources. Some rare elements with commercial and strategic value, such as lithium, are made recoverable through large-scale pyroclastic eruptions and subsequent weathering processes. Uranium and thorium, as well as lithium, are concentrated at the surface in this way. On the other end of the nuclear fuel cycle, older pyroclastic deposits have many properties that suggest their use for the storage of radioactive wastes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 67:5

TITLE: Radon, health spas, and geothermal energy
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; THERMAL WATERS; RADON; HEALTH HAZARDS; DOSE-RESPONSE RELATIONSHIPS; HEALTH SERVICES; IONIZING RADIATIONS; LOW DOSE IRRADIATION; PUBLIC HEALTH; ELEMENTS; HAZARDS; IRRADIATION; NONMETALS; RADIATIONS; RARE GASES; RESOURCES; SOCIAL SERVICES; 290600* - Energy Planning & Policy- Nuclear Energy; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 520300 - Environment, Aquatic- Radioactive Materials Monitoring & Transport- (1989); 150100 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: For some years there has been concern in many countries about the exposure to populations from various sources of ionizing radiation. One source that has received a lot of attention is radon. The concern with radon extends to a number of situations. The radon sources are radium in soil, in bed-rock, in building materials, and in radon-rich water. While radon and its daughter products emit alpha, beta, and gamma radiation on decay, and therefore an identified health hazard, health spas extol the salubrious effects of radon-rich waters. There is almost no contact nor exchange of views between the medical establishment connected with the health spa industry and those medical researchers connected with the uranium mining industry or with public health agencies. The health spa regions are, of course, potential sites for geothermal development; but, use for medical purposes prevents such development.
RELATION: Journal Name: Important for the Future; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:4

TITLE: Aqueous solubility of methane at elevated pressures and temperatures
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 03 NATURAL GAS; METHANE; SOLUBILITY; WATER; SOLVENT PROPERTIES; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GULF COAST; HIGH PRESSURE; HIGH TEMPERATURE; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKANES; DISPERSIONS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; USA; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions; 360603 - Materials- Properties; 033000 - Natural Gas- Properties & Composition
DESCRIPTION: The solubility of methane is reported in distilled water from 150/sup 0/ to 350/sup 0/C and from 100 to 28,600 psi (689.5 to 197,197 kPa). Methane solubility greatly increases with increasing temperature above 250/sup 0/C to maximum values of over 800 standard cu ft (22.66 cm m) of methane per barrel of water at 354/sup 0/C and 28,600 psi (197,197 kPa). These high methane solubilities suggest that dissolved methane in the pore waers of sediments buried at 20,000 ft (6.10 km) and deeper in the Gulf Coast and other sedimentary basins could be a significant energy resource. These solubilities are also consistent with the concept of primary migration of natural gas and crude oil by molecular solution from the deep sediments of petroleum basins.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:9
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: High temperature electronics for geothermal energy
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; WELL LOGGING EQUIPMENT; CONVERSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; EQUIPMENT; WELLS; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware
DESCRIPTION: Recent estimates indicate that geothermal energy sources could produce over 10 GW of electric power in the USA by 1990. Once a system is in operation, engineers periodically need accurate and timely downhole information from each well in order to obtain optimum production. Instrumentation for geothermal borehole measurements is being expanded beyond today's limited capabilities. Prototypical logging tools have been successfully field-tested to 275 C a high-resolution quartz pressure transducer and a gallium phosphide diode have been successfully tested. Near-term goals of current programs are to develop instrumentation for use at 275 in pressures up to 48.3 MPa (7000 psi).
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Circuits Syst. Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1

TITLE: Seismic array noise studies at Roosevelt Hot Springs, Utah geothermal area
AUTHORS: Douze, E J; Laster, S J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ROOSEVELT HOT SPRINGS; SEISMIC NOISE; RAYLEIGH WAVES; SEISMIC P WAVES; SEISMOGRAPHS; UTAH; KGRA; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SEISMIC ARRAYS; SEISMIC DETECTORS; SEISMIC SURFACE WAVES; SEISMIC WAVES; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: As part of a study of a geothermal steam field at Roosevelt Hot Springs in Utah, the background seismic noise was investigated using seismometer arrays. Roosevelt Hot Springs is located on the Wasatch front in southern Utah, an area characterized by Tertiary intrusions. Arrays of vertical seismometers with spacings of 50 to 100 m were installed at selected locations. The data from three arrays were studied in detail; one was located directly above the geothermal reservoir, one was in the valley to the west, and one was in the Mineral Mountains to the east of the reservoir. The principle analysis technique consisted of computing frequency-wavenumber spectra of the noise in the frequency range from 0.5 to 10 Hz. For frequencies less than 1.0 Hz, the arrays were too small for adequate resolution, and at frequencies higher than 10.0 Hz, the noise showed no spatial organization. The theoretical response of seismometer arrays to waves arriving from numerous directions, such as would be the case directly above a geothermal reservoir, is developed to allow comparison with the experimental results. During times of cultural activity (mainly road traffic and trains in the valley), the noise was highly variable in amplitude and consisted almost exclusively of Rayleigh waves from the cultural sources. At quiet times, the noise field was more complex. For the arrays at the reservoir and in the valley, the results of frequency-wavenumber computations indicate that the noise consists of isotropic Rayleigh waves. No waves were detected that could be related to the geothermal reservoir. The array in the Mineral Mountains, farther away from the cultural noise sources, showed a completely different noise field. The noise consisted of high-velocity P-waves from a source to the east of the known geothermal area.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:9

TITLE: Developments in West Coast area in 1978
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; EXPLORATORY WELLS; NATURAL GAS FIELDS; OIL FIELDS; IMPERIAL VALLEY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; DRILLING; ELECTRIC POWER; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; OREGON; RESERVES; WASHINGTON; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 020200* - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 030200 - Natural Gas- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 150801 - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: New-field discoveries in the West Coast area were down in 1978 from the previous year, although the total exploratory footage drilled was significantly higher and the total number of successful exploratory wells in California was up 12% from 1977. One new oil field and 6 new gas field discoveries were reported in California. None of these discoveries appear to be of major size and 1 gas field discovery was subsequently abandoned. Mobil commenced drilling a deep test in Oregon in 1978 on their large land block in the Willamette Valley. The well has subsequently been abandoned. No drilling activity was reported in Washington. Development drilling in California, although down from 1977, continued at an active pace and is related largely to steam-flood projects. Production of oil outstripped additions to reserves by 164 million bbl in 1978. Geothermal development drilling continued at The Geysers and in the Imperial Valley. The geothermal discovery well by McCulloch of the South Brawley field in the Imperial Valley is the deepest geothermal well drilled in California. This well may open a broad new area for deep fracture production. The first Imperial Valley geothermal power plant will begin generating electricity this year and 6 more plants are in various stages of design and construction throughout the valley. The Geysers capacity is expected to increase to 1238 MW by the end of 1982. 5 figures, 3 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: Chevron USA Inc., San Francisco, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:8
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Natural convection in a multi layered geothermal reservoir
AUTHORS: Rana, R; Horne, R N; Cheng, P
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; RESERVOIR ROCK; NATURAL CONVECTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; FINITE DIFFERENCE METHOD; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LAYERS; PERMEABILITY; TRANSIENTS; CONVECTION; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; ITERATIVE METHODS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ROCKS; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: The effect of layered structure of rock formation on free convection in a geothermal reservoir is investigated in this work. The model examined is that of a rectangular reservoir comprised of three horizontal permeable layers with different permeabilities. The reservoir is considered to be bounded by impermeable surfaces on the sides and at the bottom. The upper boundary of the aquifer is permeable, which permits the recharge and discharge of water to and from the aquifer. A transient two-dimensional convective flow is developed when the impermeable boundaries are raised suddenly to high temperatures. The governing nonlinear partial differential equations with appropriate boundary and initial conditions are solved numerically by finite difference methods. Application of the direct method for solving Poisson's equation for stream function made it possible to carry out the solution for a much longer time than possible with iterative techniques. Numerical results are obtained for various parameters and configurations of the geothermal reservoir. The influence of a less permeable middle layer on the flow and heat transfer characteristics in the aquifer is discussed. The computed vertical temperature profiles are similar in shape to the complex temperature profiles observed at the HGP-A well.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Mechanical Engineering University of Hawall, Honolulu, Hawaii 96822
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Heat Transfer; (United States); Journal Volume: 101:3

TITLE: United States of America v. Union Oil Company of California, et al. Appeal from the United States District Court for the Northern District of California
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; LEGAL ASPECTS; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; LAWSUITS; MINERAL RIGHTS; OWNERSHIP; PATENTS; PROPERTY RIGHTS; DOCUMENT TYPES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RESOURCES; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: This is a quiet title action brought by the Attorney General of the United States pursuant to section 21(b) of the Geothermal Steam Act of 1970, to determine whether the mineral reservation in patents issued under the Stock-Raising Homestead Act of 1916, reserved to the United States geothermal resources underlying the patented lands. The district court held that it did not. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed and remanded.

TITLE: Vertical groundwater movement correction for heat flow
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GROUND WATER; CONVECTION; NEW MEXICO; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HEAT FLOW; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; WATER; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: In the presence of forced convection, there exists an energy flux crhoVT, because of mass-transported heat energy. By plotting temperature gradient versus temperature the significance of convective heat transfer can be determined. Such a plot is useful even when the flow system is not one-dimensional or vertical. As an example of convective heat transfer, a temperature log from the Rio Puerco area of New Mexico shows that downward groundwater movement of 4.7 x 10/sup -7/ cm/s over a 77-m interval can reduce the observed geothermal gradient and heat flow by a factor of 2 from 4.1 to 2.0 HFU (1 HFU = 1 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/ s/sup -1/). Such strong perturbations of heat flow by groundwater indicate the need for deep heat flow measurements to obtain a geothermal heat flux undisturbed by near-surface groundwater. By considering the convective flux one can use the total energy balance at the bounderies of aquifers and a semiconfining medium to obtain information about groundwater seepage within the semiconfining layer.
RESEARCH_ORG: New Mexico Bureau of Mines and Mineral Resources, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, Socorro, N. M. 87801
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B7

TITLE: Heat flow in the central Gulf of California
AUTHORS: Lawver, L A; Williams, D L
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; GULF OF CALIFORNIA; HEAT FLOW; SEA-FLOOR SPREADING; EARTH CRUST; HEAT LOSSES; MAGMA; SEDIMENTS; ENERGY LOSSES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; LOSSES; PACIFIC OCEAN; ROCKS; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 580500 - Oceanography- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: One hundred and five new heat flow measurements in the Gulf of California support the premise that conductive heat loss is not the only mode by which heat is lost from a sea floor spreading center, even in an area with thick sediment cover. Theoretical estimates suggest that the average heat flow in the Guaymas and Farallon basins should be at least 11 ..mu..cal/cm/sup 2/ s (HFU) (325 mW/m/sup 2/. Outside a 30-km-wide zone centered on the central troughs, the heat flow values measured are reasonably uniform but average only 4.3 +- 0.2 HFU (180 +- 10mW/m/sup 2/. Although the high sedimentation rate may depress the measured heat flow, the effect probably does not exceed 15%. Some heat, particularly in the smaller basins, may be lost to the adjacent cooler continental blocks. The discrepancy between the measured and predicted heat losses, which is at least 30%, may be due to the discharge of thermal waters, through the thinner sediment cover in the central troughs or along active faults.
RESEARCH_ORG: Marine Physical Laboratory of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego La Jolla, Calfornia 92093
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B7

TITLE: Thermodynamic criteria for geothermal power plant
AUTHORS: Nishikawa, K; Yoshida, S; Mori, H; Yoshida, K; Mishima, S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMODYNAMICS; AVAILABILITY; ENERGY ACCOUNTING; ENERGY BALANCE; FLOW RATE; MASS TRANSFER; PERFORMANCE; THERMAL EFFICIENCY; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLES; ACCOUNTING; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY ANALYSIS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150801* - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: When considering the utilization factor of energy in a geothermal power plant, the heat balance and thermal efficiency which are conventionally applied to steam power plants are of less use. It is therefore proposed to adopt the availability accounting and effectiveness on the basis of the second law of thermodynamics. Some examples of energy- and availability-accounting are shown for existing geothermal power plants. The effectiveness is found to be very useful as a utiliztation factor for geothermal energy, and it is suggested that the availability accounting is usefully employed in conjunction with the conventional energy accounting in obtaining data to find measures for improvement of the performance of a geothermal power plant. In addition, with the aid of the effectiveness, comparison of the performances can be readily made among the different types of power plant, and the existing geothermal power plants are found to be as effective in utilization of energy as recent steam power plants.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dev. Jpn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:1

TITLE: Economic MInerals in Geothermal Waters
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; MINERAL RESOURCES; EVALUATION; GOLD; ELEMENTS; METALS; RESOURCES; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 150700* - Geothermal Energy- Products & By-Products
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal resources may carry minerals in water, sinters and precipitates, and in steam. The utilization of these minerals is hampered by a lack of interest on the part of geochemists, by institutional obstacles, and by incomplete data on the quantity and quality of the minerals. The potential of obtaining minerals from geothermal resources is discussed. Nearly all geothermal hot water fields carry gold; production of gold from these fields could be very large. The lifetime of these mineral sources, corresponding to that of the geothermal well, will usually exceed the normal life of a hard rock mine. The outlook for exploiting geothermal minerals is summarized. (12 references, 1 table)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:7

TITLE: System Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/-P/sub 2/O/sub 5/-H/sub 2/O at 200/sup 0/C
AUTHORS: Feng, S S; Rockett, T J
SUBJECT: 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; PHASE DIAGRAMS; POTASSIUM OXIDES; CEMENTS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HYDRATES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; BUILDING MATERIALS; CHALCOGENIDES; DIAGRAMS; MATERIALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; WELLS; 320202* - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization- Transportation- Railway; 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: The study of the system Al/sub 2/O/sub 3/-P/sub 2/O/sub 5/-H/sub 2/O was made as part of an effort to determine if aluminophospate cements can be used under geothermal conditions. The system is also of interest because of phosphate-bonded refractories, crystal growth of the piezoelectric, berlinite, and for its mineralogic significance.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Am. Ceram. Soc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 62:7-8

TITLE: Meteorology and energy
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FORECASTING; METEOROLOGY; CLIMATES; EARTH ATMOSPHERE; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY TRANSPORT; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NUCLEAR ENERGY; SOLAR ENERGY; WEATHER; CONVERSION; ENERGY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 500000* - Environment, Atmospheric- (-1989); 140000 - Solar Energy; 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 130200 - Hydro Energy- Site Geology & Meteorology
DESCRIPTION: In the consideration of the meteorological aspects of energy problems, the latter is divided into three main groups: energy production, energy transport and exploration, and new energy resources. Increased energy production will have an impact on the environment. Although at present there is insufficient information for precise forecasts, meteorologists and hydrologists will be able to make reasonable assumptions for the future. Human use of energy is strongly influenced by variations of weather. Such systems as electric power transmission networks, shipping of hydrocarbons by sea, and pipelines for the transportation of large quantities of oil and gas, are all particularly sensitive to weather and climate. The meteorologist provides basic data on weather and climate to facilitate energy exploration. The new energy resources addressed in this article are solar, wind, geothermal, and nuclear. The World Meteorological Organization's Executive Committee established a set of priorities in dealing with energy problems. This paper also briefly examines the burden imposed on global energy resources.
RELATION: Journal Name: EDIS; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:4

TITLE: Convection in a porous medium as a singular perturbation problem
SUBJECT: 25 ENERGY STORAGE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; AQUIFERS; NATURAL CONVECTION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; SENSIBLE HEAT STORAGE; WATER; CONVECTION; ENERGY STORAGE; FLUIDS; HEAT STORAGE; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; STORAGE; 250600* - Energy Storage- Thermal; 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Some preliminary results, based on the second-order approximations for the problems of natural convection in a porous medium adjacent to a vertical or a horizontal heated surface with power law variations of wall temperature, are reported. For the special case of an isothermal plate, it is found that the second-order corrections to the surface heat flux vanish identically. Thus, the relationships between the Nusselt number (Nu/sub x/) and the Rayleigh number (Ra/sub x/) for the case of an isothermal plate, as obtained from the boundary layer approximations (i.e., the first-order approximations), are actually accurate to 0(epsilon/sub x//sup 2/) where epsilon/sub x/ = (Ra/sub x/)/sup -1/2/ for the case of a vertical plate and epsilon/sub x/ = (Ra/sub x/)/sup -1/3/ for the case of a horizontal plate.
RELATION: Journal Name: Lett. Heat Mass Transfer; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:4

TITLE: One-dimensional inversion of natural source magnetotelluric observations
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGNETOTELLURIC SURVEYS; DATA PROCESSING; ALGORITHMS; EARTH CRUST; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; ITERATIVE METHODS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MATHEMATICAL LOGIC; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; PROCESSING; USA; 580203* - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989); 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Natural source magnetotelluric (MT) data are inverted to find a subsurface resistivity which is isotropic and a continuous function of depth. The inversion consists of two parts. In the first, the concern is to construct a resistivity structure whose responses are acceptably close to the observations, that is, the measured amplitudes and/or phases. This construction proceeds iteratively and is realized through an automated algorithm which is characterized by numerical stability and rapid convergence. In the second part, the degree of nonuniqueness inherent in the problem is investigated. Only spatial averages of the resistivity are considered because all models linearly close to the constructed model have the same average resistivity. The predictions of this statement are examined quantitatively in an example where the averages from five different models which reproduce the observations are compared. In an example using data from a moderately complex layered model, the amplitudes and phases are inverted jointly and separately, and their resolution is compared. Finally, data from the Snake River Plain-Yellowstone area are inverted, and the results compared with those from a parametric inversion. 22 figures, 3 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:7

TITLE: Thermodynamics of electrolytes. 12. Dielectric properties of water and Debye--Hueckel parameters to 350/sup 0/C and 1 kbar
AUTHORS: Bradley, D J; Pitzer, K S
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ELECTROLYTES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; WATER; DIELECTRIC PROPERTIES; COMPRESSIBILITY; ENTHALPY; EXPANSION; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HIGH PRESSURE; HIGH TEMPERATURE; REACTION KINETICS; SPECIFIC HEAT; TABLES; THERMODYNAMIC ACTIVITY; VOLUME; DATA; DATA FORMS; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; KINETICS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; NUMERICAL DATA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: In preparation for work with aqueous electrolytes at above saturation pressures and at temperatures to 350/sup 0/C, an equation was developed for the representation of the dielectric constant of water over this range. With this equation and an equation of state for water, the Debye--Hueckel limiting law parameters for osmotic and activity coefficients, enthalpies, heat capacities, volumes, compressibilities, and expansibilities were calculated and are presented. 5 figures, 4 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Phys. Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 83:12

TITLE: Tuscaloosa geothermal-geopressure resource of south Louisiana
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 03 NATURAL GAS; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; RESOURCES; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; LOUISIANA; ENERGY SOURCES; METHANE; PERMEABILITY; PETROLEUM; POROSITY; SAND; WATER; ALKANES; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 030100 - Natural Gas- Reserves- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Tuscaloosa Trend contains in excess of 40 cubic miles of geopressured sands which have most of the qualities needed for a geopressured-geothermal resource. Permeability is the limiting factor. The 40 cubic miles calculates to 529 billion cubic feet of pore volume based on 9% porosity. If the sands are totally saturated, then at least 94 billion barrels of water are present. If each barrel contains 40 cubic feet of dissolved methane, then the resource could be expected to contain 3.76 trillion cubic feet of dissolved methane in place for the presently defined Tuscaloosa Fairway; 1.22 trillion cubic feet or 32.5% are located in the Solitude Point Prospect. Recent information indicates that the next two fault blocks north of the Solitude Point Prospect are geopressured, with a gradient of approximately 0.6. The permeabilities and porosities are excellent and far exceed those accepted as minimal for a geothermal resource. The addition of the Tuscaloosa Trend amplifies the previous assessment of the geothermal-geopressured resource in South Louisiana. The need for a test well and its evaluation is critical to the continued understanding and development of the potential energy source. With the potential for methane development alone, we simply must make every effort to integrate this energy source into the future supplies of this nation. (6 figures) (DP)
RESEARCH_ORG: Office of Conservation, Baton Rouge, LA
RELATION: Journal Name: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:1

TITLE: Utilizing geothermal resources below 150 C (300 F)
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; IDAHO NATIONAL ENGINEERING LABORATORY; USES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; RESOURCES; US DOE; US ERDA; US ORGANIZATIONS; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: Except for the steam-dominated geothermal field at Geysers, California, the use of geothermal energy in the US has been minimal. Because of preoccupation with searching for the high temperature resources (above 350 F), for generating electricity, the greatest potential for geothermal energy, that at temperatures below 150 C (300 F) have largely been ignored. These waters are much more abundant than the higher temperature ones, and, therefore, represent 10 or more times as much useable energy than the total of the energy in all the high temperature waters. The problems have, in part, been technological - how to economically convert these lower temperature geothermal waters to useful energy - and in part institutional. This paper describes the last five years' program, largely centered at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, to make it more practical and economical to harness the lower temperture geothermal resources. 5 references, 5 figures, 2 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Resour. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 101:2; Conference: Energy resources technology and exhibition, Houston, TX, 5 Nov 1978

TITLE: Electrical production from modeate-temperature geothermal brines
AUTHORS: Jacobs, H R; Boehm, R F
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; 2-METHYLPROPANE; BOTTOMING CYCLES; BRINES; DIRECT CONTACT HEAT EXCHANGERS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; PENTANE; POWER GENERATION; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; THERMODYNAMICS; ALKANES; CONVERSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FLUIDS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; HYDROCARBONS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLES; 150802* - Geothermal Power Plants- Power Plant Systems & Components
DESCRIPTION: Direct contact binary cycles may be used to develop electrical power from moderate temperature geothermal brines. For a simple Rankine cycle using direct contact heat exchangers isobutane is preferred as a working fluid for brines at temperatures greater than 138/sup 0/C. Pentane appears more attractive at lower temperatures. For all moderate temperature applications, however, the use of bottoming cycles, multi-turbine, multi-fluid cycles, yields significantly better performance. 12 references, 11 figures, 3 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Resour. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 101:2

TITLE: Galapagos hydrothermal mounds: stratigraphy and chemistry revealed by deep-sea drilling
AUTHORS: Natland, J H; Rosendahl, B; Hekinian, R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SEA BED; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; LITHOLOGY; MANGANESE; PACIFIC OCEAN; RIFT ZONES; STRATIGRAPHY; ELEMENTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; METALS; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 150202* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Galapagos mounds sea-floor hydrothermal system is at least 300,000 years old and once produced manganese-poor sediments, which nearly blanketed the area of the present mounds field. Present-day mound deposits are limited manganese-rich exposures, suggesting that the system has changed from rock- to water-dominated and has diminished in intensity with time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 204

TITLE: Distribution of heat flow and radioactive heat generation in northern Mexico
AUTHORS: Smith, D L; Nuckels, III, C E; Jones, R L; Cook, G A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MEXICO; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; HEAT FLOW; NATURAL RADIOACTIVITY; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; EXPLORATION; LATIN AMERICA; NORTH AMERICA; RADIOACTIVITY; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Twenty-five new heat flow measurements from northern Mexico range from 0.6 HFU (1 HFU = 1 ..mu..cal/cm/sup 2/s = 41.8 mW/m/sup 2/) at Los Plomosas, Chihuahua, to 4.2 HFU about 30 km east of Mazatlan, Sinaloa. The new values, in conjunction with previous data, confirm the Baja peninsula as an area of low to normal heat flow and demonstrate an irregular decrease of heat flow eastward from the Gulf of California across the Sierra Madre Occidental and a separate pattern of decreasing heat flow eastward from the Central Plateau across the Sierra Madre Oriental. An area of high heat flow immediately east of the Gulf of California is identified and is tentatively related to the spreading ridges in the gulf. Abundances of the radioactive-heat-generating elements uranium, thorium, and potassium increase from Baja California to the eastern border of the Sierra Madre Occidental, abruptly decrease within the Central Plateau, and then increase again eastward through the Sierra Madre Oriental. Although a general positive correlation between heat flow and radioactive heat generation is observed, adherance to the expected linear patterns cannot be demonstrated. This lack of linearity prohibits the definition of separate thermal provinces in northern Mexico and suggests the assignment of the Sierra Madre Occidental as a southerly extension of the Basin and Range thermal province that is modified by sea floor spreading in the Gulf of California. Heat flow measurements in the states of Chihuahua, Durango, and Zacatecas are similar to those associated with the Rio Grande Rift thermal anomaly in New Mexico, but an indentification of a continuous extension of the rift thermal conditions into northern Mexico cannot be made.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geology, University of Florida, Gainesville, Florida 32611
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B5

TITLE: Abnormal p-wave delays in The Geysers: Clear Lake Geothermal Area, California
AUTHORS: Iyer, H M; Oppenheimer, D H; Hitchcock, T
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; SEISMIC P WAVES; SEISMIC SURVEYS; CALIFORNIA; FRACTURED RESERVOIRS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MAGMA SYSTEMS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; RESERVOIR ROCK; ROCKS; SEISMIC WAVES; SURVEYS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Large teleseismic delays, exceeding 1 second, are found near Mount Hannah in the Clear Lake volcanic field and in the steam-production area at The Geysers. The delays are superimposed on a general delay field of about 0.5 second extending over the volcanic rocks and the steam reservoir. It is postulated that a magma chamber under the surface volcanic rocks with a core of severely molten rock beneath Mount Hannah and a highly fractured steam reservoir probably underlain by partially molten rock at The Geysers are responsible for the observed delays. Both zones extend to depths of 20 kilometers or more.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 204

SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CHEMICAL REACTORS; DESIGN; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; EQUIPMENT; GOLD; MINERALS; ROCKS; TITANIUM; DISPERSIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; METALS; MIXTURES; SOLUTIONS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory

This cell, used in conjunction with a commercially available pressure vessel and noncontaminating sampling valve block, is effective in hydrothermal experimental investigations.

SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ELECTRODES; PERFORMANCE; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; WATER CHEMISTRY; SILVER; SILVER CHLORIDES; SURFACE COATING; EQUIPMENT; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; ZIRCONIUM OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DEPOSITION; ELEMENTS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; METALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SILVER COMPOUNDS; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; WELLS; ZIRCONIUM COMPOUNDS; 360604* - Materials- Corrosion, Erosion, & Degradation; 150904 - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware

A ZrO/sub 2/ electrode body acting as a diffusion barrier has been incorporated which permits thermodynamic operation at high temperatures in environments containing significant quantities of H/sub 2/ and H/sub 2/S.
