TITLE: Steam-water counterflow in porous media
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 42 ENGINEERING; MULTIPHASE FLOW; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; VAPOR-DOMINATED SYSTEMS; WATER; PERMEABILITY; POROSITY; STEAM; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; FLUID FLOW; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions; 420400 - Engineering- Heat Transfer & Fluid Flow; 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: A one-dimensional model of a counterflowing steam-water mixture above quiescent water in a porous medium is developed to study two-phase flow processes in vapor-dominated geothermal systems. Only if the temperature gradient in the underlying water lies between specified limits is it possible for a counterflowing steam-water mixture to overlie the water. In general, there is an abrupt jump in the steam fraction and the temperature gradient at the interface between the two-phase region depend on the magnitude of the temperature gradient in the water I' the temperature at the interface between the water and the steam-water mixture T/sub d/, and the permeability to thermal conductivity ratio K k; these dependences are studied quantitatively. For small K/k, the thickness of the two-phase region is essentially independent of K/k, whereas for large K/k the thickness of the region increases dramatically with K/k. For fixed K/k and I'. Normally, condensation of rising steam occurs in the two-phase region resulting in a steam flow which decreases with proximity to the surface and a water flow which increases with depth. However, downward flowing water can boil and add steam to the upflow.
RESEARCH_ORG: Space Sciences Laboratory, The Ivan A. Getting Laboratories, The Aerospace Corporation Los Angeles, California 90009
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B4

TITLE: Federal land management policy and the drive to develop an alternate energy source, geothermal energy: shall the twain ever meet
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; LEGISLATION; PUBLIC LANDS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENERGY POLICY; LAND USE; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; EXPLORATION; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 290400 - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 510500 - Environment, Terrestrial- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Present land-use planning for Federal lands is not compatible with a national policy of achieving energy independence if exploration and development must wait for an inventory and classification to be made of all Federal lands. The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (FLPMA) is examined to see what its impact will be on onshore energy development, particularly from geothermal resources. It is concluded that the Bureau of Land Management's budget and personnel levels must be upgraded and potential geothermal sites should be given high priority in the inventory and evaluation process.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nat. Resour. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2

TITLE: Electricity from hot dry rock geothermal energy: technical and economic issues
AUTHORS: Bivins, R L; Cummings, R G; Morris, G E; Tester, J W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; COMPUTERIZED SIMULATION; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; ECONOMICS; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; CONSTRAINTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; FLUID FLOW; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; OPTIMIZATION; POWER GENERATION; VARIATIONS; WELL DRILLING; CONVERSION; DRILLING; ENERGY CONVERSION; POWER PLANTS; SIMULATION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants; 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Extraction of energy from hot dry rock would make available a nearly unlimited energy source. Some of the technical problems and possible economic tradeoffs involved in a power generating system are examined and possible solutions proposed. An intertemporal optimization computer model of electricity production from a hot dry rock geothermal source has been constructed. The effects of reservoir degradation, variable fluid flow rate, and drilling operations are examined to determine optimal strategies for reservoir management and necessary conditions for economic feasibility. 33 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:4

TITLE: Geothermal energy: problems and shortcomings of classification of a unique resource - a look at problems with water law, with particular emphasis on New Mexico
AUTHORS: Silver, R M; Comeau, S P
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LEGAL ASPECTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; HEAT TRANSFER; MINERAL RESOURCES; NEW MEXICO; OWNERSHIP; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; WATER RESOURCES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY TRANSFER; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The case of US vs Union Oil may not make the classification of geothermal resources any easier because courts consistently ignore the heat, water, and mineral factors associated with geothermal energy development. State statutes such as those of New Mexico ameliorate the situation somewhat by defining and regulating production of the resource, but they don't address water treatment within a geothermal formation. Each element should be dealt with explicitly in order to clarify ownership of and jurisdiction over the resource and to avoid confusion and litigation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nat. Resour. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:2

TITLE: Viscosity of aqueous KCl solutions in the temperature range 25 to 150/sup 0/C and the pressure range 0 to 30 MPa
AUTHORS: Grimes, C E; Kestin, J; Ezzat Khalifa, H
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; DENSITY; VISCOSITY; ACCURACY; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; EXPERIMENTAL DATA; HIGH PRESSURE; HIGH TEMPERATURE; ISOLATED VALUES; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; QUANTITY RATIO; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DATA; DATA FORMS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; MIXTURES; NUMERICAL DATA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: New experimental data on the viscosity of aqueous KCl solutions are reported. The data cover the temperature range 25 to 150/sup 0/C, the pressure range 0 to 30 MPa, and the concentration range 0 to 4.4 m. The experimental values have an estimated accuracy of +-1% over the entire range of pressure, temperature, and concentration. The viscosity has been correlated as a function of pressure, temperature, and concentration. The paper also provides a correlation for the density of KCl solutions in terms of pressure, temperature, and concentration. 15 figures, 10 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Eng. Data; (United States); Journal Volume: 24:2

TITLE: Submarine thermal springs on the Galapagos rift
AUTHORS: Corliss, J B; Dymond, J; Gordon, L I; Edmond, J M; von Herzen, R P; Ballard, R D; Green, K; Williams, D; Bainbridge, A; Crane, K; van Andel, T H
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OCEANIC CRUST; THERMAL SPRINGS; RIFT ZONES; DIVING OPERATIONS; GEOCHEMISTRY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HEAT FLOW; HEAT TRANSFER; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; ROCKS; SEAWATER; UNDERWATER OPERATIONS; CHEMISTRY; EARTH CRUST; ENERGY TRANSFER; FLUIDS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; WATER; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: The submarine hydrothermal activity on and near the Galapagos Rift has been explored with the aid of the deep submersible Alvin. Analyses of water samples from hydrothermal vents reveal that hydrothermal activity provides significant or dominant sources and sinks for several components of seawater; studies of conductive and convective heat transfer suggest that two-thirds of the heat lost from new oceanic lithosphere at the Galapagos Rift in the first million years may be vented from thermal springs, predominantly along the axial ridge within the rift valley. The vent areas are populated by animal communities. They appear to utilize chemosynthesis by sulfur-oxidizing bacteria to derive their entire energy supply from reactions between the seawater and the rocks at high temperatures, rather than photosynthesis.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 203:4385

TITLE: Thermal conductivity of crystalline rocks associated with energy extraction from hot dry rock geothermal systems
AUTHORS: Sibbitt, W L; Dodson, J G; Tester, J W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HEAT FLOW; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; MOISTURE; ROCKS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; WELLS; 152002* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: Because the lifetime of and heat extraction rate from a hot dry rock (HDR) geothermal reservoir can be substantially controlled by the in situ rock thermal conductivity, information concerning the dependence of thermal conductivity on moisture content and temperature is important for proper design and management of the reservoir. Results of thermal conductivity measurements are given for 14 drill core rock samples taken from two exploratory HDR geothermal wellbores (maximum depth of 2929 m (9608 ft) drilled into Precambrian granitic rock in the Jemez Mountains of northern New Mexico. These samples have been petrographically characterized and in general represent fresh competent Precambrian material of deep origin. Thermal conductivities, modal analyses, and densities are given for all core samples studied under dry and wet ('water-saturated') conditions. A cut bar thermal conductivity comparator and a transient needle probe were used for the determinations with fused quartz and Pyroceram 9606 as the stardards. The maximum temperature range of the measurements was from the ice point to 250/sup 0/C. The measurements on wet rock were limited to the temperature range below room temperature. Conductivity values of the dense core rock samples were generally within the range from 2 to 2.9 W/mK at 200/sup 0/C. Excellent agreement was achieved between these measurements of thermal conductivity and those obtained by in situ measurements run in the HDR wellbores. By using samples of sufficient thickness to provide a statistically representative heat flow path, no difference between conductivity values and their temperature coefficients for orthogonal directions was observed. This isotropic behavior was even found for highly foliated gneissic specimens. Estimates of thermal conductivity based on a dispersion and/or mixture analysis utilizing pure minerallic phase conductivities and detailed modal analyses usually agreed to within 9% of the experimental values.
RESEARCH_ORG: Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, University of California, Los Alamos, New Mexico 87545
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 84:B3

TITLE: Minimum spacing of thermally induced cracks in brittle solids
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; THERMAL STRESSES; CRACKS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; THERMOELASTICITY; ELASTICITY; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; STRESSES; TENSILE PROPERTIES; 152002* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: When the temperature at the free surface of a linearly elastic brittle half-plane, which is initially uniform throughout the solid, is suddenly reduced by a large amount and then kept constant thereafter, a thermal boundary layer whose thickness increases with time, forms close to the free surface. Because of the consequent thermal contraction, edge cracks may form within the thermal boundary layer. For a system of equally spaced straight-edge cracks, growing collinearly with increasing thickness of the thermal boundary layer, the average minimum crack spacing is estimated on the basis of: (a) energy consideration; (b) stress consideration; and (c) consideration of stability of the growth of interacting cracks. It is shown that for a given temperature profile, one can develop a general stability chart which, in particular, gives a complete growth regime of the interacting cracks (no crack branching is included).
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Resour. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 101:1

TITLE: Pitting corrosion and scaling of carbon steels in geothermal brine
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CARBON STEELS; PITTING CORROSION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; BRINES; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; NOZZLES; PIPES; ALLOYS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CORROSION; FLUIDS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; STEELS; 360105* - Metals & Alloys- Corrosion & Erosion; 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: To obtain an understanding of pitting corrosion in geothermal brines, an evaluation was made of failures in a surface pipeline and wellhead casing exposed to hypersaline brine in the Salton Sea Geothermal Field. Uniform corrosion, pitting corrosion, and various forms of highly localized, selective attacks were observed. The corrosion product (Fe/sub 3/O/sub 4/) was covered with a transition zone of corrosion product mixed with scale that graded into a scale-rich deposit. The scales, deposited from brine, consisted of heavy metal sulfides dispersed in an Fe-rich, amorphous silicate matrix. The possible roles of the outer scale deposit, the intermediate transition zone, and the inner corrosion product on either abetting or deterring corrosion are discussed. It is proposed that cracks, resulting from thermal stresses induced during periods of intermittent operation, form in the scale, permitting the infusion of oxygen during shutdown intervals. This contributes to localized accelerated pitting, resulting in perforation of the pipe and casing walls. The importance of environmental (pH, E/sub H/, composition, heterogeneity) and material (composition, casting, thermomechanical history, microstructure, surface condition) variables that influence the formation of different pit morphologies is discussed and compared with related observations cited in the literature.
RELATION: Journal Name: Corrosion; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:3

TITLE: Effect of a heat-conducting well casing on temperature distribution in an observation well
AUTHORS: Closmann, P J; Jones, E R; Vogel, E A
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; WELL CASINGS; OIL WELLS; HEAT FLOW; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; WELLS; 020300* - Petroleum- Drilling & Production; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware
DESCRIPTION: The effect of heat conduction on temperature along the wall of a well casing has been determined by solution of the equations of heat conduction. The casing was assumed to pass vertically through a planar heat source of constant temperature. The casing and formation were assumed to be in perfect thermal contact. Numerical results were obtained for two sizes of steel casing and one size of aluminum casing. At any given distance from the heat source, the casing temperature differs most at early times from the formation temperature computed in the absence of casing. This difference decreases rapidly with time. Furthermore, the maximum difference occurs at greater distances from the heat source as time increases. In general, after about three months of heating, errors in measured temperatures due to conduction along the casing wall are negligible. 9 references, 7 figures.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Energy Resour. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 101:1

TITLE: Geothermal energy development in the Soviet Union

TITLE: Improved directional drilling will expand use
AUTHORS: Maurer, W C; McDonald, W J; Rehm, W A
SUBJECT: 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 03 NATURAL GAS; 04 OIL SHALES AND TAR SANDS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; DIRECTIONAL DRILLING; DRILLING EQUIPMENT; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; COAL GASIFICATION; COAL SEAMS; DEGASSING; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; IN-SITU GASIFICATION; IN-SITU RETORTING; MOTORS; MWD SYSTEMS; OIL SHALES; BITUMINOUS MATERIALS; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; COAL DEPOSITS; DECOMPOSITION; DRILLING; ENERGY SOURCES; EQUIPMENT; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; GASIFICATION; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; IN-SITU PROCESSING; MATERIALS; MINERAL RESOURCES; PROCESSING; RESOURCES; RETORTING; THERMOCHEMICAL PROCESSES; WELLS; 010404* - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Gasification; 030900 - Natural Gas- Artificial Stimulation, Plowshare- (-1989); 040401 - Oil Shales & Tar Sands- In Situ Methods, True & Modified; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware; 294000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Fossil Fuels; 290500 - Energy Planning & Policy- Research, Development, Demonstration, & Commercialization
DESCRIPTION: Directional drilling is important in present energy recovery technology and will become increasingly so in the future. Limitations of directional drilling and concepts for advanced systems both present and emerging energy technologies are detailed. To be technically and economically feasible methane drainage, in-situ retorting of oil shale, and underground gasification of coal will require directional drilling. Directional drilling is important in geothermal energy production to reduce costs and reduce environmental impacts. Even energy forms such as solar and nuclear are dependent on materials often found and recovered by methods involving directional drilling. Directional drilling is expected to increase significantly in the next decade. With the increase in emphasis on directional drilling will come new down hole systems. These will increase penetration rate, reduce downtime, and enhance safety. Measurement-while-drilling (MWD) systems which allow real-time monitoring of down-hole conditions are now becoming available. Improved down-hole motors hold promise of increased drilling effectiveness by increasing horsepower at the bit, improving bit hydraulics, and reducing drill-string wear. 26 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Oil Gas J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 77:9

TITLE: Summit thermal springs, Mount Shasta, California
AUTHORS: Wharton, Jr, R A; Vinyard, W C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOLOGY; THERMAL SPRINGS; EROSION; GLACIERS; MOUNTAINS; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WATER SPRINGS; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The geology of Mount Shasta, its erosion, glaciers, and physical and chemical characteristics of the summit thermal springs are described. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Calif. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 32:2

TITLE: East Mesa geothermal test site
AUTHORS: Fernelius, W A; Fulcher, M K
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; POWER GENERATION; WATER SUPPLY; COLORADO RIVER; DESALINATION; EAST MESA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; DEMINERALIZATION; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RESOURCES; RIVERS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The feasibility of using geothermal resources to increase the flow of the Colorado River and as a source of concurrent electrical energy is evaluated in the context of experiments conducted in Imperial Valley, Calif. The method of finding geothermal reservoirs, injection operations, and seismic and subsidence monitoring are described. One problem faced is the high salinity content of geothermal brines. Three types of desalting units were tested: a multistage flash unit, a vertical tube evaporator unit, and a high temperature electrodialysis unit. All three desalting systems have thus far been used successfully to desalt geothermal fluid, and the problems associated which each system have been identified, along with probable solutions. Productivity of geothermal reservoirs, injection capabilities, compatibility of fluids, environmental concerns, and the source of replacement fluid determine the economic feasibility of geothermal desalting. Tests to explore problems and to judge the possible use of concurrent power production in the desalting process are continuing. (5 diagrams, 2 photos, 5 references, 4 tables)
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Environ. Eng. Div., ASCE; (United States); Journal Volume: 105:1
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Environ. Eng. Div., ASCE; (United States)

TITLE: East Mesa Geothermal Test Site
AUTHORS: Fernelius, W A; Fulcher, M K
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; DESALINATION; DESALINATION PLANTS; EAST MESA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; DEPOSITION; DIRECT CONTACT HEAT EXCHANGERS; ELECTRODIALYSIS; EVAPORATORS; FLOW RATE; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GROUND SUBSIDENCE; REINJECTION; SEISMIC SURVEYS; SILICA; THERMAL POLLUTION; CHALCOGENIDES; DEMINERALIZATION; DIALYSIS; FLUIDS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SURVEYS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WELLS; 150000* - Geothermal Energy
DESCRIPTION: The activities of the Bureau of Reclamation at East Mesa (California) Test Site and the results of its geothermal desalting program are described. Data on location, geothermal characteristics, and results of the chemical analysis of East Mesa geothermal wells are presented. Investigations including direct contact heat exchanger experiments, and energy conversion systems are mentioned, as are the well interference tests using highly sensitive electronic pressure gauges (over 0.01 psi). Injection operations are discussed, and it is found that wellhead silica concentrations appear to be related to flow rate. A seismic monitoring system, and a subsidence monitoring system, are outlined. The Multistage Flash (MSF), Vertical Tube Evaporator (VTE), and High Temperature Electrodialysis (HTED) desalting systems are discussed in detail. It is concluded that the systems have shown the capability to desalt geothermal fluid, and problems associated with each have been identified together with probable solutions.
RELATION: Journal Name: American Society of Civil Engineers, Environmental; (United States); Journal Volume: 105
JOURNAL_NAME: American Society of Civil Engineers, Environmental; (United States)

TITLE: Mining earth's heat: hot dry rock geothermal energy
AUTHORS: Cummings, R G; Morris, G E; Tester, J W; Bivins, R L
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; COMMERCIALIZATION; ECONOMIC ANALYSIS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; ECONOMICS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 299001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Solar- (1989-); 150904 - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware
DESCRIPTION: Power generation from hot dry rock (HDR) resources appears to be commercially competitive in numerous areas of the U.S. based on analysis of economic and reservoir parameter values. More experimental and economic research is indicated before a definitive assessment can be made, but feasibility is promising in areas with temperature gradients in the 40-plus/sup 0/C per kilometer range and where competitive busbar costs are approximately three cents per kilowatt-hour. Competitiveness could vary with reservoir design, operating parameter values, as well as financial and regulatory criteria. High busbar costs could provide considerable incentive for HDR development. (Author, edited) 33 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Technol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 81:4

TITLE: Seismic refraction study of the Raft River geothermal area, Idaho
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; RAFT RIVER VALLEY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; SEISMIC SURVEYS; EXPLORATORY WELLS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; IDAHO; REFRACTION; SEDIMENTS; VOLCANIC REGIONS; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; USA; WELLS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The Raft River geothermal system in southeastern Idaho is a convective hot water system, presently being developed to demonstrate the production of electricity from low-temperature (approx. 150/sup 0/C) water. Interpretation of seismic refraction recordings in the area yielded compressional velocities from near the surface to the crystalline basement at a maximum depth of approximately 1600 m. The results show a complex sequence of sediments and volcanic flows overlying basement. Velocities in the sedimentary section vary laterally. Correlation with well data suggests that zones of higher velocities may correspond to zones where sediments are hydrothermally altered. Flowing hot wells occur near the boundary between inferred shallow altered and unaltered rocks. The basement surface does not appear to be displaced by large faults, although there is ample surface evidence of faulting. The deep circulation of hot water necessary for a convective system may be through many small faults and fractures. Fracturing is suggested on the basis of lateral velocity variations within the basement complex.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:2

TITLE: Use of water quality file WATSTORE in geothermal exploration: an example from the Imperial Valley, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IMPERIAL VALLEY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; WATER QUALITY; CALCIUM; DATA COMPILATION; GEOTHERMOMETRY; GROUND WATER; HEAT FLOW; KGRA; POTASSIUM; SILICA; SODIUM; ALKALI METALS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; CALIFORNIA; CHALCOGENIDES; DATA; ELEMENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; EXPLORATION; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; METALS; MINERALS; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL DATA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; USA; WATER; WESTERN REGION; 150300* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology; 150600 - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The US Geological Survey water quality file WATSTORE contains chemical analyses for several hundred thousand ground-water samples from the United States. Nearly 100,000 of these analyses are sufficiently complete to be of use in geothermal exploration. Through examination of about 500 analyses of samples from the Imperial Valley, California, supplemented by an additional 8000 analyses from adjacent parts of the Basin and Range province, normal ranges were established for the various chemical geothermal indicators and the criteria by which a geothermal water may be recognized. For the Imperial Valley, California, the following values are proposed as signifying potential geothermal water: silica geotemperature, > 100/sup 0/C; Na-K-Ca geotemperature, > 125/sup 0/C; fluoride, >2.5 ppM; in situ temperature, > 35/sup 0/C; heat flow, > 120 mW m/sup -2/. These criteria were used to scan WATSTORE for potential geothermal prospects in the Imperial Valley. This scan outlined at least ten major anomalous areas, including all but one of the six Known Geothermal Resource Areas (KGRAs). The rediscovery of the KGRAs underscores the potential value of WATSTORE as a rapid reconnaissance tool in geothermal exploration. Anomalous areas that are not KGRAs are located east and west of the Salton Sea (Hot Mineral Well and Holly Hot Well), near Coyote Wells, near Camp Dunlap, and east of Brawley. Smaller anomalies are present throughout the study area, particularly along the Brawley fault and the southern extension of the San Andreas fault zone.
RESEARCH_ORG: New Mexico State Univ., Las Cruces
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:2

TITLE: Onshore and offshore measurements of temperature gradients in the Salton Sea geothermal area, California
AUTHORS: Lee, T C; Cohen, L H
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SALTON SEA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; BOREHOLES; CALIFORNIA; HEAT FLOW; HYDROLOGY; SALTON SEA; SEDIMENTATION; SPECIFIC HEAT; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; THERMAL DIFFUSIVITY; CAVITIES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; IMPERIAL VALLEY; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: By removing the effect of the annual temperature cycle with an iterative least-squares method, geothermal gradients at 44 sites were determined from onshore and offshore temperature measurements at depths less than 16 and 2 m, respectively, around the southeastern end of the Salton Sea (water depth < 20 m). Onshore temperatures were measured at 1-m intervals in drill holes cased with 0.25-inch PVC pipes and offshore temperatures were obtained with a 2-m lance-like thermal probe (0.50-inch OD) which contains 7 equally spaced thermistor sensors. The gradients range from 0.02/sup 0/ to 1.7/sup 0/C/m and from 0.72/sup 0/ to 4.3/sup 0/C/m in the onshore and offshore areas, respectively. Heat fluxes, calculated from an assumed value of heat capacity, and in-situ determined thermal diffusivities and gradients, decrease away from a chain of four Quaternary volcanic domes, near the present shoreline. Superimposed on this general trend are several sites with high heat flux, reflecting local hydrological influence. Corrections for sedimentation, for presence of the lake, or for disturbance around the thermal probe may individually exceed 0.030/sup 0/C/m (normal geothermal gradient of the upper curst); however, the net effects cannot account for the disparity between the onshore and offshore data sets. Even if the offshore gradients are divided by a factor of 3 to make the two sets of data compatible, these new data (together with data from 22 onshore sites measured previously) indicate the offshore anomaly covers an area at least the size of the onshore anomaly, defined somewhat arbitrarily as an area with heat flux greater than 200 x 10/sup -3/ W/m/sup 2/.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 44:2

TITLE: Magnetic and chemical variations of Mesozoic diabase dikes from eastern North America: evidence for a hotspot in the Carolinas
AUTHORS: De Boer, J; Snider, F G
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NORTH CAROLINA; GEOLOGY; HOT SPOTS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; SOUTH CAROLINA; GEOCHEMISTRY; IRON; MINERALOGY; TITANIUM OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMISTRY; ELEMENTS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; METALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SOUTHEAST REGION; TITANIUM COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; USA; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Tholeiitic diabase dikes of Late Triassic and Early Jurassic age occur in swarms throughout the Appalachians. The intrusions exhibit regional variations in magnetic and chemical parameters. Aeromagnetic and ground-magnetic anomalies are highest over dikes in the Carolinas. High amplitude is due primarily to a stronger magnetization (the induced component dominates and is nearly constant within individual intrusions). Effects of host-rock magnetization, thermoremanence, and dike width, attitude, and orientation are insignificant. Chemically the Carolinas dikes are characterized by higher mean values for total iron and relatively low TiO/sub 2/ content. The magnetic and chemical patterns are reminiscent of those found for tholeiitic complexes over oceanic hotspots (Galapagos, Iceland), and suggest that the Carolinas may have been the site of such a feature in Late Triassic--Early Jurassic time. Crustal arching, rifting, and volcanism probably origniated in the Carolinas. Tectonic-volcanic activity gradually migrated northeast (and possibly, southwest) along the Appalachian axis with enlargement of the crustal bulge. In Jurassic time, spreading began farther east; the crustal stress configuration changed, and the tectonic pattern was dominated by the formation of new sets of tensional fractures and sinistral slip along pre-existing faults.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 90:2

TITLE: Gravity interpretation of the Egersund anorthosite complex, Norway: its petrological and geothermal significance
AUTHORS: Smithson, S B; Ramberg, I B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ANORTHOSITES; PETROGENESIS; NORWAY; GRAVITY SURVEYS; HEAT FLOW; GRANITES; MAPS; PETROLOGY; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; ROCKS; SCANDINAVIA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: The Egersund anorthosite complex consists of several bodies of anorthosite and a large synchline of layered norite and anorthosite with granitic rocks in the core. This igneous complex is emplaced in granulite-facies gneisses. These gneisses have a mean density of 2.70 g/cm/sup 3/, indicative of granitic rocks. A Bouguer gravity anomaly map shows no distinctive gravity anomaly over anorthosite, but a sharp 25-mgal positive anomaly is present over the norite syncline. Gravity models indicate that the norite synchline is about 4 km thick and that relatively minor amounts of granitic gneiss are present in the core of the syncline. Anorthosite masses cannot be modeled directly but can be inferred to have a thickness of at least 4 km. Relative amounts of the rock types in the anorthosite complex are anorthosite, 70%; norite, 25%; and granitic rocks, 5%. No evidence is found for a dense mafic residuum that would be formed if the anorthosite differentiated from a basaltic magma in place. If the rocks of the complex are cogenetic, the parent magma would be noritic anorthosite, and the volume of granitic rocks is so small that it would not change the presumed composition of the parent magma appreciably. Heat flow through the anorthosite is so low (0.45 HFU) that mantle heat flow in this area can hardly be greater than 0.2 to 0.3 HFU. Granulitic gneisses or other rocks produced at low heat must compose the entire crust beneath the anorthosite complex.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 90:2

TITLE: Correlation between the silica concentration and the orifice temperature in the warm springs along the Jordan-Dead Sea Rift Valley
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ISRAEL; THERMAL SPRINGS; SILICA; ABUNDANCE; GEOCHEMISTRY; THERMAL WATERS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; BRINES; CALCIUM; GEOTHERMOMETRY; POTASSIUM; RESERVOIR TEMPERATURE; RIFT ZONES; SODIUM; ALKALI METALS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; ASIA; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMISTRY; DEVELOPING COUNTRIES; ELEMENTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; METALS; MIDDLE EAST; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; WATER SPRINGS; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Analysis of twenty-one thermal springs emerging along the Jordan-Dead Sea Rift Valley in Israel indicates a very good correlation between the concentration of dissolved silica and the temperature of the spring orifice. Dissolution of quartz was identified as the apparent source of the silica in the water. Application of the silica geothermometer for mixed systems suggests that the springs in the Tiberias Lake Basin are supplied with hot water from deep reservoir (or reservoirs) at a temperature of 115/sup 0/C (239/sup 0/F). The same temperature was postulated earlier by the application of the Na-K-Ca hydro-geothermometer to a group of thermal springs in the same basin. The temperature of the reservoir supplying hot brines to the springs emerging along the western shore of the Dead Sea is estimated at 90/sup 0/C (194/sup 0/F).
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:1

TITLE: Quantitative comparison of energy-costing methods
AUTHORS: El-Sawy, A; Leigh, J G; Trehan, R K
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; POWER GENERATION; COST; CALCULATION METHODS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ELECTRIC POWER; TABLES; DATA FORMS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 200106 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Economics; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: This paper presents a review and analysis of methodologies used for estimating electricity-generation costs, with particular reference to geothermal energy, although the main conclusions apply equally to other sources of electricity. The costs projected by the different methods for two test cases are presented, and estimates are made of the sensitivity of the results to critical methodological choices.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Syst. Policy; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:2

TITLE: Geothermal power generation update
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; ENGINEERING; CORROSION; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; EQUIPMENT; EVALUATION; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; POWER GENERATION; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WELLS; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants; 150900 - Geothermal Engineering
DESCRIPTION: General Electric Company's participation in geothermal research and development began in the 1950s, but the potential for geothermal power generation to meet regional electrical needs remains largely untapped. Variations in the water quality and temperatures from geothermal wells create corrosion problems that require materials and equipment able to meet a range of conditions in order to maintain a high level of reliability.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. Forum; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:2

TITLE: Scale inhibitor evaluation for oil field and geothermal operations
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; SCALE CONTROL; OIL WELLS; EVALUATION; CORROSION INHIBITORS; EFFICIENCY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GYPSUM; OIL FIELDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM SULFATES; CONTROL; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; MINERAL RESOURCES; MINERALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; SULFATE MINERALS; SULFATES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; WELLS; 020300* - Petroleum- Drilling & Production; 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: The few published methods on scale inhibitor evaluation are controversial and do not allow impartial screening and/or evaluation of scale inhibitors. The methods suffer from a critical lack of reliability for 2 reasons: (1) the test conditions do not simulate the most critical field conditions; and (2) the analytical parts of these methods are not accurate enough. An elaborate new study of practical scale inhibition is presently in progress that includes both laboratory and field evaluations of scale inhibitors. The main objectives are to develop test procedures and to use these procedures for screening and evaluating large numbers of scale inhibitors. The relevancy of the test procedures and test data for field operations is emphasized. Problems and solutions of efficiency determinations are described. A new test procedure suitable for routine screening of scale inhibitors has been developed. Thirty-four scale inhibitors are presently being screened using this new procedure. 19 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Soc. Pet. Eng. AIME, Pap.; (United States); Journal Volume: SPE-7864
JOURNAL_NAME: Soc. Pet. Eng. AIME, Pap.; (United States)

TITLE: 64th annual report of the State Oil and Gas Supervisor. [California]
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; NATURAL GAS WELLS; OIL WELLS; PRODUCTION; DATA; ENHANCED RECOVERY; NATURAL GAS; OFFSHORE SITES; ONSHORE SITES; PETROLEUM; RESERVES; STEAM INJECTION; WATERFLOODING; WELL DRILLING; WELL STIMULATION; DRILLING; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION IX; FLUID INJECTION; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; RECOVERY; RESOURCES; STIMULATION; THERMAL RECOVERY; USA; WELLS; 020300* - Petroleum- Drilling & Production; 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 020100 - Petroleum- Reserves- (-1989); 030100 - Natural Gas- Reserves- (-1989); 150101 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: This 64th annual report of the State Oil and Gas Supervisor, California Division of Oil and Gas, presents information on oil and gas operations during 1978. Oil production decreased to 335.2 million bbl in 1978. Production was made from 229 active oil fields with 43,375 oil wells in operation. Incremental oil production from all types of enhanced oil recovery projects accounted for 45% of the production; steam stimulation produced 26% of the total, and waterflood operations accounted for 18%. Offshore tidelands production amounted to 13% of 1978 production. Net natural gas production declined for the tenth consecutive year to 305 billion cu ft. Recoverable oil and gas reserves are estimated at 4.2 billion bbl and 4.4 TCF, respectively. Drilling activity and geothermal operations also are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Calif. Div. Oil Gas Publication; (United States); Journal Volume: 6
JOURNAL_NAME: Calif. Div. Oil Gas Publication; (United States)

TITLE: Effects of controlled disturbance on ferruginous hawks as may occur during geothermal energy development
AUTHORS: White, C M; Thurow, T; Sullivan, J F
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BIRDS; BIOLOGICAL STRESS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; NOISE; ANIMALS; EXPLORATION; VERTEBRATES; 150600* - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects; 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: Disturbance treatments consisted of frequent walking and driving to the nest and placing noisemakers near the nest. Hawk responses to disturbance were highly variable. Several nests were deserted and not reoccupied during the following year. Little nest failure was evident, but treatment nests fledged significantly fewer young than control nests. It is suggested that a 1 mi buffer zone be established around each nest to minimize adverse impacts.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. - Geotherm. Resour. Counc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3; Other Information: Abstract of item included in Wildlife management implications of petroleum exploration and development in wildland environments

TITLE: Oxygen isotope equilibration systematics between quartz and water
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OXYGEN ISOTOPES; FRACTIONATION; QUARTZ; CRYSTALLIZATION; EQUILIBRIUM; GEOTHERMOMETRY; ISOTOPE EFFECTS; OXYGEN 16; OXYGEN 18; SILICIC ACID; WATER; CHALCOGENIDES; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; NUCLEI; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; STABLE ISOTOPES; 152004* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Isotope & Trace Element Studies; 152003 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: The /sup 18/O//sup 16/O fractionation accompanying the hydrothermal crystallization of quartz from silicic acid at 265/sup 0/ to 465/sup 0/C has been studied in order to assess the influences of (a) rate of quartz formation, (b) the nature of the reaction mechanism, and (c) temperature. At 360/sup 0/ and 465/sup 0/C, there are no indications of rate effects influencing isotope partitioning, but at 265/sup 0/C (where fractionation factors show an unusally large scatter) the evidence is inconclusive in this respect. All reaction appears to occur through solution-precipitation processes, with the intermediate phases, cristobalite and silica K, giving identical fractionation factors (within experimental errors) to quartz samples formed at the same temperature. The temperature-dependence of fractionation in the range 265/sup 0/ to 465/sup 0/C is given by the equation 10/sup 3/ ln ..cap alpha..(SiO/sub 2/--H/sub 2/O) = 3.05 x 10/sup 6/T/sup -2/ - 2.09. The data are in good agreement with other experimental calibrations of the quartz-water fractionation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Mineral.; (United States); Journal Volume: 64:1-2

TITLE: High-temperature heat capacities of corundum, periclase, anorthite, CaAl/sub 2/Si/sub 2/O/sub 8/ glass, muscovite, pyrophyllite, KAlSi/sub 3/O/sub 8/ glass, grossular, and NaAlSi/sub 3/O/sub 8/ glass
AUTHORS: Krupka, K M; Robie, R A; Hemingway, B S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ALUMINIUM SILICATES; SPECIFIC HEAT; ANORTHOSITES; CALCIUM SILICATES; CORUNDUM; GLASS; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; MUSCOVITE; PYROPHYLLITE; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MICA; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKS; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 152002* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: The heat capacities (C/sup 0//sub p/) of corundum, periclase, anorthite, CaAl/sub 2/Si/sub 2/O/sub 8/ glass, muscovite, pyrophyllite, KAlSi/sub 3/O/sub 8/ glass, grossular, and NaAlSi/sub 3/O/sub 8/ glass have been determined to an accuracy of +-1.0% by differential scanning calorimetry between 350 and 1000 K. Results have been combined smoothly with existing low-temperature heat capacity and entropy data, and fitted by least squares to the equations presented. The accuracy of the differential scanning calorimeter was checked by measuring the heat capacities of corundum and periclase and comparing these results with those published by the U.S. National Bureau of Standards. Calorimetric data for muscovite, pyrophyllite, and grossular were combined with data from recent equilibrium studies to derive improved values for ..delta..H/sup 0//sub f,298/ and ..delta..G/sup 0//sub f,298/ for muscovite, pyrophyllite, and grossular.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Mineral.; (United States); Journal Volume: 64:1-2

TITLE: Initial geothermal activities held not to require an EIS
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LAWSUITS; LEASES; DOCUMENT TYPES; EXPLORATION; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 290300 - Energy Planning & Policy- Environment, Health, & Safety; 510500 - Environment, Terrestrial- Site Resource & Use Studies- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Environmental impact statements are not required for the use of roads and trails by lessees exploring for geothermal resources. The Oregon court ruled against the Sierra Club and other environmentalists on the grounds that casual use has little environmental impact. Casual use, which is described as geochemical surveys using existing roads and trails, mapping, and aerial microgas surveys, is the first of six steps in the commercial development of geothermal energy.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nat. Resour. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:1

TITLE: Geological and geochemical characteristics of geothermal resources in Japan
AUTHORS: Nakamura, H; Sumi, K; Ozawa, T

TITLE: Problems of the origin of therms in regions of active volcanism
AUTHORS: Ivanov, V V; Kononov, V I
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; THERMAL WATERS; ORIGIN; VOLCANIC REGIONS; CARBON DIOXIDE; DEPTH; GASES; GEOCHEMISTRY; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; HYDROGEN; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMISTRY; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; DIMENSIONS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NONMETALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESOURCES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; 150300* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: Specific geological, geothermal, geochemical and hydrogeological conditions of active volcanism determine the formation within them of different groups of thermal waters: hydrogen sulfide-carbon dioxide (fumarolic and magmatogenic), nitrogen-carbon dioxide (metamorphogenic), and carbon dioxide-hydrogen (rift). Thermals of specific compositions are formed, and are of two characteristic subtypes, (surface and deep-seated formations). 56 references, 4 tables.

TITLE: Thermodynamic properties and phase transitions of H/sub 2/O up to 1000/sup 0/C and 100 kbar
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; WATER; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; ENTHALPY; FREE ENTHALPY; GASES; HIGH PRESSURE; HIGH TEMPERATURE; LIQUIDS; MEDIUM PRESSURE; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; PHASE DIAGRAMS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; VERY HIGH PRESSURE; VERY HIGH TEMPERATURE; VOLUME; DIAGRAMS; ENERGY; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: Data have been reported for the properties of water in an attempt to provide a uniform system of thermodynamic potentials and specified volumes of water over wide ranges in temperature and pressure. The phase diagram and the phase equilibria in the water system show that all transitions are gradual. There are no sharp boundaries between the supercritical(fluid) and gas fields, nor between the supercritical(fluid) and liquid fields, nor are there any between the gas and fluid states, although the mechanisms and cooling rates of natural systems may vary. The data show that changes in pressure and temperature in mineralizing water systems are regularly coupled, and the two have to be considered as factors acting simultaneously. 5 figures, 3 tables.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. Geol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 21:1

TITLE: Effect of CO/sub 2/ on the buoyancy of geothermal fluids
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BROADLANDS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; THERMAL EXPANSION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CARBON DIOXIDE; CONVECTIVE INSTABILITIES; FLUID WITHDRAWAL; STREAMS; WATER; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; EXPANSION; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INSTABILITY; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PLASMA INSTABILITY; SURFACE WATERS; 150902* - Geothermal Engineering- Fluid Transmission
DESCRIPTION: The presence of large amounts of CO/sub 2/ in geothermal fluids is shown to generally enhance convective instability. The buoyancy of water-CO/sub 2/ solutions can be dominated by the large volume changes that occur when CO/sub 2/ enters or leaves solution. The transfer of water between the liquid and vapor phases which accompanies the movement of CO/sub 2/ into or out of solution also contributes to changes in the fluid volume and resultant buoyancy. The effective thermal expansivity ..cap alpha../sub eff/ in the CO/sub 2/ rich fluid of the Broadlands geothermal region of New Zealand exceeds the coefficient of thermal expansion of ordinary water ..cap alpha../sub l/ for depths are large as a 2 km; ..cap alpha../sub eff/ is more than an order of magnitude larger than ..cap alpha../sub l/ at depths less than 500 m.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Res. Lett.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:1

TITLE: Corrosivity of carbon steel in concentrated chloride solution
AUTHORS: Posey, F A; Palko, A A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; CARBON STEELS; CORROSION; SODIUM CHLORIDES; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; ELECTROCHEMISTRY; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; PH VALUE; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALLOYS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHEMISTRY; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; MIXTURES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; STEELS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development; 360105 - Metals & Alloys- Corrosion & Erosion
DESCRIPTION: The effect of pH (from neutral to moderately acidic solutions) and temperature (from 25 to 200 C) on the corrosion rate of carbon steel in deaerated 4M NaCl is described. Corrosion rates were estimated by extrapolation of anodic and cathodic Tafel lines back to the corrosion potential and by measurement of polarization resistance. A refreshed, stirred titanium autoclave system is described which permits electrochemical measurements to be made up to at least 200 C in corrosive aqueous saline media. A relatively simple numerical correlation describes the data over the entire temperature and pH range.
RELATION: Journal Name: Corrosion; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:1

TITLE: Use of potential-pH diagrams for the interpretation of corrosion phenomena in high salinity geothermal brines
AUTHORS: MacDonald, D D; Syrett, B C; Wing, S S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; BRINES; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; CARBON STEELS; CORROSION; CARPENTER; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HASTELLOY C; HASTELLOYS; HAYNES ALLOYS; INCONEL 625; STAINLESS STEEL-316L; STAINLESS STEELS; TITANIUM ALLOYS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHROMIUM; IRON; NICKEL; PH VALUE; SALINITY; TITANIUM; VOLTAMETRY; ALLOYS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM ALLOYS; CHROMIUM STEELS; CHROMIUM-NICKEL STEELS; COBALT ALLOYS; CORROSION RESISTANT ALLOYS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; HEAT RESISTANT MATERIALS; HEAT RESISTING ALLOYS; INCONEL ALLOYS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; MATERIALS; METALS; MOLYBDENUM ALLOYS; NICKEL ALLOYS; NICKEL BASE ALLOYS; NIOBIUM ALLOYS; STEELS; TANTALUM ALLOYS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; TUNGSTEN ALLOYS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development; 360105 - Metals & Alloys- Corrosion & Erosion
DESCRIPTION: corrosion potentials and cyclic voltammograms are reported for AISI 1010 carbon steel, E-Brite 26-1 stainless steel, AISI 316L stainless steel, Haynes Alloy 20 Mod, Carpenter 20 Cb-3, Inconel Alloy 625, Hastelloy Alloy G, Hastelloy Alloy C-276, Titanium 50A, and TiCode 12 in high salinity geothermal brine at 250 C. Potential-pH diagrams for the component metals (Fe, Ni, Cr, Ti) in the brine at 25 and 250 C are also derived, and are used to interpret the corrosion behavior and cyclic voltammetric responses of the alloys in the elevated temperature brine environment.
RELATION: Journal Name: Corrosion; (United States); Journal Volume: 35:1

TITLE: Geothermal paplans picking up steam on coast
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; BRINES; CAPACITY; COST; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: Three proposed geothermal power plants in California are described. A 110 Mw dry steam plant is planned for The Geysers geothermal field by the Northern California Power Agency. Construction on the $57 million plant is to begin in 1979 and be completed by 1981. A 55 Mw plant is also proposed for The Geysers as part of the state Department of Water Resources plan to supply 12% of needed energy by the mid-1980s by geothermal power. Also, a 50 Mw plant is planned for Imperial Valley by Southern California Edison that will convert geothermal brine to steam. The $70 million plant which is scheduled for completion in 1982 could save an estimated 450,000 bbl of oil a year.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 201:25

TITLE: Commercialized unconventional sources of natural gas: 50 or 50,000 TCF. [Role of DOE]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; NATURAL GAS; ENHANCED RECOVERY; MARKET; METHANE; PRODUCTION; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; SHALE GAS; US DOE; ALKANES; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 294003* - Energy Planning & Policy- Natural Gas; 030900 - Natural Gas- Artificial Stimulation, Plowshare- (-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Top-level DOE officials have been focusing on the untapped potential of ''unconventional'' sources of natural gas--including gas recovery from tight gas sands, Eastern gas shales, methane seams in coal, and geo-pressured brine. The stakes are large, with some saying unconventional gas could totally change the U.S. supply picture. This special report on the status of these resources covers what DOE is doing, what others would like DOE to do and the obstacles to commercializing one or all of the sources. First, there is a rundown of just what DOE's Resource Applications Division has in mind for unconventional gas recovery, as reflected in RA's 'resource manager' plan for commercialization. Next, the Gas Research Institute blasts RA chief George McIsaac's assessment of the commercialization potential of unconventional gas. Finally, there is a rundown of an analysis by former Federal Energy Administrator John Sawhill for Energy Secretary James Schlesinger--urging DOE to expand it's R and D program by more than $300-million over the next five years, and to put geopressured methane R and D in the top priority (DOE has currently a very limited program for geopressured methane).
RELATION: Journal Name: Inside DOE; (United States); Other Information: Special report on unconventional gas recovery

TITLE: Hydrothermal activity at the TAG hydrothermal field, Mid-Atlantic ridge crest at 26/sup 0/N
AUTHORS: Rona, P A; Thompson, G; Mottl, M J; Karson, J A; Jenkins, W J; Graham, D; Mallette, M; Von Damm, K; Edmond, J M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MID-ATLANTIC RIDGE; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; HEAT FLUX; LAYERS; PETROLOGY; SEDIMENTS; VARIATIONS; VOLCANISM; ENERGY SYSTEMS; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 150202* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The first submersible observations of the only known active submarine hydrothermal field on a slow-spreading oceanic ridge are incorporated with results of 10 prior years of investigation to derive an understanding of periodicity, duration, and varying intensity of hydrothermal activity at the Trans-Atlantic Geotraverse (TAG) Hydrothermal Field on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge crest near latitude 26/sup 0/N. Hydrothermal activity has persisted at this location for a least 1 x 10/sup 6/ years based on the distribution of hydrothermal and hydrogenous mineralization with respect to crustal age. The hydrothermal activity has been cyclic, multistage, and episodic. Prior high-temperature hydrothermal venting stages with a periodicity of the order of 1 x 10/sup 4/ years and duration of the order of 10/sup 1/ years are deduced from the estimated ages of discrete sedimentary layers anomalously enriched in Cu, Fe, and Zn and correspond with the independently determined periodicity of volcanic eruptive cycles on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. The most recent episode of high-temperature venting is inferred to have ceased in the recent past based on metal enrichment (Cu, Fe, Zn) in the surficial sediment layer. Low-temperature hydrothermal venting stages with a duration of the order of 1 x 10/sup 4/ years intervene between the short high-temperature stages and produce stratiform deposits of layered and earthy manganese oxide, iron oxide, hydroxide and silicate. Bivalve-like forms with the characteristics of vent clams in various stages of dissolution are identified on bottom photographs.
RESEARCH_ORG: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Atlantic Oceanographic and Meteorological Laboratory, Miami, Florida
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 89:B13

TITLE: Heat flow in the Eastern Caribbean
AUTHORS: Clark, T F; Korgen, B J; Best, D M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CARIBBEAN SEA; PLATE TECTONICS; EARTH CRUST; HEAT FLOW; ATLANTIC OCEAN; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; TECTONICS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A west-to-east traverse of 24 heat flow measurements was made across the Caribbean Sea floor from the eastern Venezuelan basin to 80 km east of the Lesser Antilles arc crest. The resulting heat flow profile includes an increase from basin values in the eastern Venezuelan basin and a zone of high values extending the length of the transect. Superimposed on this zone are two heat flow peaks containing maximum values, one at the Aves swell and the other at the Lesser Antilles arc. Based on 21 acceptable values, average heat flows were 1.87 heat flow units (1 HFU=1 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/s/sup -1/) (8 values) for basin regions, 3.63 HFU (9 values) for the Aves swell peak, and 4.16 HFU (4 values) for the Lesser Antilles are peak. High heat flow is expected for the Lesser Antilles arc, the present site of seismic and volcanic activity associated with subduction of the North American plate at the West Indies trench. The heat flow peak at the Aves swell agrees with an island arc formation for this presently inactive feature, with its high heat flow anomaly attributed to radiogenic heat sources concentrated during subduction in the past. Both the Aves swell and the Lesser Antilles arc are believed to be heated by radiogenic sources accumulated during past subduction, but only the Lesser Antilles arc is now receiving new heat from mechanical processes directly coupled to active underthrusting. This suggests that differences in the two heat flow peaks at the Aves swell and Lesser Antilles arc reflect the relative importance of different heat-producing mechanisms at island arcs.
RESEARCH_ORG: Curriculum in Marine Sciences, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27514
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 83:B12

TITLE: Solubility of methane in water at elevated temperatures and pressures
SUBJECT: 10 SYNTHETIC FUELS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; METHANE; SOLUBILITY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; HIGH PRESSURE; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; VERY HIGH PRESSURE; WATER; ALKANES; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; FLUIDS; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; 090110* - Hydrocarbon Fuels- Properties- (1979-1989); 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions

TITLE: Geothermal hot water plant
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; DESIGN; GEOTHERMAL REFRIGERATION; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; SPECIFICATIONS; CONVERSION; COOLING; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FEDERAL REGION IX; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; REFRIGERATION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: A geothermal hot water plant which will provide 11 Mw of electricity is being completed in California's Imperial Valley, according to a report in the Washington Post. The process used to convert underground hot water into power was developed and funded entirely by a small, innovative company, Magnum Power, which also produces geothermal power from dry steam at its Geysers plant in northern California. The method used was designed by J.G. Hilbert, known as the father of Ocean Thermal Energy Conservation. A synthetic refrigerant is used to drive the turbine rather than steam from the hot water, so that the process largely eliminates the corrosion problems which have constituted a major drawback to using geothermal hot water for power production. According to Magnum Power, it will be possible to build hot water powerplants for less than $600/kw, well under half the cost of a nuclear plant. Hot water plants will probably always be relatively small, producing about 50 Mw, enough to provide the power needs of a city of 50,000. Medium- to low-temperature underground hot water is available in many places throughout the American West and elsewhere in the world.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:10

TITLE: Some results from audiomagnetotelluric investigations in geothermal areas
AUTHORS: Hoover, D B; Long, C L; Senterfit, R M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; MAGNETOTELLURIC SURVEYS; ALASKA; CALIFORNIA; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; ELECTRIC FIELDS; HZ RANGE; IDAHO; KGRA; NEVADA; NEW MEXICO; OREGON; UTAH; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; FREQUENCY RANGE; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Audiomagnetotelluric (AMT) surveys have been made in more than 40 geothermal areas in the western U.S. The majority of the measurements was made in the Basin and Range and Columbia Plateau physiographic provinces. Complete spectral analyses made in conjunction with the field surveys illustrate the impulsive nature of the natural signals which appear to overshadow the Schumann resonances at the low frequencies. The spectrum below 200 Hz is fairly flat and the signal strength is sufficient for operation throughout the year. Above 200 Hz and centered near 2 kHz, an absorptive band limits the signal strength making data acquisition difficult if not impossible in the mid-band region, particularly during the winter months. The spectra also show that power line harmonics may be very strong to about 1000 Hz and can be 30 to 50 dB above the natural signal level. Histograms of the measured apparent resistivities at 7.5 and 27 Hz for all measurement locations within the Basin and Range and Columbia Plateau physiographic provinces indicate a narrow distribution for the Basin and Range, while a broader distribution characterizes the Columbia Plateau. Comparisons between the average resistivities and Known Geothermal Resource Areas (KGRA) show that low average resistivities appear to correlate with regions containing a number of large volume geothermal systems and not with high heat flow.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:7

TITLE: Quadripole resistivity survey of the Imperial Valley, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IMPERIAL VALLEY; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; KGRA; SALINITY; SALTON SEA; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A quadrupole resistivity survey of the Imperial Valley, California, was carried out from the Salton Sea in the north to the Mexican border in the south. The east and west boundaries of the survey were the topographic limits of the valley. The quadripole resistivity method consists of sequentially energizing two orthogonal bipole sources with a square wave of electric current and measuring the resultant electric fields with a pair of orthogonal wire receivers. Two resultant electric fields are measured and by combining them in different proportions, their resultant can be made to rotate through 360 degrees. By performing this procedure, an ellipse of resistivity can be calculated at each measurement location. The arithmetic mean of the maximum and minimum axes of the ellipse is a tensor invariant resistivity. It was this value which was used to define the variation of electrical resistivity over the Imperial Valley. The quadripole survey of the Imperial Valley was undertaken to compare its known geothermal fields with previously unsurveyed areas. The results show that the geothermal fields of the Imperial Valley have distinctive resistivity characteristics. A large circular area south of the city of Brawley was found which has the same characteristics as the known geothermal fields. From the resistivity data, it is predicted that this south Brawley resistivity anomaly represents a geothermal field which will produce water with a temperature of approximately 200/sup 0/C and with a salinity between 20,000 and 50,000 ppM. A well to test the prospect was scheduled to be drilled early in 1978.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:7

TITLE: Reconnaissance geophysical studies of the geothermal system in southern Raft River Valley, Idaho
AUTHORS: Mabey, D R; Hoover, D B; O'Donnell, J E; Wilson, C W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; RAFT RIVER VALLEY; GRAVITY SURVEYS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; TELLURIC SURVEYS; CENOZOIC ERA; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IDAHO; LITHOLOGY; ROCKS; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC AGES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Gravity, aeromagnetic, and telluric current surveys in the southern Raft River have been used to infer the structure and the general lithology underlying the valley. The gravity data indicate the approximate thickness of the Cenozoic rocks and location of the larger normal faults, and the aeromagnetic data indicate the extent of the major Cenozoic volcanic units. The relative ellipse area contour map compiled from the telluric current survey generally conforms to the gravity map except for lower values in the area of the geothermal system. An area of low apparent resistivity values defined by the audiomagnetotelluric (AMT) survey appears to outline the extent of the geothermal reservoir even though the reservoir is deeper than the penetration of the survey. Self-potential anomalies relate to near surface hydrology. The Raft River Valley is underlain by about 2 km of Cenozoic rock, most of which is Tertiary sediments of the Salt Lake formation. On the west side of the valley the Tertiary rocks appear to be separated from the underlying Precambrian basement by a low angle fault along which the Tertiary rocks have slid off a buried basement dome. Subsequent normal faults displace both the basement surface and the Tertiary beds. The geothermal system occurs where these north-trending faults intersect a poorly understood northeast-trending zone that may be a basement shear zone. Apparently deep circulating water at a temperature of about 150/sup 0/C rises in the area of this intersection and then spreads laterally in porous zones near the base of the Tertiary rocks to form the geothermal reservoir. Upward leakage from the reservoir produces shallower effects that were measured by the AMT survey.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:7

TITLE: Summary of the geology, geochemistry, and geophysics of the Roosevelt Hot Springs thermal area, Utah
AUTHORS: Ward, S H; Parry, W T; Nash, W P; Sill, W R; Cook, K L; Smith, R B; Chapman, D S; Brown, F H; Whelan, J A; Bowman, J R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ROOSEVELT HOT SPRINGS; GEOCHEMISTRY; GEOLOGY; GEOPHYSICS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC AGES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GRAVITY SURVEYS; HEAT FLOW; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; KGRA; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; MAPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MICROEARTHQUAKES; RHYOLITES; UTAH; CHEMISTRY; EARTHQUAKES; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SEISMIC EVENTS; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: Progress to early 1978 of research on the geology, geochemistry, and geophysics of the Roosevelt Hot Springs thermal area is summarized. Efforts are described in the following areas: devlopment of a complete case study of the area, delineation of the reservoir and its sources of heat, and the development of exploration procedures suited to detection and delineation of similar geothermal fields in the eastern basin and Range province. (MHR)
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City

TITLE: Tectonic implications of the heat flow of the western Snake River Plain, Idaho
AUTHORS: Brott, C A; Blackwell, D D; Mitchell, J C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IDAHO; HEAT FLOW; TECTONICS; BOREHOLES; DATA; GEOLOGIC MODELS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; VOLCANIC REGIONS; CAVITIES; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Heat-flow values within the western Snake River Plain average about 1.7 ..mu..cal/cm/sup 2/ sec, but even higher values are measured in granitic rocks along the margins of the Snake River Plain (2.5 ..mu..cal/cm/sup 2/ sec or higher). The heat-flow distribution is related to the combined effects of crustal thermal refraction and a large, transient crustal heat source. A regional model consistent with the heat-flow pattern and other geophysical and geological data is described which assumes the emplacement of a large heat source (mafic intrusion) under the western Snake River Plain about 10 to 15 m.y. ago. An anomaly of about 0.3 ..mu..cal/cm/sup 2/ sec is predicted over the center of the heat source at the present time. The timing of the emplacement of the heat source corresponds with the age of voluminous silicic volcanism in the western Snake River Plain. A time-progressive thermal model is presented for the Snake River Plain which is consistent with the time progression of silicic volcanism. Based on the model, higher regional heat-flow values are predicted for the eastern Snake River Plain. Confirmation of the high regional heat-flow values is not possible in the boreholes available (200 +- m deep) because of regional circulation of cold groundwater in the Snake Plain Aquifer. However, a close correlation between integrated crustal and upper mantle temperature and observed elevation changes along the axis of the Snake River Plain is strong support for the heat-flow model. The possibility of high heat flow in the eastern part of the Snake River Plain implies that the area may have significant geothermal potential in spite of the low surface heat flow. The regional aseismic warping observed in the eastern Snake River Plain can be interpreted as a thermal contraction phenomenon involving the crust and upper mantle.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 89:12

TITLE: Electromagnetic and Schlumberger resistivity sounding in the Roosevelt Hot Springs KGRA
AUTHORS: Tripp, A C; Ward, S H; Sill, W R; Swift, Jr, C M; Petrick, W R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ROOSEVELT HOT SPRINGS; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; HOT SPRINGS; KGRA; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; THERMAL SPRINGS; USA; UTAH; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: One- and two-dimensional modeling of the Schlumberger soundings at the Roosevelt Hot Springs KGRA have indicated a low-resistivity zone of approximately 5 ..cap omega..-m paralleling the dome fault. The low resistivity of this zone is probably due to intensely fractured and altered water-saturated rock. A zone of resistivity 12 ..cap omega..-m extending to the west of the dome fault is probably due to leakage of brine away from the geothermal system through alluvium or moderately altered rock. A resistive basement underlies the conductive zones and is believed to be essentially nonporous and unaltered rock. A major problem in the application of one-dimensional (1-D) modeling of Schlumberger data in the Roosevelt Hot Springs KGRA is poor resolution of the 1-D parameters. The joint inversion of Schlumberger and electromagnetic sounding data gives a least-squares 1-D conductivity model in which parameters are much better resolved than are the model parameters estimated by the inversion of Schlumberger data alone. One-dimensional modeling of Schlumberger soundings along a traverse does indicate the presence of a 2-D inhomogeneity but gives no hint of the possible complexity of that inhomogeneity even though the parameters of the models fitting each sounding have acceptable standard deviations when constrained by electromagnetic sounding data. Since the model parameter standard deviations are model dependent,good resolution of 1-D model parameters does not indicate that the assumption of a 1-D model is valid. On the other hand, the possible compexity of structure is brought out by 2-D modeling of the same data, but since the degrees of freedom for complex 2-D models is large, a thorough study of the resolution of such models is prohibitively costly at present. In these circumstances, one must constrain the 2-D models with independent geologic or geophysical data and then accept the subsequent best-fit model as semiquantitative.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:7

TITLE: Thermal gradient anomalies: Southern Arizona
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ARIZONA; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; ANOMALOUS DIMENSION; DEPTH; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GROUND WATER; NATURAL GAS WELLS; OIL WELLS; WATER; DIMENSIONS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SCALE DIMENSION; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A survey of the records of numerous thermally anomalous water wells in the southern portion of the Basin and Range province of Arizona indicate that most of these wells are less than 300 m deep. The temperature and depth data of most of these shallow wells produce abnormally high computed thermal gradients that are inconsistent with considerably lower gradients in deeper wells. Utilization of a method devised for an appraisal of shallow well data permits identification of the most attractive thermal gradient anomalies warranting additional data-gathering methods. Water moving vertically from deep-heated crustal rock along faults and then moving horizontally into relatively shallow basin-fill deposits seems to be the most probable explanation for the irregular but widespread occurrence of thermal ground water in the study area. 4 figures, 1 table.
RESEARCH_ORG: Oil and Gas Commission, Phoenix, AZ
RELATION: Journal Name: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:2
