TITLE: California energy dream includes some clean coal
SUBJECT: 32 ENERGY CONSERVATION, CONSUMPTION, AND UTILIZATION; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; ENERGY DEMAND; ENERGY SOURCES; AIR POLLUTION CONTROL; COAL; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEYSERS; SOLAR POWER PLANTS; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; POLLUTION CONTROL; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 320000* - Energy Conservation, Consumption, & Utilization; 010900 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Environmental Aspects; 140000 - Solar Energy; 150000 - Geothermal Energy
DESCRIPTION: Recent responses in California to the threat of future power shortages due to a moratorium on nuclear plants and strict environmental controls on coal- and oil-fired facilities are discussed. A comparative study by California's Air Resources Board of oil vs. coal power generation is cited which claims coal power plant particulate and SO/sub 2/ emissions can be reduced to one-tenth those of oil-fired plants. This indicates that California may be able to use coal in the future. Also, recent progress in the pursuit of clean, alternative energy sources is discussed. For example, additions to power stations at the Geysers are expected to yield 1350 Mw by 1985. Also, a 10 Mw solar power tower is being constructed near Barstow, and a 55% tax credit on solar projects is in effect. Out-of-state sources of power for the early 1980's are also explored.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 201:20

DESCRIPTION: The major factors to be considered when trying to formulate a reasonable estimate for the cost of direct use geothermal energy are presented. Pricing for a specific geothermal resource with specific users is broken down into four major categories: (1) the capital investment to develop the resource, (2) the cost of delivering the resource, (3) the cost of maintaining the system, and (4) the savings or cost benefit realized from utilizing the resource. TITLE: Utility estimates of geothermal electricity generating capacity

Growth-rate estimates show that the announced use of geothermal resources will double and could contribute a significant portion of the energy for power generation. SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EAST MESA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; DESALINATION PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; DESALINATION; COLORADO RIVER; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; PLANNING; REINJECTION; WATER QUALITY; WATER RESOURCES; DEMINERALIZATION; ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; POWER PLANTS; RESOURCES; RIVERS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: The feasibility of desalting geothermal fluids for augmentation of water supplies in the Pacific southwest is being studied. Three desalting units, a multistage flash unit, a vertical tube evaporator unit, and a high-temperature electrodialysis unit, have been installed at the East Mesa geothermal field. Tests are underway on the three systems; one will be chosen for combination with a power plant. (JGB)

TITLE: Thermosyphon models for downhole heat exchanger applications in shallow geothermal systems
AUTHORS: Kreitlow, D B; Reistad, G M; Miles, C R; Culver, G G
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; FLOW RATE; HEAT EXTRACTION; HEAT TRANSFER; MASS TRANSFER; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; ENERGY TRANSFER; 150902* - Geothermal Engineering- Fluid Transmission
DESCRIPTION: The analysis of downhole heat exchangers used to extract energy from relatively shallow geothermal wells lead to the consideration of several interesting problems of buoyancy-driven heat transfer in enclosures. This paper considers thermosyphoning through and around the wellbore casing which is perforated at two or more depths. Analytical models are developed for thermosyphoning in the cased well both with and without a heat exchanger installed. Theoretical results are compared with experimental values. These comparisons show that the observed energy extraction rates and flow rates through the well casing are possible with thermosyphoning as the only circulation mmechanism within the well bore. The model with a heat exchanger installed is parametrically evaluated to illustrate the sensitivity of the model to estimated parameters and the effect of changes in design variables or constraints.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Heat Transfer; (United States); Journal Volume: 100:4

TITLE: Corrosion characteristics of materials in hypersaline geothermal brine
AUTHORS: Harrar, J E; McCright, R D; Goldberg, A
SUBJECT: 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; CHROMIUM-MOLYBDENUM STEELS; CORROSION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HASTELLOYS; HAYNES 25 ALLOY; INCONEL 625; STAINLESS STEEL-304; STAINLESS STEEL-410; STAINLESS STEEL-422; STAINLESS STEEL-430; CHROMIUM ALLOYS; MOLYBDENUM ALLOYS; NICKEL ALLOYS; COPPER ALLOYS; ALUMINIUM ALLOYS; TITANIUM ALLOYS; VANADIUM ALLOYS; EQUIPMENT; ALLOYS; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHROMIUM STEELS; CHROMIUM-NICKEL STEELS; COBALT ALLOYS; COBALT BASE ALLOYS; CORROSION RESISTANT ALLOYS; FLUIDS; HEAT RESISTANT MATERIALS; HEAT RESISTING ALLOYS; INCONEL ALLOYS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; MATERIALS; NICKEL BASE ALLOYS; NIOBIUM ALLOYS; STAINLESS STEELS; STEELS; TANTALUM ALLOYS; TUNGSTEN ALLOYS; 360105* - Metals & Alloys- Corrosion & Erosion; 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: A flow cell (with appropriate accessories) was developed for use in short-term testing of the corrosion behavior of materials in approx. 100/sup 0/C, hypersaline geothermal brine. An apparatus was designed to accommodate commercial (Petrolite) corrosion measurement equipment and to conduct experiments on-line at the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory Test Station in the Salton Sea Geothermal Field. The apparatus also permitted direct readings of corrosion potentials, solution redox potential (E/sub h/), brine flow rate, pH, and temperature. Estimates of general corrosion rates were obtained by the linear polarization resistance technique and from measurements of complete potentiodynamic polarization curves. Twenty-two alloys (with various heat treatments) were tested and readily grouped according to general corrosion resistances in acidified hypersaline (approx. 4 M chloride) brine.
RELATION: Journal Name: SAMPE Q.; (United States); Journal Volume: 10:1

TITLE: Geothermal electricity: a promising as well as problematic Basin energy alternative. [Caribbean Basin]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CARIBBEAN SEA; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; POWER GENERATION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; ATLANTIC OCEAN; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER PLANTS; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150102 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: Located in an area dotted with volcanoes, the Caribbean Basin has become a world leader in the effort to develop electricity from geothermal sources. Geothermal electricity is already produced in Mexico, El Salvado, and St. Lucia, while exploration and drilling projects are underway in several other countries. While the output is an insignificant one percent of the total power produced in the Basin, recent petroleum price increases have pointed out the advantages of geothermal development: less dependence on imports, more power for domestic industry, and an economical way to increase capacity in stages. 8 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Caribb. Basin Econ. Surv.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:5

TITLE: Alternative energy in the USSR
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 16 TIDAL AND WAVE POWER; 17 WIND ENERGY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; USSR; DISTRICT HEATING; ENERGY CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENERGY SUPPLIES; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; IRRIGATION; RESOURCE CONSERVATION; SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION; SOLAR HEATING SYSTEMS; TIDAL POWER PLANTS; WIND POWER PLANTS; CONVERSION; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; HEATING; HEATING SYSTEMS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 299000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 290500 - Energy Planning & Policy- Research, Development, Demonstration, & Commercialization; 140100 - Solar Energy- Resources & Availability; 150102 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants; 160700 - Tidal Power Plants; 170603 - Wind Energy Engineering- Power-Conversion Systems
DESCRIPTION: Although renewable energy sources have a relatively low priority in the resource-rich Soviet Union, research and development in new energy-conversion systems will be expanded to exploit wind and solar energy. Wind research projects will include desalination and pumping water, cathodic protection of pipelines, and large-scale power generation. Solar projects will include desert irrigation, solar-powered houses and appliances, and pulsed solar irradiation. In addition, tidal power plants are being installed along the coasts and geothermal plants for both power generation and local heating will operate at several sites. 22 references.
RELATION: Journal Name: Environment; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:7

TITLE: Regional gravity and magnetic anomalies in the eastern Snake River Plain, Idaho
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IDAHO; GRAVITY SURVEYS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; DENSITY; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; RIFT ZONES; VOLCANIC ROCKS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKS; USA; 580200* - Geophysics- (-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Over the eastern Snake River Plain, the Bouguer gravity anomaly and the magnetic intensity are, in general, high. In detail, both the gravity and the magnetic anomalies are a complex of highs and lows, in contrast to the simpler anomalies over the western Snake River Plain. The broad gravity high associated with the eastern Snake River Plain cannot be produced by a dense mass at shallow depth under the plain, but must be produced either by a deep feature under the plain or by a broader, shallower feature extending well beyond the plain. The high could be produced by a thinning of the crust under the plain by 4.5 to 7 kilometers. The data suggest that the Cenozoic rocks of the plain are underlain by rocks that have density and magnetization similar to the density and magnetization of the pre-Cenozoic rocks north and south of the plain. The data do not suggest rifting of the upper crust such as is inferred for the western Snake River Plain. The plain is in approximate isostatic equilibrium with adjoining regions to the north and south and thus contrasts with the adjoining areas where the basin-and-range topography is not in isostatic equilibrium. The local gravity anomalies on the plain are probably produced by variations in the thickness of Cenozoic rocks, but the wavelength of the anomalies is about twice that of the basin-and-range structural features in areas adjoining the plain. The gravity expression of basin-and-range structural features does not extend far onto the plain.Magnetic anomalies on the plain are produced by Cenozoic volcanic rocks.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Res. U.S. Geol. Surv.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:5
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Res. U.S. Geol. Surv.; (United States)

TITLE: Estimation of aquifer permeabilities from electric well logs
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 02 PETROLEUM; 47 OTHER INSTRUMENTATION; AQUIFERS; PERMEABILITY; DRILL CORES; ELECTRIC LOGGING; OIL WELLS; PETROLEUM GEOLOGY; GEOLOGY; WELL LOGGING; WELLS; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 020200 - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 440400 - Well Logging Instrumentation
DESCRIPTION: Evidence from core data and log studies shows that permeability is related to formation resistivity factor. Empirical correlation relating the two rock parameters is determined using core data. Knowing the formation resistivity factor from electric logs, it is possible to calculate the permeability of a given formation interval. Field examples show that the proposed method is applicable in both water bearing and hydrocarbon bearing zones. The ability to predict the permeability of water bearing zones from electric well logs is of great importance in the assessment of aquifers geopressure energy resource.
RELATION: Journal Name: Log Anal.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:5

TITLE: Availability ratio for performance of pipeline components in two-phase flow
AUTHORS: Harrison, R F; Dean, R B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; PIPELINES; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; TWO-PHASE FLOW; AVAILABILITY; DIFFUSERS; EQUATIONS; PERFORMANCE; STEADY FLOW; FLUID FLOW; FLUIDS; 150902* - Geothermal Engineering- Fluid Transmission
DESCRIPTION: A new method is presented which uses the steady flow availability function to analyze the efficiency with which energy can be transmitted in a pipeline. It is suggested that the availability approach can be used to compare the performance of all types of pipeline components such as bends, diffusers, etc., and their effect on the power available at the power turbine.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Fluids Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 100:3

TITLE: Terrestrial heat flow and crustal radioactivity in northeastern New Mexico and southeastern Colorado
AUTHORS: Edwards, C L; Reiter, M; Shearer, C; Young, W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COLORADO; HEAT FLOW; NEW MEXICO; DATA COMPILATION; EARTH CRUST; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; GREAT PLAINS; RADIOACTIVITY; RADIOISOTOPE HEAT SOURCES; RIO GRANDE RIFT; ROCKY MOUNTAINS; TECTONICS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; VOLCANIC REGIONS; DATA; HEAT SOURCES; INFORMATION; MOUNTAINS; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL DATA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SOUTHWEST REGION; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: New heat-flow data obtained in northeastern New Mexico and southeastern Colorado show three regional trends: (1) A broad heat-flow anomaly associated with the southern Rocky Mountains contrasts with a narrow heat-flow anomaly between lat 35.5/sup 0/ and 34/sup 0/N, apparently associated only with the Rio Grande rift. (2) The high heat-flow anomaly apparently associated with the southern Rocky Mountains extends 200 to 300 km onto the Great Plains of northeastern New Mexico and southeastern Colorado. (3) Areas of extensive volcanic activity do not necessarily have high heat flow. In addition, measurements of crustal radioactivity in the vicinity of the Rio Grande rift suggest that the radioactive heat generation contributes uniformly to the surface heat flow. This implies that the heat-flow anomaly observed along the Rio Grande rift is caused by tectonic and volcanic sources and not by anomalously high crustal radioactivity.
RESEARCH_ORG: New Mexico Inst. of Mining and Tech., Socorro
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 89:9

DESCRIPTION: The fundamental principles and assumptions underlying the methods, and also the main results, of a prognostic estimate of the resources and exploitable reserves of hot mineral waters in mountain regions of folded structure are considered. Corresponding results are cited for major areas along the Baykal-Amur RR Trunk Line (BAM) and also for large areas of the Baykal-Okhotsk and Lesser Caucasus regions.

TITLE: Calculation of two-phase dispersed droplet-in-vapor flows including normal shock waves
AUTHORS: Comfort, III, W J; Alger, T W; Giedt, W H; Crowe, C T
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; TURBINES; TWO-PHASE FLOW; DROPLETS; MASS TRANSFER; NOZZLES; ONE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; SHOCK WAVES; STEADY-STATE CONDITIONS; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; VELOCITY; FLUID FLOW; MACHINERY; PARTICLES; TURBOMACHINERY; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: A method for calculating quasi-one-dimensional, steady-state, two-phase dispersed droplet-in-vapor flow has been developed. The technique is applicable to both subsonic and supersonic single component flow in which normal shock waves may occur, and is the basis for a two-dimensional model. The flow is assumed to be inviscid except for droplet drag. Temperature and pressure equilibrium between phases is assumed, although this is not a requirement of the technique. Example calculations of flow in one-dimensional nozzles with and without normal shocks are given and compared with experimentally measured pressure profiles for both low quality and high quality two-phase steam-water flow.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Fluids Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 100:3

TITLE: Volcanic steam would run Hawaii Manganese plant
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ORE PROCESSING; HAWAII; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; LOCAL GOVERNMENT; METAL INDUSTRY; NOISE; PILOT PLANTS; POWER GENERATION; PROCESSING; PUBLIC OPINION; SITE SELECTION; STATE GOVERNMENT; STEAM; US DOE; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; HEATING; INDUSTRY; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; US ORGANIZATIONS; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150700* - Geothermal Energy- Products & By-Products; 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: A consortium in Hawaii has submitted a proposal to DOE for using volcanic steam as an energy source in a new plant that will treat manganese nodules mined from the ocean floor. The consortium plans to spend $3.2 million over three years to build the plant at a proven geothermal site. Only one ton of nodules per day will be treated in the pilot plant. Steam from the well will generate electricity to prepare the metals for extraction, while hot brine will be tapped for direct steam use. Condensate will be used in the processing also and cooled brine will be used for slurry transport of nodules and waste water. The wellhead steam pressure of 1000 pounds will emit considerable noise. Private businesses have expressed interest, although there are no commercial facilities planned at present. Seabed mining combined with geothermal power is expected to become commercially attractive as Congress establishes policies for developing ocean mining techniques. Support for the project has come from both the state and local governments and the populace.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:33

TITLE: Developments in Four Corners--Intermountain area in 1977
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ARIZONA; WELL DRILLING; COLORADO; NEVADA; NEW MEXICO; PETROLEUM INDUSTRY; UTAH; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; NATURAL GAS WELLS; OIL WELLS; DRILLING; INDUSTRY; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 020200* - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 030200 - Natural Gas- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 150303 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging
DESCRIPTION: Total drilling in the Four Corners--Intermountain area during 1977 increased 84% from 1976. The increase was mostly in development drilling, particularly in the Mesaverde infill drilling in the San Juan basin. Exploratory drilling decreased in southwestern Colorado and western New Mexico, but was up sharply in Utah and Nevada. Exploration in the overthrust belt of Utah was very active with 3 new-field discoveries being made. The Trap Spring oil discovery in Nevada accelerated both exploratory and development drilling in that state. Success rates of 18.9 and 92.3% for exploratory and development wells, respectively, were higher than in 1976. Leasing was heavy in parts of Utah and Nevada and fillings were made on over 4 million acres of state leases in Arizona. Geothermal exploration continued in western New Mexico and southwestern Utah with an agreement being made to construct a geothermal plant at Roosevelt Hot Springs in Utah. It is anticipated that both exploratory and development activity will remain high and most probably will increase in 1978. 1 figure, 2 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: El Paso Natural Gas Co., TX
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 62:8
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Developments in West Coast area in 1977
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; WELL DRILLING; OREGON; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; RESERVES; DATA COMPILATION; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PETROLEUM INDUSTRY; DATA; DRILLING; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; INDUSTRY; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL DATA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; RESOURCES; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 020200* - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 150303 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging
DESCRIPTION: West Coast exploration accelerated in 1977, except in Washington where no wells were reported completed by year end. One significant oil discovery was made onshore in California on the west side of the San Joaquin Valley. Two additional discoveries were made offshore in the Santa Barbara Channel, 1 oil and 1 gas. These were reported by the media, but are not reflected in CSD statistics. Additions to reserves in California outstripped production by 45 million bbl in 1977. Development activity increased in California and was concentrated in shallow drilling relating largely to steam-flood projects. Geothermal activity included the possible discovery of a new resource area in Inyo County, California. Development drilling continued at The Geysers and in Imperial Valley. The Geysers capacity will be raised to 908,000 kW over the next few years. Two 50-MW plants are being planned for the Heber area in Imperial Valley. 4 figures, 3 tables.
RESEARCH_ORG: Chevron U.S.A. Inc., San Francisco, CA
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 62:8
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Analysis of airborne spectroradiometric data and the use of Landsat data for mapping hydrothermal alteration
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; AERIAL SURVEYING; NEVADA; INFRARED SPECTRA; LANDSAT SATELLITES; MAPS; MINERALIZATION; NEAR INFRARED RADIATION; VISIBLE RADIATION; VISIBLE SPECTRA; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; INFRARED RADIATION; NORTH AMERICA; RADIATIONS; SATELLITES; SPECTRA; USA; WESTERN REGION; 510100* - Environment, Terrestrial- Basic Studies- (-1989); 152003 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: An airborne spectroradiometer system has been developed to take 500-channel ground target measurements simultaneously in the spectral region between 400 and 1100 nm. Survey flights with the instrument over an exposed hydrothermal alteration zone in Gold-field, Nevada provide the high-spectral resolution and spatially correlated data necessary to establish a computerized technique for spectral discrimination of limonitic zones that could indicate mineralization. The data generated by the airbonre system are used, in particular, to determine the spectral properties of alteration materials as they appear in integrated measurements over extended field areas, to determine which spectral properties are unique under field conditions and will remain unique in the low-spectral resolution Landsat data, and to determine accurately the nature and magnitude of the relative spectral differences among geologic targets under the broadband configuration. Field measurements from the aircraft are spatially integrated over contiguous 18 m square fields-of-view along traverses flown to cover both background and altered rock assemblages. A small spectral signal unique to zones enriched in ferric iron minerals is recoverable in the aircraft data. Based on a differential spectral discriminant, a computer-compatible method has been devised to extract the ferric iron signal from atmospheric and background terrain and geologically induced variations in Landsat data. 8 figures.
RESEARCH_ORG: Goddard Space Flight Center, New York, NY
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 43:5

TITLE: Microearthquake survey in the Gerlach-Fly Ranch area of northwestern Nevada
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NEVADA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; SEISMIC SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; MICROEARTHQUAKES; SEISMIC P WAVES; SEISMICITY; EARTHQUAKES; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC EVENTS; SEISMIC WAVES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: In the Black Rock Desert, during a 30-day monitoring period, a microearthquake swarm lasting 18 hours occurred in a localized (3 by 3 km in plan) zone of intense fracturing (3 to 7 km deep). Fault plane solutions indicate reactivation of dormant trends and a discordance with regional trends. Teleseismic P-wave delays do not indicate a local magma chamber; rather, they indicate a shallow low velocity zone near the Granite Range.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Geothermal study of the southwest part of the Black Rock Desert and its geothermal areas; Washoe, Pershing, and Humboldt Counties, Nevada
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; HOT SPRINGS; GEOTHERMOMETRY; NEVADA; ACID CARBONATES; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CHLORIDES; GROUND WATER; HIGH TEMPERATURE; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; METEORIC WATER; ORIGIN; PH VALUE; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SILICA; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SULFATES; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; THERMAL WATERS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MINERALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; THERMAL SPRINGS; USA; WATER; WESTERN REGION; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Several hydrothermal systems were explored in northwestern Nevada in parts of Washoe, Pershing, and Humboldt Counties. These hydrothermal systems included the Great Boiling springs and Mud springs at Gerlach, the Fly Ranch hot springs in Hualapai Flat, Double Hot and Black Rock springs at the southern end of the Black Rock Range, Trego hot spring, Soldier Meadows hot springs, and hot springs at Pinto Mt., at Pyramid Lake Needles region, and in the San Emidio and Smoke Creek Deserts. Thermal and nonthermal groundwater was analyzed to determine the water quality of the various hot spring regions. Water discharged from the hot springs of Trego, Gerlach, San Emidio and Smoke Creek Deserts, and Pyramid Lake Needles area is classified as Na--Cl. This water is characterized by high values of Na/sup +/, Cl/sup -/, HCO/sub 3//sup -/, and SiO/sub 2/ and is neutral in pH. Water discharged from the hot springs of Soldier Meadows, Pinto Mt., Double Hot springs, and Fly Ranch hot springs is classified as Na--HCO/sub 3/. This water is similar to the nonthermal water of these areas, and probably represents circulation of meteoric water near a heat source, with very little addition of magma-derived fluids. The similarities of the trilinear plots of the chemical quality of nonthermal and thermal waters suggest the origin of the thermal waters is deep circulation of meteoric water with the addition of some connate water. Based on the use of the silica, Na/K, and Na--K--Ca geothermometers, the Great Boiling springs at Gerlach appears to be the most promising geothermal prospect in the study area. The sub-surface temperature calculated for this area was 175 to 200/sup 0/C. The springs along the eastern edge of the San Emidio Desert have the greatest potential for yielding commercial geothermal fluids based on a geochemical temperature of 216/sup 0/C. Hualapai Flat (Fly Ranch) contains a large number of hot springs, but temperatures of the reservoir based on geochemistry ranged from 125 to 155/sup 0/C.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Reflection seismic traverse across Black Rock Desert and Hualapai Flat, Nevada
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NEVADA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; SEISMIC SURVEYS; CENOZOIC ERA; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MAPPING; STRATIGRAPHY; VOLCANIC ROCKS; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGIC AGES; GEOLOGY; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: During May 1975, a seismic reflection survey was carried out along a traverse across the Black Rock Desert and Hualapai Flat in Pershing and Washoe Counties, Nevada. The purpose was to obtain a profile of the bedrock surface, the thickness of various stratigraphic units, the faulting style, and structure along the traverse. The results indicate a typical Basin and Range style of faulting. The section above high velocity bedrock probably consists entirely of Cenozoic rocks.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Well site safety at the Geysers
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; SITE SELECTION; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; WELL DRILLING; REGULATIONS; BLOWOUTS; EQUIPMENT; FAILURES; LANDSLIDES; SAFETY; STATE GOVERNMENT; ACCIDENTS; DRILLING; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; WELLS; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware; 150905 - Geothermal Engineering- Control Systems
DESCRIPTION: It is pointed out that the four well blowouts occurring at the Geysers between 1957 and 1975 were caused by mass earth movement at the well site, insufficiently cased wellbores in incompetent or hydrothermally altered rock, and equipment failure. California siting and drilling regulations that assist in the safe and efficient development of geothermal resources are summarized. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Calif. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 31:7

TITLE: Geology and slope stability in the Geysers
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GEOLOGY; STABILITY; EARTHQUAKES; EROSION; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GROUND SUBSIDENCE; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; LANDSLIDES; MINES; RESERVOIR ROCK; SITE SELECTION; SOILS; SOLID WASTES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; ROCKS; SEISMIC EVENTS; WASTES; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Geologic features of the Geysers GRA as related to the stability of Franciscan terrain were studied. Although the Franciscan assemblage is generally unstable under natural conditions, there are several geologic features within the Geysers GRA that may be relatively favorable to site stability. These are competent formational units, ridge tops, flat ground, competent masses of rock in sheared melange matrix, and naturally buttressed landslides. Geologic features that could pose problems to site stability include landslides, erosion, sheared melange matrix, hydrothermally altered rock, unfavorably dipping bedding plants, faults and shear zones, sheared serpentinite, mines and mine tailings, subsidence, and expansive soils. Other factors and processes affecting slope stability are earthquake shaking, surface and ground water, vegetation, and human activities related to road, power plant, and well pad construction. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Calif. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 31:7

TITLE: Probes developed for high temperature, corrosive geothermal power plants
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 47 OTHER INSTRUMENTATION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; PROBES; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; CORROSION; CORROSION RESISTANCE; ELECTRIC COILS; ELECTRIC PROBES; ELECTRODES; HIGH TEMPERATURE; ION PROBES; SCALING; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; WATER CHEMISTRY; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; ELECTRICAL EQUIPMENT; EQUIPMENT; FLUIDS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development; 440300 - Miscellaneous Instruments- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Researchers at Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratories are developing a package including high temperature reference electrode, redox potential, conductivity, pH, corrosivity and specific ion probes to measure aspects of water chemistry in order to predict corrosion and scaling in geothermal equipment. Success has been reported with a reference electrode and conductivity probe which should be capable of withstanding corrosive 250/sup 0/C fluids. One of the major problems faced was the development of a flexible, electrically insulating seal that could withstand high temperatures without the deficiencies of Teflon and Rulan. The Ag/AgCl electrode is reversible at temperatures up to at least 120/sup 0/C. A salt bridge protects the electrode from species in the geothermal fluids that could disturb the poential, and an insulating shell keeps out H and H/sub 2/S. The electrodeless conductivity probe consists of two toroidally wound coils, one driven by a pulsing DC voltage and one acting as a receiver. The current induced between the two coils is proportional to the conductivity of the medium. There is a break in the circuit, a 0.004 in. air gap between the spool and support ring, which prevents the electromagnetic field made by the driven coil from coupling through the probe case to the receiver coil and short circuiting the device.
RELATION: Journal Name: Instrum. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 25:7

TITLE: Geology of the Gerlach--Hualapai Flat geothermal area, northwestern Nevada
AUTHORS: Grose, L T; Sperandio, R J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT SPRINGS; HYDROLOGY; NEVADA; GEOLOGY; ALLUVIAL DEPOSITS; ANDESITES; BASALT; CAP ROCK; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; GRANITES; GRANODIORITES; HEAT FLOW; NATURAL CONVECTION; QUATERNARY PERIOD; RHYOLITES; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; TERTIARY PERIOD; TRIASSIC PERIOD; VOLCANIC ROCKS; CENOZOIC ERA; CONVECTION; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGIC AGES; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; MESOZOIC ERA; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; THERMAL SPRINGS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The 500-square mile (1,280 square km) area around Gerlach and Hualapai Flat in northwestern Nevada includes Permo-Triassic metavolcanic and metasedimentary rocks disposed as roof pendants in Cretaceous granodiorite, Late Oligocene-Early Miocene rhyolitic, andesitic, and basaltic sequences, and Pliocene (.) and Quaternary alluvial and lacustrine sediments. The volcanic activity is far too old (23 my) to act as a source of heat in the area. Metasedimentary, granitic, volcanic, and alluvial clastic rocks may act as geothermal reservoirs. Thick lacustrine clays and alluvial-fluvial sediments as well as thick tuffaceous units have strong thermal insulating or cap rock properties. The location of the Gerlach hot springs is controlled by quasiradial spreading effected by contemporaneous activity on intersecting major regional normal faults. The location of Fly Ranch hot springs is also fault controlled and in addition is associated with modern tectonic rifting. Geothermal convection systems occur in the area, not by virtue of volcanic heating, but by trapping high regional heat flow beneath thermally insulating layers and by creating and maintaining open fractures by recurrent tensional tectonic activity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Geothermal resources of Japan
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; EVALUATION; JAPAN; ENTHALPY; GEOLOGIC FORMATIONS; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; NATURAL STEAM; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; THERMAL WATERS; VOLCANIC REGIONS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; ASIA; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RESOURCES; ROCKS; STEAM; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 150202* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989); 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Characteristics of geothermal resources of Japan are summarized with special attention given to their geological distributions. Japan has four potential types of geothermal resources: natural dry steam, high-enthalpy thermal water in volcanic areas; low-enthalpy thermal water in sedimentary basins in non-volcanic regions; hot dry rock; and volcanic heat. Among these, the high-enthalpy thermal water in volcanic areas is of the greatest interest at present because most of Japanese geothermal resources are distributed in a big volcano-tectonic depressed region which was formed in the Miocene period. The depressed region is filled mainly with Neogene tertiary volcanic rocks in thicknesses of one or two kilometers and overlain by the clusters of volcanic cones of Quaternary age. Such a structure is apparently conducive to the formation of high-enthalpy thermal water which requires a reservoir structure and a sufficient supply of heat and water. National reserves of the natural dry steam and high-enthalpy thermal water, which may be utilized for commercial power generation, are calculated to be more than ten million kW for at least a thousand years taking into account only production wells not deeper than 1.5 km. It is demonstrated that prospecting hereafter should be focused on the deeply seated geothermal resources which may occur in pre-Miocene fractured sedimentary rocks hidden beneath the Miocene volcanic rocks of the Neogene volcano-tectonic depressed area in Japan. 39 references.
RESEARCH_ORG: Geological Survey of Japan, Kawasaki-shi, Japan
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dev. Jpn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:1

TITLE: Gravity survey of Hualapai Flat and the southern part of Black Rock Desert, Nevada
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NEVADA; GRAVITY SURVEYS; DIAGRAMS; GEOLOGIC MODELS; GEOLOGY; GRANODIORITES; MAPPING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: During May and June 1975, a gravity survey was carried out along a series of traverses crossing the southern part of the Black Rock Desert and Hualapai Flat. Values for the free-air gravity anomaly were computed, with the effect of low-density alluvium being removed. The free-air gravity is close to zero over most of the survey area, indicating that the area was in complete isostatic compensation prior to development of the alluvial-filled graben structures, and that readjustment to these late tectonic elements has not taken place. Depths to basement computed from the gravity profiles are 1 to 2 km. Close agreement was obtained from such calculations and depths to bedrock derived from a seismic reflection survey along one traverse where both methods were used.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Analysis of thermal infrared imagery of the Black Rock Desert geothermal area
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; INFRARED THERMOGRAPHY; NEVADA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; HOT SPRINGS; LITHOLOGY; FRACTURES; GEOLOGIC FISSURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; IMAGES; THERMAL WATERS; EXPLORATION; FAILURES; MATERIALS TESTING; NONDESTRUCTIVE TESTING; NORTH AMERICA; TESTING; THERMAL SPRINGS; THERMAL TESTING; THERMOGRAPHY; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Thermal infrared scanner imagery was flown over the Black Rock Desert area of Nevada to inventory known geothermal features and to detect unknown thermal effluents. Predawn flights produced imagery that shows all of the known thermal features, as well as many unreported hot springs. In addition to direct sensing of hot springs, the thermal imagery yields useful information on related fractures that may determine the discharge pattern of the thermal waters.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Late quaternary tectonic controls of occurrence of geothermal systems in Gerlach--Hualapai Flat area, northwestern Nevada
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT SPRINGS; HYDROLOGY; NEVADA; TECTONICS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; RIFT ZONES; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; THERMAL SPRINGS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Gerlach hot spring system is localized by the intersection of three major and one minor concurrently active normal fault zones which effect quasiradial spreading. The Fly Ranch hot spring system is localized mainly by Late Holocene and historic faulting and rifting along a north-south normal fault zone where it is believed to intersect older fault zones. Late Quaternary deformational features occur abundantly in the region. Extension of these features within fracturable rocks beneath thermally insulating layers may point up locations of hidden geothermal reservoirs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Ground temperature survey
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NEVADA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; SOILS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; SEASONAL VARIATIONS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; EXPLORATION; NORTH AMERICA; USA; VARIATIONS; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Two temperature surveys were carried out in the Hualapai Flat area in northwestern Nevada with measurements taken in 1-meter-deep holes. One survey was made in January, the other in June. Temperature differences of 10/sup 0/C, caused by seasonal variations in air temperature and the thermal diffusivity of the soil, were observed between the two sets of measurements. An obvious anomaly in temperature was found along a linear zone extending 2 miles (3.2 km) northward from the Fly Ranch hot springs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Preliminary study of hydrothermal alteration associated with hot spring activity, Gerlach area
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GRANODIORITES; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NEVADA; HOT SPRINGS; ROCK-FLUID INTERACTIONS; SILICA; THERMAL WATERS; CHALCOGENIDES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; MINERALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; ROCKS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; THERMAL SPRINGS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 152003 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: Alteration of surficial rocks by thermal waters is a phenomenon that may be used to study and understand subsurface geothermal systems. At Gerlach, Nevada, present hot springs occur along fault scarps in recent valley alluvium. In general, alteration is that to be expected when hot, slightly acid, aqueous solutions come in contact with rocks of granodiorite composition. Silicification is widespread in alteration, indicating silica has been introduced. However, this silica need not have a deep-seated source, but could have been derived locally. No limits can be placed on temperatures of the altering solutions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Colo. Sch. Mines; (United States); Journal Volume: 73:3

TITLE: Enthalpies of solution of some salts in water
AUTHORS: Montgomery, R L; Melaugh, R A; Lau, C C; Meier, G H; Grow, R T; Rossini, F D
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CESIUM BROMIDES; ENTHALPY; CESIUM CHLORIDES; CESIUM IODIDES; LITHIUM CARBONATES; RUBIDIUM CHLORIDES; ALCOHOLS; AMINES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; WATER; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; BROMIDES; BROMINE COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CESIUM COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROXY COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC PHOSPHORS; IODIDES; IODINE COMPOUNDS; LITHIUM COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHOSPHORS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; RUBIDIUM COMPOUNDS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: Using the apparatus and procedure described in a recent report, with the energy equivalent of the calorimeter system determined with standard substances, enthalpies of solution in water at 298.15 K were measured for the following salts, as ..delta..H in kJ mol/sup -1/: RbCl(c), in 1500 mol of H/sub 2/O, 17,225 +- 0.019; CsCl(c), in 800 mol of H/sub 2/O, 17.438 +- 0.014; CsBr(c), in 900 mol of H/sub 2/O, 26.146 +- 0.043; CsI(c), in 1500 mol of H/sub 2/O, 33.239 +- 0.030; Li/sub 2/CO/sub 3/(c), in 725 mol of H/sub 2/O, -14.800 +- 0.021. 8 tables, 5 figures.

TITLE: Regional geophysical setting of the Rio Grande rift
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; RIO GRANDE RIFT; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; HEAT FLOW; AERIAL SURVEYING; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GRAVITY SURVEYS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; MAPS; SEISMICITY; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 580200 - Geophysics- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Rio Grande rift encompasses uplifts of the southern Rocky Mountains and their southern extension as well as axial fault blocks. The rift widens irregularly southward from a narrow horst in Colorado into a broad collapsed vault, characterized by grabens, in southern New Mexico. Whether manifested by horsts or grabens, primarily extensional strain is involved which increases in magnitude southward. Extensional faulting along the rift occurred in Neogene to Quaternary time, but the rift follows an axis of Laramide, Pennsylvanian, and possibly earlier uplifts. Gravity gradients due to the low density of graben fill delineate major faults of the rift system, which show a gridded or en echelon pattern over distances of tens of kilometers. Aeromagnetic data show these faults to be aligned with basement structural grain. Zigzags hundreds of kilometers long in the trend of the rift may also be related to basement grain. Basement trends in the Colorado Plateau to the west seem to differ in direction from those in the High Plains to the east. Seismic data also show that the rift occurs in an area of transition between anomalous crustal and upper mantle structure typical of the Cordillera and crustal structure typical of the High Plains. Deep seismic data are sparse within the rift, but high heat flow, high elevation, high electrical conductivity, and both residual positive (shallow source) and negative (deep source) gravity anomalies suggest the presence of symmetrical anomalous crustal and upper-mantle structure along the axis of the rift. In the Socorro area, where the rift has been studied intensively, available data indicate relatively low compressional velocity, rapid Holocene uplift, and the presence of magma within the crust. In view of geomorphic evidence for widespread Holocene faulting, the seismicity of the rift is surprisingly low.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 89:7

TITLE: Hydrothermal alteration of basalts from Hawaii Geothermal Project Well-A, Kilauea, Hawaii
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BASALT; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; KILAUEA VOLCANO; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; MINERALOGY; AMPHIBOLE; CHLORITE MINERALS; HAWAII; LAVA; MONTMORILLONITE; PERMEABILITY; RIFT ZONES; STABILITY; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; VOLCANOES; WELL DRILLING; ZONES; CLAYS; DRILLING; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; MINERALS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions; 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Mineralogical examination of basaltic rocks obtained during drilling of a successful 1,962-m-deep geothermal well (HGP-A) in the east rift zone of Kilauea Volcano, Hawaii, reveals three zones of hydrothermal alteration beneath a zone of unaltered lavas. Each alteration zone is characterized by the dominance of a particular mineral: zone 1, montmorillonite; zone 2, chlorite; zone 3, actinolite. Three zones of relative permeability can be tentatively identified on the basis of filled versus partly filled vesicles and fractures. Because the well has not returned to thermal equilibrium as of this writing, stability relations between secondary minerals and temperatures cannot be calculated with accuracy. However, the latest downhole temperatures measured at the boundaries of alteration zones, compared with similar data from high-temperature geothermal areas in Iceland, indicate that HGP-A temperatures are considerably higher than those encountered for the same alteration-zone boundaries in Icelandic wells. This indicates that the present-day thermal regime in HGP-A is relatively young and that the hydrothermal minerals probably have not reached equilibrium with existing conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:7

TITLE: Steps in the development of commercial geothermal power generation
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ELECTRIC UTILITIES; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; COMMERCIALIZATION; CAPITAL; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; FINANCING; INVESTMENT; LOAD MANAGEMENT; PILOT PLANTS; PLANNING; POWER GENERATION; RELIABILITY; RESOURCE POTENTIAL; RISK ASSESSMENT; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; MANAGEMENT; POWER PLANTS; PUBLIC UTILITIES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: A plan for integrating geothermal resources into local utility planning and financing processes points out potential problem areas and recommends an approach that begins with smaller unit sizes to serve as a base for future development. Major constraints between the developer and the utility (including the large front-end field investment, reservoir guarantees, base-load reliability, resource utilization, and utility financing) justify the strategy of starting small in order to develop an equity market for financing geothermal capability. To do this, a new capital base must be designed that can coordinate a geothermal resource from wellhead to sale of power to the utility. The utility could then schedule the load requirements and plan financing accordingly. Several strategies for sharing the risks are outlined.
RELATION: Journal Name: Public Util. Fortn.; (United States); Journal Volume: 101:13

TITLE: Legal impediments to the development of the geopressured resource
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; EXPLOITATION; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LEASING; REGULATIONS; WELL SPACING; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The principal legal impediments which the author believes will be encountered in the development of pressurized water resources of the Gulf Coast are discussed. Uses suggested for the heated, pressurized water are as process heat in industrial and commercial operations, for generation of electricity directly, and for extraction of methane in sufficient quantities from the water. It is felt that, unlike exploitation of petroleum resources, the main problems will be encountered not in the exploration stage but after well completion and production begins. The geopressured well will produce large volumes of water and drain a very large area. These large volumes of water must be disposed after use. A legal dilemma resulting from study of the exploration and use of this resource is raised but not resolved. This dilemma concerns whether a decision on the extent of modification of existing leasing patterns and utilization or spacing provisions for wells should be made now on the basis of preliminary data concerning the resource development or whether the decision should be delayed until development of the resource has begun and a better understanng of the resource and problems related to its development are better understood. (BLM)
RELATION: Journal Name: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 20:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Interstate Oil Compact Comm. Com. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Numerical study of diffraction of plane elastic waves by a finite crack with application to location of a magma lens
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; KILAUEA VOLCANO; SEISMIC SURVEYS; MAGMA SYSTEMS; CRACKS; DIFFRACTION; HAWAII; SEISMIC P WAVES; SEISMIC S WAVES; WAVELENGTHS; COHERENT SCATTERING; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; SCATTERING; SEISMIC WAVES; USA; VOLCANOES; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Location, shape, and size of near-surface heterogeneities in the Earth may be determined by active or passive seismic diffraction experiments. An array of geophones would be set up to record near-field wave motion resulting from diffraction by the inhomogeneity. As an example of such inhomogeneities, the diffraction of plane P and S waves was studied by a finite two-dimensional crack as a function of wavelength and direction of incident wave. A method that can be used to solve for diffraction effects by empty and fluid-filled (zero viscosity) cracks was developed. The diffraction problem was solved using the finite difference scheme developed by Madariaga (1976) to study dynamic crack propagation problems. The results of the theoretical calculation are used to try to locate the edge of a magma lens in Kilauea Iki Crater, Hawaii. It was found that the ratio of vertical-to-horizontal displacement and the direction of rotation of initial particle motion measured by a seismic array located on the floor of the crater agree qualitatively with what the theory predicts. The edge of the magma found by this method shows excellent agreement with the one inferred from the distribution of seismic events originating in the crust of tha lava lake (Aki et al., 1977).
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Seismol. Soc. Am.; (United States); Journal Volume: 68:3

TITLE: Laminar throughflow of varying-quality steam between corotating disks
AUTHORS: Truman, C R; Rice, W; Jankowski, D F
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; STEAM; LAMINAR FLOW; STEAM TURBINES; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OPERATION; TWO-PHASE FLOW; WATER; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUID FLOW; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: A local analysis was made of the laminar throughflow between corotating disks of a Newtonian vapor containing liquid droplets. Such a flow is of practical interest in multiple-disk turbomachinery, and specifically is a model of a two-phase, single component flow (saturated vapor--saturated liquid steam) which would arise in geothermal applications of a multiple-disk turbine. Local mass conservation and momentum equations for the vapor and droplet fields were used, as well as mass conservation and energy equations for a single droplet. The vapor--droplet interaction was modeled by a drag force based on the well-known drag coefficients for flow past spheres. The governing equations were reduced to parabolic form by order-of-magnitude arguments to allow a marching-type solution. The nonlinear partial differential equations were replaced by nonlinear finite-difference equations, which were linearized. The resulting system of linear algebraic equations was solved directly. Various results are presented, including results for a set of flow parameters which are close to those applicable for multiple-disk turbines operating on geothermal steam.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Fluids Eng.; (United States); Journal Volume: 100:2

TITLE: Methane from below rises in priority
SUBJECT: 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NATURAL GAS; RECOVERY; TEXAS; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; BRINES; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; METHANE; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ALKANES; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY SYSTEMS; FEDERAL REGION VI; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; HYDROCARBONS; NORTH AMERICA; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; USA; 030300* - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 150700 - Geothermal Energy- Products & By-Products
DESCRIPTION: Next month, drilling equipment will start plumbing the depths of a sand and shale formation that lies 15,000 to 16,500 ft below ground in Brazoria County, Texas. The experiment, funded by DOE, is part of a DOE program to assess how much methane is dissolved in the geothermal brines of Texas and Louisiana, how much of it is recoverable and what technology should be used to exploit this resource. The hunt for geopressured methane, which will absorb a large chunk of the $17.1 million that DOE is spending this year on geothermal studies, is expected to answer vital questions on the size and economic value of the reserves. Existing data are inconclusive, and often based on different geographical premises. As a result, estimates of the amounts of recoverable gas vary widely.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 85:11

TITLE: Effect of molecular geometry on the electron affinity of water
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; WATER; BINDING ENERGY; BOND ANGLE; BOND LENGTHS; DIPOLE MOMENTS; GASES; GEOMETRY; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; MOLECULAR ORBITAL METHOD; MONOMERS; PHASE STUDIES; SURFACE ENERGY; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ENERGY; FLUIDS; FREE ENERGY; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATHEMATICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SURFACE PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: Using self-consistent-field molecular orbital methods with inclusion of diffuse atomic orbitals in the basis set, the potential energy surfaces of H/sub 2/O and H/sub 2/O/sup -/ gas-phase monomers have been studied as the HOH bond angle varies from 30 to 180/sup 0/ and as one OH bond length is stretched from its equilibrium value by up to 0.3 A. The potential surface of H/sub 2/O/sup -/ was found to be very close to that of H/sub 2/O at all points studied. In particular, the H/sub 2/O/sup -/ surface showed no local minima other than the absolute minimum which occurs at the same geometry as the minimum of the H/sub 2/O surface. H/sub 2/O/sup -/ is calculated to be slightly stable with respect to vertical electron detachment at geometries with an HOH bond angle of less than about 95/sup 0/ or at any angle if one OH bond length is stretched sufficiently. However, the calculated binding energy of the excess electron is so small in the Franck-Condon region (a maximum of about 10/sup -4/ eV) that calcuations not invoking the Born-Oppenheimer approximation would be required to determine whether H/sub 2/O/sup -/ is truly a stable species.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Phys. Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:9

TITLE: Vapor pressure measurements, thermodynamic parameters, and phase diagram for the system potassium oxide--silicon oxide at high temperatures
AUTHORS: Eliezer, N; Howald, R A; Marinkovic, M; Eliezer, I
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; POTASSIUM OXIDES; DECOMPOSITION; EVAPORATION; PHASE DIAGRAMS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; VAPOR PRESSURE; SILICA; ABSORPTION SPECTROSCOPY; ENTHALPY; EQUILIBRIUM; REACTION KINETICS; SAMPLE PREPARATION; SOLUTIONS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THERMODYNAMIC ACTIVITY; VAPORIZATION HEAT; VERY HIGH TEMPERATURE; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; DIAGRAMS; DISPERSIONS; KINETICS; MINERALS; MIXTURES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SPECTROSCOPY; TRANSITION HEAT; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: Potassium oxide vaporizes from solutions in SiO/sub 2/ primarily according to the equation: KO/sub 0/./sub 5/(1) ..-->.. K(g) + /sup 1///sub 4/O/sub 2/(g) (1). We have studied this equilibrium using atomic absorption in a constant temperature graphite furnace to measure the absorbance of the steady-state distribution of potassium atoms. The potassium atoms were introduced at the center of the furnace by diffusion through an orifice in sample cells which we developed for vapor pressure measurement. We have shown both experimentally and theoretically that, at a particular temperature, the absorbance we measure is proportional to the rate of diffusion of potassium atoms from the vapor pressure sample cells. For a particular cell with a particular orifice, there is a temperature-dependent conversion factor between absorbance and pressure which we evaluated from measurements with potassium aluminate standards in the cells. The pressure of potassium atoms was measured over a sufficient range of temperature to obtain the heat of vaporization. The Redlich-Kister coefficients for the enthalpy of mixing of liquid KO/sub 0/./sub 5/ and SiO/sub 2/ (A = -86, B = -53 kcal mol/sup -1/) were obtained from this data and estimates for the thermodynamic properties of KO/sub 0/./sub 5/ (liquid), literature data on the enthalpy of glasses, the temperature dependence of rate of vaporization, and the variation of the activity of SiO/sub 2/ with temperature. Redlich-Kister coefficients for log ..gamma../sub KO/sub 0.5// were obtained from the concentration dependence of the vapor pressure of potassium over the KO/sub 0/./sub 5/-SiO/sub 2/ samples: A = -10.9923, B = -6.7801, and C = -1.0101 at 1500 K. From these values, together with the enthalpy coefficients above, activities of both KO/sub 0/./sub 5/ and SiO/sub 2/ can be calculated over a wide range of temperatures and compositions. The KO/sub 0/./sub 5/-SiO/sub 2/ phase diagram was calculated from these values. Thermodynamic quantities are given for tridymite and for two potassium silicates, K/sub 2/Si/sub 4/O/sub 9/ and K/sub 2/Si/sub 2/O/sub 5/.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Phys. Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:9

TITLE: Investigation of flow patterns of heat transfer agents in artificially fractured rock
AUTHORS: Shurchkov, A V; Prikhod'ko, N K; Zabarnyy, G N; Morozov, Yu P

TITLE: Biotite--apatite geothermometer revisited
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; APATITES; GEOTHERMOMETRY; BIOTITE; GEOTHERMOMETERS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; SOLID SOLUTIONS; THERMODYNAMICS; DISPERSIONS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MICA; MINERALS; MIXTURES; SOLUTIONS; THERMOMETERS; 152004* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Isotope & Trace Element Studies
DESCRIPTION: The proposed biotite--apatite geothermometer of Stormer and Carmichael (1971) is refined by taking the effect of octahedral cation substitution in biotite into account and by incorporating some new thermochemical data for the phases involved. For the reaction, biotite(F) + apatite(OH) reversible biotite(OH) + apatite(F), it is proposed that T(Kelvins) = 1100/log K*, where log K* = log (X/sub F//X/sub OH/)/sub ap/ + log (X/sub OH//X/sub F/)/sub bio/ - 1.107(X/sub annite/) - 1.444(X/sub siderophyllite/). These revisions lead to higher calculated temperatures.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Mineral.; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:5-6

TITLE: DOE explores soft path energy options for California by year 2025
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 13 HYDRO ENERGY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 17 WIND ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY POLICY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WESTERN REGION; 299000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 293000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Policy, Legislation, & Regulation; 130600 - Hydro Energy- Environmental Aspects; 140400 - Solar Energy- Environmental Aspects; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 170500 - Wind Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: California may provide the ultimate demonstration of the extent to which energy choices are inextricably entangled with environmental considerations. The Department of Energy funded a preliminary study that concluded that the state could get along in the year 2025 by developing and using energy technologies based on renewable resources within its own borders. The criteria selected for the energy forms were that they be environmentally gentle; be adaptable to local conditions, resources, and control; be more likely to fail gracefully than catastrophically; be resistant to malevolent actions; be comprehensible; and be matched in energy quality to end-use needs.
RELATION: Journal Name: Prof. Eng. (Wash., D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 48:5

TITLE: Aquifer chemistry of four high-temperature geothermal systems in Iceland
AUTHORS: Arnorsson, S; Groenvold, K; Sigurdsson, S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; SALINITY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; ICELAND; ANHYDRITE; CALCITE; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON DIOXIDE; CATIONS; DISTRIBUTION; ENTHALPY; EQUILIBRIUM; FLASHING; FLUORIDES; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; ION EXCHANGE; PH VALUE; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SAMPLING; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; TEMPERATURE EFFECTS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM CARBONATES; CALCIUM SULFATES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CARBONATES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHARGED PARTICLES; EUROPE; EVAPORATION; FLUIDS; FLUORINE COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; IONS; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SULFATES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; WELLS; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The deep water feeding wet-steam wells in four high-temperature geothermal areas in Iceland have highly variable salinity as reflected in the chlorine concentrations which vary from 20 to 19000 ppM. Using available values for equilibrium constants, the activities of 26 chemical species involving the major components of the reservoir water were calculated and quantitative evaluations of solute/solute, mineral/solute chemical equilibria in these geothermal systems were made. The unflashed reservoir water is just saturated with calcite. The saline geothermal waters, which represent heated sea-water, are just saturated with anhydrite, but the dilute waters, which are of meteoric origin, are somewhat undersaturated with this mineral. The fluoride mobility is thought to be limited by an ionic exchange reaction where F/sup -/ replaces some of the OH/sup -/ in the layered silicates. The pH of the unflashed reservoir water is governed by ionic exchange equilibrium in which all the major cations participate. At a given temperature it seems likely that the activity of one cation fixes the activities of all the other major cations and hydrogen ion. If this is so, and we take all the other chemical equilibria which have been demonstrated to exist for granted, it turns out that the major element composition of the unflashed high-temperature geothermal waters is controlled by two independent variables only. These variables are the temperature and the supply to the water of the incompatible element chlorine, incompatible indicating that this element is not incorporated in the geothermal minerals.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geochim. Cosmochim. Acta; (United States); Journal Volume: 42:5

TITLE: New geothermal regulations proposed by Interior Department
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; REGULATIONS; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; LICENSING; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Proposed regulations for the use of geothermal resources for the generation of electricity establishing a system for licensing electric power plant sites on geothermal resource leases are discussed. Highlights of various sections of the regulations, including environmental analysis, research and demonstration projects, lands not subject to application, term of license, and annual rental, are presented. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geyser; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:18

TITLE: Expanding Geysers
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; AIR POLLUTION; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY TRANSPORT; POWER RANGE 100-1000 MW; REVIEWS; DOCUMENT TYPES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal energy is one of the renewable energy sources available in the US - and in many parts of the world. The principal domestic source, now generating electricity from natural dry steam, is The Geysers, situated about 90 miles north of San Francisco. This 17,000-acre field began producing power back in 1960. By next year, 15 units will be generating 908 MW. Geologists and developers believe The Geysers has the potential for generating 2,000 MW - about 10% of PG and E's total system capacity.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 189:7

TITLE: Thermodynamic quantities for the ionization of water in sodium chloride media to 300/sup 0/C. [0 to 300/sup 0/C]
AUTHORS: Busey, R H; Mesmer, R E
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SODIUM CHLORIDES; WATER; IONIZATION; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; SATURATION; SOLUTIONS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: The thermodynamic quantities at the saturation pressure for the dissociation of water at rounded temperatures from 0 to 300/sup 0/C and ionic strengths to 5 m in NaCl media are presented in tabular form. The thermodynamic parameters were derived by computer from analytical expressions representing Q/sub w/ = (H/sup +/)(OH/sup -/) presented in an earlier paper. The small difference in the effect of NaCl over KCl on the ionization of water is briefly discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Eng. Data; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:2

TITLE: Volcanic structure of the crest of the Puna Ridge, Hawaii: geophysical implications of submarine volcanic terrain
AUTHORS: Fornari, D J; Malahoff, A; Heezen, B C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HAWAII; VOLCANISM; VOLCANOES; GEOMORPHOLOGY; ACOUSTIC MONITORING; GEOLOGIC FISSURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; HEAT FLOW; LAVA; POROSITY; SEA BED; VOLCANIC REGIONS; GEOLOGY; IGNEOUS ROCKS; MONITORING; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The morphology of submarine volcanic terrain on the crest of the Puna Ridge, Hawaii, was observed during two manned submersible dives in water depths of as much as 2,000 m. Steep-walled linear ridges 30 m high, trending 060/sup 0/, and composed of lava pillows and narrow fissures with the same strike were the principal volcanic features observed on the ridge crest. Lava tunnels, tubes, and pillows frequently were observed to be partially broken through, thereby exposing water-filled voids, which are inferred to be interconnected to great depths within the extrusive submarine volcanic pile. Low compressional wave velocities reported by other authors for the crustal layer composed of submarine volcanic extrusives and the low effective density of this layer, as determined from published surface gravity observations, are attributed to the large intraflow and interflow porosity of submarine volcanic terrain. Areal variations in heat flow through the crust of submarine volcanic features are also attributed to the high porosity and consequent permeability of submarine volcanic terrain which is likely to persist to the bottom of the submarine extrusive pile.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 89:4

TITLE: Specific heats of aqueous solutions of NaCl, NaBr, and KCl: comparisons with related thermal properties
AUTHORS: Tanner, J E; Lamb, F W
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; POTASSIUM CHLORIDES; SPECIFIC HEAT; SODIUM BROMIDES; SODIUM CHLORIDES; ACCURACY; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; QUANTITY RATIO; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THERMODYNAMICS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; BROMIDES; BROMINE COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: Earlier unpublished measurements of the specific heat capacities of aqueous NaCl, KCl, and NaBr solutons from 5 to 85/sup 0/C and from 0.05 m to saturation are presented. A twin calorimeter was used. A precision of nearly 1 part in 10/sup 4/ in the specific heat capacity is claimed. The results are compared with literature values (summaries or original data) for heat capacity, heat of dilution, and activity coefficient of these salts in solution by means of a polynomial in half-integer powers of molality and temperature. It is found that our values agree well with the more recent literature values of the heat capacities. Small systematic inconsistencies between the various types of data were found.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Solution Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 7:4

TITLE: Geothermal resources in Denmark
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; DENMARK; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOLOGIC FORMATIONS; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; STRATIGRAPHY; WELL DRILLING; DRILLING; EUROPE; EXPLORATION; RESOURCES; SCANDINAVIA; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; 150202* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Danish Embayment contains highly permeable aquifers of Upper Triassic age at temperatures between 80 and 100/sup 0/C, and at depths of 2000 to 3000 m. It should be possible to exploit the associated geothermal resources for district heating at prices lower than or of the same amount as for heat energy produced with oil as the energy source. Also Middle Jurassic and Lower Triassic strata contain warm aquifers of interest. The planned comprehensive investigations including deep drilling should give information on the actual exploitation possibilities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:3
