TITLE: Transport phenomena in hydrothermal systems: cooling plutons
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; FLUID FLOW; HEAT TRANSFER; PERMEABILITY; POROSITY; EARTH CRUST; EQUATIONS; MASS TRANSFER; ROCK-FLUID INTERACTIONS; ENERGY TRANSFER; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: The nature of heat and mass transport in plutonic environments has been described by partial differential equations and simulated by numerical approximation. A series of heuristic models based on these equations describes the general features of fluid circulation near an igneous intrusive body within the upper 10 km of the crust. Analysis indicates that fluid circulation is an inevitable consequence of magma emplacement. The magnitude of this circulation generates convective heat fluxes which predominate over conductive fluxes when host rock permeabilities exceed 1.0 nm/sup 2/. However, cooling rates for the pluton are not significantly shortened unless the pluton permeability is also greater than 1.0 nm/sup 2/. The geometries of circulation and isotherms are directly affected by variations in pluton size, depth, and permeability as well as permeability distribution in the host rock. The effect of fluid properties on heat and mass transport is striking. The style of circulation is controlled by coincident maxima of the isobaric thermal coefficient of expansion and heat capacity with the viscosity minima in the supercritical region of the H/sub 2/O system. Waters in intrusive systems are predicted to move several km in a few hundred thousand years. Temperature and pressure changes along the flowpaths produce changes in solvent properties. The fluid-rock interactions should generate diagnostic mineral assemblages and isotopic changes. Average fluid:rock mass ratios of 0.4 are realized over the permeable portions of the systems. The extent of circulation, and magnitude of convective heat flux over broad crustal regions and along plate boundaries may be much greater than suspected.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 277

TITLE: Transport phenomena in hydrothermal systems: the nature of porosity
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; FLUID FLOW; PERMEABILITY; POROSITY; EQUATIONS; FLOW RATE; FRACTURED RESERVOIRS; RESERVOIR ROCK; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; ROCKS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: The porosity (P) of rock is described by: P-total = P-flow + P-diffusion + P-residual. Experimental results show that P-total of fractured rock in hydrothermal systems ranges from 0.2 to 0.01, and P-diffusion ranges from 0.001 to 0.00001. Data from the literature and from field studies of fractures indicate that P-flow is 0.001-0.00001. Consequently, the greater part of P-total in plutonic environments results from residual pores which are not interconnected to P-flow or P-diffusion. Permeability is a function of the abundance and geometry of continuous flow paths. Observations suggest that a planar fracture is a good first order approximation for fractures in plutonic environments. Analysis of aperture, abundance, and continuity suggests that permeabilities on the order of 1.0 nm/sup 2/ may be characteristic of large portions of the crust. The model proposed permits definition of the interface between circulating hydrothermal fluids and reactant minerals in a manner consistent with the physical phenomena and partial differential equations which describe the processes of advection-diffusion-reaction.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 277

TITLE: Effects of subsurface boiling and dilution on the isotopic compositions of Yellowstone thermal waters
AUTHORS: Truesdell, A H; Nathenson, M; Rye, R O
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; THERMAL WATERS; ISOTOPE RATIO; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; BOILING; CHLORIDES; DEUTERIUM; HEAT FLOW; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; NATURAL STEAM; OXYGEN 18; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN ISOTOPES; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; NUCLEI; ODD-ODD NUCLEI; OXYGEN ISOTOPES; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PUBLIC LANDS; STABLE ISOTOPES; STEAM; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Studies of isotope hydrology of geothermal systems have generally emphasized deep circulation of meteoric water, demonstrated by constancy of deuterium contents, and an 'oxygen isotope shift' to higher oxygen 18 contents produced by water-rock reactions. However, subsurface boiling (in high-temperature systems) and dilution may cause deuterium (and oxygen 18) contents of hot spring and recharge waters to differ significantly. By using thermodynamic and isotopic fractionation data for water and steam the differences in chloride, oxygen 18, and deuterium between surface and deep thermal waters have been calculated for 'single-stage' (in which steam remains mixed with water and separates near a single temperature) and 'continuous' (in which steam is separated as it is formed) steam separation. Although changes in chloride concentration resulting from these processes are nearly identical, isotopic changes differ greatly. Single-stage steam separation from 250/sup 0/ to 95/sup 0/C results in increases in Cl, 10/sup 3/ ln ..delta../sup 18/O, and 10/sup 3/ ln ..delta..D(..delta..=(10/sup 3/+delta/sub surf/)/ (10/sup 3/+delta/sub deep/))) of 1.44 times, 1.75 0/00, and 9.1 0/00, respectively, whereas continuous steam separation results in increases of 1.41 times, 1.05 0/00, and 3.1 0/00. Because of these effects, deuterium contents of hot springs may be substantially higher than those of recharging waters, and part of the observed oxygen isotope shift may be due to boiling. The diverse compositions observed could result from boiling with 'multiple-stage' (intermediate between single-stage and continuous) steam separation of mixtures of a single deep thermal water (360/sup 0/C, 310 ppm Cl, and -149 0/00 deltaD) with cold dilute (5/sup 0/C, 2 ppm Cl) meteoric waters differing in deuterium according to locality (Norris, -142 0/00; Lower, -144 0/00; and Shoshone, -133 0/00). The recharge to the deep thermal water must be precipitation remote from the geyser basins or ancient precipitation from a colder period.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:26

TITLE: Geophysical surveys of Yellowstone Lake, Wyoming
AUTHORS: Otis, R M; Smith, R B; Wold, R J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; CALDERAS; DRILL CORES; MAGMA; SEDIMENTATION; SEDIMENTS; SEISMIC WAVES; TECTONICS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; PUBLIC LANDS; ROCKS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Reflection, refraction, and paleomagnetic data from Yellowstone Lake, Wyoming, were used to evaluate the Quaternary, tectonic, volcanic, and glacial history of this high mountain lake. Reflection data revealed a paleobasin beneath the main body of the lake containing up to 190 m of lake sediments deposited on intrusive or volcanic bedrock. Prominent reflectors are interpreted to correspond to glaciated layers, erosional surfaces developed during periods of desiccation, and sediments deposited during Recent lake impoundment by rhyolite flows. Volcanic units that outcrop at the south end of the lake are correlated with reflectors that plunge northward beneath the paleobasin, indicating at least 300 m of Recent subsidence of the Yellowstone caldera. Sedimentation rates of 10--13 cm/100 yr were deduced from paleomagnetic logs of shallow cores and suggest a maximum of 200,000 years of deposition within the paleobasin. Refraction data delineated a 1-km-deep, 5.0-km/s layer, interpreted as the top of a shallow crystalline intrusive or volcanic layer possibly associated with the Yellowstone caldera. A rapid decrease in the number of earthquakes occurring 4 km inside the geologically mapped caldera boundary corresponds to a zone of thermal gradients increasing from 200/sup 0/C/km to 800/sup 0/C/km and is interpreted to reflect the boundary of a deeper crustal structure, perhaps the edge of a cooling magma body. Contoured water depths obtained from high-resolution 7.5-kHz seismic reflection profiling provide a detailed bathymetric map of Yellowstone Lake.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geology and Geophysics, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah 84112
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:26

TITLE: Heat flow measurements in Yellowstone Lake and the thermal structure of the Yellowstone caldera
AUTHORS: Morgan, P; Blackwell, D D; Spafford, R E; Smith, R B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; HEAT FLOW; BOILING; CALDERAS; CHLORIDES; EARTHQUAKES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT LOSSES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; ENERGY LOSSES; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PUBLIC LANDS; SEISMIC EVENTS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Twenty-two marine-type heat flow determinations in Yellowstone Lake indicate a rapid transition from high heat flow values outside the Yellowstone caldera, 100--300 mW m/sup -2/ (2.5--7.5 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/ s/sup -1/), to an extensive area of very high heat flow, 600--700 mW m/sup -2/ (14.5 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/ s/sup -1/) and greater, within the caldera. The thermal transition occurs 5--10 km inside the mapped caldera boundary and approximately coincides with the point at which a zone of earthquake activity beginning outside the caldera terminates. Higher heat flow in West Thumb and Mary Bay (about 1600 mW m/sup -2/ (40 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/ s/sup -1/)) outlines two thermal subprovinces within the caldera. The conductive heat loss beneath the lake is similar in magnitude to the average convective heat loss calculated from chloride budgets. Extrapolated temperatures beneath the lake reach the boiling point under pressure at approximately 500-m depth, and deeper temperatures probably increase along the boiling point curve in a laterally extensive geothermal reservoir to depths of the order of 800 +- 400 m. Thermal areas in the park probably result from structurally and topographically controlled convection systems in this surficial system. A deeper, hotter fluid circulation system in fractures in the solidified granite postulated to underly the caldera at shallow depths (about 1 km) may exist at depth. The high heat flow is derived from a shallow cooling batholith beneath the caldera.
RESEARCH_ORG: Institute for the Study of Earth and Man, Southern Methodist University, Dallas 75275
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:26

TITLE: Yellowstone hot spot: Contemporary tectonics and crustal properties from earthquake and aeromagnetic data
AUTHORS: Smith, R B; Shuey, R T; Pelton, J R; Bailey, J P
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; TECTONICS; HOT SPOTS; MAGMA SYSTEMS; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; SEISMIC WAVES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; PUBLIC LANDS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: A compilation of aeromagnetic and new earthquake data is used to characterize the current tectonic activity and crustal properties of the Yellowstone hot spot. Earthquakes located during detailed surveys from 1972 to 1976 occurred west and northeast of the Yellowstone caldera along east-west zones and south of the caldera in north-south zones. The change in trend suggests that Yellowstone is at a vertex of the contemporary tectonic patterns. Seismicity showed variations of maximum focal depths from approx.20 km outside the Yellowstone caldera to approx.5 km inside the caldera. The frequency of earthquake occurrence was markedly lower within the caldera. Fault plane solutions showed general north-south extension west of the caldera, a suggestion of radial compression near the western caldera rim, and northeast to southeast extension south of the caldera. Spectral analyses of aeromagnetic data indicate the Curie isotherm to be 10 +- 3 km below sea level at the periphery of the caldera. These data support the hypothesis of a magma source within the crust for the Yellowstone hydrothermal activity, but they do not bear on the definition of a deep mantle source for the Yellowstone hot spot.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geology and Geophysics, University of Utah, Salt Lake City, Utah 84112
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:26

TITLE: Bathymetric and geophysical evidence for a hydrothermal explosion crater in Mary Bay, Yellowstone Lake, Wyoming
AUTHORS: Wold, R J; Mayhew, M A; Smith, R B
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; CRATERING EXPLOSIONS; DRILL CORES; HEAT FLOW; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; SEDIMENTS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; EXPLOSIONS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; PUBLIC LANDS; 580203* - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Results of continuous high-frequency seismic reflection profiler and towed magnetometer surveys of Mary Bay are presented. These data were taken, along with several piston cores and heat flow determinations, as part of a broader reconnaissance survey of Yellowstone Lake. The bathymetric data reveal an oval basin occupying the center of the bay, bounded by steep slopes. The southeastern slope appears to trend onshore, where steep bare scarps facing the lake are exposed near the north and east sides of the bay. The steep slope surrounding the basin in the bay corresponds to a change in character of the magnetic field. Broad smooth anomalies are found over the basin, and narrow high-amplitude anomalies over the surrounding platform. The center of the basin is occupied by deep narrow thermal basins having extremely rough local topography, where very high values of heat flow and sediment temperatures were measured. These data support the hypothesis that Mary Bay is the site of a submerged hydrothermal explosion crater similar to others onshore.
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Woods Hole, Massachusetts 02543
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:26

TITLE: Tapping nature's boiler room
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LEGAL ASPECTS; REVIEWS; USA; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; FORECASTING; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; IMPERIAL VALLEY; USES; CALIFORNIA; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WESTERN REGION; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989); 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Current estimates of the contribution of geothermal energy to the US energy supply by the year 2000 range from 1-12%. The United States Geological Survey estimates that reserves are sufficient to generate 12 GW of electricity for 30 years. Although the chief commercial trend in geothermal energy utilization is toward electrical power production, about 75% of the available resource base is suitable only for non-electrical applications. The efficiency of non-electrical uses can be about 50% however, as compared to 10% for power generation. Space heating is the most highly developed of the non-electrical uses, although many industrial applications could be developed. Most advanced of the electrical generation facilities in the US is the Geysers plant in California, presently generating 502 MW and expected to be producing 1.4 GW by 1985. The Imperial Valley in California is under investigation, and has been estimated to have a potential capacity of 3 GW. Research and development programs are being funded primarily through US ERDA, and include programs in drilling, life-span estimation, hardware development, and environmental impact assessment. The largest impediments to rapid development of the resource are considered to be institutional and legal, including ambiguous or contradictory regulations pertaining to land use, mineral, and water rights.
RELATION: Journal Name: Mach. Des.; (United States); Journal Volume: 49:20

TITLE: Few thoughts on pricing geothermal energy
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ELECTRIC POWER; CHARGES; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ECONOMICS; COST; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Various factors that enter into the pricing of geothermal energy from hot water reservoirs are discussed. It is concluded that there is no practical way to establish a price structure other than on the basis of mills per busbar kilowatt hour, subject to some requirements calling for the user to be efficient and to operate continuously. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:9

TITLE: Metallurgical evaluation of materials for geothermal power plant applications
AUTHORS: Toney, S; Cohen, M; Cron, C J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 36 MATERIALS SCIENCE; CORROSION RESISTANT ALLOYS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; TESTING; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; MATERIALS TESTING; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; STEAM TURBINES; CHLORIDES; CHROMIUM ALLOYS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COPPER ALLOYS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; MOLYBDENUM ALLOYS; NEW MEXICO; NICKEL ALLOYS; PH VALUE; PITTING CORROSION; STAINLESS STEELS; STEAM; STRESS CORROSION; STRESSES; VANADIUM ALLOYS; ALLOYS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; CORROSION; FLUIDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; IRON ALLOYS; IRON BASE ALLOYS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; STEELS; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development; 360105 - Metals & Alloys- Corrosion & Erosion
DESCRIPTION: The determination of the chemical composition of geothermal steam at a New Mexico site, development of a field test vehicle, and the evaluation of the effect of geothermal steam exposure on the corrosion, stress-corrosion cracking, and fatigue behavior of selected turbine and heat exchanger materials are reported. Corrosion rates for the turbine alloys are generally low and compare favorably with results obtained at Cerro Prieto and Wairakei. Compared with CrMoV, the Ni-containing steels, NiMoV and NiCrMoV, are not particularly susceptible to preferential corrosion along grain boundaries when exposed to separated steam. When tested as highly stressed U-bends, some of the 12Cr and Modified-12Cr martensitic stainless steels are susceptible to stress corrosion cracking, assumed to be caused by hydrogen sulfide; however, for materials of most interest there was no observed cracking at more meaningful stress levels. The occurrence of pitting in the martensitic stainless steels, particularly that caused by exposure to air in the absence of separated steam, causes a marked reduction in their fatigue endurance limits. Geothermal turbine shutdown procedures must be designed to avoid severe corrosion on exposure of the unit to air. The most commonly used 12Cr/Type 403 bucket alloy exhibited the smallest reduction in fatigue properties due to corrosion pitting. Separated steam at the New Mexico site was not particularly aggressive with respect to corrosion of the AgCuZnNi brazing alloy. Corrosion of the Cu-containing alloys is attributable to the presence of hydrogen sulfide as a contaminant in the separated steam. Alloys possessing the necessary corrosion resistance for heat exchanger applications are available. Corrosion product analyses confirm the important role of hydrogen sulfide and chloride in the corrosion and stress cracking behavior of the turbine alloys exposed to geothermal steam.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:9

TITLE: Utility inks hot brine power project pact. [San Diego G and E; for Imperial Valley, CA]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; PLANNING; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; BRINES; CORROSION; DEMONSTRATION PLANTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; EPRI; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; POWER GENERATION; PUBLIC UTILITIES; SALINITY; STATE GOVERNMENT; US ERDA; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: The first U.S. effort to use hot brine rather than steam for generating power will be made by the San Diego Gas and Electric Co. (SDG and E) with a $42 million, 45-MW binary-fluid demonstration plant scheduled for completion in 1980. Hot brine will be brought to the surface and the heat transferred to isobutane, which will expand into a gas to drive a turbine. A potential 1,000 to 5,000 MW is estimated to be available for exploitation in the Imperial Valley if the demonstration succeeds. The project was researched by Magma Power Co., with design work by Fluor Pioneer Corp., and will be funded by ERDA, the state Energy Commission, the Electric Power Research Institute, and several utilities. No claims are being made for competitive electricity costs from the geothermal plant, but the utilities will stress its nonpolluting features. Salinity in the area is lower than most geothermal brine and will lessen corrosion problems. Still unknown is whether the reinjected brine will reheat or whether it will cool the untapped brine. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:34

TITLE: Concentration dependence of correlation times from proton NMR relaxation in hydrous melts
AUTHORS: Girard, C; Braunstein, J; Bacarella, A L; Benjamin, B M; Brown, L L
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE; VISCOSITY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CALCIUM; MOLTEN SALTS; NITRATES; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; MAGNETIC RESONANCE; METALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESONANCE; SALTS; 152001* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: Proton spin--lattice relaxation times (T/sub 1/) for hydrous melts of Ca(NO/sub 3/)/sub 2/ containing 2.8, 4.0, 8.0, and 16.O moles H/sub 2/O/mole salt (55.5 to 2.32 moles H/sub 2/O/l) at temperatures between 290 and 390 K are analyzed in terms of intramolecular and intermolecular contributions. Rotational correlation times for water (tau/sub rot/) are estimated from the relaxation rates in the high temperature (narrow line) region using intermolecular correlation times (tau/sub inter/) estimated from melt viscosities or from diffusivities of protons or of dilute solute ions (Cd/sup 2 +/). The ratio tau/sub inter//tau/sub rot/ increases from about 2.5 in pure water to about 17 in the viscous melt Ca(NO/sub 3/)/sub 2/-2.8 H/sub 2/O, suggesting a much greater medium effect on translational than on rotational motion. An empirical relation was found that quantitatively correlates the dependence of the relaxation rate, varying over three orders of magnitude, with viscosity (or water diffusivity) and the volume concentration of water at all of the compositions and temperatures investigated.
RESEARCH_ORG: Chemistry Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Oak Ridge, Tennessee 37830
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Phys.; (United States); Journal Volume: 67:4

TITLE: Two-phase convection in a porous medium
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; CONVECTION; POROUS MATERIALS; TWO-PHASE FLOW; BOILING; POROSITY; STEAM; WATER; ENERGY TRANSFER; FLUID FLOW; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT TRANSFER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATERIALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 580100 - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The conditions for the onset of convection and the characteristics of the convection at the onset of instability are determined for a porous medium containing either a saturated liquid or a steam-water mixture. Convection is driven by a phase change instability mechanism. If steam and water are always in thermodynamic equilibrium, then temperature perturbations are directly responsible for pressure variations, which tend to move the fluid against the frictional resistance of the medium to flow. Mass conservation insures that any horizontal divergence of fluid is balanced by an appropriate vertical motion, while condensation and boiling occur to achieve a balance of forces in the vertical. Convection occurs more readily in a porous medium containing saturated liquid by the phase change instability than it would in a porous layer filled with ordinary water by the Rayleigh-Benard buoyancy-driven instability. Porous layers with steam-water mixtures are also more susceptible to convection than are those containing ordinary water. Phase-change-driven convection is concentrated toward the bottom of the porous layer; the cells are narrow in comparison to their depth.
RESEARCH_ORG: Space Sciences Laboratory, Ivan A. Getting Laboratories, Aerospace Corporation, Los Angeles, California 90009
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:23

TITLE: Developments in Four Corners--Intermountain area in 1976
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ARIZONA; NATURAL GAS WELLS; OIL WELLS; COLORADO; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; WELL DRILLING; WELL COMPLETION; NEVADA; NEW MEXICO; UTAH; EXPLORATION; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; DRILLING; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 020300* - Petroleum- Drilling & Production; 030300 - Natural Gas- Drilling, Production, & Processing; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware
DESCRIPTION: Total drilling in the Four Corners-Intermountain area during 1976 decreased from that of 1975. The decrease was mostly in development drilling with a lesser decrease in exploratory drilling. On an individual basis, Arizona and Nevada recorded increases in exploratory drilling and the second oil field was discovered in Nevada. Success rates of 14% and 85.2% for exploratory and development wells were less than in 1975. Leasing activity was heavy in the eastcentral part of Nevada and extended into western Utah. Geothermal leasing and exploration were active in Utah and New Mexico. It is anticipated that both exploratory and development activity will increase in 1977.
RESEARCH_ORG: El Paso Natural Gas Co., TX
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 61:8

TITLE: Reykjavik district heating
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL HEATING SYSTEMS; ICELAND; GEOTHERMAL DISTRICT HEATING; COST; DISTRIBUTION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; PUMPING; REGULATIONS; THERMAL INSULATION; DISTRICT HEATING; EUROPE; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEATING; HEATING SYSTEMS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: The number of inhabitants of Reykjavik and its suburbs benefiting from geothermal heating are 109,829 living in 15,614 homes and apartments or 97.1 percent of the population of the city. Converted into units of energy, the sales of hot water in 1976 corresponded to 1840 GWh, which is equivalent to burning some 1.1 million barrels of fuel oil. Discussion is centered on production from wells in the Reykin and Reykajahlid field, the distribution system, insulation, and regulations and price. It is pointed out that the savings to district heating customers is 25 to 30 percent when compared to fuel oil costs. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:1

TITLE: Developments in West Coast area in 1976
SUBJECT: 02 PETROLEUM; 03 NATURAL GAS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; WELL DRILLING; OREGON; WASHINGTON; EXPLORATION; STATISTICS; DRILLING; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; MATHEMATICS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; RESOURCES; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 020200* - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 030200 - Natural Gas- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: West Coast exploration continued at about the same pace as in 1975. The only exception was in Oregon, where no wells were drilled for oil or gas. No significant oil or gas discoveries were made in the California onshore. A major oil field may have been discovered in the southern California outer continental shelf. Geothermal development at The Geysers continued to expand the area of production. An additional 271,000 kW of generating capacity is under construction. When completed, generating capacity at The Geysers will be 773,000 kW.

SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; WASTE DISPOSAL; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; EVAPORATION; GROUND WATER; LAND POLLUTION; LINERS; LIQUID WASTES; PERMEABILITY; PONDS; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MANAGEMENT; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; POLLUTION; WASTE MANAGEMENT; WASTES; WATER; 150600* - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Reinjection of geothermal brines is considered the most desirable method of disposal. Until reinjection technology is further developed, disposal to evaporation or sedimentation ponds (lined or unlined) is a major method. Lagoon design is mentioned briefly. The deterioration of synthetic liners is pictured and discussed. The possibility of the chemical matrix of the effluents providing a natural, impermeable liner through the precipitation of elements from the liquids is described. (MHR)

TITLE: Geothermal heat for Presbyterian Intercommunity Hospital and Klamath County Nursing Home
AUTHORS: Howard, R L; Hubbard, K; Rosecrans, D
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL HEATING SYSTEMS; OPERATION; HOSPITALS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; DIAGRAMS; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; OREGON; PIPES; PUMPS; VALVES; BUILDINGS; CONTROL EQUIPMENT; FLOW REGULATORS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEATING; HEATING SYSTEMS; MEDICAL CENTERS; NORTH AMERICA; SPACE HEATING; USA; WELLS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The geology and hydrology of the Klamath Falls area is discussed briefly. The geothermal heating system which serves the Presbyterian Intercommunity Hospital and the Klamath County Nursing Home is shown in photographs and schematic drawing. The system consists basically of a well, settling tank, various heat exchangers, pumps, piping, and controls to move the water. From the heat exchangers system water is pumped to the terminal units, where it is used for space heating, domestic hot water, and a glycol snow melting system. The operation of the various parts of the system is described. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:8

TITLE: Geopressured geothermal resources of Texas
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; LEGAL ASPECTS; TEXAS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GROUND WATER; LAWS; OWNERSHIP; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NORTH AMERICA; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; RESOURCES; USA; WATER; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A comprehensive legal research project was proposed to examine the complex legal-regulatory framework within which any development of these geopressured resources would have to occur. As a first step in the proposed research, legal issues affecting ownership of the geopressured resources were examined. The results of that examination are reported as a possible aid in early resolution of a threshold issue for orderly resource development: ownership of the resource and ways of establishing ownership. Topics covered are: statutory resource definition, judicial theories of ownership, an analysis of ownership issues for Texas resources, and royalty considerations. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:8

TITLE: Geothermal prospecting in The Geysers-Clear Lake area, northern California
AUTHORS: Goff, F E; Donnelly, J M; Thompson, J M; Hearn, Jr, B C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; THERMAL WATERS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; GEOCHEMISTRY; BOREHOLES; CALIFORNIA; CHLORIDES; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; FLOW RATE; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMOMETRY; MAPS; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; SILICA; VAPOR-DOMINATED SYSTEMS; VOLCANIC REGIONS; CAVITIES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMISTRY; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MINERALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys; 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The geochemistry of thermal waters combined with mapping and geophysical studies have been used to define boundaries of the geothermal steam field in The Geysers-Clear Lake area, California. Chemical geothermometry and drill hole data imply that a 200/sup 0/C hot-water geothermal system underlies much of the 2.0 to 0.01-m.y.-old Clear Lake Volcanics. Chloride concentrations and electrical resistivity define the concealed extent of Great Valley sedimentary rocks underlying the young volcanic cover. It is suggested that the 80 or more vents in the volcanic field act as permeable conduits for water recharge and thus prevent creation of a widespread vapor-dominated system northeast of the Collayomi fault zone.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:8

TITLE: VES dipole--dipole filter coefficients
SUBJECT: 47 OTHER INSTRUMENTATION; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; RESISTIVITY LOGGING; DATA ANALYSIS; DIGITAL FILTERS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GROUND WATER; ELECTRIC LOGGING; EXPLORATION; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; WATER; WELL LOGGING; 440400* - Well Logging Instrumentation; 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The conversion of sampled Schlumberger and dipole-dipole vertical electrical sounding (VES) apparent resistivity values into raised kernel function values is an important step in the interpretation of these data. This conversion involves the convolution of the sampled values, uniformly spaced on a log distance scale, with a set of filter coefficients. For Schlumberger and dipole-dipole configurations, these coefficients can be calculated directly from the Schlumberger filter function. Oscillations of the filter coefficients at large indices (distances) can be minimized by proper selection of the sampling interval, as suggested by Koefoed. The choice of an optimal sampling interval has a more pronounced effect on the accuracy of the inverse transform (raised kernel function into apparent resistivity) than on that of the forward transform. The accuracy of the inverse transform can be improved for nonoptimal sampling intervals by ''phase perturbation'' of the filter function. Both transforms are sensitive to aliasing, which can be severe for certain dipole-dipole configurations.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Texas at Dallas, Richardson
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 42:5

TITLE: Similarity solutions for convection of groundwater adjacent to horizontal impermeable surfaces with axisymmetric temperature distribution
SUBJECT: 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GROUND WATER; CONVECTION; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; FLUID FLOW; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; HEAT TRANSFER; ENERGY TRANSFER; EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WATER; 520400* - Environment, Aquatic- Thermal Effluents Monitoring & Transport- (-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: The axisymmetric buoyancy-induced groundwater flow adjacent to horizontal impermeable surfaces, wall temperature being a power function of radius, is discussed in this paper. With the boundary layer simplifications the governing nonlinear partial differential equations can be transformed into a coupled pair of nonlinear ordinary differential equations with two-point boundary conditions that can be integrated numerically by established techniques. Simple algebraic expressions for boundary layer thickness and heat transfer rate are obtained. Applications to free convective flow in a liquid-dominated geothermal system at high Rayleigh numbers are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:4

TITLE: Implications of a magnetic model of the Long Valley Caldera, California
AUTHORS: Williams, D L; Berkman, F; Mankinen, E A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LONG VALLEY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; MAGNETIC SURVEYS; CALDERAS; KGRA; MAGMA; MAGNETIC FIELDS; TUFF; CALIFORNIA; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A quantitative magnetic model of Long Valley, California, shows that the magnetic field above this caldera is dominated by intracaldera Bishop tuff, part of the ash flow tuff whose eruption precipitated the caldera collapse. We propose that about half of the 350 km/sup 3/ of intracaldera Bishop tuff, or that part beneath the resurgent dome, has been subjected to extensive hydrothermal alteration. The heat that produced this alteration is apparently associated with the residual magma chamber, and much of the formation may still be hot (>200degreeC). The magnetic minerals in the remaining intracaldera Bishop tuff have not been drastically altered, presumably because the tuff was not heated sufficiently. As a result, the tuff may not be very hot today. The model also reveals the existence of parts of two large precaldera mountains beneath the caldera fill. The resolving power attained in this investigation was possible because we were dealing with large, magnetically distinct lithologic units and a large amount of geological and geophysical data were available constraints to produce the solution.
RESEARCH_ORG: U. S. Geological Survey, Denver, Colorado 80225
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:20

TITLE: Sound speed in liquid-gas mixtures: Water-air and water-steam
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; FLUIDS; SOUND WAVES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; ACOUSTIC MONITORING; VELOCITY; GASES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; HEAT TRANSFER; LIQUIDS; MIXTURES; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; SEISMIC SURVEYS; STEAM; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; TWO-PHASE FLOW; WATER; DISPERSIONS; ENERGY TRANSFER; EXPLORATION; FLUID FLOW; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MONITORING; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580203 - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989); 580201 - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The sound speed of a two-phase fluid, such as a magma-gas, water-air, or water-steam mixture, is dramatically different from the sound speed of either pure component. In numerous geologic situations the sound speed of such two-phase systems may be of interest: in the search for magma reservoirs, in seismic exploration of geothermal areas, in prediction of P wave velocity decreases prior to earthquakes, and in inversion of crustal and upper mantle seismic records. Probably most dramatically, fluid flow characteristic during eruptions of volcanoes and geysers are strongly dependent on the sound speed of erupting two-phase (or multiphase) fluids. In this paper the sound speeds of water, air, steam, water-air mixtures, and water-steam mixtures are calculated. It is demonstrated that sound speeds calculated from classical acoustic and fluid dynamics analyses agree with results obtained from finite amplitude 'vaporization wave' theory. The sound speed of pure liquid water is a complex function of pressure and temperature and is given here to 8 kbar 900degree C.The sound speed of a water-air mixture depends on the pressure, the void or mass fraction of air, the frequency of the sound wave, and, if surface tension effects are included, on bubble radius. The sound speeds of the pure liquid and gas end-members are nearly independent of pressure, but the sound speed of a mixture is highly dependent on pressure. The sound speed in a single-component two-phase system, such as a water-steam mixture, depends on whether or not equilibrium between the phases on the saturation curve is maintained. Heat and mass transfer which occur when equilibrium is maintained cause the sound speed to be much lower than under nonequilibrium conditions in which heat and mass transfer are absent.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geology, University of California, Los Angeles, California 90024
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:20

TITLE: Geothermal significance of magnetotelluric sounding in the eastern Snake River Plain-Yellowstone Region
AUTHORS: Stanley, W D; Boehl, J E; Bostick, F X; Smith, H W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; MAGNETOTELLURIC SURVEYS; RAFT RIVER VALLEY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; WYOMING; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; BASALT; EARTH CRUST; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; RHYOLITES; VOLCANISM; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; IDAHO; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; PUBLIC LANDS; ROCKS; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580203 - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Magnetotelluric soundings along a profile extending from the Raft River geothermal area in southern Idaho in Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming reveal a highly anamalous crustal structure involving a conductive zone at depths that range from 18 km in the central part of the eastern Snake River Plain to 7 km beneath the Raft River thermal area and as little as 5 km in Yellowstone. Resistivities in this conductive zone are less than 10 ohm m and at some sites than 1 ohm m. Structural parameters obtained in processing the magnetotelluric data suggest the possibility of a conductive axis along the center of the eastern Snake River Plain, and these parameters also point to very conductive structures beneath the Yellowstone caldera system. A sounding completed in the Island Park caldera can only be modeled with a crustal structure very different from the Yellowstone caldera system, requiring the absence of this conductive zone to depths greater than 25 km in the Island Park caldera. In addition to the deep conductive zone the thickness of extensive surface basalts in the eastern Snake River Plain was mapped geophysically, and units between the basalts and the deep conductive zone were also well defined and fitted to geologic models.
RESEARCH_ORG: U. S. Geological Survey, Denver, Colorado 80225
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:17

TITLE: Differential thermal expansion of the pore fluids: Fracture propagation and microearthquake production in hot pluton environments
AUTHORS: Knapp, R B; Knight, J E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; COMPRESSION STRENGTH; FRACTURE PROPERTIES; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; MICROEARTHQUAKES; POROSITY; TENSILE PROPERTIES; THERMAL EXPANSION; COMMINUTION; EARTHQUAKES; EXPANSION; FRACTURING; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; SEISMIC EVENTS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; 150906* - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology; 580300 - Mineralogy, Petrology, & Rock Mechanics- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Thermally induced differential expansion between fluid in isolated pores and enclosing minerals decreases effective pressure at the pore-mineral interface. With a sufficient increase in temperature, effective pressure becomes equal to the tensile strength, and the rock fractures. The ratio of the coefficient of thermal expansion to the compressibility for the pore fluid defines the nature of this process. Finite element computations indicate that thermally induced hydraulic fracturing of host rocks is inevitable in hot pluton environments. A fracturing front propagates away from cooling plutons at a rate of 100 cm/yr for the first 400 years and at 1 cm/yr at 10/sup 5/ years. Fluid energy release upon fracturing can produce microearthquakes of measurable magnitude. Predicted frequencies of microearthquakes vary from 4 x 10/sup 3/ events/day at 5 x 10/sup 3/ years to 500 events/day at 10/sup 5/ years. Estimates of ambient pore fluid pressures and effective pressures show that effective pressure continually increase with depth for geothermal gradients less than 10degreeC/km. For larger geothermal gradients the effective pressure first increases but eventually decreases.
RESEARCH_ORG: Department of Geosciences, University of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona 85721
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:17

TITLE: Mercury emissions from geothermal power plants

SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GASEOUS WASTES; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; MERCURY; ABUNDANCE; BRINES; CERRO PRIETO GEOTHERMAL FIELD; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; LIQUID WASTES; STEAM; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; METALS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WASTES; 150600* - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects

Mercury emissions from geothermal power plants, on a per megawatt (electric) basis, are comparable to releases from coal-fired power plants.

TITLE: Mining outer space
AUTHORS: Gaffey, M J; McCord, T B
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MINERAL RESOURCES; EXPLOITATION; SPACE; ASTEROIDS; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS; LEGAL ASPECTS; MINERALS; MINING; MINING EQUIPMENT; NICKEL ALLOYS; REENTRY; SAFETY; SATELLITES; SOCIAL IMPACT; SPACE FLIGHT; SPACE VEHICLES; VELOCITY; ALLOYS; EQUIPMENT; RESOURCES; 290400* - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 290700 - Energy Planning & Policy- Transport & Storage; 150500 - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 150600 - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The need to develop new mineral resources as terrestrial supplies are depleted could lead to mining efforts in outer space, where other bodies can be found with materials similar to those of the earth. The high cost of direct sampling requires that earth-based observations be made first, followed by unmanned flights and landing missions. The surface composition of over 100 metal-rich asteroids has already been measured by reflectance spectroscopy. A determination of retrievability and obtainable economic and social benefits is needed before mining of extraterrestrial minerals is undertaken. The possible economic benefits of nickel-iron mining are developed, and ecological and political advantages of not mining low-grade ores on earth are emphasized. Although no legal framework exists for mining in space, the same arrangements could be used that were developed for the sea floor. Solar energy could be used for refining and processing materials during transport through space. All transport options are energy-intensive and must be able to accomplish two velocity changes in order to push the material out of the sun's orbit and into the earth's orbit. Safety requires that the re-entry mass be of lower density than water. Other problems will involve developing an acceptable life for space miners. 21 references. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Technol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 79:7

TITLE: Geothermal heat, instead of electrically powered compression, proposed for cooling a small residence or office building
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL REFRIGERATION; PLANNING; HOUSES; OFFICE BUILDINGS; AIR CONDITIONING; COOLING; FLOWSHEETS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; HEAT PUMPS; BUILDINGS; DIAGRAMS; REFRIGERATION; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: A proposed system in which low-grade geothermal heat is used in place of the compressor motor of a heat pump to supply a cooling system for small buildings is described. The key process in the use of geothermal heat as a direct source of energy for refrigeration is an absorption refrigeration system. Two systems are suggested--the use of LiBr as absorbent and water as the refrigerant, and the use of water as the absorbent and ammonia as refrigerant. Flow diagrams for a system which allows for parallel flow of heat exchangers (continued operation while cleaning one exchanger) is described. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:6
