TITLE: Numerical model for saturated--unsaturated flow in deformable porous media. I. Theory
AUTHORS: Narashimhan, T N; Witherspoon, P A
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GROUND WATER; FLUID FLOW; BOUNDARY LAYERS; COMPRESSIBILITY; HYDROLOGY; HYSTERESIS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MICROSTRUCTURE; PERMEABILITY; POROSITY; POROUS MATERIALS; SATURATION; SOILS; SOLIDS; STRESSES; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; VOLUME; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; LAYERS; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; WATER; 580100* - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory; 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: A theory is presented for numerically simulating the movement of water in variably saturated deformable porous media. The theoretical model considers a general three-dimensional field of flow in conjunction with a one-dimensional vertical deformation field. The governing equation expresses the conservation of fluid mass in an elemental volume that has a constant volume of solids. Deformation of the porous medium may be nonelastic. Permeability and the compressibility coefficients may be nonlinearly related to effective stress. Relationships between permeability and saturation with pore water pressure in the unsaturated zone may be characterized by hysteresis. The relation between pore pressure change and effective stress change may be a function of saturation. In the transition zone where pore water pressure is less than atmospheric but greater than air entry value, soil moisture diffusivity as used in soil physics and coefficient of consolidation as used in soil mechanics are shown to be conceptually equivalent. It is believed that this model will be of practical interest in studying saturated--unsaturated systems undergoing simultaneous desaturation and deformation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 13:3

TITLE: Geophysical data on deep-seated magmatic activity below Kamchatka and an estimate of the forces that cause the rise of magmas into volcanoes
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; KAMCHATKA; SEISMIC SURVEYS; VOLCANISM; MAGMA; INTRUSION; CONVECTION; HYDROSTATICS; ISLANDS; MELTING; TECTONICS; USSR; VOLCANIC REGIONS; ENERGY TRANSFER; EUROPE; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; HEAT TRANSFER; IGNEOUS ROCKS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; ROCKS; 580202* - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Using geophysical data, the mechanism of deep-seated magmatic and volcanic activity was studied in the region of the island arcs and associated structures. Data on magmatic activity below the volcanic belt of East Kamchatka, obtained during geophysical investigations, mainly during detailed seismological investigations and deep seismic sounding, provide evidence for an association between the volcanoes and the processes in the Pacific Ocean focal layer of earthquakes, and for the accumulation of magmas below the volcanic belt at depths less than 60 km. Anomalous columnar bodies more than 5 to 7 km across were found linking the volcanoes with the focal layer. There was also a very large concentration of convective heat flow and volatiles in the magma columns feeding the volcanoes. As to the role of different forces in the uprise of magmas into the volcanoes, hydrostatic forces probably predominate in the asthenosphere, supplemented by tectonic pressure in the lithosphere and forces associated with boiling of magmas during release of volatiles in the crust, especially in its upper layers.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. Geol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:6

TITLE: Mechanism of deep-seated magmatic activity below island-arc volcanoes and similar structures
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGMA; INTRUSION; DEPTH; EARTH CRUST; EARTH MANTLE; FLUID FLOW; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; USSR; VOLCANIC REGIONS; VOLCANISM; DIMENSIONS; EUROPE; IGNEOUS ROCKS; ROCKS; 580202* - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Geophysical data on deep-seated magmatic activity below Eastern Kamchatka and the mechanism of uprise of magmas were analyzed, and phenomena associated with the uprise of magmas through hydrostatic forces were investigated. Ultrabasic magmatic columns must rise from a local layer at depths of 100 to 250 km. Above it in the asthenosphere, a regular series of major magmatic columns develops with a spacing of about 30 km, which provides separate individual volcanic centers. The optimal radius of the columns is 350 to 1000 m and the velocity of their uprise is about 1 m/yr. Magma is moved in them by an order more rapidly than in the asthenoliths. Excess magmatic pressure in the columns contributes to the formation of accumulations of ultrabasic and basic magmas near the base, the crust and the transitional layer between the crust and the mantle, and also to the development of peripheral andesitic magmatic foci on the boundary between the crystalline basement and the sediments. A probable scheme for deep-seated magmatic activity below the volcanic belt of Eastern Kamchatka, the island arcs and similar structures is presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. Geol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:6

TITLE: Correlation of Mg/Fe partitioning between garnet and biotite with /sup 18/O//sup 16/O partitioning between quartz and magnetite
AUTHORS: Goldman, D S; Albee, A L
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BIOTITE; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; GARNETS; IRON; PARTITION; MAGNESIUM; MAGNETITE; OXYGEN 16; ISOTOPE RATIO; OXYGEN 18; QUARTZ; GEOTHERMOMETRY; METAMORPHIC ROCKS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; CHALCOGENIDES; ELEMENTS; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON ORES; IRON OXIDES; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; METALS; MICA; MINERALS; NUCLEI; ORES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN ISOTOPES; ROCKS; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; STABLE ISOTOPES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; 152004* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Isotope & Trace Element Studies
DESCRIPTION: Isotopic and chemical data for thirteen metamorphic rocks containing garnet and biotite are used to investigate the dependence of the Mg--Fe partition upon temperature, expressed as the /sup 18/O//sup 16/O fractionation between quartz and magnetite, and upon chemical variation in both phases. Additional sets of samples considered to have equilibrated at nearly the same temperature are utilized to improve the least-squares solution of the compositional coefficients. The most acceptable least-squares solution, using the singular-value decomposition algorithm, is: K/sub D//sup Mg-Fe//sub G-B/ = -0.177(+-0.010)1000 ln/sub ..cap alpha..//sup Q//sub M/ - 1.22(+-0.14)X/sup G//sub Mn/ - 2.14(+- 0.13)X/sup G//sub Ca/ + 1.40(+- 0.09)X/sup B//sub Fe/ + 0.942(+- 0.109)X/sup B//sub Ti/ - 1.59(+- 0.21)X/sup B//sub Al/sup vi// - 0.492(+- 0.068). K/sub D/ is primarily dependent upon temperature but is also dependent upon compositional variation, particularly upon X/sup B//sub Fe/, although X/sup G//sub Ca/ becomes significant at higher concentrations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 277:6

TITLE: Stability of the magnesium carbonate ion pair from 10 to 90/sup 0/C
AUTHORS: Siebert, R M; Hostetler, P B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; MAGNESIUM CARBONATES; STABILITY; ACID CARBONATES; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; CATIONS; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; MAGNESIUM CHLORIDES; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; PH VALUE; POTASSIUM CARBONATES; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; TITRATION; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CHARGED PARTICLES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; IONS; KINETICS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SOLUTIONS; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions; 580400 - Geochemistry- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The dissociation constants of the aqueous MgCO/sub 3//sup 0/ ion pair were determined experimentally from 10 to 90/sup 0/C at 15/sup 0/ intervals. Absolute pH measurements in MgCl/sub 2/--KHCO/sub 3/ solutions being titrated with K/sub 2/CO/sub 3/ were used to calculate the results. The experimental pK/sub MgCO/sub 3//sup 0// (-log K/sub dissociation/) at 25/sup 0/C is 2.98 +- 0.03, and the pK values rise smoothly, as a function of temperature, to a value of 3.41 +- 0.067 at 90/sup 0/C. The temperature variation is in excellent agreement with that predicted by electrostatic ion pair theory. The derived values of ..delta..G/sub R//sup 0/, ..delta..H/sub R//sup 0/, and ..delta..S/sub R//sup 0/ of dissociation at 25/sup 0/C are 17050 +- 125 J mol/sup -1/ (4075 +- 30 cal mol/sup -1/, -8439 J mol/sup -1/ (-2017 cal mol/sup -1/), and -85.48 J deg/sup -1/ mol/sup -1/ (-20.43 cal deg/sup -1/ mol/sup -1/), respectively.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 277:6; Journal Issue: 6

TITLE: Digitalization of magnetotelluric signals: description of the equipment
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGNETOTELLURIC SURVEYS; EQUIPMENT; DATA PROCESSING; DESIGN; DIGITAL SYSTEMS; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; PROCESSING; 580203* - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989); 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A magnetotelluric digital equipment has been designed and built for operation in geophysical and applied geophysical and applied geophysical research. The five components of the natural electromagnetic field can be digitized in the frequency range /sup 1///sub 1000/ Hz (magnetic sensor's response limits) to some tens Hz. The magnetotelluric (MT) data are directly digitized in the field and stored in a cassette tape recorder.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Prospect.; (United States); Journal Volume: 25:2

TITLE: Stability of the magnesium bicarbonate ion pair from 10 to 90/sup 0/C
AUTHORS: Siebert, R M; Hostetler, P B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; CATIONS; STABILITY; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; ADDITIVES; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; CARBON DIOXIDE; CHEMICAL REACTION KINETICS; DISSOCIATION; MAGNESIUM CHLORIDES; PH VALUE; POTASSIUM COMPOUNDS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHARGED PARTICLES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; IONS; KINETICS; MIXTURES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; REACTION KINETICS; SOLUTIONS; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions; 580400 - Geochemistry- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The dissociation constants of the aqueous MgHCO/sub 3//sup +/ ion pair were determined experimentally from 10 to 90/sup 0/C at 15/sup 0/ intervals. The experimental pH change between alternating additions of MgCl/sub 2/ and KHCO/sub 3/ to MgCl/sub 2/--KHCO/sub 3/ solutions in equilibrium with CO/sub 2/ was used to calculate the dissociation constants by a new floating point method which does not require absolute pH and P/sub CO/sub 2// values. The approach reduces the sources of error to single-ion activity coefficients and reference electrode liquid-junction potentials. The experimental pK/sub MgHCO/sub 3//sup +// (-log K/sub dissociation/) at 25/sup 0/C is 1.07 +- 0.03, and the pK's increase smoothly to 1.34 +- 0.03 at 90/sup 0/C. The 25/sup 0/C result is in general agreement with several previous determinations; the pK variation as a function of temperature is in excellent agreement with that predicted by the Fuoss electrostatic ion pair theory. Derived values of ..delta..G/sub R//sup 0/, ..delta..H/sub R//sup 0/, and ..delta..S/sub R//sup 0/ of dissociation at 25/sup 0/C are 6087.7 +- 167 J mol/sup -1/ (1455 +- 40 cal mol/sup -1/), -4987.3 J mol/sup -1/ (-1192 cal mol/sup -1/), and -37.15 J deg/sup -1/ mol/sup -1/ (-8.88 cal deg/sup -1/ mol/sup -1/), respectively.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 277:6

TITLE: Institutional and environmental aspects of geothermal energy development
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; LEGAL ASPECTS; AIR QUALITY; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; EXPLOITATION; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GROUND SUBSIDENCE; LAND USE; LEGISLATION; NOISE POLLUTION; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; WATER POLLUTION; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; POLLUTION; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The increasing interest in exploiting the variety of geothermal resources has prompted an examination of the institutional barriers to their introduction for commercial use. A significant effort was undertaken by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory as a part of a national study to identify existing constraints to geothermal development and possible remedial actions. These aspects included legislative and legal parameters plus environmental, social, and economic considerations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Nucl. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 34

TITLE: Free' and renewable energy sources
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 09 BIOMASS FUELS; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 16 TIDAL AND WAVE POWER; 17 WIND ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; USA; FORECASTING; BIOMASS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGMA SYSTEMS; OCEAN THERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; POWER POTENTIAL; SOLAR ENERGY; WAVE POWER; WIND POWER; CONVERSION; ENERGY; ENERGY CONVERSION; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability; 140504 - Solar Energy Conversion- Biomass Production & Conversion- (-1989); 140800 - Solar Energy- Ocean Energy Systems; 160800 - Tidal & Wave Power- Wave Energy Converters; 170000 - Wind Energy
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal resources in the US include dry steam, hot water, geopressurized water, hot dry rock, crustal gradients, and magma. The most recent US Geological Survey estimate shows that the energy content of magma located within 10 km of the surface is equivalent to 700 times the US energy consumption in 1974. Research is being conducted on the development of heat exchange systems for direct energy extraction from magma. Much of this research is under the auspices of USERDA. Sandia Laboratories is studying locations for magma experiments, methods of drilling, heat exchangers for magmatic environments, and heat transfer properties. Other applications of geothermal energy include domestic heating and electrical power generation from shallow and surficial steam and hot water sources. USERDA predictions and budgets for various energy sources are graphed. Renewable energy sources other than geothermal are reviewed. These include solar, wind, ocean thermal, and biomass.
RELATION: Journal Name: Mach. Des.; (United States); Journal Volume: 49:12

TITLE: Iceland harnesses heat from lava while geothermal projects gather steam
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ICELAND; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEOTHERMAL DISTRICT HEATING; DISTRICT HEATING; EUROPE; HEATING; RESOURCES; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: A pilot installation in the Vestman Islands (Iceland) has successfully delivered 85-90/sup 0/C water to a hospital and 40 residences. Plans call for expansion of the facility to heat most of the 1000 residences in the town of Vestmannsaeyjar. The system utilizes steam produced by 1000/sup 0/C lava beneath 10-20 m of volcanic ash produced by a volcanic eruption in 1973. Pipes in 1.6 m diameter holes carry steam to heat exchangers. The lava fields are expected to produce steam for about 15-20 years and research is underway on methods of prolonging their usefulness. Also in Iceland, the city of Reykjavik has been using geothermal heat since 1930. Approximately 46% of the homes were heated geothermally in 1973 and the present goal is to provide heat to 77% by 1985. A 1% sales tax has produced 4 million dollars for geothermal R D. Eleven wells at Laugavegur produce 18,000 liters/min of water at 128/sup 0/C and five wells at Ellioaar produce about 10,000 liters/min at 103/sup 0/C.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. News-Rec.; (United States); Journal Volume: 198:21

TITLE: Down-well geothermal pump tested
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PUMPS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; DESIGN; TESTING; WELLS; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: A successful 600-hr test of a down-well pump was conducted. The self-operating pump, consisting of a turbine and a pump, puts continuous pressure on the geothermal brines to bring them to the surface without flashing. The down-well pump eliminates the use of a surface pump and possibly a shaft, thus doing away with problems of rotation and torque, and additional labor time and equipment. Another advantage is near-elimination of corrosion due to flashing. It also decreases the number of wells needed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Electr. World; (United States); Journal Volume: 187:10

TITLE: Columbia/Snake River: Yellowstone magmatism in the context of western U. S. A. cenozoic geodynamics
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IDAHO; MAGMATISM; MAGMA; UPWELLING; OREGON; WASHINGTON; WYOMING; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; CENOZOIC ERA; COLUMBIA RIVER; EARTH CRUST; EARTH MANTLE; GEOLOGIC MODELS; HEAT TRANSFER; IGNEOUS ROCKS; INTRUSION; NATURAL CONVECTION; RIVERS; TECTONICS; CONVECTION; ENERGY TRANSFER; GEOLOGIC AGES; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; PUBLIC LANDS; ROCKS; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; STREAMS; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 580202* - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: An attempt was made to calculate the total volume of Middle Cenozoic to Recent igneous rocks in the Columbia--Snake River--Yellowstone region by adding geophysically-derived estimates of the amounts of mafic intrusion to published data on the volumes of volcanic rocks. Recently published radiometric ages allow comparison of rates of basaltic magmatism in these ensialic provinces with those along equivalent lengths of mid-oceanic ridge. The rates of total magmatic activity (extrusive and intrusive) during the genesis of the Columbia River Plateau, Western Snake River Plain and Eastern Snake River Plain--Yellowstone sub-provinces were equivalent to those of mid-oceanic ridges with spreading half-rates of 10, 3 and 0.3 cm per year, respectively. It is shown that the hypothesis that magmatism in this region is the product of a deep-mantle convective plume, situated at present beneath Yellowstone, does not explain adequately several features of the Snake River Plain and becomes untenable when applied to the province as a whole. It is proposed instead that all major post-Eocene tectonic and magmatic features of the western U.S.A., east of the Sierra Nevada and Cascades, are products of comparatively shallow-rooted diapiric upwelling in the mantle; triggered at about 40 m.y. by extraction of mafic silicate melt and volatiles from the Farallon lithospheric plate, subducted at a comparatively low angle beneath the North American plate. Constriction of the Columbia River Plateau diapir by the subduction zone to its west led to ''run away'' mantle fusion and massive production of basic magmas.
RESEARCH_ORG: Imperial Coll. of Science and Technology, London
RELATION: Journal Name: Tectonophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 39:4

TITLE: Free convection about a vertice flat plate embedded in a porous medium with application to heat transfer from a dike
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; HEAT TRANSFER; POROUS MATERIALS; NATURAL CONVECTION; AQUIFERS; BOUNDARY LAYERS; THICKNESS; CONVECTION; DIMENSIONS; ENERGY TRANSFER; LAYERS; MATERIALS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory; 150200 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: An analysis is made for steady free convection about a vertical flat plate embedded in a saturated porous medium at high Rayleigh numbers. Within the framework of boundary layer approximations, similarity solutions are obtained for a class of problems where wall temperature varies as x/sup lambda/, i.e., a power function of distance from the origin where wall temperature begins to deviate from that of the surrounding fluids. Analytical expressions are obtained for boundary layer thickness, local and overall surface heat flux, and local and average heat transfer coefficients. Application to convective heat transfer about an isothermal dike intruded in an aquifer is discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:14

TITLE: Velocity of compressional waves in dry franciscan rocks to 8 kbar and 300/sup 0/C
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; SEISMIC SURVEYS; ROCKS; WAVE PROPAGATION; SANDSTONES; MINERALOGY; SHALES; CRACKS; DENSITY; DEPTH; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; HIGH TEMPERATURE; LITHOLOGY; POROSITY; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; SEISMIC P WAVES; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THICKNESS; VELOCITY; VERY HIGH PRESSURE; DIMENSIONS; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; METAMORPHIC ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; SEISMIC WAVES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 580300* - Mineralogy, Petrology, & Rock Mechanics- (-1989); 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: Compressional velocities to 300/sup 0/C and 8 kbar are presented for dry Franciscan sandstone, metasand-stone, shale, and melange matrix. Mineralogical data, density, and porosity are also given for each rock. Velocity hysteresis was found to vary systematically with experimental temperature and pressure conditions. This result is tentatively explained on the basis of crack behavior in the rocks. Velocity was found to depend strongly on bulk density and weakly on mineralogy. Samples of shale and melange matrix have velocities similar to sandstone of comparable density. Results suggest that structural and lithologic complexities in clastic rocks of uniform metamorphic grade will not lead to complex velocity structure. Velocities in rocks of common density are consistent with velocity profiles measured in the upper crust in central California. On the basis of these data the total thickness of Franciscan rocks east of the San Andreas fault in central California is 12 km.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:14

TITLE: Rotary separator/turbine handles geothermal brines
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FRESH WATER; PRODUCTION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; DESALINATION; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; INERTIAL SEPARATORS; TURBINES; VAPOR SEPARATORS; DUAL-PURPOSE POWER PLANTS; TWO-PHASE FLOW; DEMINERALIZATION; EQUIPMENT; FLUID FLOW; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; TURBOMACHINERY; WATER; 150802* - Geothermal Power Plants- Power Plant Systems & Components; 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: The product of most geothermal fields is a pressurized hot water with high mineral content rather than dry steam. As only a small quantity of the fluid is flashed to steam the development of devices which can effectively utilize the two-phase product is desirable. A device patented in 1975 combines aspects of centrifugal separators and turbines. Brine is expanded through nozzles tangential to the rotating components and partially flashed to steam which accelerates the remaining liquid. At the nozzle exit the fluid enters a rotating separator drum where it separates into a liquid ring and vapor core. This is accomplished with minimal friction losses. Finally the liquid is fed through a radial inflow turbine and the vapor is ducted to a heat exchanger. The condensor output is potable and may be used for municipal supply or irrigation. Biphase Engines Inc. has built a test unit which is truck mounted for field testing. It is expected that the system is capable of producing 1.1 MW and 866,250 liters/day of fresh water, given a wellhead pressure of 1.5 MN/cm/sup 2/ (225 psi).
RELATION: Journal Name: Des. News; (United States); Journal Volume: 33:9

TITLE: Solids control for high salinity geothermal brines
AUTHORS: Hill, J H; Otto, Jr, C H; Morris, C J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRINES; ACIDIZATION; CALCIUM CARBONATES; PRECIPITATION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; REINJECTION; LEAD SULFIDES; MANGANESE CARBONATES; SILICA; ZINC SULFIDES; CONTROL; DISSOLUTION; EROSION; HYDROCHLORIC ACID; NITRIC ACID; PH VALUE; PLUGGING; REMOVAL; SOLIDS; SUSPENSIONS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CHALCOGENIDES; DISPERSIONS; FLUIDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; INORGANIC PHOSPHORS; LEAD COMPOUNDS; MANGANESE COMPOUNDS; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHOSPHORS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; ZINC COMPOUNDS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: Solids which precipitate when high salinity geothermal brines are cooled can cause extensive erosion and plugging to occur in power plant components. During reinjection of spent brine, they may also cause plugging of the formation adjacent to the reinjection wells. Work done to characterize these solids and control their production by acidifying the brine to a pH <4.5 is described. At this time, control by acidification seems to offer an attractive alternative to conventional methods (filtering, settling, etc.) for removing suspended solids from spent brine prior to reinjection.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Resour. Counc., Trans.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1

TITLE: Potential land subsidence at geothermal development sites
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GROUND SUBSIDENCE; COMPACTING; FORECASTING; GEOLOGY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; MAGMA SYSTEMS; VAPOR-DOMINATED SYSTEMS; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 150600* - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Potential severities of five physical subsidence processes for magma, hot rock, steam, hot water, and geopressured systems are summarized. Compaction is thought to be the most significant, possibly followed by fracture closing. Site geology, fluid, reservoir, and material characteristics are identified as indicators of subsidence potential. Two methods of subsidence prediction, analogy and analysis, are discussed. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:5

TITLE: Summary of 1976 geothermal drilling: Western United States
AUTHORS: Smith, J L; Isselhardt, C F; Matlick, J S
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; WELL DRILLING; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; IDAHO; NEVADA; OREGON; UTAH; BOREHOLES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; MAPS; CAVITIES; DRILLING; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; USA; WELLS; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 150901 - Geothermal Engineering- Drilling Technology & Well Hardware
DESCRIPTION: In 1976 there were 52 wells and 13 deep observation holes drilled to explore for and develop geothermal resources in the States of California, Idaho, Nevada, Oregon, and Utah. This was an increase of 27% over the total number of locations drilled in 1975. Of the 52 wells drilled during 1976, 39 (75%) are now considered to have successfully found at least potentially commercial quantities of steam or hot water, 8 are otherwise suspended, and 5 were abandoned. Two new fields were discovered, in the Imperial Valley and Nevada, and four important extensions to production were made at The Geysers. The drilling activity for 1976 is summarized by state and by operator. The total footage drilled was 437,752 feet, which represents an increase of 82,609 feet (23%) over the total footage drilled in 1975. As in 1975, the three operators most active in 1976 were Union, Aminoil, and Republic Geothermal, based on footage drilled.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:5

TITLE: Update of world geothermal energy development
AUTHORS: Meidav, T; Sanyal, S; Facca, G
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ARGENTINA; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BRAZIL; COSTA RICA; GERMAN FEDERAL REPUBLIC; GUATEMALA; HONDURAS; NICARAGUA; PANAMA; PORTUGAL; SPAIN; SWEDEN; CAPACITY; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; REVIEWS; CENTRAL AMERICA; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SCANDINAVIA; SOUTH AMERICA; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The current status of geothermal development in the following countries is summarized: Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Panama, Argentina, Brazil, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, West Germany, United Kingdom, Yugoslavia, Israel, Jordan, French Somali, and Fiji. Present and projected electrical generating capacities from geothermal resources in these and certain other highly developed countries are tabulated. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:5

TITLE: Earth's crustal plate boundaries: energy and mineral resources
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 02 PETROLEUM; EARTH CRUST; PLATE TECTONICS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; PETROLEUM DEPOSITS; DEPOSITS; EXPLORATION; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; MINERAL RESOURCES; ORES; RESOURCES; TECTONICS; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology; 020200 - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration
DESCRIPTION: Acceptance of the plate tectonics concept as explaining how the Earth really works may point to new locations of energy and mineral resources. Distributed along three-fourths of the Pacific's perimeter are geothermal energy sites, areas of off-shore petroleum potential, and deposits of precious, base, iron and ferro-alloy metals that have been concentrated by geologic processes at the convergent and divergent boundaries of tectonic plates of the Earth's outer shell. Interpreted in terms of past boundaries, such resources may be found in other more accessible areas where less than 10 years ago it was not suspected they might exist. Increasing shortages of many of these resources may be alleviated by discoveries stemming from the new geological concept.
RELATION: Journal Name: Calif. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 30:5

TITLE: Geothermal energy and energy conservation: policy planning objectives
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; USES; DISTRICT HEATING; ENERGY CONSERVATION; ENERGY POLICY; PROCESS HEAT; RECOMMENDATIONS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HEAT; HEATING; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989); 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Potential use of geothermal energy for process heat, district heating, and other low temperature end uses is discussed. Development of geothermal resources as a part of an energy conservation policy is stressed. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:5

TITLE: Regional geotherms and lithospheric thickness
AUTHORS: Chapman, D S; Pollack, H N
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EARTH CRUST; ISOTHERM; THICKNESS; EARTH MANTLE; HEAT FLOW; MAPS; PLATE TECTONICS; VISCOSITY; DIMENSIONS; TECTONICS; 580100* - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Continental and oceanic geotherm families parametric in surface heat flow intersect the mantle solidus at a depth coincident with the top of the seismic low-velocity zone, thus allowing surface heat-flow variations to be used to map the thickness of the lithosphere on a global scale. Thermal models were developed that predict a lithospheric thickness of a few tens of kilometers in young oceans and continental orogenic provinces and more than 300 km in shield areas. The variable thermal structue of the mantle implies a greater viscosity beneath shields, which offers an explanation for the observed retarded motions of plates that bear shields.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:5

TITLE: Rate of crustal extension across the Rio Grande rift near Albuquerque, New Mexico
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; RIO GRANDE RIFT; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; EARTH CRUST; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; NEW MEXICO; TECTONICS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: There has probably been about 8 km of crustal extension in a northwest-southeast direction across the Rio Grande rift near Albuquerque, New Mexico, since approximately 26 m.y. ago, giving an annual rate of about 0.3 mm/yr. This estimate is based on an interpretation that the normal faults bounding the graben decrease in dip downward and extend to a depth of about 10 to 15 km. Below that depth the crust is assumed to have undergone plastic deformation.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:5

TITLE: Hot dry rock: widespread but invisible. [Report of workshop discussion]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GRAVITY SURVEYS; HEAT FLOW; REVIEWS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 150300* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: Discussion at a meeting held on June 22, 1976, at Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory on the subject of Exploration Methods for Hot Dry Rock (HDR) is reported under the subject headings: geological methods; heat flow; seismic studies; electromagnetic methods; gravity methods; and exploration. The importance of using a variety of exploration techniques to assess HDR regions was emphasized.
RELATION: Journal Name: EOS, Trans., Am. Geophys. Union; (United States); Journal Volume: 58:5
JOURNAL_NAME: EOS, Trans., Am. Geophys. Union; (United States)

TITLE: Successful test for a down-well, self-operating geothermal pump
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PUMPS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; HEBER GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; TESTING; WELLS; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: The test was performed at a geothermal well at Heber, Calif. The pump is suspended from two concentric pipes inside a standard 12 in. diameter oil well casing at a 1000 ft depth. Fresh water is pumped down the annulus where it changes to steam, which drives a turbine attached to the pump before it returns to the surface. The pump, whose principle does not involve the conversion of steam to electricity, pressurizes the geothermal fluid to force it up the well.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. News (Wash., D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 55:15

TITLE: Geothermal energy: the hot prospect
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GLOBAL ASPECTS; RESERVES; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; POWER GENERATION; ECONOMICS; EXPLORATION; FORECASTING; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; MAGMA SYSTEMS; NATURAL STEAM; ORIGIN; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; STEAM; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Developed geothermal capacity, 502 MW, all of it belonging to Pacific Gas and Electric Company at The Geysers in California, amounts to 0.2 percent of U.S. power generated. From 11 MW in 1960, PG and E's capacity at The Geysers grew to 290 MW by 1972. Two plants of 106 MW each were later added, raising the total to 502 MW in 1975. Three more units are now being built, and capacity at The Geysers, by PG and E alone, is planned to hit 2000 MW by 1987, quadrupling the 1975 figure in just 12 years. The four prospects--dry steam, hot-water systems, geopressured systems, and crystalline rock and magma--are described. An attempt is made to describe global aspects of geothermal reserves. Data are incomplete and inaccurate, but it is instructive to assess major capacity and learn the locations and applications of geothermal heat. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: EPRI J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:3

TITLE: Evaluation of geopressured zones
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; REVIEWS; TEXAS; NATURAL GAS FIELDS; DOCUMENT TYPES; GEOLOGIC DEPOSITS; NATURAL GAS DEPOSITS; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A critique of a recently completed, ERDA-sponsored study on methodology for geopressured zones is presented. The study is entitled ''Development of an Assessment Methodology for Geopressured Zones of the Upper Gulf Coast Based on a Study of Abnormally Pressured Gas Fields in South Texas, Final Report.'' Inadequacies of the study are emphasized. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Rep.; (United States); Journal Volume: 6:7

TITLE: Thermal efficiency of geothermal power
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; POWER POTENTIAL; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMAL EFFICIENCY; ENTHALPY; FLASHED STEAM SYSTEMS; FLUID FLOW; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; STEAM TURBINES; EFFICIENCY; FLUIDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; 150801* - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: Thermal efficiency is sensitive to steam pressures entering and leaving a turbine; to maximize the power-life of a geothermal field, the fluid from discharging wells is considered as separated in two pressure stages in series, at 75 psia (5.17 bar) and 20 psia (1.38 bar). Hence steam enters the turbine at 65 psia (4.48 bar) and at a pass-in point at 15 psia (1.03 bar). For the above conditions, curves of power potential and thermal efficiency are drawn for geothermal fluid of various enthalpies up to that of dry steam, for three different values of turbine outlet pressure (within the condenser) which covers the range most likely to be met. For comparison purposes, curves are also shown for the case where the fluid is separated in one-stage at the higher pressure given above, with elimination of the supplementaty steam entering the turbine at the lower, pass-in pressure. The spread of enthalpies studied was from 300 to 1200 Btu/lb (700 to 2800 j/g) which gave a range of thermal efficiencies from 0.014 to 0.16.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4

TITLE: Bog Hot Springs, Nevada: the geothermal cycle
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT SPRINGS; NEVADA; FLUID FLOW; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; NORTH AMERICA; THERMAL SPRINGS; USA; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Bog Hot Springs are located in one of the high desert valleys of northern Nevada below the Pueblo Mountains. The flow of the springs is estimated to be 2,500 gpm. Temperatures range from 125 to 212/sup 0/F. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4

TITLE: Status of the Los Alamos experiment to extract geothermal energy from hot dry rock
AUTHORS: Laughlin, A W; Pettitt, R A; West, F G; Eddy, A C; Balagna, J P; Charles, R W
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; WELL DRILLING; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; HEAT EXTRACTION; BOREHOLES; FLUID FLOW; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; NEW MEXICO; PERMEABILITY; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; SITE SELECTION; WELL LOGGING; CAVITIES; DRILLING; EXPLORATION; FRACTURING; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; USA; WELLS; 150906* - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology
DESCRIPTION: For the past four years, the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory (LASL) has been investigating a method for extracting geothermal energy from hot, but essentially impermeable, rocks at moderate depths. The concept is to drill a hole into the hot, relatively impermeable rock and create a large hydraulic fracture that serves as a downhole heat exchanger. A second hole is drilled to intersect the fracture, creating a circulation loop for the injected water. Two deep holes (GT-2 and EE-1) were drilled at the Fenton Hill site in northern New Mexico. The first hole, GT-2, has a depth of 2,928 m and a bottom-hole temperature of 197/sup 0/C. The second hole, EE-1, was temporarily halted at a depth of 3,062 m, where the temperature is 205.5/sup 0/C. Hydraulic fractures were created in both holes, and fluid communication between the holes was established in October 1975. Circulation experiments are now being conducted between the two holes.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4

TITLE: Geochemistry of geopressured geothermal waters from the Frio Clay in the Gulf Coast region of Texas
AUTHORS: Kharaka, Y K; Callender, E; Wallace, Jr, R H
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GEOCHEMISTRY; THERMAL WATERS; GULF OF MEXICO; TEXAS; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; GEOTHERMOMETRY; SALINITY; ACID CARBONATES; AMMONIA; BORON; CALCIUM; CHLORINE; CLAYS; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; IRON; MAGNESIUM; MANGANESE; NATURAL GAS; NATURAL GAS WELLS; OIL WELLS; PH VALUE; POTASSIUM; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; QUARTZ; RUBIDIUM; SILICA; SODIUM; STRONTIUM; SULFATES; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; ALKALI METALS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; ATLANTIC OCEAN; CARIBBEAN SEA; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMISTRY; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GASES; HALOGENS; HYDRIDES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; METALS; MINERALS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEAS; SEMIMETALS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SURFACE WATERS; TRANSITION ELEMENTS; USA; WELLS; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Detailed chemical analyses of 54 formation-water samples from the Frio Clay from 11 oil and gas fields in the Houston-Galveston and Corpus Christi areas, Texas, indicate that the salinity of water in the geopressured zone ranges from about 20,000 to 70,000 mg/l dissolved solids. Samples from many gas wells yield low salinities that are not representative of the true salinity of formation water because of dilution by condensed water vapor produced with natural gas. Quartz and Na-K-Ca geothermometers are used in conjunction with the measured subsurface temperatures to identify the diluted samples and to estimate their true salinities.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:4

TITLE: Deep-water temperatures in the FAMOUS area
AUTHORS: Fehn, U; Siegel, M D; Robinson, G R; Holland, H D; Williams, D L; Erickson, A J; Green, K E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ATLANTIC OCEAN; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; DEPTH; HEAT FLOW; ISOTHERM; MID-ATLANTIC RIDGE; OCEANIC CRUST; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; DIMENSIONS; EARTH CRUST; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory; 150202 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Some of the results of Project FAMOUS studies, which were undertaken in the axial area of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge between approximately 36/sup 0/30' and 37/sup 0/N latitudes, are reported. The distribution of water temperatures in the FAMOUS area was investigated during the years 1972 to 1974. Forty-seven vertical temperature profiles were taken and bottom-water temperature measurements along 110 km of traverses were carried out during the course of four cruises. Potential temperatures in the FAMOUS area were found to range between 3.53 and 3.85/sup 0/C below a depth of 2,200 m. These temperatures are almost 1/sup 0/C higher than temperatures outside the axial zone of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge at comparable depths. The potential temperature in deep waters was observed to increase from 3.53/sup 0/C in the western part of fracture zone B to 3.80/sup 0/C in the eastern part of fracture zone A. Vertical temperature gradients are smaller than 1 x 10/sup -4/ /sup 0/C/m at depths below 2,200 m in the various basins of the FAMOUS area. Between 2,000 and 1,800 m, the temperature differences between the different parts of the area gradually disappear; above 1,500 m, there are no significant differences between water temperatures in the ridge and those in the surrounding ocean. The observed near-bottom temperature distribution in the FAMOUS area is related to the bottom topography. The temperatures in the various basins are determined mainly by their sill depth; the observed south-north increase of deep-water temperatures and the velocity of bottom-water currents in the area can be related quantitatively to hydrologic effects. The influence of hydrothermal activity and of heat flow through the ocean floor on the temperature distribution in the area is negligible.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 88

TITLE: Mineral equilibria in the MgO--SiO/sub 2/--H/sub 2/O system. II. Talc--antigorite--forsterite--anthophyllite--enstatite stability relations and some geologic implications in the system
AUTHORS: Hemley, J J; Montoya, J W; Shaw, D R; Luce, R W
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ENSTATITE; EQUILIBRIUM; MAGNESIUM OXIDES; MAGNESIUM SILICATES; SILICA; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; FREE ENTHALPY; GEOCHEMISTRY; METAMORPHISM; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; STABILITY; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; WATER; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMISTRY; ENERGY; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; PYROXENES; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; 580400* - Geochemistry- (-1989); 152003 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: Mineral equilibria in the MgO--SiO/sub 2/--H/sub 2/O system were investigated, with emphasis on the stability relations of talc, antigorite, forsterite, anthophyllite, and enstatite. Thermal dehydration temperatures at 1 kb H/sub 2/O are at 514/sup 0/ +- 12/sup 0/C (Ta--Antig--Fo), 627/sup 0/ +- 7/sup 0/C (Ta--Fo--Anth), 670/sup 0/ +- 7/sup 0/C (Anth--Fo--En), 675/sup 0/ +- 7/sup 0/C (Ta--Anth--Q), 643/sup 0/ +- 8/sup 0/C (Ta--Fo--En), 690/sup 0/ +- 8/sup 0/C (Ta--En--Q), 729/sup 0/ +- 8/sup 0/C (Anth--En--Q). Derived G/sup 0//sub f/ values in kcal/gf are -928.756 +- 1.1 (Antig, based on Mg/sub 2/./sub 825/Si/sub 2/O/sub 3/ (OH)/sub 3/./sub 65/), -2711.320 +- 1.7 (Anth) and -348.955 +- 0.6 (EN). Anthophyllite has a relatively narrow temperature stability range at 1 kb, but it increases as P/sub H/sub 2/O/ increases. The Ta--Fo--En and Ta--En--Q reactions are low-pressure changes, metastable at 1 kb. The (Q) and (Fo) invariant points are at approximately 603/sup 0/C, 500 bars, and 601/sup 0/C, 175 bars, P/sub H/sub 2/O/, respectively. Higher P/sub total/ raises and spreads the P/sub H/sub 2/O/ values of the invariant points. The log SiO/sub 2/ /sub aq/ versus 1/T diagrams utilized in this study are applied to metasomatic and isochemical processes involving this system. Aspects of contact metamorphism and metasomatism, the process of serpentinization, and compositional controls and relative stabilities of the serpentine phases are discussed. Isochemical cooling in the subsolidus at finite, though not necessarily constant, P/sub H/sub 2/O/ results in a mineral reaction series analogous to that of the classical reaction series of silicate melts. The chemical constraints revealed in the various equilibria studied help to clarify and more rigorously to define the isochemical PT relationships of the system. The geological application of activity-activity or chemical potential diagrams is also discussed, and the necessity of considering reactions that correspond to or approximate the true process involved is illustrated.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 277:4

TITLE: Chemical and isotopic investigations of groundwater in potential geothermal areas in Hawaii
AUTHORS: McMurtry, G M; Fan, P F; Coplen, T B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GROUND WATER; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; GEOTHERMOMETRY; HAWAII; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; CALCIUM; DEUTERIUM; ISOTOPE RATIO; OXYGEN 18; PH VALUE; POTASSIUM; SALINITY; SILICA; SODIUM; ALKALI METALS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; CHALCOGENIDES; ELEMENTS; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; EXPLORATION; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN ISOTOPES; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; METALS; MINERALS; NORTH AMERICA; NUCLEI; ODD-ODD NUCLEI; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN ISOTOPES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; STABLE ISOTOPES; USA; WATER; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The chemical and isotopic compositions of Hawaiian groundwater were studied to locate and evaluate potential geothermal areas. Analyses were made of forty-three samples from twenty-seven wells, two coastal springs, local precipitation, and steam. Three methods of chemical geothermometry were applied: (1) silica, (2) Na--K--Ca, and (3) stable isotope or deuterium-oxygen-18. Based on the silica and stable isotope methods, the most promising geothermal areas are the summit of Kilauea Volcano and the area near geothermal test hole 3 in the Puna district (east rift zone of Kilauea Volcano). There, temperatures calculated from dissolved silica range from about 160 to 275/sup 0/C. Mixing with cooler groundwaters appears to be a significant feature of these geothermal reservoirs. Seawater intrusion, possibly due to thermal disruption of the equilibrium of the Ghyben-Herzberg lens in geothermal areas, tends to interfere with the geothermometry of the Na--K--Ca and stable isotope methods.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 277:4

TITLE: Geothermal study of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge near 37/sup 0/N
AUTHORS: Williams, D L; Lee, T C; Von Herzen, R P; Green, K E; Hobart, M A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MID-ATLANTIC RIDGE; HEAT FLOW; ATLANTIC OCEAN; COOLING; FLUID FLOW; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; OCEANIC CRUST; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; TOPOGRAPHY; EARTH CRUST; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory; 150202 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Some of the results of Project FAMOUS studies, which were undertaken in the axial area of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge between approximately 36/sup 0/30' and 37/sup 0/N latitudes, are reported. A suite of 101 well-navigated heat-flow stations was used to investigate lithospheric cooling on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge near 37/sup 0/N. Measurements in two topographic depressions marking the intersection of transform faults with axes of sea-floor spreading show evidence of hydrothermal circulation in basement rocks. One of these depressions appears to have been subjected to a recent bottom-water temperature change which severely biases the heat-flow data. Some of the evidence suggests that transform faults are more permeable than other regions of the ocean crust and therefore may cool much faster. The heat flow in rift mountains extending from 10 to 35 km west of the spreading axis was also measured. The data here also suggest that a hydrothermal system is presently active in the crustal rocks. Although hydrothermal vents have not yet been unambiguously identified on the sea floor, hydrothermal circulation seems likely to be the dominant mode of cooling oceanic crust near spreading axes where sediment cover is thin (that is, few tens of metres) or nonexistent.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 88

TITLE: On shallow-hole temperature measurements: a test study in the Salton Sea geothermal field
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SALTON SEA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; BOREHOLES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ERRORS; GROUND WATER; LEAST SQUARE FIT; LEVELS; PIPES; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; THERMAL DIFFUSION; THERMISTORS; CAVITIES; DIFFUSION; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD FIT; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEMICONDUCTOR DEVICES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; WATER; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Shallow-hole (<13 m) temperature measurements made at various depths and/or times may yield reliable values of geothermal gradient and thermal diffusivity if the groundwater table is shallow (a few meters) such that the effect of time-dependent moisture content and physical properties is negligible. Two numerical methods based on nonlinear least-squares curve fitting are derived to remove the effect of annual temperature wave at the ground surface. One method can provide information on the gradient and diffusivity as a function of depth while the other gives average value over the depth interval measured. Experiments were carried in six test holes cased with 2 cm OD PVC pipes in the Salton Sea geothermal field. A set of 5 to 7 thermistors was permanently buried inside the individual pipes with dry sand. Consistent gradient determinations were obtained with both numerical methods from six monthly observations. By linearly extrapolating the depths to the 100/sup 0/C and 200/sup 0/C isotherms from the calculated gradients and mean ground temperatures, good agreement was found with the nearby deep-well data for four holes. Discrepancy is found for two holes, one of which is located near the field of CO/sub 2/ mud volcanoes and the other near the volcanic Red Hill, reflecting complicated local hydrologic conditions.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 42:3

TITLE: Preliminary data on the pressure effect of the viscosity of sodium chloride--water solutions in the range 10 to 40/sup 0/C
AUTHORS: Kestin, J; Khalifa, H E; Ro, S T; Wakeham, W A
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SODIUM CHLORIDES; VISCOSITY; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; QUANTITY RATIO; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SOLUTIONS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: The paper describes new, and preliminary, measurements of the viscosity of NaCl solutions in H/sub 2/O over a range of temperatures 10 to 40/sup 0/C, a range of pressures 0 to 30.0 MPa, and at three concentrations, together with check measurements on pure water. The precision is 0.2 percent and the accuracy is 0.3 percent. The measurements are represented by a purely empirical, analytic correlation which reproduces the ensemble of data with a standard deviation of 0.2 percent.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Eng. Data; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:2

TITLE: Review of osmotic coefficients of aqueous CaCl/sub 2/ at 25/sup 0/C
AUTHORS: Rard, J A; Habenschuss, A; Spedding, F H
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALCIUM CHLORIDES; OSMOSIS; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; DIFFUSION; ELECTROLYTES; ELECTROMOTIVE FORCE; MELTING POINTS; REVIEWS; VAPOR PRESSURE; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM HALIDES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; DISPERSIONS; DOCUMENT TYPES; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SOLUTIONS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TRANSITION TEMPERATURE; 400400* - Electrochemistry; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: New data have become available since Robinson and Stokes' review of the use of CaCl/sub 2/ solutions as isopiestic standards. Electrolyte activity coefficient and water activity determinations for aqueous CaCl/sub 2/ solutions from vapor pressure, isopiestic, freezing point depression, emf, and diffusion coefficient measurements are reviewed here. These activities have been updated to presently accepted values of the physical constants, and vapor pressure measurements have been corrected for the nonideal behavior of the solvent vapor. A semiempirical equation is given which represents the osmotic coefficients of aqueous CaCl/sub 2/ solutions at 25/sup 0/C from 0 to 9 m, to within the experimental uncertainty of the data. This equation is recommended for all isopiestic measurements using a CaCl/sub 2/ standard at 25/sup 0/C.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Chem. Eng. Data; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:2

TITLE: Geothermal builds steam, but slowly
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; REVIEWS; COORDINATED RESEARCH PROGRAMS; CORROSION; DEMONSTRATION PROGRAMS; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SOURCE DEVELOPMENT; EPRI; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; MANUFACTURING; POWER GENERATION; PRODUCTION; US ERDA; USES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONVERSION; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY CONVERSION; NATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; US ORGANIZATIONS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150101 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989); 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization; 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal energy is gradually being accepted, primarily in the West, but technological and economic questions still must be resolved. Technical problems of pipe and valve corrosion and capital costs are being studied by ERDA and the Electric Power Research Institute (EPRI). Demonstrations of hydrothermal power indicate that there is a potential for supplementary power and the higher production costs can be readily absorbed in utility rates. Estimates range from 11 to 100 mills per kilowatt hour (20 mills is equivalent to $12 per-barrel of oil). Although other countries have generated electricity from geothermal sources since 1904 and some U.S. cities use it for space heating, industrial use is new. Plants expect to use it to generate power, dry timber, extract sulfur, etc., as is already done in some countries. ERDA projects are exploring 18 possible industrial applications, including sugar-refining operations and chemical processing. While resource estimates are great (44,000 quads), ERDA estimates only 100 quads are recoverable. Other research is aimed at circulating liquid through fractured hot, dry rock formations, which contain about half the country's geothermal energy. (DCK)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy User News; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:11

TITLE: Geothermal-energy system readies for tryout
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; STEAM SEPARATORS; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; INDUSTRIAL PLANTS; MACHINERY; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; SEPARATION EQUIPMENT; SOUTHWEST REGION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; TURBINES; TURBOMACHINERY; USA; VAPOR SEPARATORS; 150802* - Geothermal Power Plants- Power Plant Systems & Components
DESCRIPTION: Biphase Engines Inc. will try out its new device for power and fresh water production from geothermal hot brine in the Salton Sea area, Calif., or in New Mexico. The device passes the well mixture through a nozzle to a rotary steam-brine separator. The steam may be passed through a turbine and condensed to fresh water, and further power may be extracted from the hot brine. A full-scale system would produce a net 1.1 Mw electric power and 250,000 gal/day fresh water.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 84:6

TITLE: Strain rate dependence in dolomite inferred from impact and static compression studies
AUTHORS: Grady, D E; Hollenbach, R E; Schuler, K W; Callender, J F
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 04 OIL SHALES AND TAR SANDS; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; DOLOMITE; YIELD STRENGTH; COAL INDUSTRY; COMPRESSION; CRYSTAL-PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; FAILURES; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OIL SHALE INDUSTRY; PETROLOGY; STRAIN RATE; STRAINS; STRESSES; VERY HIGH PRESSURE; WAVE PROPAGATION; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATE ROCKS; CARBONATES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOLOGY; INDUSTRY; MAGNESIUM CARBONATES; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; MINERALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESERVOIR ROCK; ROCKS; 580300* - Mineralogy, Petrology, & Rock Mechanics- (-1989); 010900 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Environmental Aspects; 041000 - Oil Shales & Tar Sands- Environmental Aspects; 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: Plate impact techniques and laser interferometry instrumentation were used to obtain continuous one-dimensional compression wave data through states of loading and unloading on Blair dolomite in the stress range of 0 to 6.5 GPa. These data are used to infer the dynamic stress--strain response. Both the character of the wave propagation and a comparison with quasi-static uniaxial strain data obtained by other workers suggest substantial strain rate dependence in this rock. The dynamic yield stress of 2.5 GPa determined from the wave propagation data was approximately a factor of 10 higher than that observed in the quasi-static data. Wave propagation below 2.5 GPa is suggestive of viscoelastic response, and a nonlinear Maxwell constitutive equation fitted to these data provides a characteristic relaxation time of 0.01 ..mu..s. Comparison of dynamic and quasi-static loading data suggests that the large difference in observed yield stress could be the result of a transition from failure by brittle fracture to failure by intracrystalline plastic flow.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 82:8

TITLE: In the North Atlantic: young and hot drilling
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; ATLANTIC OCEAN; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; MID-ATLANTIC RIDGE; OCEANIC CRUST; PETROLOGY; AGING; BOREHOLES; DATA ACQUISITION; DRILL CORES; EARTH CRUST; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; HOT SPOTS; ICELAND; LAVA; STRATIGRAPHY; CAVITIES; EUROPE; GEOLOGY; IGNEOUS ROCKS; ROCKS; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; 152000* - Geothermal Data & Theory; 580100 - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Crustal formation processes in the North Atlantic were studied in a 49-day, 4,275 mile expedition in which nine holes were drilled at eight sites in water 832 to 2,977 m deep. Scientific problems studied included: the history of the Icelandic hot spot and its associated geochemical anomaly; the evidence for hydrothermal alteration of ocean crust in both transverse and longitudinal transects of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge; evidence for aging effects in the ocean crust; the variability of petrology and chemistry along an isochron in the Mid-Atlantic Ridge crestal regions; the history of glaciation in the North Atlantic. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotimes; (United States); Journal Volume: 22:3

TITLE: Geothermal energy: on the way up
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; REVIEWS; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; USA; ENERGY SUBSTITUTION EQUIVALENT; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; IMPERIAL VALLEY; KGRA; WELL DRILLING; CALIFORNIA; DOCUMENT TYPES; DRILLING; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A survey of the status of geothermal energy in the US covers the ongoing expansion of capacity at The Geysers in northern California, in terms of oil equivalent, from 5 to 9 million bbl/year; expectation of an imminent breakthrough in the use of geothermal hot water to produce energy in California's Imperial Valley; classification by the US Geological Survey of 2 million acres in western states as geothermal resource areas; and the fact that the greatest drilling activity continues to be in the area of The Geysers geothermal field.
RELATION: Journal Name: Pac. Oil World; (United States); Journal Volume: 70:3

TITLE: Recent fractures along the northeast margin of the Salton Trough, Imperial County, California
AUTHORS: Buckley, C P; Magee, M E; Hayden, N A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IMPERIAL VALLEY; FRACTURES; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; AERIAL MONITORING; EARTH CRUST; MAPS; ORIGIN; SIZE; CALIFORNIA; FAILURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; MONITORING; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Ground fractures along the northeast margin of the Salton Trough near Dos Palmas Spring, Imperial Valley were investigated. The west-northwest-trending fracture zone measured 4 km in length with a maximum width of 135 meters. Both aerial and surface mapping methods were used in the investigation. Preliminary data indicate that the fractures are aseismic, tectonic in origin, and the product of tensional stress. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Calif. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 30:3

TITLE: Estimating depth of the source of hydrothermal solutions from thermobarometric data
AUTHORS: Pek, A A; Piloyan, G O
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; DEPTH; GEOBAROMETRY; HEAT TRANSFER; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; ROCKS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; DIMENSIONS; ENERGY TRANSFER; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: Possible interpretations of data on the thermal evolution of hydrothermal systems are discussed. A model of a hydrothermal system with gradually diminishing source of solutions is presented and the problem of heat exchange between the flow of solutions and the wall rocks is formulated and solved. A method of estimating the depth to the source of hydrothermal solutions from mineralogical thermobarometry data and information on the geometry of ancient hydrothermal system and thermal properties of rocks is proposed and analyzed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. Geol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 19:3; Other Information: Translated from Geol. Rud. Mestorozhd.; 19: No. 4, 68-81(1975)

SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; POROUS MATERIALS; ELASTICITY; COMPRESSION; FLUIDS; MATHEMATICS; POROSITY; ROCKS; MATERIALS; MECHANICAL PROPERTIES; TENSILE PROPERTIES; 152002* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: In calculations of the effective elastic moduli of heterogeneous materials, special care must be taken if one of the components is a liquid. Connections between liquid-filled regions (pores) can lead to a substantial reduction of the moduli. This effect can be incorporated into the computations with use of a theorem due to Gassmann.
