TITLE: Economics of geothermal heat as an alternate fuel
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; ELECTRIC POWER; COST; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ECONOMICS; USES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ENERGY DEMAND; FUELS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; POWER GENERATION; PROFITS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; HEATING; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal energy can substitute for and compete with other fuels, but until now it has been used only in special situations where it costs much less than alternate fuels. Geothermal heat is expected to be developed where it can: (1) compete with alternate fuels, (2) replace scarce fuels, (3) be more environmentally acceptable, or (4) is especially adapted to local needs. Economic problems in development include the often high capital costs of wells and gathering systems and the long lead-times required for electric generating plants. The large investment and long payout times for large industrial uses adversely affect the economics.
RELATION: Journal Name: Trans. Soc. Min. Eng. AIME; (United States); Journal Volume: 260:4
JOURNAL_NAME: Trans. Soc. Min. Eng. AIME; (United States)

TITLE: Tectonic transpression and basement-controlled deformation in San Andreas fault zone, Salton trough, California
AUTHORS: Sylvester, A G; Smith, R R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; CALIFORNIA; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; TECTONICS; DEFORMATION; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; IMPERIAL VALLEY; SALTON SEA; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 580201 - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The San Andreas fault zone in the Salton trough is characterized by subparallel, high-angle faults, en-echelon folds, and systematically arranged arrays of reverse and normal faults which are typical of major wrench faults elsewhere in the world. Detailed field mapping in the Mecca Hills shows that the fault zone is delineated by two northeast-striking high-angle faults which subdivide pre-Cenozoic crystalline and schistose basement and overlying late Cenozoic and Quaternary nonmarine sedimentary rocks into three structural domains: (1) a high-standing, relatively undeformed block northeast of the fault zone; (2) a 1.5 km-wide zone of folded sedimentary rocks between the two faults; and (3) a sparsely exposed, deeply down-faulted block on the southwest. Locally the two faults branch upward and flatten abruptly outward into low-angle thrusts which carry thrust slices and gravity slides of sedimentary rocks from the central block short distances on to the adjacent blocks. Between the two faults the sedimentary succession is folded into broad west-northwest-trending open folds which tighten and are overturned and truncated against the faults. Where exposed in the fault zone the basement-sedimentary rock contact is a buttress unconformity which also is folded and overturned locally. Field observations reveal that the basement in the core of the fold is fractured and sheared pervasively, indicating that the mechanism of basement deformation was one of cataclastic flow by piecemeal slip on the closely spaced fracture and shear planes, whereas the folding of the overlying sedimentary rocks was largely a passive consequence of deformation at the basement level. Although horizontal shear strain predominated, local vertical uplift of the basement occurred as a result of compression between two convergently and laterally slipping rigid crustal blocks.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 60:12
JOURNAL_NAME: Am. Assoc. Pet. Geol. Bull.; (United States)

TITLE: Statistical evaluation of electrical sounding methods. Part II. Applied electromagnetic depth sounding
AUTHORS: Ward, S H; Smith, B D; Glenn, W E; Rijo, L; Inman, Jr, J R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; UTAH; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; LEAST SQUARE FIT; STATISTICAL MODELS; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MAXIMUM-LIKELIHOOD FIT; NORTH AMERICA; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580203 - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Schlumberger resistivity and electromagnetic sounding data were obtained over prehistoric Lake Bonneville sediments near Delta, Utah. Inverse interpretation of these data illustrates that vertical electric sounding with the Schlumberger array is superior, for this environment, to electromagnetic sounding with either a vertical magnetic dipole or a horizontal magnetic dipole. Combined parametric and geometric electromagnetic sounding using 84 data points is inferior to Schlumberger sounding using 21 data points. However, superiority in these contexts pertains to parameter resolution. The earth models obtained with all three soundings are virtually identical within the limits of resolution. The importance of percent parameter standard deviations, parameter correlations, and least-squares residuals are all illustrated for a field example in this manuscript. Reparameterization in terms of the Dar Zarrouk parameters S and T reduces the parameter correlations as expected. A generalization of reparameterization beyond the Dar Zarrouk parameters is suggested.
RESEARCH_ORG: Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 41:6A

TITLE: Dual-wavelength thermal infrared scanner as a potential airborne geophysical exploration tool
AUTHORS: LeSchack, L A; Del Grande, N K
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; INFRARED SURVEYS; CORRECTIONS; AERIAL PROSPECTING; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; PROSPECTING; 580203* - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989); 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The authors are investigating a new airborne method for measuring surface temperatures that may be useful for identifying thermal anomalies of geologic origin. Complicating factors, such as surface emissivity, soil composition and moisture, topography, hydrology and meteorological conditions, which can completely mask the temperature effects sought, must be removed. The techniques developed appear to be useful in making the needed correction to ir data, thus permitting the isolation of the true temperature anomalies sought.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 41:6

TITLE: Working model of some equilibria in the system alumina--silica--water
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ALUMINIUM OXIDES; PHASE DIAGRAMS; SILICA; WATER; CORUNDUM; DIAGENESIS; ENTROPY; EQUILIBRIUM; PYROPHYLLITE; QUARTZ; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TOPOLOGY; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM SILICATES; CHALCOGENIDES; DIAGRAMS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATHEMATICS; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: Topological analysis, petrographic, experimental, and thermodynamic data have been used to construct a phase diagram for some equilibria in the system alumina-silica-water. Topological analysis is used to deduce the possible arrangements of univariant curves and invariant points. A choice among the possible arrangements was made using a simple criterion for orientation based on the signs and relative magnitudes of the entropies and volumes of univariant reactions. Experimental data and one assumption regarding some petrographic information were used to locate the univariant and invariant equilibria in pressure-temperature space. The resulting phase diagram suggests that a field for the stable coexistence of pyrophyllite and corundum does not exist. Most natural occurrences of diaspore + quartz probably represent disequilibrium, but a stability field for this assemblage may exist at high pressure. A field for the stable coexistence of pyrophyllite, diaspore, and water might be restricted to pressures where kyanite is stable. It is suggested that pyrophyllite may be stable during the diagenesis or very low-grade metamorphism of sediments. It is concluded that the proposed phase diagram represents a viable working model for some equilibria in this system.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 276:10

TITLE: Will US geothermal resources win a role in process plants
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL PROCESS HEAT; USA; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ABUNDANCE; CONSTRUCTION; COST; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY CONSERVATION; FEDERAL REGION IX; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT RECOVERY; HEAT TRANSFER; ENERGY; ENERGY RECOVERY; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY TRANSFER; HEAT; HEATING; NORTH AMERICA; POWER PLANTS; PROCESS HEAT; RECOVERY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 151000 - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: Outside the U.S., the chemical process industries are already exploiting geothermal energy for several tasks. Now, the U.S. is moving toward similar applications. A prime attraction is that low-grade heat from geothermal resources is widely available in the U.S., particularly in the western states. Despite the greater attention now afforded to using geothermal resources for electricity generation, which requires temperatures starting at about 150/sup 0/C, lower temperature geothermal resources are about equally abundant. Second, nonelectric use of low-temperature resources boasts greater utilization efficiency than electricity generation from higher temperature geothermal resources. A third attraction for nonelectric tasks is fewer technical complications and risks in actually using the geothermal energy. Fourth, a typical nonelectric geothermal system is much smaller and thus far less expensive to build than a power plant. However, there is one prominent cloud on the nonelectric horizon. The use installation must be situated quite near the geothermal resource, since heat cannot be shipped very far.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 83:24

TITLE: Nonelectric geothermal: a versatile resource
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT SPRINGS; REVIEWS; AGRICULTURE; BALNEOLOGY; DATA COMPILATION; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; DOCUMENT TYPES; MEDICINE; RESOURCES; THERMAL SPRINGS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization

TITLE: Thermodynamics of seawater at one atmosphere
AUTHORS: Millero, F J; Leung, W H
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SEAWATER; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; ENTHALPY; ENTROPY; FREE ENERGY; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; OSMOSIS; SPECIFIC HEAT; ENERGY; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; WATER; 152001* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: The solution thermodynamic properties of seawater at 1 atm have been examined over the range of 0/sup 0/ to 40/sup 0/C and 0 to 40% salinity. By combining the osmotic coefficients (phi = -(55.51/2m) ln a/sub 1/, where m is the molality and a/sub 1/ is the activity of water) determined from the freezing point measurements of Doherty and Kester (1974), with the heat capacity data of Millero, Perron, and Desnoyers (1973), and the enthalpy data of Millero, Hansen, and Hoff (1973), the osmotic coefficients were determined over the range of 0/sup 0/ to 40/sup 0/C at 1 atm using the extended Debye-Heuckel equation. The results at 25/sup 0/C were found to be in excellent agreement with the results of Robinson (1954). From the osmotic coefficient data, the vapor pressure and osmotic pressure have been determined. The osmotic coefficient data at 0/sup 0/C has been used to calculate the mean activity coefficient and activity of ''sea salt.'' By using the thermodynamic equation delta lna/sub 2//delta T + - anti L/sub 2//RT, activities have been determined at other temperatures (0/sup 0/ to 40/sup 0/C). The relative free energies of seawater, G - G/sup 0/ + 55.51 RT ln a/sub 1/ = m RT ln a/sub 2/, have been calculated from the osmotic and activity data.The relative entropy of seawater (S - S/sup 0/) was determined from the relative free energies by using the thermodynamic relationship, S - S/sup 0/ + ((G - G/sup 0/) - (H - H/sup 0/))/T, where H - H/sup 0/ is the relative enthalpy. All the specific thermochemical properties (P) of seawater have been fitted to equations.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 276:9

TITLE: Geothermal energy promising but risky
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; USA; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; ECONOMICS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; REVIEWS; TECHNOLOGY ASSESSMENT; DOCUMENT TYPES; EXPLORATION; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Some technical, economic, and environmental problems associated with the exploration and development of geothermal resources are discussed. Some potentially important areas noted are Hawaii, Buffalo Valley, Nevada, and the Gulf Coast of Texas and Louisiana. It is stated that geothermal energy seems to be approaching something of a crucial period of decision in the next few years. (LBS)
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. News; (United States); Journal Volume: 54:42

TITLE: Growth rate of a penny-shaped crack in hydraulic fracturing of rocks
AUTHORS: Abe, H; Mura, T; Keer, L M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; CRACKS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; ROCKS; COMMINUTION; FRACTURING; 150906* - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology
DESCRIPTION: The stable growth of a crack created by the hydraulic pressurizing of a penny-shaped crack in a dry rock mass is investigated. The rock mass is infinitely extended, homogeneous, and isotropic. It is verified on the basis of the equations of fluid dynamics that the fracturing fluid cannot penetrate the entire domain of a crack when the crack is moving. The effects of various terms in the basic equations are also studied. The solution of some typical examples is given, and the significant effect of the stress intensity factor of the rock on the crack propagation is shown. When the crack is expanding under a constant flow rate, the classical solution by Sack is found to be approximately valid for very large cracks, and nevertheless the crack is stable.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 81:29

TITLE: Making electricity from moderate temperature fluids
AUTHORS: Kunze, J F; Whitbeck, J F; Miller, L G; Griffith, J L
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PLANNING; TESTING; IDAHO; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; DRILL CORES; ECONOMICS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; LITHOLOGY; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; POWER GENERATION; RAFT RIVER VALLEY; REVIEWS; TEST FACILITIES; USES; DOCUMENT TYPES; EXPLORATION; FLUIDS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; RESOURCES; USA; WELLS; 150900* - Geothermal Engineering

The Idaho National Engineering Laboratory's geothermal program to find ways of economically utilizing such fluids is described. Data from exploratory well drilling are shown. The proposed program to develop the wells needed for producing and reinjecting 5,000 gpm and to construct a versatile test facility to examine method of reducing the costs of electricity is outlined. (MHR)

AUTHORS: Rosenbruch, J C; Bottge, R G

TITLE: Comparison of two electrical probing techniques. [Loop-source and grounded-ware methods]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HAWAII; ELECTROMAGNETIC SURVEYS; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; ROCKS; VOLCANOES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Two electromagnetic survey techniques were applied to an area surrounding the crater of Kilauea volcano in Hawaii. The subject of the investigation was a conductive zone at a depth of about 1.0 km which is associated with geothermal heating. In one technique, the EM field was generated by passing current steps through a grounded wire transmitter. In the second, current steps were passed through an ungrounded loop. Detection at the receiver site was accomplished by measuring the vertical induction component with an ungrounded loop. Both methods accurately indicated a conductive layer at depth, but the grounded wire source proved more effective due to a slower field decay with distance. This enabled a larger area to be surveyed.
RELATION: Journal Name: IEEE Trans. Geosci. Electron.; (United States); Journal Volume: 14:4

DESCRIPTION: Spectral gamma logging in the crystalline basement rocks of two deep holes of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory's Dry Hot Rock Geothermal Project indicates that this type of log is useful for determining rock types, detecting fracture zones, and examining mobility of the heat-producing elements U, Th, and K.

TITLE: Entropy estimates for some silicates at 298/sup 0/K from molar volumes
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; SILICATES; ENTROPY; FELDSPARS; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; MINERALS; PARTIAL MOLAL VOLUME; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 152002* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: Third law entropies for silicates of Be, Mg, Ca, Zn, Na, and K containing the same anion group, for example, SiO/sub 4/ or SiO/sub 3/ or AlSi/sub 3/O/sub 8/, are found to be linearly related to their molar volumes. The relationship between the molar volume and the entropy of silicates of Fe and Mn, atoms with unfilled d electron subshells, is different from that of other silicates. The linear correlations yield a useful method of estimating the entropies of ortho-, meta-, and framework silicates (feldspars and feldspathoids). The estimated entropies of pyrope and almandine at 298/sup 0/K are 47.47 and 68.13 gibbs per mole, respectively.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 193:4259

TITLE: Yellowstone: seismic evidence for a chemical mantle plume
AUTHORS: Hadley, D M; Stewart, G S; Ebel, J E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK; HOT SPOTS; SEISMIC SURVEYS; CALDERAS; EARTH MANTLE; NEVADA TEST SITE; SEISMIC P WAVES; VELOCITY; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; PUBLIC LANDS; SEISMIC WAVES; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Arrivals of P waves from a recent event at the Nevada Test Site, recorded at a distance of 15.3/sup 0/, passed beneath the Yellowstone caldera at depths of 200 and 400 kilometers. The travel time anomalies are modeled by a vertical cylindrical structure with a high-velocity core and a low-velocity collar as compared with the more normal mantle. The velocity structure and vertical extent of this feature are consistent with a chemical mantle plume beneath the Yellowstone caldera.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 193:4259

TITLE: Heat flow data and their relation to observed geothermal phenomena near Klamath Falls, Oregon
AUTHORS: Sass, J H; Sammel, E A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OREGON; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; HEAT FLOW; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Two holes were drilled to depths of about 180 m in the Lower Klamath Lake basin south of Klamath Falls, Oregon, to obtain heat flow data and to provide estimates of the thermal conductivity of the valley fill. Twenty-nine thermal conductivity determinations on eight cores give a mean conductivity of 1.82 meal/cm s degreeC (0.75 W/m degreeK). Curvature in the upper 50 m of both temperature profiles indicates a decrease in surface temperature of about 1.8degreeC, presumably resulting from reclamation of what was marshland in the early part of this century. A surprisingly low heat flow of 0.3 HFU (F HFU=10/sup -6/ cal/cm/sup 2/s=41.8 mW/cm/sup 2/) was measured at site LS near the center of the basin. At site OC-1,7 km east of LS and 2 km from the Klamath Hills geothermal zone, the heat flow was 1.44 HFU, also a low value in this setting. Temperature profiles in 15 unused water wells in the area had linear gradients ranging from 47degree to 170degreeC/km. The corresponding lower limits of heat flow (conductivities measured at the two heat flow sites being used) range from 0.8 to 3.1 HFU. These variations in heat flow evidently are caused by temperature variations in a convecting system within the near-surface volcanic rocks and do not provide firm constraints on the nature sources at depth. (AIP)
RESEARCH_ORG: U.S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025

TITLE: Geothermal activity in Iceland

TITLE: Hawaiians test first U. S. volcanic geothermal well
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; TESTING; WELL DRILLING; HAWAII; KILAUEA VOLCANO; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; FLASHING; HIGH TEMPERATURE; PERMEABILITY; PRESSURE MEASUREMENT; PUMPING; RIFT ZONES; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; DRILLING; EVAPORATION; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; USA; VOLCANOES; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging
DESCRIPTION: It is stated that a test well drilled into Kilauea Volcano's east rift zone may produce enough steam for 617/sup 0/F water to supply electricity for up to 10,000 persons. The latest test indicates the well has sufficient rock permeability and fluid storage to recharge itself. Drilling begun in Dec. 1975 was completed at 6450 ft in Apr. 1976. A slotted casing was installed in the bottom 4300 ft of the well, drilling mud was flushed from the hole, a series of pumping tests were conducted to obtain temperature and pressure measurements, and the well was flashed for a short period early in July 1976. The next step, a 4 to 6 week flash within the next two months, will explore recharging capabilities. At least two more comparative test wells probably will be drilled before a prototype powerplant is built. Power could be on the line within four years if the project proceeds on schedule. More than $3 million has already been committed by the National Science Foundation, ERDA, the Hawaiian Electric Co., and Water Resources International Inc., which drilled the shaft.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. Min. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 177:9

TITLE: Legal issues in the development of geopressured geothermal resources of Texas and Louisiana Gulf Coast (Summary). [Resource definitions in statutes of 15 states]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; LAWS; LEGAL ASPECTS; ALASKA; ARIZONA; CALIFORNIA; COLORADO; HAWAII; IDAHO; LEGISLATION; LOUISIANA; MONTANA; NEVADA; NEW MEXICO; OREGON; TEXAS; USA; UTAH; WASHINGTON; WYOMING; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; RESOURCES; ROCKY MOUNTAIN REGION; SOUTHWEST REGION; WESTERN REGION; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Two major topics, legal scholarship and legal support, are covered. Scholarship is distinguished from support by concentration on abstract analyses of issues, which include resource definition, ownership, taxation, and multistate reservoirs. Support is based entirely on those legal tasks called up by the technical work scheduled in the areas of resource assessment, advanced research and technology, institutional and environmental and resource utilization. The definitions contained in the statutes of the thirteen western states, Texas, and Louisiana are presented. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:9

TITLE: Geothermal energy in North Sea might extend platform usefulness
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NORTH SEA; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; UNITED KINGDOM; AQUIFERS; COST; ENERGY YIELD; EXPLOITATION; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; OFFSHORE PLATFORMS; RECOVERY; ROCKS; ATLANTIC OCEAN; EUROPE; EXPLORATION; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The North Sea is one area to be studied for geothermal energy potential by Britain's Department of Energy. A relatively well documented area shows some of the highest temperature gradients recorded in the UK. Fairly extensive regions are known to have gradients over 40/sup 0/C/km and as these tend to correlate with deep sections of the sedimentary basin there are good prospects for obtaining heat in the range 150--200/sup 0/C. The temperature at the bottom of one hole drilled for oil topped 160/sup 0/C. It is suggested that heat recovered from hot rocks or hot aquifers might cost less at the well-head than low-temperature heat from imported oil. It estimates that the heat beneath each square kilometer of hot rock could be recoverable at a rate equivalent to 200,000--300,000 tons/year of coal for 20 years, while hot aquifers might yield heat equivalent to 50,000 tons/year of coal per sq km over the same period. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Ocean Ind.; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:9

TITLE: Geothermal steam roars. [Flashing of first geothermal test well in Hawaii]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; TESTING; HAWAII; FLASHING; RECHARGE; EVAPORATION; NORTH AMERICA; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: A successful four-hour flashing of Hawaii's first geothermal test well is described. The results of this test are discussed. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:9

TITLE: Depressions surrounding volcanic fields: a reflection of underlying batholiths
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; VOLCANIC REGIONS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; IMAGES; MOUNTAINS; REMOTE SENSING; SATELLITES; VOLCANIC ROCKS; EXPLORATION; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The eastern Klamath Mountains of northern California are cut sharply by an arcuate scarp that forms the west wall of a depression containing Pliocene to Holocene lavas. This depression may have formed by collapse along hidden concentric fractures over a batholith and, if so, reflects the shape and areal extent of the body. Large depressions enclosing other volcanic fields are evident on small-scale satellite imagery. If such depressions overlie still hot or even molten batholithic bodies, analysis of satellite imagery might delineate the areal extent of associated geothermal resources.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geology; (United States); Journal Volume: 4

TITLE: On the form and stability of open hydraulic fractures in the earth's crust
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; FRACTURES; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; WELL STIMULATION; COMMINUTION; FAILURES; FRACTURING; RESOURCES; 150906* - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology
DESCRIPTION: The cross-sectional form and stability of large hydraulic fractures are found to be very sensitive to symmetric gradients in fluid pressure and regional stress. Horizontal sections through vertical fractures may be subjected to symmetric pressure gradients by locating inflow and outflow wells near the fracture center and tips. A dumbbell form, resulting from flow from the tips toward the center, has a limital length beyond which the fracture closes at the center and propagates unstably at the tips. A diamond form, resulting from the opposite sense of flow, has no limital length and a stable propagation. These features of fracture form and stability may play an important role in the design of hydraulic fractures for geothermal energy production. (AIP)
RESEARCH_ORG: U. S. Geological Survey, Menlo Park, California 94025
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Res. Lett.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:9

TITLE: Kinetics of illite formation
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ILLITE; HYDROTHERMAL SYNTHESIS; ACTIVATION ENERGY; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CLAYS; DIAGENESIS; HIGH TEMPERATURE; REACTION KINETICS; ENERGY; KINETICS; MINERALS; SYNTHESIS; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: An activation energy of 19.6 +- 3.5 kcal/mole was found for conversion of synthetic beidellite with the composition Al/sub 2/Si/sub 3/./sub 66/Al/sub 0/./sub 34/O/sub 10/(OH)/sub 2/K/sub 0/./sub 34/ to mixed-layer illite/smectite. The size of this activation energy and the rate constants suggest that (1) the alteration of smectite to illite during diagenesis involves the breaking of chemical bonds in the 2:1 layers; (2) either an equilibrium or a kinetic interpretation for the range of mixed layering found in burial diagenetic sequences is compatible with the kinetic data; and (3) the formation of illite from smectite on the ocean floor will not be seen, even if the reaction is favored thermodynamically, because the reaction rate is too slow.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:9

TITLE: Indians cautious on development
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 98 NUCLEAR DISARMAMENT, SAFEGUARDS, AND PHYSICAL PROTECTION; 02 PETROLEUM; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 03 NATURAL GAS; COAL INDUSTRY; PLANNING; ENERGY POLICY; ENERGY SOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; NATURAL GAS INDUSTRY; PETROLEUM INDUSTRY; URANIUM RESERVES; USA; ALLOCATIONS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENTS; INCOME; LAND USE; LEASING; RESERVES; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; DOCUMENT TYPES; INDUSTRY; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; 290400* - Energy Planning & Policy- Energy Resources; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 055000 - Nuclear Fuels- Safeguards, Inspection, & Accountability; 021000 - Petroleum- Legislation & Regulations; 017000 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Legislation & Regulations; 031000 - Natural Gas- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The stresses and strains that would result from the mining of fossil and nuclear fuels on Indian reservations in the western U. S. cannot be conveyed in environmental impact statements, according to Ronald G. Faich, director of the Navajo Research and Statistics Center at Window Rock, Arizona. There are 22 Indian tribes with valuable energy resources. In the U.S., Indian lands contain more than half the known coal reserves on public domain and 33 percent of all proven reserves west of the Mississippi. More than three-fourths of the Navajo tribe's revenues do come from its energy leasing program. Indians currently have two geothermal, 13,583 petroleum, 380 uranium, and 11 coal leases. Some tribes desire to mine, refine, and sell their own resources. Federal agencies are helping with financial, technical, and legal guidance. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Dig. (Wash., D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 6:10

TITLE: Hearing on the ownership of geothermal steam underlying Geysers. Geothermal Kinetics Inc. , plaintiff, vs Union Oil Company of California, defendants, May 28, 1976
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; HEARINGS; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; MINERAL RESOURCES; AGRICULTURE; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; LEASING; LEGISLATION; NATURAL STEAM; WATER RESOURCES; FLUIDS; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; STEAM; USA; WESTERN REGION; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: The question before the court (Superior Court of the State of California) was whether the geothermal steam system belongs to the owner of the mineral rights or the surface rights. This case involved conflicting claims to the geothermal steam system which underlies 408 acres of essentially unimproved mountain property lying south of Big Sulfur Creek in an area known as ''The Geysers'' in Sonoma County, California. A history of the land and mineral rights transfers since 1925 is reviewed. The Federal government and California recognize a geothermal system as being an energy resource. It was concluded at the hearing that the energy produced is a direct product of the molten minerals and gases within the resource. The water which transports the energy to the surface is a conveyor belt, nothing more. The total resource has all of the basic characteristics of those resources which the courts have classified as minerals on many occasions in many jurisdictions. The water condensed from the resource is not necessary for or beneficial to the use of the land. The surface owner wants the energy which the water carries, not the water itself. It is for these reasons that the court held that the plaintiff is the owner and entitled to the possession and control of all the geothermal steam and power and geothermal resources in and under the subject property by virtue of its leasehold interest. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geyser; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:11

TITLE: Heat flow measurements in deep crustal holes on the mid-Atlantic ridge
AUTHORS: Hyndman, R D; von Herzen, R P; Erickson, A J; Jolivet, J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; EARTH CRUST; HEAT FLOW; ATLANTIC OCEAN; SEA BED; SEA-FLOOR SPREADING; SEDIMENTS; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580202 - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 580201 - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Heat flow measurements have been made in five deep crustal holes drilled into the mid-Atlantic ridge by the Deep-Sea Drilling Project ship Glamar Challenger. The data provide new information on the hydrothermal circulation that probably controls the crustal temperature distribution near ocean ridge spreading centers. Nearly constant very low heat flow of 0.6 +- 0.1 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/ s/sup -1/ (25 +- 4 mW m/sup 2/) was found for three deep holes and three standard ocean probe measurements across one 3-km-wide sediment pond on 3.5-m.y.-old sea floor and to a depth of 400 m into the underlying basaltic basement. The heat flow predicted by conductive cooling models of plate accretion is much higher, about 6.4 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/ s/sup -1/ (270 mW m/sup -2/). The result suggests that heat is carried to the surface by extensive hydrothermal circulation that extends at least to the lower part of layer 2, such that the heat flux based on conductive estimates represents only a fraction of the total flux. A borehole into 16-m.y.-old sea floor appears to have penetrated a convective system. Temperature measurements in the basement part indicate that seawater was flowing rapidly down the hole into a permeable horizon near the bottom at 324-m depth. The heat flow of 0.5 ..mu..cal cm/sup -2/ s/sup -1/(21 mW m/sup -2/) measured in the overlying sediments suggests that before the hole was drilled,water at about 10degreeC may have been flowing horizontally in this horizon. (AIP)
RESEARCH_ORG: Victoria Geophysical Observatory, Earth Physics Branch, Department of Energy, Mines and Resources, Victoria, British Colombia, Canada
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 81:23

TITLE: Strong-motion earthquake accelerograms at Brawley, California: January 25, 1975
AUTHORS: Johnson, D A; Hanks, T C
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EARTHQUAKES; SEISMIC DETECTION; IMPERIAL VALLEY; ACCELEROMETERS; CALIFORNIA; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC EVENTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: During the Brawley earthquake swarm of January, February, 1975, a single strong-motion accelerograph installed after the swarm began recorded 27 positively identified earthquakes in 14 hr, at hypocentral distances of approximately 5 km. Eight of these had magnitudes (M/sub L/) greater than or equal to 3.5, and several had M/sub L/ less than 2.5; the instrument independently triggered 18 times. Peak accelerations in excess of 10 percent g were obtained for five of the eight earthquakes with M/sub L/ greater than or equal to 3.5, and a peak acceleration of 25 percent g was recorded for the largest event, M/sub L/ = 4.3.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Seismol. Soc. Am.; (United States); Journal Volume: 66:4

TITLE: Earthquake sounds generated by body-wave ground motion
AUTHORS: Hill, D P; Fischer, F G; Lahr, K M; Coakley, J M
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EARTHQUAKES; ACOUSTIC MONITORING; IMPERIAL VALLEY; SEISMIC SURVEYS; GROUND MOTION; CALIFORNIA; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MONITORING; MOTION; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC EVENTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Simultaneous recordings of acoustic pressure waves and seismic body waves were obtained for three earthquakes of magnitude 2.0, 2.6, and 2.8 in the Imperial Valley, California, at hypocentral distances of 7 to 8 km. The recordings show that an acoustic signal with frequencies between 50 and 70 Hz begins within 0.02 sec of the P-wave arrival and gradually dies out by the time of the S-wave arrival about 2 sec later. These recordings are consistent with reports that a low rumbling sound frequently accompanied earthquakes in the January 1975 swarm. They also explain reports that the sound was often heard several seconds before the earthquakes were felt in that perceptible shaking apparently begins with the S wave for local earthquakes of magnitude less than about 3. Calculations of the transmission coefficients for seismic P and SV waves converted to acoustic waves at the Earth's surface confirm that body-wave ground motion from local earthquakes is sufficient to generate audible acoustic pressure waves.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Seismol. Soc. Am.; (United States); Journal Volume: 66:4

TITLE: Surface faulting in Imperial Valley during the earthquake swarm of January--February 1975
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IMPERIAL VALLEY; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; CRACKS; EARTH CRUST; EARTHQUAKES; FRACTURES; CALIFORNIA; FAILURES; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC EVENTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Surface ruptures formed along a 10.4-km segment of the Brawley fault during the earthquake swarm of January and February, 1975, in central Imperial Valley, California. This newly recognized fault appears to branch northward from the Imperial fault about 8 km east-northeast of El Centro. Displacement at the surface was apparently vertical and reached a maximum of probably more than 0.2 m at Keystone Road. En echelon cracking suggested an incipient right-lateral component, but roads and irrigation canals were not laterally offset by the faulting. Surface cracks and most of the displacement probably developed suddenly at the time of the largest shock (M 4.7) in the swarm on January 23. At Harris Road, vertical movement continued at least until March 24, but significant afterslip across the fault zone may have ceased by February 13. Vertical movement after the 13th apparently took the form of a relative subsidence centered on the fault with no important net slip across the fault. Pre-1975 historic displacements on the Brawley fault occurred in 1940 at the time of the M 7.1 Imperial Valley earthquake and probably as intermittent creep between 1940 and 1975.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Seismol. Soc. Am.; (United States); Journal Volume: 66:4

TITLE: Tectonic implications of the Brawley earthquake swarm, Imperial Valley, California, January 1975
AUTHORS: Johnson, C E; Hadley, D M
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IMPERIAL VALLEY; TECTONICS; EARTHQUAKES; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; CALIFORNIA; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; NORTH AMERICA; SEISMIC EVENTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 580201* - Geophysics- Seismology & Tectonics- (1980-1989); 150201 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Brawley earthquake swarm was most intense for a period of 4 days including 75 events with M/sub L/ between 3.0 and 4.7 with a spatial extent of 12 km. Precise relative hypocenters were obtained for 264 earthquakes (M/sub L/ greater than or equal to 1.5) using a master event method to calibrate the USGS Imperial Valley array. These locations together with well-constrained focal mechanisms for 16 of the largest events suggest faulting on at least three distinct structures. Hypocentral depths ranged from 4 to 8 km, compared to a basement depth of about 6 km for this part of the Imperial Valley. The swarm began on a nearly vertical right-lateral fault striking N8 W (Brawley fault) about 8 km southeast of Brawley at a point which had experienced enhanced shallow seismicity during the preceding 4 days. The seismicity migrated bilaterally north and south from this point at a constant velocity of 0.5 km/hr terminating to the north on a steeply south dipping, N50/sup 0/E-striking fault. This structure is on trend with splays associated with the northern end of ground breakage of the 1940 Imperial Valley earthquake. To the south the seismicity ended near the northern end of the 10 km of surface rupture mapped by R.V. Sharp, which continues on strike to a point near the Imperial fault. Tectonic interpretations include the transfer of right-lateral offset from the Imperial fault to the Brawley fault associated with the formation of a closed depression bounded on the west and east by these two faults.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bull. Seismol. Soc. Am.; (United States); Journal Volume: 66:4

TITLE: Structural features of the Salton Trough as seen from Skylab
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; IMPERIAL VALLEY; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; SALTON SEA; CERRO PRIETO GEOTHERMAL FIELD; IMAGES; MAPS; PHOTOGRAPHY; SKYLAB; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; SATELLITES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 580100 - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Examination of four adjoining Skylab frames of the Salton Trough (taken 2 June 1973) allows regional tracing of important tectonic lineaments (faults, fractures, fault controlled valleys, and sand dunes) and a description of the entire region's structural features. Structural sketch maps compiled from each frame of the photo imagery are given and discussed. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Calif. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 29:8

TITLE: OPEC oil price enhances U. S. geothermal development
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ECONOMICS; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; POWER GENERATION; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ENERGY SUPPLIES; NATURAL GAS; PETROLEUM; RESERVES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Higher costs of imported oil have caused the price for geothermal steam to more than double in two years, greatly enhancing economics of geothermal development. And, considering the demonstated ability of OPEC to maintain strong world crude prices and the slow materialization of other domestic alternate energy sources, it is expected that future prices for geothermal steam will continue to be attractive. A general appraisal of the U.S. geothermal energy picture is presented, which tells why geothermal development is attractive at this time; some specific comments are included on evaluating reserves and operating economics in The Geysers geothermal area of California.
RESEARCH_ORG: Keplinger and Associates, Inc., Tulsa, OK
RELATION: Journal Name: World Oil; (United States); Journal Volume: 183:2

TITLE: OPEC oil price enhances U. S. geothermal development
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ECONOMICS; RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT; PETROLEUM; PRICES; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; SUPPLY AND DEMAND; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FEDERAL REGION IX; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Despite government's well intentioned, but misguided, efforts to tamper with the laws of supply and demand, higher costs of imported oil have caused the price for geothermal steam to more than double in 2 yr greatly enhancing economics of geothermal development. Considering the demonstrated ability of OPEC to maintain strong world crude prices and the slow materialization of other domestic alternate energy sources, it is expected that future prices for geothermal steam will continue to be attractive. Steam purchased by utilities at The Geysers field have kept pace with alternative fuel costs as shown in an example economic analysis. New plants are expected to be built in other states in the near future. This study is a general appraisal of the U.S. geothermal energy picture that will tell why geothermal development is attractive at this time, and some specific comments are presented on evaluating reserves and operating economics in The Geysers geothermal area of California.
RELATION: Journal Name: World Oil; (United States); Journal Volume: 183:2

TITLE: Variations on a theme by Mollier (a study of the properties of steam and hot water)
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; AQUEOUS SOLUTIONS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; STEAM; MOLLIER DIAGRAMS; WATER; WATER VAPOR; DIAGRAMS; ENTHALPY; ENTROPY; DISPERSIONS; FLUIDS; GASES; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MIXTURES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SOLUTIONS; VAPORS; 152001* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions; 400201 - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties
DESCRIPTION: The ''state'' of steam, hot water, and steam/water mixtures can be expressed in terms of the following five interdependent variables: pressure, temperature, dryness, enthalpy, and entropy. If any two of these variables are selected as rectangular coordinates of a chart, the other three variables may be represented on that chart by a series of curves. There are ten possible pairs of coordinates, and thus ten possible forms of chart, which can represent the thermodynamic properties of steam and hot water. Each of the ten possible charts is discussed in turn and illustrated. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:8

TITLE: Geothermal energy needed: effective heat transfer equipment
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; GEOTHERMAL REFRIGERATION; CORROSION; DESIGN; FOULING; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONVERSION; COOLING; ENERGY CONVERSION; REFRIGERATION; 150802* - Geothermal Power Plants- Power Plant Systems & Components
DESCRIPTION: For large-scale application of geothermal energy from steam and hot water, effective heat exchange equipment is needed to overcome the fouling and corrosion from such pollutants as silica, lime, CO/sub 2/, and sulfurous compounds that impede efficient heat transfer. The problems are discussed in regard to both binary cycle units and refrigeration systems. (LBS)
RESEARCH_ORG: International Society for Geothermal Engineering, Whittier, CA

TITLE: Hungary cuts back oil imports by increasing geothermal energy production
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PERFORMANCE; HUNGARY; MAPS; TABLES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; USES; EUROPE; INFORMATION; WELLS; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 294002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Petroleum; 150102 - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 150904 - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: Hungary's use of geothermal energy is reviewed. The nominal heat capacity of geothermal wells of more than 60/sup 0/C outflow temperature is listed. In another table the nominal heat capacity of wells and the actual consumption of geothermal energy according to the type of usage are presented. Wells less than 60/sup 0/C outflow temperature are also included. A temperature gradient map of Hungary showing high-energy geothermal wells is included. (MHR)

TITLE: Field measurements of apparent Curie temperatures in a cooling basaltic lava lake, Kilauea Iki, Hawaii
AUTHORS: Zablocki, C J; Tilling, R I
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BASALT; MAGNETIC SUSCEPTIBILITY; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; HAWAII; VOLCANISM; KILAUEA VOLCANO; COOLING; LAVA; BOREHOLES; CURIE POINT; CAVITIES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; MAGNETIC PROPERTIES; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; TRANSITION TEMPERATURE; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; VOLCANOES; 580202* - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: Magnetic susceptibility and temperature measurements have been made in two of three holes drilled in 1975 through the crust and into the still molten lens of tholeiitic basalt in Kilauea Iki lava lake (formed in 1959). The temperature above which magnetic susceptibility drops to zero--the apparent Curie temperature--is 540/sup 0/C at depths of 34.7 to 35.9 m below the lake surface. These field measurements suggest that the dominant ferromagnetic mineral in the cooling basalt is titanomagnetite containing about 10 mol percent ulvospinel.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Res. Lett.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:8

TITLE: Hydrothermal crystallization of silica gel. [Chalcedonic spherulites; 3kb, 100 to 300/sup 0/C]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; QUARTZ; HYDROTHERMAL SYNTHESIS; SILICA GEL; CRYSTALLIZATION; HIGH TEMPERATURE; NUCLEATION; ADSORBENTS; CHALCOGENIDES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SYNTHESIS; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: Under hydrothermal conditions (3 kb, 100/sup 0/ to 300/sup 0/C, 25 to 5,200 hr), freshly solidified silica gel crystallized to quartz, predominantly in the form of chalcedonic spherulites. No intermediate crystalline phases in the transition from amorphous silica to quartz were detected. Chalcedony that made up the synthetic spherulites was either length-slow, length-fast, or both, depending on the experimental conditions. These findings contrast with the hypothesis that chalcedony derived from silica gel should be length-fast. In experiments in which blue-green algae had been embedded in the silica gel, spherulite nucleation occurred preferentially on surfaces of particulate organic matter, and the chalcedony generally was length-slow. A summary of spherulitic crystallization mechanisms is presented, and emphasis is placed on impurity and viscosity requirements. Considering these requirements and the experimental results, a viscous colloidal origin is postulated for cherts and other siliceous sedimentary rocks that contain abundant silica microspheres. The seemingly biological attributes of quartz microspheres in Precambrian iron formation cherts can be explained by strictly inorganic processes related to spherulitic crystallization of colloidal precursors.
RESEARCH_ORG: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Canberra, Australia
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:8

TITLE: Heat flow in Lake Tahoe, California--Nevada, and the Sierra Nevada--Basin and Range transition
AUTHORS: Henyey, T L; Lee, T C
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; HEAT FLOW; LAKES; NEVADA; DATA; SEDIMENTS; TABLES; TECTONICS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; INFORMATION; NORTH AMERICA; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SURFACE WATERS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 580202* - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989); 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Heat-flow measurements made in Lake Tahoe, California-Nevada, demonstrate that the transition from subnormal heat flow in the Sierra Nevada to above-normal heat flow in the Basin and Range province occurs west of the assumed physiographic boundary between these two areas, contrary to earlier belief. In addition, these data, together with data of other workers, clearly reveal the sharpness of this transition, which suggests that the causative thermal sources and (or) sinks must be restricted to depths not greater than the uppermost mantle. The way in which heat-flow data constrain the current hypotheses of crustal structure and evolution of the Sierra Nevada-Basin and Range provinces is illustrated with a tectonic model that employs a post-Cretaceous shallow-dipping subduction zone beneath the Sierra Nevada and an active upper-mantle diapir under the Basin and Range province during late Cenozoic time.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geol. Soc. Am., Bull.; (United States); Journal Volume: 87:8

TITLE: Geophysical activity in 1975
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 02 PETROLEUM; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; COST; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GROUND WATER; EXPLORATION; MINERALS; PETROLEUM; OCEANOGRAPHY; ENERGY SOURCES; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; WATER; 580203* - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989); 020200 - Petroleum- Reserves, Geology, & Exploration; 150300 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology
DESCRIPTION: Statistics are provided on worldwide use of geophysical methods in 1975. Data were obtained primarily through a survey questionnaire which was mailed out to more than 1500 companies, government agencies, and universities that use geophysical techniques for petroleum exploration, oceanography, engineering, mining, geothermal exploration, and groundwater exploration. Response to the survey provided detailed information on more than 2100 geophysical surveys. One of the objectives of an annual activity report is to show trends from year to year on levels of activity by major geographical area. This report also provides details on geophysical methods used to aid in detecting and tracking trends in technological developments. Average costs have been calculated for all survey methods by area and survey objective. (LBS)
RESEARCH_ORG: Exxon Production Research Co., Houston, TX
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 41:4

TITLE: Apparent resistivity of a perfectly conducting sphere buried in a half-space
AUTHORS: Singh, S K; Espindola, J M
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; COMPUTER CALCULATIONS; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; IMAGES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SPHERES; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Recently, the application of the method of images to obtain apparent resistivity of a perfectly conducting sphere buried in a half-space has been criticized on the grounds that the number of images needed is too large. Instead, use of the method of graphs, in conjunction with the method of images, has been suggested. Although the number of images needed is large, they are easy to compute and many of them occupy the same position, thereby the amount of necessary computation is drastically reduced. A computer program based on the method of images is used to give normalized total-field apparent resistivity contours for bipole--dipole arrays. Such theoretical contours can be used to locate the epicenter of a conductive buried sphere by comparing them with field data.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 41:4

TITLE: Seismic exploration of Mono Basin, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; SEISMIC SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GRAVITY SURVEYS; MAPS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A seismic exploration of Mono Basin, California, was conducted by the U.S. Geological Survey in 1970 and 1971 to resolve two conflicting interpretations regarding the thickness of the basin fill and the nature of the boundaries of the structure. Interpretation of the seismic data obtained leads to the conclusions that the depth to basement in Mono Basin in 2 to 2/sup 1///sub 2/ km and that the structural deformation along the boundaries of the basin was accomplished by a combination of warping and faulting. Thus the geophysical data suggest a structural model that lies between the two extremes of interpretation. Geologic, seismic, magnetic, and gravity data all indicate the presence of a pile of intrusive and extrusive volcanic rocks near the center of Mono Basin.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 81:20

TITLE: Geothermal development in California will come under scrutiny in two studies
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; LEGAL ASPECTS; REGULATIONS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The draft of the Battelle Memorial Institute, Pacific Northwest Laboratories study, to be released after review in late August 1976, finds the major roadblocks to be the utilities, aversion to technological risks and a foggy regulatory climate. The study discusses legal, institutional, and political problems. It was performed under contract to E.R.D.A., the Federal Energy Administration and the EPA. A second study, by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory under sponsorship of E.R.D.A. and the California Energy Resources Conservation and Development Commission, will determine what kind of Federal, State, and local actions are needed to assist local authorities in developing the State's geothermal resources. This study is one of four E.R.D.A. regional investigations; the others are to cover the northwest, southwest, and Texas-Louisiana areas.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. (N.Y.); (United States); Journal Volume: 83:14

TITLE: Potential for geothermal steam
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ECONOMICS; CALIFORNIA; COMPETITION; FORECASTING; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; USA; WELL DRILLING; DRILLING; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Experience to date indicates that at increments of about 100 Mw, geothermal energy is economically competitive with energy produced by large fossil fuel and nuclear plants, which have to be about 1000 Mw in size to enjoy the benefits of the economy of scale. Geothermal energy production is not necessarily cheaper than fossil fuel power, but it can be generated efficiently from smaller units. This makes geothermal energy a very attractive form of power generation in developing countries with geologic potentials. The geologic occurrence of geothermal resources, the geothermal gradients at various places in the earth's crust, geothermal well drilling problems, the limited transportability of geothermal energy, the status of geothermal power development in the U.S. (including the Geysers field in California) and elsewhere, and U.S. geothermal energy forecasts for 1985 to 2000 vs. 1970 to 1975 capacities, are surveyed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. Prog.; (United States); Journal Volume: 72:7

TITLE: Home heating, 1930 style
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ALFALFA; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; USES; SOILS; STERILIZATION; SULFUR; EXTRACTION; PROCESSING; AGRICULTURE; BROADLANDS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; DRYING; NEW ZEALAND; AUSTRALASIA; BIOMASS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HEATING; LEGUMINOSAE; NONMETALS; PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SEPARATION PROCESSES; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: Nonelectric uses of geothermal energy in Rotorua-Taupo area of North Island are alfalfa drying, soil pasteurization, and sulfur extraction and processing. Details of fluid temperatures and operating experiences are given.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States)

TITLE: Geo-heated swimming pool
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SWIMMING POOLS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEAT EXCHANGERS; OREGON; HEATING; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; SURFACE WATERS; USA; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: Klamath Falls Municipal Swimming Pool has used geothermal energy for its heating needs the past 22 years. Its heating source is a 250 ft deep, 200/sup 0/F artesian hot-water well. The 10-inch cased well has 200 ft downhole heat exchangers which supply heat to the pool, bathhouse, showers, and deck. Details of the circulation system and heat exchangers are given. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States)

TITLE: Aquaculture at Oregon Inst. of Technology
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; AQUACULTURE; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; THERMAL WATERS; USES; CRUSTACEANS; FISHES; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; OREGON; ANIMALS; AQUATIC ORGANISMS; ARTHROPODS; FLUIDS; HEATING; INVERTEBRATES; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; USA; VERTEBRATES; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: The geothermal hot water resource developed from on-campus wells is used for space heating and heating the college's potable hot water supply. The development of this resource has provided waste water for aquaculture. The available water for aquaculture is a volume of 200 to 250 gal/min with a mean temperature of 57/sup 0/C. This water was tested on mosquitofish, guppies, and crayfish. A program is now underway to see if the giant freshwater prawn may be grown commercially in geothermal waste water. (MHR)
RESEARCH_ORG: Oregon Inst. of Technology, Klamath Falls
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 2:1
JOURNAL_NAME: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States)

TITLE: Process design for geothermal power
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; WORKING FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; DESIGN; OPERATION; 2-METHYLPROPANE; AMMONIA; BRINES; FLASHING; FREONS; OPTIMIZATION; POWER GENERATION; STEAM; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; ALKANES; CONVERSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; EVAPORATION; FLUIDS; HALOGENATED ALIPHATIC HYDROCARBONS; HYDRIDES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; ORGANIC HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POWER PLANTS; REFRIGERANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: The design and optimization of geothermal power plants needs process design studies as well as exploration of resources. The multi-stage, multi-flash heat exchanger appears very attractive, especially for brines below 400/sup 0/F, for transferring heat from geothermal brine to a power fluid, and the use of mixtures as power fluids can greatly reduce cooling costs. Inventive process design engineers have a challenge to develop the optimum design for each of the many different types of geothermal energy sources.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. Prog.; (United States); Journal Volume: 72:7

TITLE: Volcanic rocks of the eastern and northern parts of the San Francisco volcanic field, Arizona
AUTHORS: Moore, R B; Wolfe, E W; Ulrich, G E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; ARIZONA; VOLCANIC REGIONS; BASALT; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; VOLCANIC ROCKS; AGE ESTIMATION; ANDESITES; MAPS; RHYOLITES; IGNEOUS ROCKS; NORTH AMERICA; ROCKS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 580202 - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The eastern and northern parts of the San Francisco volcanic field, between San Francisco Mountain and the Little Colorado River, contain about 175 cinder cones, many with one or more associated lava flows, and one center of silicic volcanism, O'Leary Peak. Basaltic flows and cones are divided into five groups, primarily on the bases of stratigraphic and physiographic relations, degree of weathering and erosion, K-Ar and tree-ring age determinations, and, in part, chemical and petrographic data.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Res. U.S. Geol. Surv.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:5
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Res. U.S. Geol. Surv.; (United States)

TITLE: Water required to develop geothermal energy
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY CONVERSION; WATER REQUIREMENTS; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; VAPOR-DOMINATED SYSTEMS; CONVERSION; ENERGY CONVERSION; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 150800* - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal resources may be found distributed in the earth in a variety of modes consisting of various fluid and reservoir characteristics. It seems likely that these resources will represent a substantial portion of the world's total energy supply as the availability of petroleum declines. Important environmental considerations, however, including the problems of subsidence and ground-water contamination, must be further researched in order to determine the extent of possible problems and methods for mitigating their effects.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Am. Water Works Assoc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 68
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Am. Water Works Assoc.; (United States)

TITLE: Nonelectric uses of geothermal energy in New Zealand
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ALFALFA; DRYING; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; SOILS; STERILIZATION; SULFUR; EXTRACTION; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; NATURAL STEAM; NEW ZEALAND; USES; AUSTRALASIA; BIOMASS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; HEATING; LEGUMINOSAE; NONMETALS; PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SEPARATION PROCESSES; STEAM; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: Among the unique uses of geothermal energy is soil sterilization, where the soil is heated to 140/sup 0/F for a half hour to kill insects, fungus, worms, and some bacteria. A low grade sulfur surface deposit is presently being strip mined and geothermal steam used to extract the sulfur. Alfalfa is dried using geothermal steam and formed into pellets for ease of storage and shipment. (MHR)

DESCRIPTION: Initial results of field work in the eastern margin of the Albuquerque-Belen Basin of the Rio Grande Rift in central New Mexico are reported. The seismic-reflection technique was used successfully in the spatial resolution of geological features of basement rocks. (JGB)

TITLE: Big Island Puna well hotter
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; FINANCING; PLANNING; HAWAII; HIGH TEMPERATURE; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; TESTING; NORTH AMERICA; USA; WELLS; WESTERN REGION; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging; 150904 - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: The temperature in the 6400 ft Puna test well on the Big Island reached 576/sup 0/F and is predicted to reach the boiling point of 626/sup 0/F at that depth. The Puna well begins on a volcanic flank at a point 600 ft above the ocean. It is believed that sea water will fill the shaft from sea level down to the bottom of the hole. Plans are made to complete and test the hole. (LBS)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:7

TITLE: NMSU annual energy conference: geothermal energy
AUTHORS: Smith, C; Morgan, P; Jiracek, G; Swanberg, C A
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MEETINGS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; NEW MEXICO; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EXPLORATION; NORTH AMERICA; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Papers were presented on a wide range of geothermal related subjects, including geothermal processes, the search for and evaluation of geothermal resources, and the economic, political, legal, environmental, and institutional problems associated with geothermal development. Progress reports were given on essentially all geothermal programs in New Mexico. A synopsis of the conference papers is given. Selected geothermal references for New Mexico are also given. (LBS)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:7

TITLE: Klamath Falls geothermal deep well probe to start
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; PLANNING; OREGON; WELL DRILLING; DRILLING; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; USA; WELLS; 150303* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging
DESCRIPTION: A geothermal deep well exploration planned within Klamath Falls KGRA is discussed. The potential drilling depth of 8000 ft aimed at finding a hot-water geothermal reservoir will be the deepest attempted in Klamath County. Possible uses of the local potential lie in lumber processing, freeze drying and refrigeration. (LBS)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:7

TITLE: Economic analysis of geothermal energy. [Using GEOCOST computer code]
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; COMPUTER CODES; G CODES; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ECONOMICS; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; CAPITAL; ELECTRIC POWER; FLASHED STEAM SYSTEMS; FLOW RATE; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; INVESTMENT; POWER GENERATION; WELL DRILLING; DRILLING; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EXPLORATION; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POWER; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: The development of the GEOCOST computer program which combines the technical and economic factors of power generation from geothermal energy into one systematic cost accounting framework is described. The model simulates the cost of geothermal reservoir exploration, development, and operation and the cost of power plant design, construction, and operation. This model showed that fluid temperature, well flow rate, well drilling, and fluid extraction costs are the principal factors that determine the price of geothermal energy. (LCL)
RESEARCH_ORG: Batelle Pacific Northwest Labs., Richland, WA
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Eng. Prog.; (United States); Journal Volume: 72:7

TITLE: Comparative data on the volatile component composition of magma
AUTHORS: Kravtsov, A I; Onikiyenko, S K
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; FUMAROLIC FLUIDS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; GEOCHEMISTRY; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HOT SPRINGS; LAVA; MAGMA; PARATUNKA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; PAUZHETSK GEOTHERMAL FIELD; TABLES; USSR; VOLCANIC REGIONS; CHEMISTRY; EUROPE; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; INFORMATION; ROCKS; THERMAL SPRINGS; VOLCANIC ROCKS; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys; 580202 - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The results of several hundred analyses of fumarole gases of the Kuril--Kamchatka area are classified and tabulated. Studies in the geology and geochemistry of natural gases associated with magmatism yielded much information on the composition of volcanic gases of this zone. Also fumarole gases directly correlated with eruptive or lava streams and gases of hot springs were studied. The main attention was centered on the geochemistry of carbon and hydrogen as the principal elements of the hydrocarbons in the earth's crust. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. Geol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:7

TITLE: Isotopic composition of carbon of gases of active volcanoes and hot springs of the Kuril-Kamchatka volcanic arc
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; CARBON ISOTOPES; ISOTOPE RATIO; FUMAROLIC FLUIDS; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; USSR; HOT SPRINGS; VOLCANOES; CARBON DIOXIDE; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; EUROPE; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; THERMAL SPRINGS; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys; 580202 - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: To determine the effect of geologic factors on the composition of abyssal derivates (complementing existing information on the geochemistry of volcanic gases) isotopic analysis of carbon was used to obtain physicochemical criteria of the origin of gases, independent of geologic-petrographic data. The investigations include component analysis of all the gases, particularly hydrocarbon compounds, repeatedly found in the fumarole emanations of pyroclastic streams. Volcanic carbon dioxide which is the principal component of gases of active volcanoes and hot springs in the Kuril-Kamchatka volcanic arc and of other volcanoes was investigated.
RELATION: Journal Name: Int. Geol. Rev.; (United States); Journal Volume: 18:7

TITLE: Research today for tomorrow's power. [Geothermal, solar, wave, wind and tidal possibilities]
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 16 TIDAL AND WAVE POWER; 17 WIND ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EXPLOITATION; SOLAR ENERGY; TIDAL POWER; UNITED KINGDOM; ENERGY SOURCES; WAVE POWER; WIND POWER; AVAILABILITY; COST; COST BENEFIT ANALYSIS; ECONOMICS; EFFICIENCY; ENERGY STORAGE; ENGINEERING; RESEARCH PROGRAMS; ENERGY; EUROPE; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; STORAGE; 299000* - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 140000 - Solar Energy; 150000 - Geothermal Energy; 160000 - Tidal & Wave Power; 170000 - Wind Energy
DESCRIPTION: Much R and D will be required for solar, tidal, wave, wind, and geothermal energy to be exploited on a large scale in the UK. Wind energy is widely available but irregular and variable, the basic problem being storage. Tidal and wave power are of practical interest only to large electricity supply organizations; wave power is more of a conventional base-load energy source for which storage is needed if the full potential is to be realized; an expanded tidal scheme could provide this storage because it is complementary to any primary source. Estuaries like the Severn provide suitable conditions--pumping at night combined with an intermittent tidal input can give steady daytime output to meet up to 30 percent of the present maximum excess of daytime over night load; no other storage is needed for either source. This would reduce by 40 percent the amount of thermal plant operating by day and would lower total thermal generating capacity by 10 percent. Technical and economic constraints are present for geothermal energy, but the total heat content under Britain is enough to supply all her energy needs at present consumption rates, for 20,000 years. Solar energy is by far the most versatile of the renewable sources. Thermal applications for space heating, hot water heating, and electricity generation through solar thermal power cycles are well known. Solar cells are potentially an attractive means of generating electricity for all sectors (except transportation) because they have no running costs or moving parts and no waste products. The present capital cost is too high to be competitive. The economics of the development of all the alternative sources is summarized. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Engineer (London); (United States); Journal Volume: 242:6275

TITLE: Lattice thermal conductivity within the Earth and considerations of a relationship between the pressure dependence of the thermal diffusivity and the volume dependence of the Grueneisen parameter
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; EARTH MANTLE; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; QUARTZ; THERMAL DIFFUSIVITY; SODIUM CHLORIDES; GRUENEISEN CONSTANT; MAGNESIUM SILICATES; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; VOLUME; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CHALCOGENIDES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 152002* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks; 580202 - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The method proposed by Mooney and Steg (1969) for obtaining the dilatational dependence of the Grueneisen parameter from data on the pressure dependence of the thermal conductivity (or, equivalently, thermal diffusivity) is critically examined and applied to thermal diffusivity data for sodium chloride and quartz. The values obtained are ..gamma../sub 0/'(identical with (d..gamma../d..delta..)parallel bar/sub ..delta.. = 0/) = 3.0 for sodium chloride and ..gamma../sub 0/' = 2.0 for quartz. Corresponding values of the parameter q(identical with ..gamma../sub 0/'/..gamma../sub 0/) are 1.9 and 2.8, in reasonable agreement with values obtained by other methods. It is suggested that this method be further investigated as a means of obtaining ..gamma../sub 0/' and q from thermal data. A model for the lattice thermal conductivity of the mantle to the core boundary is presented. The model suggests that increases in conductivity with pressure due to lattice conduction processes in the mantle are less than 2.0 percent/kbar or 0.7 percent/km. Under conditions of normal geothermal gradient in the crust and upper mantle the increase in lattice conductivity due to the pressure effect will be substantially less than the decrease due to the temperature effect. A minimum value of lattice conductivity is attained in the region of the olivine-spinel phase change, 400 km. The lattice conductivity may increase by a factor of 3 at the depth of the spinel-postspinel phase change owing to the high conductivity of the dense oxide phases. The lattice contribution to the thermal conductivity at the mantle-core boundary is approximately 0.01 cal/cm s/sup 0/K.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 81:17

TITLE: Experimental determination of the pressure dependence of the thermal diffusivity of teflon, sodium chloride, quartz, and silica
AUTHORS: Kieffer, S W; Getting, I C; Kennedy, G C
