TITLE: Ionization of water in NaCl media to 300/sup 0/C
AUTHORS: Busey, R H; Mesmer, R E
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; WATER; IONIZATION; DATA ANALYSIS; EQUATIONS; HIGH TEMPERATURE; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; POTENTIOMETRY; SODIUM CHLORIDES; THERMODYNAMICS; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; TITRATION; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: The apparent ionization quotient for water has been measured potentiometrically near the saturation pressure from 25 to 295/sup 0/ in 1 and 3 m NaCl using a previously described hydrogen-electrode concentration cell. The results are presented in terms of a modification of the Broensted--Guggenheim treatment for activity coefficients of ions. The mathematical form of the temperature dependence for the interaction coefficients was indicated by the more extensive data on ..gamma../sub H/ + ..gamma../sub OH/sup -// in KCl media. From a least-squares analysis of these data in NaCl along with the very precise data from the literature for NaCl media from 0 to 50/sup 0/C, the following expression for the effect of salt concentration and temperature on log Q'/sub w/ is obtained: log Q'/sub w/ = log K/sub w/ + 2.0AI/sup 1/2/(1 + I/sup 1/2/) - (p/sub 1/ + p/sub 2//T + p/sub 3/T/sup 2/ + p/sub 4/F(I))I - 0.0157 phi m/sub NaCl/ and F(I) = (1 - (1 + 2I/sup 1/2/ - 2I) exp(-2I/sup 1/2))/4I.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Solution Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 5:2

TITLE: Improved method of computing the thermal conductivity of fluid-filled sedimentary rocks
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; CALCULATION METHODS; CORRECTIONS; ERRORS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POROSITY; SANDSTONES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; ROCKS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 152002* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: In the absence of suitable material on which to make thermal conductivity measurements, it is still possible to compute a value on the basis of an idealized model. The Maxwell model for the thermal conductivity of a two-component material, a model which has frequently been successfully used for relatively small values of porosity (<0.1) and moderate conductivity ratios (<10), may be extended to much wider ranges of these parameters (0.3 and 300, respectively) by the use of appropriate correction factors obtainable from data already in the literature. Significant errors due to overlooking a thermal contact resistance have been detected in some experimental work. The errors can be as high as 50 percent of the measured value for an air-filled sandstone of 0.2 porosity. Unless corrected, such errors can contribute a great deal to the lack of agreement between computed and experimental values. Correction for these errors also leads to much better consistency among published experimental values measured with various techniques. Conductivity values accurate to better than 15 percent may therefore be predicted for specimens saturated with low conductivity fluids such as air, steam, or oil.
RELATION: Journal Name: Log Anal.; (United States); Journal Volume: 17:6

TITLE: Exposures of field-grown lettuce to geothermal air pollution: photosynthetic and stomatal responses
AUTHORS: Shinn, J H; Clegg, B R; Stuart, M L; Thompson, S E
SUBJECT: 63 RADIATION, THERMAL, AND OTHER ENVIRON. POLLUTANT EFFECTS ON LIVING ORGS. AND BIOL. MAT.; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 54 ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS; AIR POLLUTION; CARBON DIOXIDE; DIFFUSION; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; LETTUCE; METHANE; NITROGEN; PHOTOSYNTHESIS; PLANTS; PLUMES; QUANTITY RATIO; STIMULATION; STOMATA; STRESS RELAXATION; TOXICITY; ALKANES; BIOMASS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOOD; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NONMETALS; OPENINGS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHOTOCHEMICAL REACTIONS; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SYNTHESIS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; VEGETABLES; 560303* - Chemicals Metabolism & Toxicology- Plants- (-1987); 150600 - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects; 500200 - Environment, Atmospheric- Chemicals Monitoring & Transport- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Field-grown lettuce was exposed in-situ to a facsimile geothermal gas mixture (15 CO/sub 2/ : 1 H/sub 2/S : 1 CH/sub 4/ : 2 N/sub 2/ parts by volume added to air). The objective was to determine the effects of geothermal air pollution on photosynthesis and stomatal diffusion resistance during a three-hour period of exposure. The question was to what degree the extra CO/sub 2/ might compensate for the phytotoxic effect of H/sub 2/S during an exposure analogous to fumigation by a typical geothermal power plant plume. The apparent mean values indicate a stimulation of photosynthesis and a relaxation of stomatal resistance at low concentrations. There is no significant depression of photosynthesis until exposure concentrations approach 75 ppM CO/sub 2/ : 5 ppM H/sub 2/S added to air. The normal variation in photosynthesis is so high (coefficient of variation 0.5) that it is necessary to take many samples to establish a mean, and this should be considered in designing future experiments.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Environ. Sci. Health, Part A; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:10-11
JOURNAL_NAME: J. Environ. Sci. Health, Part A; (United States)

TITLE: New Zealand helps Indonesia's geothermal programme
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; EXPLORATION; INDONESIA; NEW ZEALAND; INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION; DRILLING; EDUCATION; EXPLOITATION; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; PRODUCTION; ASIA; AUSTRALASIA; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 299002* - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989); 150303 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Exploratory Drilling & Well Logging
DESCRIPTION: New Zealand, in its largest overseas project at Kamojang, southeast of Bandreng, Java aims to add 30 MW to Indonesia's present 380 MW power generating capacity. In its geothermal development, the national electricity undertaking has been encouraged and supported by PN Pertamina (State Oil Company), appointed by the Indonesian government to act as the counterpart to the New Zealand team carrying out the bilateral aid program. The Kmojang project is planned for completion before 1980. The technical appraisal of many areas in Indonesia indicate the potential for geothermal energy is great, and its utilization will increase the electrical generating capacity to improve the living standards in this country that has only 5 percent of its population living in dwellings to which electricity is connected. (MCW)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:12

TITLE: Search for geothermal seismic noise in the East Mesa area, Inperial Valley, California
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EAST MESA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; SEISMIC SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; IMPERIAL VALLEY; NOISE; SEISMIC DETECTION; SEISMIC NOISE; CALIFORNIA; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A seismic noise monitoring study was conducted at the East Mesa area of Imperial Valley, Calif. to determine if there is a correlation between seismic noise levels and thermal gradients and high heat flow regions at East Mesa. The measuring methods and data obtained are described. It was concluded that the seismic noise detected over the Mesa thermal anomaly is caused by freeway traffic and canal and agricultural activities, and that, if there is any geothermal noise generated, its amplitude is less than that of the other sources, and probably is one or two magnitudes less than the noise levels generated at the Geysers Geothermal Field. (LCL)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 40:6

TITLE: Faulting in geothermal areas
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GEOLOGIC FAULTS; DIAGRAMS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; TECTONICS; VOLCANISM; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: Major geothermal areas occur in regions of normal faulting and accompanying volcanic activity caused by tectonic tension. Specifically they are associated with (1) Quaternary volcanic centers in structures caused by volcanic processes, (2) Quaternary volcanic centers in structures caused by tectonic processes, (3) Cenozoic tectonism producing hinterland fault block structures, (4) Cenozoic rift zones, (5) Cenozoic tectonism in hinterland basins, and (6) foreland and platform areas. Descriptions are given of the fault patterns for the Geysers, Larderello and Monte Amiata, Wairakei and Broadlands, Imperial Valley, Cerro Prieto and Pathe, Matsukawa and Otake, Pauzhetsk, Yellowstone Park, Iceland, and Long Valley. 19 figures (LBS)
RELATION: Journal Name: Geotherm. Energy Mag.; (United States); Journal Volume: 3:12

TITLE: Transformations of fluxes and forces describing the simultaneous transport of water and heat in unsaturated porous media
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; POROUS MATERIALS; FLUID FLOW; HEAT TRANSFER; MASS TRANSFER; AQUIFERS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; ONSAGER RELATIONS; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; PRESSURE GRADIENTS; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; WATER; ENERGY TRANSFER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATERIALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems
DESCRIPTION: Balances of mass for the water in N distinct phases and a balance of heat for the medium as a whole were formulated. Following Philip and de Vries, it was assumed that the flux of water in each phase is proportional to the gradient of the pressure in that phase and that the diffusive component of the flux of heat is proportional to the gradient of the temperature. Clapeyron equations were used to express the gradient of the pressure in any phase in terms of the gradient of the pressure in a reference state and of the temperature. The reference state may be the water in one of the phases or the water in some measuring device such as a tensiometer or a psychrometer. Expressions for the total flux of water and for the diffusive flux of heat plus the convective flux of heat associated with the conversion from any phase to the reference state were shown to satisfy the onsager reciprocal relations. A theorem due to Meixner was used to delineate the class of fluxes and forces that preserves these relations. In particular, it was shown that if the gradients of water content and temperature are used as the driving forces, the onsager relations are no longer satisfied.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:6

TITLE: Heavy metal contamination from geothermal sources
AUTHORS: Sabadell, J E; Axtmann, R C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; CHEMICAL EFFLUENTS; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; MERCURY; ABUNDANCE; AIR POLLUTION; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; COAL; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; LAND POLLUTION; METALS; POWER PLANTS; VAPOR-DOMINATED SYSTEMS; CARBONACEOUS MATERIALS; ELEMENTS; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; FOSSIL FUELS; FUELS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POLLUTION; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; 150600* - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Field data on heavy metal effluents from geothermal plants are reviewed. It is concluded that contamination of both soil and air by Hg and other heavy metals is a potential problem. The effects of the chemical content of the hydrothermal fluids and power plant design are considered. Mercury production by coal and geothermal power plants are compared. (JGB)
RELATION: Journal Name: Environ. Health Perspect.; (United States); Journal Volume: 12

TITLE: Analysis of geothermal power plant water using gamma rays from capture of /sup 252/Ca neutrons
AUTHORS: Duffey, D; Balogna, J P; Wiggins, P F
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; NUCLEAR REACTION ANALYSIS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMAL WATERS; CALCIUM; CALIFORNIUM 252; CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; CHLORINE; GAMMA SPECTROSCOPY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HOT SPRINGS; NEW MEXICO; SILICON; SODIUM; TRACE AMOUNTS; ACTINIDE ISOTOPES; ACTINIDE NUCLEI; ALKALI METALS; ALKALINE EARTH METALS; ALPHA DECAY RADIOISOTOPES; CALIFORNIUM ISOTOPES; ELEMENTS; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; FLUIDS; HALOGENS; HEAVY NUCLEI; ISOTOPES; METALS; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; NUCLEI; POWER PLANTS; RADIOISOTOPES; SEMIMETALS; SOUTHWEST REGION; SPECTROSCOPY; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; THERMAL SPRINGS; USA; WELLS; YEARS LIVING RADIOISOTOPES; 150801* - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation; 150903 - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: The geothermal power effort to extract energy from hot dry rock will require careful water analysis to assist in plant control, to monitor corrosion and solid deposition, and perhaps to recover byproduct minerals. To demonstrate laboratory techniques and indicate plant feasibility, geothermal waters frm the Valle Grande Caldera near Jemez Springs, New Mexico were irradiated in laboratory assemblies with neutrons from a /sup 252/Cf source and the high-energy capture gamma rays were measured. The results indicate that chlorine, sodium, calcium, and silicon (and probably other trace elements) can be determined and can help evaluate a geothermal area for power. Such nondestructive analytical techniques applied on-line in the plant, and, depending on neutrons and high-energy gamma rays penetrating thick metal pipes holding the water, should prove useful in the operational needs of the power plant. (auth)
RELATION: Journal Name: Nucl. Technol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 27:3

TITLE: Geothermal energy for everybody
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; REVIEWS; FRACTURING; ROCKS; COMMINUTION; DOCUMENT TYPES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability; 150906 - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology
DESCRIPTION: Hot rock formations are widespread but at great depths. Given the technology to drill down to these hot strata and create a flow path for a working fluid, a vast reservoir of heat could be trapped for a wide range of low temperature heating applications and power generation. Methods of impermeable rock fracturing in order to obtain geothermal energy from the world's non-thermal areas are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Energy Int.; (United States); Journal Volume: 12:11

TITLE: Geothermal resources, a new look
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; RESOURCE ASSESSMENT; USA; CALIFORNIA; CAPACITY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; IDAHO; LOUISIANA; MAGMA SYSTEMS; NEW MEXICO; TEXAS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; RESOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; WESTERN REGION; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: An assessment by the USGS (Circular 726) underlines how limited current use of geothermal energy potential is in this country. The report provides conservative estimates to the effect that an electric generating capacity of 12,000 megawatts, 15 times the current U.S. output from geothermal sources, could be achieved at present energy prices and with current technology. Nearly 10 times that resource either remains to be discovered or awaits improved technology for its exploitation. Main interest at present is in geothermal deposits in which heat is transferred by hydrothermal convection. As with mineral resources, much geothermal heat seems to concentrate in a few large deposits, with some particularly outstanding areas located in California, New Mexico, and the Bruneau--Grandview area of Idaho. Geologically recent magma chambers and the geopressured zone of the Texas--Louisiana gulf area hold promise for the future as drilling and well technology advance with respect to tapping high temperature and high pressure sources, and as energy prices increase.
RELATION: Journal Name: Science; (United States); Journal Volume: 190:4212

TITLE: Heat flow in the Mariana Marginal Basin
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OCEANIC CRUST; HEAT FLOW; SEA BED; MEASURING METHODS; PACIFIC OCEAN; EARTH CRUST; SEAS; SURFACE WATERS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Twenty-one new heat flow measurements in the Mariana Trough delineate a central zone of high heat flow corresponding to an axial topographic high and a flank zone of low heat flow. The high heat flow is an indication that the axial high is a narrow zone of magmatic intrusion and that sea floor spreading is occurring in the Mariana Trough in a manner similar to its occurrence on midocean ridges. The low heat flow values appear to be the result of the occurrence of hydrothermal circulation in the oceanic crust of the Mariana Marginal Basin.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 80:29

TITLE: Non-electric uses of geothermal energy in Japan
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; USES; JAPAN; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; AGRICULTURE; AQUACULTURE; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; GREENHOUSES; ROADS; ASIA; BUILDINGS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; FLUIDS; HEATING; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; SPACE HEATING; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: Diversified uses of geothermal fluids other than for power generation and bathing are listed along with the location of use. The water temperatures necessary for these and other potential uses are tabulated. Some details are given of the following uses: greenhouse horticulture, poultry raising, fish breeding, alligator and crocodile breeding, salt-making, space heating, and road heating.
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States)

TITLE: Case for the downhole exchanger
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; FLOORS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; GEOTHERMAL HEATING SYSTEMS; HEAT EXCHANGERS; OPERATION; OREGON; BUILDINGS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HEATING; HEATING SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; USA; WELLS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: The experience of the Klamath Ice Company in using geothermal heat since 1926 is related. In the 1940's a downhole heat exchanger using Diesel oil as a working medium was installed and used to heat the floors of the cold storage areas to prevent heaving. The temperatures involved and replacement times of equipment are mentioned. It is considered a satisfactory heat output using relatively low temperature water and having little reservoir depletion. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States)

TITLE: OIT adds a new building to it's geothermal heating system
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BUILDINGS; GEOTHERMAL SPACE HEATING; GEOTHERMAL HEATING SYSTEMS; OPERATION; OREGON; COST; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; GEOTHERMAL HEATING; HEATING; HEATING SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; SPACE HEATING; USA; WELLS; 151000* - Geothermal Energy- Direct Energy Utilization
DESCRIPTION: The use of geothermal hot water for heating the buildings on the campus of Oregon Institute of Technology began in 1964. With the addition of Semon Hall Lab II about 500,000 ft/sup 2/ building space is heated. The old campus in operation from 1947 to 1964, averaged in the final three years just over $94,000 per year for heating instructional buildings and housing. The cost today is $12,600 per year. Well temperatures, operating experience, details of the heating systems and equipment problems are described. Diagrams of the geothermal well, a section of geothermal distribution line and the geothermal heating system are included. (MHR)
RELATION: Journal Name: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:2
JOURNAL_NAME: Q. Bull., Geo-Heat Util. Cent.; (United States)

TITLE: Solubility and thermodynamic functions for a 3-2 salt, samarium sulfate, in water and sulfuric acid solutions at temperatures to 350/sup 0/C. [Comparison with solubility of lanthanum sulfate hydrate]
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LANTHANUM SULFATES; SOLUBILITY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; SAMARIUM SULFATES; HIGH TEMPERATURE; HYDRATES; MEDIUM TEMPERATURE; SULFURIC ACID; WATER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; LANTHANUM COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RARE EARTH COMPOUNDS; SAMARIUM COMPOUNDS; SULFATES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; 400200* - Inorganic, Organic, & Physical Chemistry; 152001 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Aqueous Solutions
DESCRIPTION: To broaden the types of salts studied in high temperature aqueous systems, solubilities of 3 to 2 samarium sulfate hydrates have been determined in water (25 to 350/sup 0/C) and in aqueous sulfuric acid (150 to 250/sup 0/C). The values in water for the octahydrate decrease from 0.033 m at 25/sup 0/C to 8 x 10/sup 6/ m for a lower hydrate at 350/sup 0/C. Assumptions of several sets of ionic species saturating the sulfuric acid solutions have been tested by extended Debye--Hueckel theory, which suggests that the 3 to 2 samarium sulfate may behave predominantly as a 2 to 2 sulfate at high temperatures, thus producing Sm/sub 2/(SO/sub 4/)/sub 2//sup 2 +/ and SO/sub 4//sup 2 -/ ions in solution. Similar treatment of Lietzke and Stoughton's solubilities of lanthanum sulfate in sulfuric acid at 135 to 160/sup 0/C is not inconsistent with this suggestion. Based on behavior as a 2 to 2 salt, thermodynamic functions for the solubility of samarium sulfate hydrate at 150 to 250/sup 0/C are presented, together with some comparisons from the solubilities of lanthanum sulfate hydrate.
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Inorg. Nucl. Chem.; (United States); Journal Volume: 37:10

TITLE: Advanced electric power systems. [Identification and preliminary evaluation; matching energy sources and conversion systems]
AUTHORS: Giramonti, A J; Lessard, R D
SUBJECT: 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; 20 FOSSIL-FUELED POWER PLANTS; 01 COAL, LIGNITE, AND PEAT; 14 SOLAR ENERGY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 21 SPECIFIC NUCLEAR REACTORS AND ASSOCIATED PLANTS; 30 DIRECT ENERGY CONVERSION; ELECTRIC POWER; ENERGY SOURCES; ENERGY CONVERSION; POWER GENERATION; PUBLIC UTILITIES; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; COAL GASIFICATION; COAL LIQUEFACTION; COMBINED CYCLES; ECONOMICS; ENERGY SUPPLIES; FORECASTING; FOSSIL FUELS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; LOW BTU GAS; NUCLEAR ENERGY; REVIEWS; SOCIO-ECONOMIC FACTORS; SOLAR ENERGY; THERMODYNAMIC CYCLES; TURBINES; CONVERSION; DOCUMENT TYPES; ENERGY; FLUIDS; FUEL GAS; FUELS; GAS FUELS; GASES; GASIFICATION; LIQUEFACTION; POWER; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; TURBOMACHINERY; 296001* - Energy Planning & Policy- Electric Power Generation- (-1989); 299000 - Energy Planning & Policy- Unconventional Sources & Power Generation; 200100 - Fossil-Fueled Power Plants- Power Plants & Power Generation; 014000 - Coal, Lignite, & Peat- Combustion; 140700 - Solar Thermal Power Systems; 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants; 210000 - Nuclear Power Plants; 300000 - Direct Energy Conversion
DESCRIPTION: An identification and preliminary evaluation was made of alternative advanced electric power systems that have been suggested for possible future use by the American electric utility industry. The motivation for interest in advanced power systems stems primarily from the rapidly rising costs of clean fossil fuels, especially conventional fuel oil, and uncertainties of fuel supply. Four basic energy sources have been identified for prospective future American utility applications; namely, coal, nuclear, solar, and geothermal. Each source must generally be subjected to extensive preprocessing before thermal energy can be delivered in a form useful to an electric power conversion system. Numerous candidate advanced energy conversion systems can be matched to the various energy sources, including steam, open-cycle gas turbines, combined cycles, closed-cycle gas turbines, MHD, fuel cells, liquid metal topping, supercritical carbon dioxide topping, and others. Each has advantages and disadvantages which can be ranked and weighted numerically, based on present knowledge. A tentative selection of promising combinations of energy sources and conversion systems has been made to focus attention on those which satisfy the socio-political requirements and also offer potential profit opportunities for suppliers to the electric utility industry. (auth)
RESEARCH_ORG: United Technologies Research Center, East Hartford, CT
RELATION: Journal Name: Appl. Energy; (United States); Journal Volume: 1:4

TITLE: Economical (basis for) exploration assessed on five types of geothermal resources
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; ECONOMICS; FORECASTING; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POWER POTENTIAL; EXPLORATION; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Only 1100 Mw of geothermal power are being generated world-wide in 1975. Cumulative geothermal drilling in the U.S. has amounted to only 240 wells, and the most optimistic forecast predicts that U.S. geothermal power capacity may rise from 500 Mw in 1975 to 5000 Mw in 1985. In Canada there is no legal provision for acquiring geothermal development rights. Geothermal research is being sponsored by the Canadian government to obtain background knowledge for legislation to ensure conservation and optimum use of resources. The final criterion is not whether geothermal resources exist, but whether they can be exploited economically. Five types of geothermal resources are considered: (1) steam reservoirs, (2) high-temperature water (200 to 259/sup 0/C), (3) low-temperature water (80 to 200/sup 0/C), (4) dry hot rock, and (5) normal heat in the earth's crust. Map.
RELATION: Journal Name: Oilweek (Calgary, Alberta); (United States); Journal Volume: 26:31

TITLE: Thermal infrared technique applied to modern investigation
AUTHORS: Thomas, J; Pedeux, J P; Arnaud, C
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; INFRARED SURVEYS; RECORDING SYSTEMS; EARTH CRUST; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; REMOTE SENSING; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580203 - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: During the last few years a substantial improvement has been made in the development of the thermal infra-red scanner so that 1.5 milli-radian resolution is now commonly obtained. Direct transfer of information on 70 mm film through fiber glass transcoder allows immediate and refined interpretation. Although the collected data represent the image of thermal anomalies within a pellicular section of the earth's crust, it is proved that because of ''per ascensum'' phenomena, deep buried sources induce surface thermal changes. The difficulty lies in showing an absolute relationship between these deep phenomena and thermal surface occurrences. A careful examination of several cases related to hydrology, karstic geology, civil engineering, pollution, hot springs should help the geophysicist by providing him a new tool for shallow investigations. Thermographics with interpretation are shown to support this statement.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophys. Prospect.; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:3

TITLE: Geothermal energy: a hot subject becoming a lot hotter
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; POWER POTENTIAL; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HEAT EXCHANGERS; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; VAPOR-DOMINATED SYSTEMS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 150100* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability
DESCRIPTION: A brief discussion is given on the types of geothermal resources: dry steam, wet steam, hot dry rock, volcanoes, and geopressured deposits. The downhole heat exchanger is pointed out as a promising means of tapping geothermal power more efficiently and cleanly. It is concluded that with proper encouragement, geothermal energy can be made available virtually anywhere on earth with the application of new technologies. (LBS)
RELATION: Journal Name: Energies (Canoga Park, Calif.); (United States); Journal Volume: 1:4

TITLE: Geothermal resources operational (GRO) Order No. 4 for central and western regions
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; INJECTION WELLS; LAND RECLAMATION; LAND USE; POLLUTION; REGULATIONS; WASTE DISPOSAL; MANAGEMENT; RESOURCES; WASTE MANAGEMENT; WELLS; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: Regulations are issued by the U.S. Department of the Interior in order to provide general environmental protection requirements for these regions. The regulations cover land use and reclamation; pollution prevention, including liquid disposal, solid waste disposal, and air quality; fire prevention; slope stability and erosion control; pollution inspections; disposal of fluids in injection wells; and several other topics. These regulations became effective as of 8/1/75.
RELATION: Journal Name: Fed. Regist. (Wash., D.C.); (United States); Journal Volume: 40:159

TITLE: Geothermal power: strangled by red tape
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GOVERNMENT POLICIES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; DEPLETION ALLOWANCES; FINANCIAL INCENTIVES; GEOTHERMAL INDUSTRY; LEASING; MINERALS; REGULATIONS; TAXES; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; INDUSTRY; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; 150400* - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations
DESCRIPTION: A commentary is given on problems faced by industry in seeking to develop geothermal resources. The problems briefly discussed include government roadblocks, tax problems, and classification of geothermal resources. Corrective actions by Congress are suggested.
RELATION: Journal Name: Bus. Week; (United States)

TITLE: Geothermal steam offers chemical bonus
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CALIFORNIA; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; SCRUBBERS; PERFORMANCE TESTING; BINARY-FLUID SYSTEMS; BRINES; FLASHED STEAM SYSTEMS; IMPERIAL VALLEY; PILOT PLANTS; PLANNING; EQUIPMENT; FUNCTIONAL MODELS; NORTH AMERICA; POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT; POWER PLANTS; TESTING; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; USA; WESTERN REGION; 150801* - Geothermal Power Plants- Design & Operation
DESCRIPTION: In June 1975, San Diego Gas and Electric Co. (SDGE) began construction of a 10 kw geothermal powerplant at Niland, Calif., in the Imperial Valley. The plant, scheduled for completion in Nov. 1975, will evaluate a scrubber for cleaning brines that have an average dissolved solids content of 225,000 ppm. SDGE has committed $4.2 million for pilot-plant tests in conjunction with Magma Power Co. of a four-stage flash system. In 1974, a two-stage flash cycle with two separators and two scrubbers ran 3200 hours before brine, salt, and mineral buildup in the heat exchangers and piping made performance unacceptable. The four-stage system will operate within design limits for more than 10,000 hours. Each of the four stages has a gravity separator and a scrubber. The scrubbed steam will heat isobutane which is vaporized and passed through an expander turbine in a closed-cycle system. Geothermal chemical projects in Iceland are discussed.
RELATION: Journal Name: Chem. Week; (United States); Journal Volume: 116:25

TITLE: Heat flow and gravity interpretation across the Rio Grande rift in southern New Mexico and west Texas
AUTHORS: Decker, E R; Smithson, S B
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; NEW MEXICO; RIFT ZONES; HEAT FLOW; TEXAS; GRAVITY SURVEYS; GEOLOGIC STRUCTURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; NORTH AMERICA; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Recent heat flow measurements at 10 separate localities range from 0.9 to 3.6 HFU (1 HFU = 1 x 10/sup -6/ cal/cm/sup 2/ s). When the heat flow measurements are reduced by the heat from bedrock radioactivity, the Rio Grande rift and immediately adjacent areas are characterized by very high reduced flux (greater than or equal to 1.8 HFU). A positive gravity ridge of about +30 mGal exists along the rift in the Frankling and San Andres mountains and the Tularosa Valley. The combined thermal and gravity observations may be explained by shallow crustal intrusions, a hot low-density upper mantle and relative crustal thinning, beneath the rift. 62 refs. (Phys. Abstr.)
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 80:17

TITLE: Geothermal electricity rates a second look from New Zealanders
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; BROADLANDS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; CORROSIVE EFFECTS; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; POWER GENERATION; NEW ZEALAND; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; HEAVY WATER; POWER POTENTIAL; PRODUCTION; WAIRAKEI GEOTHERMAL FIELD; AUSTRALASIA; EXPLORATION; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POWER PLANTS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WATER; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 150800 - Geothermal Power Plants
DESCRIPTION: Under a grant from the New Zealand Energy Research and Development Committee, two key projects are being undertaken: surveys of the geothermal fields to determine optimum drilling areas, and research into corrosion problems of steam and water from the new Broadlands field. New Zealand's only geothermal power station, the 192 Mw Wairakei facility developed in 1958--63, is located in the middle of a 240-km belt of underground thermal activity that includes three active volcanoes, geysers, hot springs, and the like. Serious consideration is being given to building a second power station at Broadlands field, where Japan's Showa Denko K.K. estimates that heavy water could be produced at a cost 25% below any other source. Other New Zealand geothermal fields are estimated to have potential for 1000 to 2000 Mw of electrical power.
RELATION: Journal Name: Eng. Min. J.; (United States); Journal Volume: 176:6

TITLE: Dipole mapping method
AUTHORS: Keller, G V; Furgerson, R; Lee, C Y; Harthill, N; Jacobson, J J
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; ELECTRICAL SURVEYS; DATA PROCESSING; MEASURING METHODS; USES; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; CONFIGURATION; DIPOLES; ELECTRIC CONDUCTIVITY; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; ELECTRIC POTENTIAL; MAPS; NOMOGRAMS; CURRENTS; DIAGRAMS; ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; MULTIPOLES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; PROCESSING; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580203 - Geophysics- Geophysical Survey Methods- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: In the bipole-dipole mapping method, a current field is set up by the use of a bipole current source. The current field is then studied by making measurements of electric field intensity with dipole receivers at many locations around the bipole source. The values for electric field intensity may be used to compute apparent resistivities if we assume that the earth is uniform or to compute apparent conductance if we assume that the earth resembles a conducting sheet. Maps of apparent resistivity values or apparent conductance values may be interpreted by comparing them with similar maps computed analytically for various simplified earth models. The bipole-dipole mapping method is useful mainly in locating areas where ground resistivity varies rapidly in the horizontal direction. It has found application mainly in exploration for geothermal reservoirs but also has been used for mining exploration and engineering studies, and an example of each is described.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geophysics; (United States); Journal Volume: 40:3

TITLE: Gravity field of the Kuril-Kamchatka arc and its relation to the thermal regime of the lithosphere
SUBJECT: 58 GEOSCIENCES; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; KAMCHATKA; GRAVITY SURVEYS; HEAT FLOW; USSR; DENSITY; EARTH CRUST; EARTH MANTLE; SEISMICITY; VOLCANIC REGIONS; EUROPE; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; 580200* - Geophysics- (-1989); 152000 - Geothermal Data & Theory
DESCRIPTION: Five gravity anomaly profiles across the Sea of Okhotsk and the Kuril island arc and trench and two profiles from Fiji to Tonga were presented and studied. The four profiles across the Kuril arc are similar and differ from the profile extending off southern Kamchatka. The contributions to gravity anomalies from the crust and mantle were investigated by means of continuous seismic refraction measurements along tracks coincident with the gravity profiles. The mantle gravity anomalies computed from various density models are positive over the island arc, trench, and adjacent Pacific basin and amount to at least +50 mGal. Gravity anomalies due to the mantle suggest the existence of a denser slab 50 to 60 km thick parallel to the seismic zone. The positive gravity effect of the slab appears to be balanced over the Okhotsk basin by the negative effect of the heated, less dense mantle. The local minimum of Bouguer anomalies occurring over the shoreward flank of the Kuril trench is rather insensitive to the density contrast adopted. The sediments measured seismically account for this Bouguer minimum. The gravity field over the Kuril and Tonga ridges supports the idea of reduced density under the volcanic chain. The local minimum of gravity anomalies associated with the northwestern boundary of the Okhotsk basin is probably related to the fault separating the Academy of Sciences rise from the basin. The ocean-to-continent trend of the free-air anomalies in the Kuril area is unlike that in Tonga, which might be related to features of heat flow anomalies in the Kurils.
RESEARCH_ORG: Inst. of Physics of the Earth, Moscow
RELATION: Journal Name: J. Geophys. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 80:11

DESCRIPTION: In a report to the Energy Research and Development Administration, TRW Systems group suggests a major geothermal research facility should be established in California's Imperial Valley. A huge reservoir of water at 350/sup 0/F exists at a depth of between 4200 and 6200 feet, which could be utilized for more than a century. A 10 MW plant is planned.

TITLE: K--Ar dating quaternary and Neogene volcanic rocks of the Snake River Plain, Idaho
AUTHORS: Armstrong, R L; Leeman, W P; Malde, H E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; IDAHO; VOLCANIC ROCKS; ISOTOPE DATING; ARGON; BASALT; LAVA; POTASSIUM; SEDIMENTARY ROCKS; SILICA; AGE ESTIMATION; ALKALI METALS; CHALCOGENIDES; ELEMENTS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; METALS; MINERALS; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; PACIFIC NORTHWEST REGION; RARE GASES; ROCKS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; USA; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Ninety-eight K-Ar dates for lavas of the Snake River Plain (SRP) and vicinity provide calibration for the stratigraphic framework discussed by Malde and Powers (1962). The Idavada Volcanics, predominantly silicic volcanic rocks, are 9 to 13 m.y. old in the western SRP. Rocks of similar type and comparable stratigraphic position are 8 to 10 m.y. old in the central SRP and as young as 4 to 5 m.y. old in the eastern SRP. This time-transgressive silicic volcanic assemblage merges in the east with the silicic volcanic units erupted during the last 2 m.y. from Island Park, Yellowstone, and related volcanic centers. The Idaho Group, consisting of intercalated basalt flows and sedimentary deposits in the western half of the SRP, ranges in age from about 0.6 to 11.5 m.y. (71 refs.)
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 275:3

TITLE: Effect of solute dispersion on thermal convection in a porous medium layer. II
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; AQUIFERS; CONVECTION; HYDRODYNAMICS; GROUND WATER; FLUID FLOW; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; POROUS MATERIALS; DISPERSIONS; EQUATIONS; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; STABILITY; TEMPERATURE DEPENDENCE; ENERGY TRANSFER; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HEAT TRANSFER; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; MATERIALS; MECHANICS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; WATER; 150200* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems; 580100 - Geology & Hydrology- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: In some situations, associated with geothermal activity, groundwater motions are affected by convection currents due to large temperature gradients. In such cases, usually saline hot water is located in the deep layers of the aquifer from which salt and heat are transferred to the upper layers. In part 1 of this study the parameters of the two-dimensional flow field stability were determined. In this paper, further analysis of the phenomenon in three dimensions is presented. It was found that the convection cells have the shape of rolls whose axes are perpendicular to the steady state flow velocity. However, there is also a possibility of overstability of the flow field caused by rolls whose axes are parallel to the steady state velocity. The parameters of these two kinds of instability were determined in this study.
RELATION: Journal Name: Water Resour. Res.; (United States); Journal Volume: 11:1

TITLE: Texas geothermal energy study
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOPRESSURED SYSTEMS; FEASIBILITY STUDIES; POWER POTENTIAL; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; TEXAS; COASTAL REGIONS; NORTH AMERICA; RESOURCES; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; 150101* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: A three-year, $3 million study is sponsored by the University of Texas Center for Energy Studies to determine the feasibility of producing geothermal energy from geopressurized sands beneath the Texas coast and the Gulf of Mexico. The Center has received two grants from the electric power industry. The sands may be able to produce 15,000 to 30,000 Mw of electricity over a 50 year period. A preliminary study was supported by the University and the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission.

DESCRIPTION: The recording PTG-3 instrument designed for oceanological measurements of the geothermal flux is described. The geothermal flux is measured with the PTG-3 instrument according to the usual method in which the temperature gradient and the thermal conductivity of sediments are separately measured; the thermal flux is then determined by calculation.

TITLE: Carbon--oxygen--hydrogen--sulfur gaseous system. III. Magmatic gases compatible with oxides and sulfides in basaltic magmas
AUTHORS: Gerlach, T M; Nordlie, B E
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MAGMA; GASES; BASALT; HAWAII; HYDROGEN; LAVA; MAGNETITE; OXYGEN; PYRRHOTITE; SULFUR; SULFUR DIOXIDE; CHALCOGENIDES; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON ORES; IRON OXIDES; IRON SULFIDES; MINERALS; NONMETALS; NORTH AMERICA; ORES; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; ROCKS; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; SULFUR OXIDES; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; USA; VOLCANIC ROCKS; WESTERN REGION; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: The interaction of magma-gas systems was investigated, employing fugacity data derived from mineral equilibrium in basaltic lavas. These data were compared with equilibrium composition in the C-O-H-S gaseous system to identify atomic and molar composition of gases compatible with lavas over a range of physical conditions. The atmospheric compositions of gases compatible with pyrrhotite-magnetite assemblages crystallized from immiscible sulfide liquids at Alae Crater, Hawaii were determined. At 800/sup 0/, 1 atm total pressure, the allowed range of gas compositions for these assemblages includes abundant C and S and excludes compositions dominated by H/sub 2/O. SO/sub 2/ is more abundant that H/sub 2/S, and, at C/S ratio 1.5, the molar composition is like that derived for the ''initial'' gas at Kilauea (B. E. Nordlie, 1971). At 900/sup 0/, 1 atm total pressure, only gases with anomalously low C/S ratios are allowed. The allowed range of gases compatible with oxide-sulfide assemblages at higher pressures includes more water-rich compositions. However, data from submarine lavas indicate that such gases may not be favored at higher pressures. Pyrrhotite-magnetite assemblages and immiscible sulfide liquid are favored in environments allowing rapid quenching or maintenance of early magmatic gas compositions by confining pressure.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 275:4

TITLE: Emission control of gas effluents from geothermal power plants
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL POWER PLANTS; GASEOUS WASTES; AIR POLLUTION; AMMONIA; BORON; CARBON DIOXIDE; ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; HYDROGEN; HYDROGEN SULFIDES; METHANE; NITROGEN; RECOVERY; SULFUR; ALKANES; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBON OXIDES; CHALCOGENIDES; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; HYDRIDES; HYDROCARBONS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN COMPOUNDS; NITROGEN HYDRIDES; NONMETALS; ORGANIC COMPOUNDS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; POLLUTION; POWER PLANTS; SEMIMETALS; SULFIDES; SULFUR COMPOUNDS; THERMAL POWER PLANTS; WASTES; 150600* - Geothermal Energy- Environmental Aspects
DESCRIPTION: Geothermal steam at the world's five largest power plants contains from 0.15 to 30 percent noncondensable gases including CO/sub 2/, H/sub 2/S, H/sub 2/, CH/sub 4/, N/sub 2/, H/sub 3/BO/sub 3/, and NH/sub 3/. At four of the plants the gases are first separated from the steam and then discharged to the environment; at the fifth, the noncondensables exhaust directly to the atmosphere along with spent steam. Some CO/sub 2/ and sulfur emission rates rival those from fossil-fueled plants on a per megawatt-day basis. The ammonia and boron effluents can interfere with animal and plant life. The effects of sulfur (which emerges as H/sub 2/S but may oxidize to SO/sub 2/) on either ambient air quality or longterm human health are largely unknown. Most geothermal turbines are equipped with direct contact condensers which complicate emission control because they provide two or more pathways for the effluents to reach the environment. Use of direct contact condensers could permit efficient emission control if coupled to processes that produce saleable quantities of purified carbon dioxide and elemental sulfur. (auth)
RELATION: Journal Name: Environ. Lett.; (United States); Journal Volume: 8:2

TITLE: Experiments on the hydrothermal alteration of mordenite rocks in sodium carbonate solution, with reference to analcimization around Kuroko deposits
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ANALCIME; HYDROTHERMAL SYNTHESIS; MORDENITE; HYDROTHERMAL ALTERATION; ROCK-FLUID INTERACTIONS; SEAWATER; SODIUM CARBONATES; SODIUM CHLORIDES; TUFF; ALKALI METAL COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; CHLORIDES; CHLORINE COMPOUNDS; HALIDES; HALOGEN COMPOUNDS; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; IGNEOUS ROCKS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; MINERALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; ROCKS; SODIUM COMPOUNDS; SYNTHESIS; WATER; ZEOLITES; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: An attempt is made to estimate the formation environment of the analcime alteration zone in Miocene tuffs around Kuroko (Black ore)-type mineral deposits. Natural mordenite tuff and mordenite-opal tuff of Miocene age were subjected to alteration in Na/sub 2/CO/sub 3/ solution (1 molar; 0.25 molar) at 100 to 300/sup 0/C and 30 to 110 kg/cm/sup 2/ for 2 to 20 days using a test-tube-type reactor. After treatment at 150 to 200/sup 0/C, analcime (NaAlSi/sub 2/O/sub 6/ . H/sub 2/O) was formed as an alteration product. At 300/sup 0/C, most of the analcime was decomposed with the elapse of time. In the dilute solution at 300/sup 0/C, analcime was secondarily altered to albite. Albite formed more readily in the mordenite-opal tuff (high-silica tuff) than in the mordenite tuff. Both tuffs showed no remarkable changes when treated at 200/sup 0/C in NaCl solution and artificial seawater environments. Even though treated in Na-bearing reaction solution, they did not always produce analcime. It is possible to estimate from the present experiments that the alkalinity of the reaction solution is a significant controlling factor in analcimization, and the possible formation temperature of the analcime zone cannot exceed 200/sup 0/C. It also appears probable that the analcime zone around Kuroko-type mineral deposits is formed by the interaction of an alkaline interstitial solution and the precursor zeolite-bearing acidic pyroclastic rocks. These interstitial solutions might have been heated by submarine volcanism and/or exhalative activities which accelerated analcimization. (auth)
RELATION: Journal Name: Econ. Geol.; (United States); Journal Volume: 70:4

TITLE: Geologic applications of thermal infrared images
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOLOGICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; INFRARED SURVEYS; FRACTURES; GEOLOGY; HEAT TRANSFER; HOT SPRINGS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MAPS; REMOTE SENSING; VOLCANISM; ENERGY TRANSFER; EXPLORATION; FAILURES; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; THERMAL SPRINGS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Thermal infrared images provide information about the near-surface physical state of geologic materials, particularly the density, water content, and heat transfer. Nonterrestrial planetary studies, conducted at fairly coarse resolution, have been useful primarily in determining the distribution of rock fragments. Terrestrial studies, conducted from satellite and aircraft at coarse to fine resolutions, have been successful for monitoring effusive volcanism, delineating areas of steaming altered ground and hot-spring activity, detecting fractures expressed hydrologically and topographically, and distinguishing a variety of geologic materials with physical and compositional differences. Interpretation of thermal images is complicated by the various types of physical processes involved and commonly requires an assessment of many different factors. A simple theoretical model was used in this analysis to provide quantitative assessment of some of these factors, to predict optimum times to acquire thermal data, and to determine quantitative values of various properties of terrain. Two geologic applications were studied in some detail: geothermal mapping and thermal inertia mapping. Initial results indicate that both techniques have considerable potential, especially in reconnaissance studies. These data were acquired under optimal meteorological conditions and at sites where the geologic materials were well exposed. A realistic assessment of the limitations of these techniques must await future studies.
RELATION: Journal Name: Proc. IEEE; (United States); Journal Volume: 63:1

TITLE: Reich case: economic implications of depletion allowances
AUTHORS: Peterson, R E; Seo, K K
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 29 ENERGY PLANNING, POLICY AND ECONOMY; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; ECONOMICS; RESERVES; TAXES; GEYSERS GEOTHERMAL FIELD; LEGAL ASPECTS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; 150500* - Geothermal Energy- Economics, Industrial, & Business Aspects; 150400 - Geothermal Energy- Legislation & Regulations; 299002 - Energy Planning & Policy- Geothermal- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The Reich case was tried in the 1969 Tax Court of the United States and the Court held that geothermal steam is a gas and is an exhaustible resource at The Geysers field. Accordingly, all geothermal steam producers are now entitled to deduct as current expense the intangible costs of developing and drilling geothermal steam wells and all producers who can demonstrate that their geothermal steam resource is depletable are entitled to what is now a 22 percent depletion allowance. The key expert witness in the case was Dr. Henry J. Ramey, Jr. and a summary is presented of his monograph which was submitted as evidence. His conclusion, based on a reservoir engineering analysis, was that the geothermal resource at the Big Geysers area had, as of 1968, 20 to 46 years of productive life remaining. In the economics discussion, it is demonstrated that the corporate income tax discriminates against risky and capital-intensive industries such as oil and gas and geothermal. The central economic argument in favor of percentage depletion allowances and expensing privileges is that these provisions remove the discriminatory bias of corporate income taxes. The economic consequences of depletion allowances are: a short- and long-run increase in production; a short- and long-run increase in investment in renewal--exploration, discovery, and development; lower prices; a ratio of reserves to output--the Life Index--which tends to be constant; and a short-run increase in profits which encourages the entry of new firms and a long-run situation in which average rates of return are again equalized across industries.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Kaolinite synthesis: role of the silicon--aluminum and alkali--hydrogen ion ratio in hydrothermal systems
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; KAOLINITE; HYDROTHERMAL SYNTHESIS; ABUNDANCE; ALUMINIUM; HYDROGEN; SILICON; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM SILICATES; CRYOGENIC FLUIDS; ELEMENTS; FLUIDS; METALS; MINERALS; NONMETALS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEMIMETALS; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SYNTHESIS; 152003* - Geothermal Data & Theory- Rock-Water-Gas Interactions
DESCRIPTION: The Si--Al ratio of a hydrothermal system is important in kaolinite synthesis. For an atomic Si--Al ratio more than 2.0 kaolinite disappeared at 345/sup 0/ and 2 kbars H/sub 2/O pressure by reaction with quartz giving pyrophyllite. For Si--Al less than 2.0 kaolinite persisted to 405/sup 0/ where it formed pyrophyllite and boehmite. The b-axis-ordered form of kaolinite was favored by a lower Si--Al ratio and a higher temperature than was the disordered form. Kaolinite was prepared at 150/sup 0/ and 5 bar in distilled H/sub 2/O from amorphous starting materials if the alkali--H/sup +/ ratio was low. Halloysite converted to kaolinite at 150/sup 0/.
RELATION: Journal Name: Clays Clay Miner.; (United States); Journal Volume: 23:4

TITLE: Flow in geothermal hot water wells
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; FLUID FLOW; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; LIQUID FLOW; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PERFORMANCE; PRESSURE DROP; TWO-PHASE FLOW; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; WELLS; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: One of the basic conditions for planning the production of free flowing and airlifted wells is the ability to model correctly the pressure losses incurred in wells with single- and two-phase flows. Based on theories developed in the petroleum industry, as well as the data obtained in the course of Hungarian air-lift water pump tests, a survey is given of the laws governing vertical flow in high-yield hot water wells of small gas and air content. An explanation is given for the fundamental disagreement between the relationships used to simulate pressure losses in short and long tubing. Modes for calculating the pressure profiles of wells are included.
RESEARCH_ORG: Technical Univ. of Heavy Industries, Miskolc, Hungary
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Problems related to operating thermal wells subject to scaling in Hungary
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; SCALING; HUNGARY; CALCIUM CARBONATES; CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; CONTROL; DATA; DEPOSITION; HYDROCHLORIC ACID; PRECIPITATION; THERMAL WATERS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; CALCIUM COMPOUNDS; CARBON COMPOUNDS; CARBONATES; EUROPE; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INFORMATION; INORGANIC ACIDS; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SEPARATION PROCESSES; WELLS; 150903* - Geothermal Engineering- Corrosion, Scaling & Materials Development
DESCRIPTION: Detailed information is provided on the methods and procedures of scaling control and elimination, within the upper portion of the well structure in Hungary. Recent investigations and tests were planned to develop a routine and economic scaling control method for the majority of thermal water wells. The most appropriate method seems to be, according to the results of various tests and experiments, periodical acid treatment under operating conditions which ensure the continuous flow of thermal water wells liable to scaling. Acid treatment can be carried out by the well-operators themselves, at reduced costs, with simple equipment. This work can also be done at the same time by a service company, according to an acid treatment schedule. Acid treatment has the advantage of being an inexpensive operation of only a few hours duration. The necessity and importance of this type of acid treatment in thermal water wells combined with the hydrodynamic surveys should be emphasized. It is supported by the direct relationship between the chemical composition of the thermal waters and their tendency to scaling. On the basis of preliminary investigations, taking into account the local conditions and circumstances, the use of other control methods treated in this study must not be eliminated if it seems more simple and effective in particular conditions.
RESEARCH_ORG: Research Institute for the Development of Water Resources, Budapest
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Seismic noise measurements in the Mt. Amiata geothermal area, Italy
AUTHORS: Del Pezzo, E; Guerra, I; Luongo, G; Scarpa, R
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; MONTE AMIATA GEOTHERMAL FIELD; SEISMIC SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL EXPLORATION; ITALY; SEISMIC NOISE; EUROPE; EXPLORATION; GEOPHYSICAL SURVEYS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: A seismic noise study has been carried out on the well-known Mt. Amiata geothermal area; the aim of this work is to understand the correlation between the geothermal system and seismic noise characteristics. The power spectra of the recorded noise show that in the whole geothermal area a low frequency noise (3 Hz) is predominant. The fitting of the results with a pressure variation source model shows contradictory results.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Research and development of geothermal energy production in Hungary
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HUNGARY; GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES; HEAT FLOW; ENERGY YIELD; GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; THERMAL WATERS; ENERGY; ENERGY SOURCES; EUROPE; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES; RESOURCES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; WELLS; 150102* - Geothermal Energy- Resources & Availability- Non-USA- (-1989); 150202 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: The basement of the Pannonian (Carpathian) basin is represented by Paleozoic metamorphic and Mesozoic dolomite and limestone formations. A heat flow of 2.0 to 3.4 ..mu..cal/cm/sup 2/s gives temperature gradients between 45 and 70/sup 0/C/km in the basin. At 2000 m depth the virgin rock temperature is between 110 and 150/sup 0/C. 80 geothermal wells about 2000 m deep have shown the great geothermal potential of the basin. The main hot water reservoir is the Upper Pliocene (Pannonian) sandstone formation. Between a 100-300 m interval, 3 to 8 permeable layers are exploited resulting in 1-3 m/sup 3//min hot water at 80-99/sup 0/C temperature. Wells at present are overflowing with shut-in pressures of 3-5 atm. The assessment of geothermal resources revealed that the content of the water-bearing rocks down to 3000 m amounts to 12,600 x 10/sup 18/ cal. In the Tertiary sediments 10,560 x 10/sup 18/ cal and in the Upper Pannonian, 1938 x 10/sup 18/ cal are stored. In the Upper Pannonian geothermal reservoir, below 1000 m, where the virgin rock temperature is between 70 and 140/sup 0/C, the stored heat is 768 x 10/sup 18/ cal. The amount of recoverable geothermal energy from 768 x 10/sup 18/ cal is 7.42 x 10/sup 18/ cal, i.e., about 10,000 MW century, not considering reinjection. At present the Pannonian geothermal reservoir stores the greatest amount of identified heat which can be mobilized and used. Hungary has 496 geothermal wells with a nominal capacity of 428 m/sup 3//min, producing 1342 MW heat. 147 wells have an outflow temperature of more than 60/sup 0/C producing 190 m/sup 3//min, that is, 845 MW. In 1974 290 MWyear of geothermal energy was utilized in agriculture, district heating and industry.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Micaceous vermiculite, glauconite, and mixed-layered kaolinite-montmorillonite examination by ultramicrotomy and high resolution electron microscopy
AUTHORS: Lee, S Y; Jackson, M L; Brown, J L
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CLAYS; STRUCTURAL CHEMICAL ANALYSIS; INORGANIC ION EXCHANGERS; MINERALS; MONTMORILLONITE; VERMICULITE; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; LAYERS; ALKALINE EARTH METAL COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM COMPOUNDS; ALUMINIUM SILICATES; ION EXCHANGE MATERIALS; IRON COMPOUNDS; IRON SILICATES; MAGNESIUM COMPOUNDS; MAGNESIUM SILICATES; MICROSCOPY; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICATES; SILICON COMPOUNDS; TRANSITION ELEMENT COMPOUNDS; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: Electron optical fringes of the layer structures of micaceous vermiculite (Colorado), glauconite (Wisconsin), and mixed-layered kaolinite-montmorillonite (Mexico) were observed after separation of clay fractions, saturation with various cations, embedment in Epoxy, thin sectioning normal to the (001) planes by a diamond-knife ultramicrotome, and high resolution, diffraction contrast electron microscopy. In the thin section of Cs-saturated micaceous vermiculite, the electron optical fringes at 10 A may represent the basal crystallographic spacing of unweathered K mica; fringes at 11 A and 5.5 A may represent the (001) and (002) crystallographic basal orders of Cs vermiculite with the interlayers nearly closed; and fringes at 12.5 A may represent incompletely collapsed vermiculite (possibly lower layer charge and/or hydrous metal oxide-interlayered). The K-saturated glauconite particles occur as thin crystal packets consisting of 5 to 20 layers of mica + vermiculite + montmorillonite with 10 A spacing; occasional interstratified 14 A spacings are believed to represent the Raman-Jackson chlorite. A Mg-saturated, mixed-layer kaolinite-montmorillonite from Mexico showed interleaving among the electron optical (001) fringes of kaolinite (7 A), montmorillonite (12 to 14 A), micaceous vermiculite (10 A), and regularly interstratified kaolinite-montmorillonite (19 A).
RELATION: Journal Name: Soil Sci. Soc. Am., Proc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 39:4
JOURNAL_NAME: Soil Sci. Soc. Am., Proc.; (United States)

TITLE: Heat flow map, a review of heat flow data and anomalies for the European Plate
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; 58 GEOSCIENCES; EUROPE; HEAT FLOW; DATA; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MAPS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; INFORMATION; 150202* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989); 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 580202 - Geophysics- Volcanology- (1980-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Heat flow values are shown in mW/m/sup 2/ on a map compiled using data from more than 1200 stations. The given area covers the European continental block as far as the Ural folding system, including the Caucasus, the Carpathian mountain system, the East European platform, the Scythian plate and foredeeps and also including such marginal seas as the Mediterranean, Black and Caspian seas, the Alpine lakes, a part of the Atlantic Ocean and Iceland. Heat flow values in the continental areas around the main hydrothermal manifestations of Larderello and Radicofani in Italy, Novoselovskaja in the Crimea, the Pannonian basin in Hungary, the Rhodopean Massif in Bulgaria are discussed. Besides the magmatic and tectonic processes, the hydrothermal systems also affect the parameters of the thermal field in the upper layers of the crust. A number of regional hydrothermal anomalies of high heat flow values on the Earth's surface, e.g., Tuscany in Italy, the Pannonian Basin in Hungary, Rhodopean Massif in Bulgaria are related to convective processes of heat transfer.
RESEARCH_ORG: Institute of Physics of the Earth, Moscow
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory dry hot rock geothermal project (LASL Group Q-22)
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HOT-DRY-ROCK SYSTEMS; HYDRAULIC FRACTURING; ROCK DRILLING; NEW MEXICO; BOREHOLES; GEOLOGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; HEAT FLOW; SEISMOLOGY; SITE SELECTION; CAVITIES; COMMINUTION; DRILLING; FRACTURING; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; NORTH AMERICA; SOUTHWEST REGION; USA; WELLS; 150906* - Geothermal Engineering- Reservoir Stimulation & Extraction Technology
DESCRIPTION: An exploratory hole 785 m (2576 ft) deep was drilled in Barley Canyon, about 5 km (3 miles) outside the western geologic rim of the Valles Caldera in New Mexico. This hole, identified as ''GT-1'', penetrated about 143 m (470 ft) into the granitic Precambrian rock. Bottomhole temperature was 100.4/sup 0/C. Hydraulic fracturing was accomplished repeatedly in the granitic section of the hole at pumping pressures of the order of 10.3 MPa (1500 psi). The fractures appeared to be essentially vertical and to have a consistent northwest-southeast orientation. The fractures could be held open by pumping pressures of the order of 6.9 MPa (1000 psi), and at such pressures the rate of fluid loss from the system was very low. It was concluded that the basement rock penetrated by GT-1 was well suited to creation and containment of a pressurized-water energy-extraction loop. A second deep exploratory hole, GT-2, has been drilled to a present depth of 2042 m (6701 ft). It is located on top of Fenton Hill, a flat-topped mesa about 2.5 km (1.5 miles) south of GT-1. It is being used primarily to investigate the structure, temperature, permeability, and fracturing behavior of the Precambrian basement rock at a second location and at greater depth than was reached in GT-1. Discussions of the geology, site selection, drilling, core studies, heat flow and hydraulic fracturing primarily for the GT-2 exploratory hole are presented.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Application of the silica geothermometer in low temperature hydrothermal areas in Iceland
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; GEOTHERMOMETRY; ICELAND; SILICA; THERMAL WATERS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; AGE ESTIMATION; BOREHOLES; EQUILIBRIUM; GEOTHERMOMETERS; QUARTZ; ROCKS; CAVITIES; CHALCOGENIDES; EUROPE; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MEASURING INSTRUMENTS; MINERALS; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; THERMOMETERS; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: Temperatures measured in drillholes indicate that the amount of dissolved SiO/sub 2/ in thermal waters at depth in the low temperature hydrothermal areas in Iceland is governed by the solubility of chalcedony at below approximately 110/sup 0/. At above approximately 180/sup 0/, the solubility of quartz governs the amount of dissolved SiO/sub 2/ in the water. The factors that determine with which of these SiO/sub 2/ minerals the dissolved SiO/sub 2/ may reach equilibrium in this temperature range were not shown. Equilibrium with chalcedony appears in some instances to be established at 20/sup 0/, but most commonly cold ground water is SiO/sub 2/ supersaturated with respect to chalcedony solubility. Provided SiO/sub 2/ is the only varying component in the system, SiO/sub 2/ temperatures are minimum temperatures and represent temperatures of last equilibrium with quartz or chalcedony. If mixing with cold ground water takes place and an originally high pH of the thermal water is lowered, the estimated SiO/sub 2/ temperatures are likely to be high compared with the temperature of the mixture. There is a clear relation between the intensity of low temperature hydrothermal activity in Iceland and the age of the rocks in which this activity is located.
RELATION: Journal Name: Am. J. Sci.; (United States); Journal Volume: 275:7

TITLE: Interaction of hot water reservoirs and deep wells
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL WELLS; LIQUID FLOW; EQUATIONS; HOT-WATER SYSTEMS; HYDRAULICS; TRANSPORT THEORY; WATER RESERVOIRS; FLUID FLOW; FLUID MECHANICS; GEOTHERMAL SYSTEMS; HYDROTHERMAL SYSTEMS; MECHANICS; SURFACE WATERS; WELLS; 150904* - Geothermal Engineering- Geothermal Reservoir & Well Performance
DESCRIPTION: A water reservoir and a deep water well producing from it constitute a hydraulic system connected in series. The prescribed amount of water to be produced most economically may be planned and withdrawn only if the elements of the system and the laws of their interaction are known. The laws of interaction are given for production planning in the case of free flowing and airlift water production. Using a numerical example, it is demonstrated how the airlift of a water well producing gas-free water is to be planned with a minimum of specific air consumption.
RESEARCH_ORG: Technical Univ. of Heavy Industries, Miskolc, Hungary
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Influence of late Cenozoic glaciations on the geothermal field in northern and central Europe
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; EUROPE; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; GLACIERS; TEMPERATURE DISTRIBUTION; CLIMATES; FREEZING; ISOTHERM; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PALEONTOLOGY; THAWING; 150202* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: On the basis of the numerical solution of Stefan-like boundary-value problems the simplest palaeoclimatic and geothermal models are analyzed. Typical histories of freezing isotherms, temperature and heat flow changes are calculated taking into account the effects of accumulation and denudation. The results show that the geothermal field demonstrates a better ability to recollect palaeocryologic environment when the phase transitions of subsurface water are involved. However, the geothermal traces of past cryogenic events in Northern and Central Europe before the middle of the Pleistocene could hardly remain up to the present day.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Terrestrial heat flow in the Neogene foredeep and the flysch zone of the Czechoslovak Carpathians
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CZECHOSLOVAKIA; HEAT FLOW; DATA; GEOTHERMAL GRADIENTS; ROCKS; TABLES; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; EUROPE; INFORMATION; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; TEMPERATURE GRADIENTS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 150201* - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- USA- (-1989); 150301 - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: All available heat flow data together with temperature gradients and thermal conductivities of rocks from deep holes in the area forming the contact zone between the Bohemian massif and the western Carpathians are summarized. These data include 20 previously published values and 12 new values. The technique of measurement of the underground temperature, as well as the laboratory determination of the coefficient of thermal conductivity is briefly described. The most important result is the increase of the geothermal activity along the Carpathian foredeep from the south to the north and the generally high heat flow in the area of Permo-carboniferous sedimentation known as the Ostrava-Karvina coal basin in the north.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Radon-222 survey in Larderello geothermal field, Italy (part I)
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; GEOTHERMAL FLUIDS; RADIOACTIVITY; LARDERELLO GEOTHERMAL FIELD; GEOCHEMICAL SURVEYS; RADON 222; ABUNDANCE; ITALY; SAMPLING; ALPHA DECAY RADIOISOTOPES; DAYS LIVING RADIOISOTOPES; EUROPE; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; FLUIDS; GEOTHERMAL FIELDS; HEAVY NUCLEI; ISOTOPES; NUCLEI; RADIOISOTOPES; RADON ISOTOPES; 150302* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geochemical Techniques & Surveys
DESCRIPTION: The data from a radon survey carried out in Larderello geothermal field are presented, together with a description of the methodology used. Discussion is limited to the most important factors affecting Rn concentration in the geothermal fluid.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Combined heat flow and heat generation measurements in the Bohemian massif
SUBJECT: 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; CZECHOSLOVAKIA; HEAT FLOW; EARTH CRUST; EARTH MANTLE; RADIOISOTOPE HEAT SOURCES; ROCKS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENT; THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY; EUROPE; HEAT SOURCES; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; 150301* - Geothermal Exploration & Exploration Technology- Geophysical Techniques & Surveys; 150202 - Geology & Hydrology of Geothermal Systems- Non-USA- (-1989)
DESCRIPTION: Six new heat flow values from western and north-western parts of the Bohemian massif are presented. Two of these heat flow measurements were combined with the determinations of heat generation due to the radioactive decay. The heat flow values fit the general geothermal pattern of Czechoslovakia (Cermak 1968), of clearly sustained low heat flow in the stable parts of the Bohemian massif and increased heat flow in Krusne Hory mountains. The linear relationship between heat flow Q and heat generation A, Q = q/sub 0/ + bA, revealed preliminary values of b = 3.8 km and q/sub 0/ = 1.05 x 10/sup -6/ cal/(cm/sup 2/s), which may be of physical meaning for the uppermost crustal structure. However, such a low value of b does not seem to be adequate for deep extrapolation of surface heat flow observations and for the calculation of crustal temperature distribution. Characteristic deep temperatures of individual tectonic sub-units of the Bohemian massif were calculated using the ''two-layers step model'' of the crust formed by granitic and basaltic layers. The Moho temperature and the upper mantle heat flow contribution are increasing from 500-550 to 650-700/sup 0/C and from 0.50-0.55 to 0.60-0.65 x 10/sup -6/ cal/(cm/sup 2/s) respectively, beneath the most stable central part northward beneath the northern tectonically rejuvenated region of the Krusne Hory mountains.
RELATION: Journal Name: Geothermics; (United States); Journal Volume: 4:1-4

TITLE: Quartz oxygen isotopic stability in relation to isolation from sediments and diversity of source
AUTHORS: Sridhar, K; Jackson, M L; Clayton, R N
SUBJECT: 37 INORGANIC, ORGANIC, PHYSICAL AND ANALYTICAL CHEMISTRY; 15 GEOTHERMAL ENERGY; OXYGEN ISOTOPES; ISOTOPE RATIO; QUARTZ; BORIC ACID; ELECTRON MICROSCOPY; GRAIN SIZE; HYDROFLUORIC ACID; ORIGIN; OXYGEN 18; SEDIMENTS; WATER; CHALCOGENIDES; CRYSTAL STRUCTURE; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; HYDROGEN COMPOUNDS; INORGANIC ACIDS; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; MICROSCOPY; MICROSTRUCTURE; NUCLEI; OXIDES; OXYGEN COMPOUNDS; SILICON COMPOUNDS; SILICON OXIDES; SIZE; STABLE ISOTOPES; 400201* - Chemical & Physicochemical Properties; 152002 - Geothermal Data & Theory- Properties of Minerals & Rocks
DESCRIPTION: The NaOH boiling treatment to remove amorphous silica relics in the quartz isolation procedure is unnecessary because the subsequent H/sub 2/SiF/sub 6/ treatment dissolves both the amorphous silica relics and feldspars. Washing with 0.1N HF, water, and saturated boric acid in the new procedure removed fluorates that precipitate during the H/sub 2/SiF/sub 6/ treatment. Failure to remove the fluorates depressed the oxygen yield (to as much as 85 percent) of theoretical SiO/sub 2/ and slightly raised the quartz weight percent, but the oxygen isotopic ratio of quartz derived from various sources was not affected by these washings, by Na/sub 2/S/sub 2/O/sub 7/ fusion, or by H/sub 2/SiF/sub 6/ treatment. When 35 to 45 percent of the outer shells of the 1--3.5, 3.5--7, and 7--10 ..mu..m quartz size fractions from Cretaceous (Pierre) marine shales was dissolved with 3N HF, the quartz delta/sup 18/O decreased by 0.8, 2.1, and 2.6 /sup 0///sub 00/ for a central-basin shale and 0.7, 1.2, and 0.8 /sup 0///sub 00/ for a near-shore shale, respectively. The trend, the greater the particle size the greater the delta/sup 18/O decrease, is the opposite of that expected (finer particles, higher specific surface) if the delta/sup 18/O decrease by HF treatment is a result of dissolving an isotopically exchanged portion and/or overgrowths in outer shells. The decrease appeared by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to result from preferential dissolution of the cements holding fine quartz crystals (formed at low temperature) together as silt-size clusters. A systematic increase in delta/sup 18/O with decreasing grain size occurred in the quartz from the near-shore shale.
RELATION: Journal Name: Soil Sci. Soc. Am., Proc.; (United States); Journal Volume: 39:6
